Love the atmosphere, love the over-the-top "meat culture" shtick on the menu and in the decor!  This joint, right smack in the groin of the Cultural District, has a huge lively bar yet is still comfortably appointed for foursomes on the perimeter.  We had two awesome appetizers - the Escolar (a seviche) and the Watermelon Salad, with feta, olives and a lime vinaigrette.  The main course was a nice try, but not a perfect 10 on execution: Soft Shell Tacos, consisting of soft shell crab, pickled carrots and cucumber salad, cilantro and Thai chili sauce.  The taste combination was interesting but I found the tartness of the pickled carrots overpowered the poor crab, who showed up dutifully for work, all dressed up, and ended up with a little desk near the file room.  But, hey, perhaps that's what I get for ordering crab at a "meat" place ... sometimes you have to take credit for your own poor choices.  I still approve of this joint, and I love that you can still find a meal downtown at 10pm on a weeknight amid the hustle and bustle of the Pittsburgh theater jet-set.

We stopped in before seeing a show and will be back. The restaurant had such a unique atmosphere and the breakfast was outstanding. I look forward to trying their Korean BBQ at some point. Our waitress seemed a little out of sorts and started talking to a customer next to us who was an awkward acquaintance, which was distracting for us seeing as how close the tables are. Overall an excellent experience.

I can not say enough good things about this restaurant. I took my mother, mother in law and sister in law here for brunch this morning and I think I had one of the single best meals of my life.   We each ordered a bloody mary and thoroughly enjoyed the huge bloody mary bar with endless fixins and various infused vodkas. Absolutely delicious.  I ordered the french toast breakfast and it was sublime. The sourdough bread makes for a substantive yet fluffy toast. The warm bananas and bacon almond brittle added a sweet/savory contrast. I couldn't get enough. The chicken and waffles were ginormous. Half of one chicken fried and served over a cheddar and jalapeno waffle. You'll take some home. It's that huge. Sister said it was phenomenal. MIL ordered the quiche of the day. It looked like a slice of cheesecake. It was huge! The eggs were fluffy and the quiche itself was flavorful. Mom got the lobster omelet. It looked amazing and mom sure cleaned her plate! We had vanilla creme brulee and maple tiramisu for dessert. Both dishes were rich, creamy and delicious.  I will be going back for brunch very soon and very often. This is now my favorite restaurant in town!!

We chose this place for a special birthday dinner for the hubby.  I was so sorry I did.  The food was really grossly salty, and I like salt.  We also felt it was way overpriced and the service was terrible.  From the oh so enjoyable room temperature water, to the appetizer order not being placed, then when we did get it finally, the appetizer plates were never removed, and when the dinner came, it was served on a wooden slab and we were not given plates to use. I had to reach over the app plates to even get to the wooden slab. So messy.  The salt content left me feeling sickly.  We will not be back.  The stars I did award were for the drinks, which were refreshing. This restaurant really has a reputation of serving delicious food, guess things have definitely changed after a couple of successful years.

Meat & Potatoes is in a primte location caddy corner from the Benedum Center and in the same building as the Cabaret Theater.  It's a gastropub, which can be bad is done poorly, but this is a pretty good example of how it can be done well.  They normally have a burger special, which is usually what I end up ordering.  They had one that was basically a burger and a pulled pork sandwhich combined together with an onion ring on top... Wow.  The craft beer list is long and reasonably priced.  Great location and good food.  Enjoy!

Food was fantastic. The tartare was exceptional....if you are debating between it and the bone marrow for an appetizer, don't: it comes served on top of a bone filled with delicious marrow. One gripe, I purposefully seek "gastropubs" for the food typical of them, but also for a high-end beer selection which defines a gastropub as such. Meat and Potatoes fails on this front. Half of their beers are the type you find in big box grocers (Miller, Pabst, Tecate, Molson, etc,). The other half are domestic craft beers, none of which are particularly notable.  No belgian beers, no imports (unless you count the big corporate beers like Stella Artois and Boddingtons), and NO BEERS  ON DRAFT. This is sort of a requirement for a pub, much less a gastropub. However, if you are into the mixology, high-end cocktail scene, this place has you covered.

We had a nice time here.  The atmosphere is similar to a speakeasy.  We did not have reservations and elected to eat at the bar.  The menu was the same and the bartender was very nice.  We were there for more than an hour and never felt rushed.  They have a good selection of beers and specialty drinks.  Food is good at modest prices.  We'll be back.
Delicious food- friend pickles are to die for-   Awesome bartenders and cocktails    Must try their Monday Night Cap! With $5 snacks and awesome drink specials!

This place solidified my desire to relocate to Pittsburgh. Yes, it's that good.  My boyfriend and I were considering moving to the Steel City after reading some impressive articles about the area. We were stumbling around downtown Pittsburgh in an uncomfortable rain/wind/ohgreatnowmyumbrellaisinverted situation and this place was a beacon of hope!   Considering how busy it was, we didn't have to wait long at all-- no more than 20 minutes and they have a really comfortable, intimate seating area while you're waiting for a table to open up. We ended up in a great conversation with a friendly local and the time flew by.   Once we were seated we could see why this establishment has such rave reviews. The staff is amazing. My boyfriend and I couldn't help remarking on how kind and helpful *every* employee was. There was none of that ~avoid eye contact so you don't have to answer a question~ on the part of the employees. Providence has some great, independent restaurants but I often get the impression that I'm burdening the staff by asking for anything extra...even water. While every establishment we visited in our two and a half days in Pittsburgh featured unusually kind (by New England standards), Meat and Potatoes truly stood out.  Oh, yeah, and the meal was phenomenal. I'm not a "~*~foodie~*~*," but I'd like to think I haven't completely destroyed my palette by overindulging in packaged Ramen. This is some of the best food I've ever had. We started off with the lobster macaroni and cheese and we stopped and looked at each other...we may have even been salivating. This was beyond good. It was rich and hearty and while the portion was appetizer sized, it could easily be a meal in itself because of its density and richness. I don't even like crustaceans!  For our main dishes, my boyfriend had the mussels and chose the curry sauce (they had two other options but they escape me :/) and I had the pork belly tacos. For nearly our whole meal we kept nodding and eating, staring wide-eyed at each other in contentment. I didn't sample any of his dish but he tried some of mine and we can both vouch for its deliciousness. The sesame seed crema was the perfect addition. Again, this meal was very rich (no complaints here) so come hungry.  It's rare that I write a review anymore but the service at Meat and Potatoes (as amazing as the food was) compelled me to. Our first impression of Pittsburgh was a great one and we look forward to making Meat and Potatoes our spot in the coming months.

Super friendly staff. Offered to find me a spot around a very busy bar. Bartender was super friendly and made a great Manhattan and a great Old-fashioned. Decent whiskey list IMO. Appetizer and cob salad were great starters and the smoked lamb shank was down right the best thing I have had in a long time. Great clean experience. Would recommend to anyone looking for a nice meal.
Hard to beat this place.  Food is excellent, great scene, place is very nice inside.  Only thing I could possibly say is that it's on the expensive side, but not enough to take away a star

The food is always top notch, the bar man is charming at attentive, and service is usually pretty smooth. My only critique would be that the restaurant seating is a little awkward. Every time I go in I opt to sit at the bar so I don't get crammed in side-by-side with another table. Also, if you haven't tried absinthe, do it! It takes a few minutes to prepare, but it's delicious. Definitely worth a try.
Personally?Rosted chicken doesnt taste better than the 5 dollar roasted chicken I bought from Kroger?just personally.
Love this place! We usually end up here before or after theatre. Great cocktails and food. If you have not been here, it is a must. There is not a bad choice on the menu.
Fantastic resturant! Easily one of my favorites in the 'Burgh. Always has a deliciously unique menu that features many of my favorites. I personally reccommend the steak tartar.

I like Meat & Potatoes. I've been there several times but I just went for brunch, so let me write about that.   I had a daily special which was the pork belly with savory oats, fruit kimchi and a fried egg. This is one of the more unusual dishes that I've tried there, and it really worked for me. The rich pork balanced well with the acid in the kimchi.  I sampled some of my dining companions' choices as well and enjoyed most of their dishes. I tried the brisket flatbread, which was excellent; the eggnog French toast, which was good but didn't really excite me; and the sausage and biscuit (another daily special). That last one. Man. It was oversalted. Like: Dead Seas oversalted. It was sent back and quickly replaced with something more enjoyable. The coffee was good too.   Service was good but sort of... hover-y. Plates were removed from the table as soon as the last bite was consumed (or prior to in one case) . Almost all the serving staff has an earpiece which gives the place a bit of a Secret Service feel---not the most relaxing vibe for a lazy Saturday brunch.  I will definitely be back.

We stopped here to have a bite to eat before a CLO performance this summer.  The restaurant was filled to capacity, even though it was a weekday, so we sat at the bar.  We ordered the special tomato salad and the risotto. Both dishes were absolutely fresh and delightful to our taste buds!  It was just enough food for us and we were very satisfied!  The bartender was also very friendly, he took our order with very little wait time, and came back to us several times to make sure we were satisfied!  Can't wait to go back!!

By far the best bartender in the burgh..Ryan from meat and potatoes..amazing mixologist that truly knows his mixes inside and out. Wow!!! Thank you for such a great time Ryan for your attention to detail!! I told you what I liked and you went above and beyond!!! Definitely will be back time and time again!!!:)

Meh. This place shares their restrooms with the Cabaret theater, but somehow convinced themselves that they're way better than they actually are. I don't get the hype. I live around the block from here and so I've tried this place, I'd say, about 20 times in the last year. I've only had a descent experience once. Why come back if it's so terrible? Because they are open on Sunday and Monday when most places downtown are closed. And being from Nyc I love going to my neighborhood spots. Also, my husband loves their papadelle. If only they treated their customers well. Everyone that works here thinks they're to good to be there, and the manger is actually the worst one. We get it. You're a very busy establishment. Doesn't mean you get to treat your customers like crap. Leave your money. There's so many new and better places in pittsburgh to try
I was traveling and a friend recommended this place.  Food and drink was sublime!!!  A "must eat" in Pittsburgh!

One of my favorite Pittsburgh eateries. Delicious entrees. Even better cocktails. Everything I have tried has been superb quality with a great balance of flavors. Great place to have dinner before you see a show in the Cultural District, the staff will even ask if you have time constraints and make sure you are not late for your play/concert. Always make a reservation, this place is usually busy on the weekends.

Four of us ate the bar. The food was excellent - pub burger, pork chop, tacos and three little pigs- all nicely  prepared and yummy.  Drinks were good.  BUT - Two of three bartenders were rude, condescending, and just plain mean.  One in particular criticized our drinks choices, sneered a lot and was otherwise thought he was very cool - obviously too cool for us.  Compared to NYC bars I have been in this week, the service was much more unfriendly and haughtier here = the attitudes here make this a place I would not recommend to friends- has potential but some new staff is needed.  This experience was totally unexpected especially in Pittsburgh where most people are exceptionally nice.  Worst experience in a Pittsburgh bar- ever!

Went for brunch, amazing!  Bloody Mary is your choice of infused liqueurs, and a build-your-own Bloody Mary bar which had shrimp, bacon, cured meats, cheese, and a choice of about 20 different kinds of pickled veggies.  We got the chicken and waffles- which came with four huge pieces of fried chicken, and the brisket hash, which was amazing.

My friend and I have a before theatre light meal that I really look forward to. I usually chose a seasonal cocktail, and order from the appetizer or light plates menu. My favorite is the Caesar salad and grilled bread. What fun!.

I just went to Meat and Potatoes this weekend with a group of people. We made the reservations over a month in advance because it is such a small restaurant that it was hard to get in with a group of 10. Between all of us we tried a variety of different things on the menu. Appetizers- the Devils on Horseback were surprisingly good. I didn't think I would like them, but they were probably the best app we had. They has a fried Mac and cheese appetizer special which several people tried and it was nothing to write home about. The corn dog was pretty good, but had some kick to it! For entrees - I got the pot roast, which was pretty good by pot roast standards. The hanger steak was too small of a portion for the meat lover in our group but they said it was great. The pork chop was GIANT and really juicy, but the slaw side that came with it was too spicy for me. And the duck was excellent. Our service was pretty good and the drinks were delicious, but pricey. All in all an exceptional meal, and will go back, but maybe not worth the month and a half of anticipation!
Amazing food... Good service.  Will definitely be coming back. Best Caesar salad. Waitress very friendly and great martinis.  Overall... Great experience.

This review is based on my experience through several visits to M&P (1 dinner, 2 lunches, and a Sunday brunch).  Overall, the food is decent (good quality but does not always hit the mark for taste). At dinner I would suggest the mussels (delicious). At lunch, avoid the fried pickles appetizer (not as good as the waitress suggested) and fried chicken sandwich. Do not order the brisket on flat bread at brunch (what was I thinking?).  Service is generally slow. On my most recent visit at brunch on Sunday at 1:30 (today) we waited 45 minutes for our food. On the other hand, the waitress was great about making sure my mug was always filled with coffee.  My last complaint is that the furniture is very  uncomfortable. It looks great but makes the legs sore. It's also too low for the height of the tables. The decor is nice.  Overall, M&P is a nice place to try, but I would certainly not call it one of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh. It does not live up to the hype.

This is only based on first impressions and service. Unfortunately, we never made it to dinner. And we really wanted too. The hostesses were rude and I'm not sure if they were stoned or just worried about what their hair looked like, but they could have given two sh*ts about us being there. We had a reservation but arrived earlier to see if we could get in. Yeah, not sure they even spoke English. Bar was full, we were 'stalking' some folks about to leave until this 4-some came in, walked right in front of us. Bartenders never ack'd us. Overall, just a rude group of people. I'd like to try again next time. Maybe they'll get some more competent help.

My friends and I shared dinner, appetizers and drinks here and Saturday night and the menu was utterly outstanding.  From the duck liver pate with sauterne jelly to the beef marrow appetizer everything was incredible.  Our group was a little high maintenance too because it kept growing as friends were showing up unexpectedly and yet our server was so patient with us.  We sat outside on their patio and it was a slightly chilly fall evening.  M&P actually offers blankets to patio guests in case they are cold!  Such a unique touch that sets them apart.  I had a lovely glass of barbera which paired beautifully with steak.  I will say the portions here are huge.  I know Americans tend to be big eaters so I am used to healthier, scaled down portions but if you have a hefty appetite then this is probably the place for you.  Wonderful wine list and amazing food.  For dessert I had panna cotta with a ginger blueberry sauce.  Heavenly.  I will definitely be back.

Great Sunday brunch at Meat & Potatoes!  Make your own Bloody Mary bar ($5/per) was absolutely delicious, with all the ingredients you need to make a great Bloody. I had the Smoked Salmon flatbread, which was a fun twist on traditional lox & cream cheese, and was just the right amount of food for a Sunday brunch. The rest of the table's meals looked equally delicious, including Chicken & Waffles, Short Rib Hash, and Irish Benedict. Good service, great atmosphere, and I think one of the best brunches in the city.

Stopped here for a drink after a downtown event.  Drinks were very imaginative and delicious.  One in our party tried the most amazing looking grilled cheese.  Corn dog may be the best I have ever tried.  The mussels were good but nothing outstanding.  Server and decor were very casual and inviting.  Would definitely return.

What a delightful brunch!  It took a reservation made several weeks in advance to finally make it but once we were seated in the special "group room" and the menus came out, it was clear that the wait was worth it.  To start with, we were enticed by the make-your-own-bloody mary bar with a variety of pickled vegetables and sauces to complement one of the many unique bases.  This was good, but others were happier with their expert-prepared cocktails.  All of the dishes ordered by our group were excellent.  True to the restaurant's name there were about 15% of the items on the menu which were vegetarian options.  However, we enjoyed our meaty offerings:  Chicken and waffles with a uniquely cheesy jalapeno savory waffle, light pancakes deemed "the best pancakes I've ever had," short rib hash, etc.  Come with a group so you can mooch off of others' entrees!
Great mussels, drinks, and atmosphere. Definitely will need reservations, but the burgers and steaks are worth it.
I love it, the food, the drinks, the atmosphere, my favorite PGH restaurant

Hmmm...I love meat and potatoes, so when a friend asked me to go there for her birthday I agreed knowing it was super expensive and upscale.  It's also located downtown which equates to #parkingnightmare.  I'd say bus down there, but busing anywhere in Pittsburgh takes an eternity.  I digress.  The food here is awful.  I got some kinda Bolognese Pasta, it tasted like dirty gym socks.  Not kidding.  The presentation was terrible, and it tasted warm as opposed to hot.  I'll do a warm hamburger from a fast food joint because they aren't charging $23, but not warm pasta from a place that has reservations and $50 and up plates.  They charge $5 or some shit for toast, so that's the kinda place this is.  The wine was delicious, but it's hard to mess up red wine for someone who imbibes as regularly as I do.  Had it not been for the wine, and company, I would probably 1 star it, but I'm no high class gal.  The service was ok.  They kept trying to take all of my silverware and plates before I was done with my dishes.  It's like, back up, I'm not even finished eating yet.  And I used to serve tables for a long time, so I know the difference between hovering over a table, and allowing someone to eat and enjoy their company.  Here's the kicker, a friend got the highest priced plate cause he's a baller (unlike myself), and well, it's supposed to come with MASHED POTATOES.  Well, they said, "we're out of mashed potatoes, would you like french fries?"  My eyes got so big, as did his, and we were like "are you for real?".  Their like "yes, we ran out (on a friday night no less), so if you want mashed potatoes, we will have to make more for you".  He said, "Ummm...if I'm ordering a $50 plate of steak and potatoes, I don't wanna eat french fries".  Seriously.  I was floored.  They were kinda rude about  him wanting mashed potatoes, too.  And, as you can imagine, it took a very long time to get our food.  The atmosphere in this place is cool, and our server was pretty efficient for the most part.  The birthday girl enjoyed her food (i think), but I wish we coulda just went to Thai Cuisine.  The steak looked greasy so I figured pasta

Meat & Potatoes delivers a consistent level of good and service quality. While the menu is ... the name suggests ... pretty predicable fare, the preparation and presentation are well done.   We enjoyed a few small plates including the best mussels we've enjoyed outside of France. My wife also had the soft shell crab ... regrettably seasonal but she savored every bite.   Service was attentive and pleasant.

I want to love this place and recommend it to everyone I know, but I cant.  The food is good, great flavors, unique items with a large variety. It really is all about the meat and starches here, and they do it well.  But, if you have a sweet tooth, the desserts aren't go satisfy you.  Its okay though, you'll probably be too full from the snacks, appetizers, and main course.   Now for the bad, I've been their twice and service was terrible, to the point that I'm not sure I'm going to go back.  First visit, out dinner took almost 3 hours.  The waiter was forgetting things left and right and when it came time to pay the bill, we spent 20 minutes waiting .  Our waiter was engaged in conversation with a guy at the bar, and that guy had to point out that our WHOLE table was staring at them, before he came back to grab our cards.  Second visit:  They are particular about getting the temperature of your protein right, they even ask how you would like your salmon cooked (which I think is kind of bizarre).  Given that, I ordered my pork medium.  I got a piece that I had to saw into, definitely not medium.  They right away offered to take it back and fire a new dish for me.  Great I thought.  A long time passes, I see a couple pork dishes come out of the kitchen, none of them  mine.  One of my friends is getting irritated for me that its taking so long.  The rest of my party is piratically done eating their dinner, i'm basically full from eating everyone's french fries, and FINALLY my pork comes out.  Obviously I'm not going to eat this whole meal by my self while the rest of my table, full from their meals and ready to go, is watching me. Sigh...so I pack it up.  The second piece was cooked right, but I'm upset that it so long, I didn't even get to enjoy.  =(

Very disappointed. Poor service and unimpressive foods. First, poor service.  There was a waitress who kept hitting my father's chair in order to serve some foods to our next table. Because of her, he had to move his chair to the other side but she'd never apologized until we asked to do.  Their service was also very slow.  Second, unimpressive foods.  We had stakes and Bo Ssam there. Stakes were not bad. However, Bo Ssam was awful.  Bo Ssam is a Korean traditional dish. Since I am a native Korean, I'm really well aware of how the dish should be. It is NOT the Bo Ssam at all. It is not even close to the original dish and there is nothing close to the original dish. So disappointed.  Actually, I tried to find anything positive about this restaurant and the only positive thing is the location. That's all.   Will never go this restaurant again!!

I've never had a bad meal, or a bad time here.  Cuban sandwich is great.  They usually only have one vegetarian entree on the menu for dinner, but it has always been delicious.    Toast + Jam + goat butter is delicious  Sweet potato fries are delicious  Everything is delicious.

My husband and I dined at this establishment after having dinner the previous evening at Butcher and the Rye.  Initially we stopped in for drinks planning on hitting up another spot for dinner.  We were hooked by the drinks and the fabulous food we saw come out of the kitchen.  We had root to berry, old fashioned, and multiple other beverages.  All were artfully crafted and tasted wonderful.  We dined on tuna ceviche, beef tartar, the pork chop and mushroom flatbread.  I don't think you could go wrong with anything on this menu.  Everything was excellent!  We would go back in a heartbeat if we didn't live 6 hours away.

I have only visited Meat & Potatoes once, and for the most part it was a great experience. The food is inspired. I ate eggs in purgatory, and my date had chicken and waffles. I was delighted by my dish which truly brought me to heaven. I was jealous of my date's meal, though it more appropriately should be called "A Chicken with and waffles." Seriously though, it was more food than either of us could handle, and made a lovely chicken salad throughout the rest of the week.  It is indisputable that the food and cocktails hit the spot. However the atmosphere makes the speak-easy vibe fall short. The high ceilings, metal riveted ceilings reminiscent of Walmart, and overly packed space ultimately disservice the intimacy created by the seating and mirrors that I am guessing the establishment is striving for.  Despite the ever so slight problems with the architecture, this spot is not one to miss. Located within the cultural district, this a happening, distinguished yet casual restaurant where you nearly feel transported to another time with food that is out of this world!

Every time I have been to this restaurant it has been very busy.  They have a really weird reservation system too!   So the first time I visited was after the theater, we did not eat just had a cocktail and I mean one as the bartender that evening was too busy with some guys and the absinthe machine to ever get back to us for a second drink.  But we still vowed to return to eat.  So the second time we go for Sunday brunch, it is very busy, there were 3 of us but we managed to find 2 seats at the bar. We wanted to eat at the bar but they make you put your name on the list as it is reservations there too.  Unfortunately they have super vapid hostesses who seem to have no facial recognition or clue as to what they are doing.  So while sitting there we are seeing some food coming out and the Chicken and Waffles looks delicious.  The bartender Cecil was pretty fantastic. But then a server comes to inform the bartenders that  they are out of the chicken.  So after sitting awhile (the place had pretty much cleared out by then) the hostess finally comes over to move us to the other side of the bar .We thought this to be very odd!  Which was still dirty from previous customers and then needed to be cleaned, as we stood there and waited.  I ended up with the breakfast Americano which was a typical breakfast but with a house made sausage link and that was very good.  My other friend got short rib hash also very tasty and the other got the grilled cheese,  which he said was the "best grilled cheese he had ever had" All in all everyone was happy with that visit.   The third time we try to go again it was for Sunday brunch as we really wanted to try that Chicken.  But it was a no go as my one friend has very little patience and when they told us we couldn't wait at the bar she wanted to leave. So we went somewhere else that day.   The fourth time we had a party of six and had made a reservation and they gave us the private room.  I finally got that Chicken and Waffles along with two of my other friends and I was extremely disappointed as were they!  While the chicken itself was moist and juicy the breading lacked any flavor at all (seriously Shop n Save has better fried chicken) and the waffle was dry too!  Now it comes with a bourbon, bacon syrup which was tasty but the waffle itself broke apart when you touched it with the fork.  And four of the six had the house made sausage patty that day and the four of us that ate it got ill.  I was relating this some other people who said that also got ill after eating here. Mental note:"No more sausage here"!  Even after that a couple of months later I with two friends were in town for the Arts Festival and wanted to have a couple drinks and apps so we try to go here and it was extremely busy again and we decided to go elsewhere.  So I think in all of my visits it is either hit or miss the service is generally good with the exception of Cecil the bartender who is very welcoming and friendly.   The hostesses vapid (every time I have been there).  The food good some days and not so great others.  But I would still like to try dinner perhaps one day when there is a blizzard!

Everything we ate was so good.  We shared the Brussel sprouts and the mussels to start and they were both addictive.  My duck was out of this world and I don't even know what the many sides were that it came with, but they were so good too!  The waiter and service was fine.....we asked to be given time and we were.  Not rushed and the waiter did help with menu selection.  They could increase their tequila selection, but their bourbon, whiskey choices were extensive.  The asian salmon had excellent rice and perfect, full flavor.  We all walked out of there raving.    BTW, made the reservations months in advance.

Really good brunch food - lots of fruit flies - including ones dying in two of our coffee cups (coffee was good besides that though :-) - had French toast which was really good but at 10 it should be. Steak and eggs was also very good but at 22 it should be as well. Management should've removed both coffees from bill but tried to attribute them to open doors in the back... Which is not how fruit flies appear...
If it was legal to marry a brunch menu in the state of Pennsylvania, I would propose to Meat & Potatoes. Instead, I will continue to live in sin with the short rib hash.
Chef Dom is the GOAT. Hands down one of the best places to enjoy a meal downtown. Can't go wrong. Great drink specials too. An absolute must stop if you're downtown visiting Pittsburgh.

We went for graduation dinner on Saturday night. They had our table ready, prompt service, good food everything was perfect.! We had 45oz ribeye steak and bone marrow, especially loved duck pate highly recommend. The open bar was great too, made our daughter non alcoholic beverage with a twist. It was our son's favorite place to dine good hearty food, he'll miss this place~

My wife and I were looking for a good spot to show visiting family the good eats of Pittsburgh and decided on meat and potatoes. What can I say? The bone marrow was delicious as always! The toppings that you can add to it are a nice touch but not necessary.  The bread that it comes with is the perfect vessel for the perfect marrow. I want to go back every week just for that! My father loved the  Mac and cheese and while I'm not a huge drinker, there is an interesting cocktail list. My wife had an old fashioned and said it was fine but nothing great. Nice place to bring out of towners looking for a good meal in the city. But make a reservation!

Meat & Potatoes has a great atmosphere and I've never been disappointed by the food.  The menu has some unique options, and all of the meals I've ordered have been delicious. Twice I ordered the bone marrow, and each time it was good, but it never comes with enough toast to spread it on!  This is also a great spot to get a quick bite and drink before a show (just let them know you are going to a show and they will accommodate your schedule).  The service at the bar is always top-notch and the drinks are wonderful.  It is a little pricey, but mostly worth it.

One of my favorite BBQ restaurants in town! Come back each time to have the wings (dry rub) and pulled pork. Great vibe feels like I'm having a BBQ in my backyard. Friendly staff with great recommendations.

This is such a cool place you definitely need to try if you're in Pittsburgh! We had originally seen guy from diners, drive ins, and dives there so we knew we had to go! We walked in first thing on a Sunday morning, they weren't even open yet, but they were packed!! She asked if he has reservations and our hearts dropped as we thought we were going to have to find another place to eat. But the host very gladly accommodated us with a reservation about an hour and a half later. So we walked around, grabbed some star bucks which is right across the street, and we're back a little early and they sat us immediately. Their menu is so unique and fun. You can tell they take great pride in their food, it was amazing!! Their Bloody Mary bar was so fun! You got to choose your flavor infused vodka (I had the garlic something and my friend had the bacon) then everything else is up to you! They have literally every option available when it comes to a Bloody Mary! I cannot wait to return to this place!!

Friendly staff and good food.  We had the 45oz steak, slightly fatty but cooked perfectly.  Need slightly larger tables, our steak barely fit with our drinks and the candle.  Definitely make reservations, especially on weekends.

Over priced, trendy. Glad to see Pittsburgh has turned into such a foodie town, this isn't my favorite. If you like a lot of pork belly or pickled food, you will love it here. The fried Brussels sprouts are delicious, make a reservation, good for a small dinner meeting.
I have only eaten there twice once for dinner and once for breakfast. It was amazing. I tell people to try it all the time.

Food was outstanding! The pork chop which is smoked was ridiculously juicy and flavorful. Curry mussels were delicious, I could have licked the bowl clean. Tres leches cakes was perfect. Cocktails were just ok, a bit overpriced for how much they give you. Service was great. Will go back for sure, but will stick with wine.
Unique twist on steakhouse fare. A nice atmosphere before going to a show. A bit crowded, but, that goes with the territory...

I'm disappointed in the service and the kitchen at Meat & Potatoes.   First, I usually expect my server to know what the daily specials are, but our server read the brunch menu off of a handwritten list that she was carrying around. When it was time for dessert, she again read from her list. It appeared that she either missed one of the desserts or the kitchen had run out (we saw the table next to us order a dessert that wasn't offered to us).  Second, I was unhappy with the wait time. We waited quite a while for a table, though this was probably largely our fault for not reserving a table for Sunday brunch. But then on top of that, we waited far too long for our food after we ordered. We waited at least half an hour for our food to come in this crowded, noisy restaurant. Our server never stopped by our table to tell us what was going on with our order but let us sit and talk amongst ourselves about how long we were waiting for our meal. I'm not sure what was going on in the kitchen, but we waited over half an hour for our food. The restaurant was busy, but surely not any busier than any other Sunday brunch period. We ordered straight off the menu, so there was no excuse for the delay.   I ordered the grilled cheese and tomato soup, which was fairly good. There wasn't too much cheese on my sandwich, which I took to be intentional. In fact, I was talking about how some restaurants put too much cheese on their sandwiches, thus crowding out out the deliciousness of the fresh bread! Then my chef husband pointed out where the cheese had run off the sandwich and melted onto the grill while being overcooked. The cheese had been cooked right out of my sandwich.  My husband ordered the brisket flat bread and was disappointed. He thought it tasted charred ("dirty oven taste") and underseasoned. Our other dining companion ordered the short rib hash. She said it was delicious, but she couldn't eat the bottom layer of potatoes in the dish because they were sitting in a puddle of grease.   There were a few other things on the menu that I was thinking I'd try next time, but after today's experience, I probably won't go back.

We had theater tickets yesterday afternoon at CLO Cabaret. We thought we'd enjoy a nice brunch at Meat & Potatoes before the show. We've been there before and the food has been excellent.  As soon as we entered, we knew we couldn't stay. This place has decided to have a DJ on Sunday mornings. The music was so loud, with such heavy bass, that there was no way we would be able to carry on a conversation with our friends, much less enjoy a relaxing meal. The hostess offered to have the music turned down. After doing so, it wasn't any better.  So we left and had a lousy "meal" of bar food in the theater.  Why do places think it's a good idea to turn into a night club on an early Sunday afternoon?   We won't be back. Too bad, it used to be a nice place.

I have been to restaurants all over the country for over twenty years and let me tell you that this restaurant is now one of my top five experiences. Not only was the food amazing, but even more impressive than that was the service. While most people were dressed a little more than casual, I walked in with my family in nice jeans and a hoodie (Thanks Yelp). We didn't even get a second glance and were treated like any other customer. Everyone from the host to the waiter was so friendly and wanted to make sure we had an excellent experience.  On to the food.... wow! Spectacular! To start, we got an order of the fried brussels, fries, devils on horseback, and mac & cheese. Everything was fantastic. The devils on horseback is a dish completely unique to this establishment (I've never had it anywhere else or even heard of it) and the mac & cheese was so rich and hearty. The chorizo and pulled pork are perfectly balanced in it to ensure that you get tons of flavor without it being too heavy of a dish. You have to order these two things if you go here.  For our main courses, my wife got the Pork Chop and I got one of the specials (Black Bass with Squash Soup). Be prepared  to eat if you get the pork chop because it's as big as your head. The pork chop comes with a couple of slices of brisket on top to accentuate the dish and was delicious. The black bass comes with a cranberry relish and a small dish of the squash soup, which you are apparently supposed to pour around your bass to get a perfect combination of flavors. That is exactly what it was, a perfect combination of flavors. The soup itself was great and the taste of all those elements combined was superb.  We got the chocolate pot de creme for desert, which was like a chocolate mousse. Like the rest of the meal, it did not disappoint. Rich without being overbearing .  If you are only in Pittsburgh for a day and are looking for one hell of a dining experience, you HAVE to go here. For people with younger children, they have high chairs so go enjoy yourselves.

Lived up to its reviews. We split the 45 ounce rib eye, and it was heavenly--melts in your mouth like butter. Recommend the roasted cauliflower too. Creamed spinach a little too nutmeggy, but otherwise fine. Surprised at how easy it was to carry on a conversation given the high ceilings and background music. Waiters seemed a little too busy--ie, overworked--but service was fine. Bonus points for being so close to the stadium that we could walk to the Pirates game after dinner.

Made a reservation on this place, as last time it was a zoo without one! I would recommend a reservation before coming here, it's always busy. We came for Saturday brunch and had the Bloody Mary bar. Their Bloody Mary bar had a large selection of charcuterie, dolmas, cheeses and vodkas - even bacon and mini meat sticks. I got the steak frites. It was cooked perfectly, and the fries were really good! Not going to lie, my boyfriend got the chicken and waffles and those were even more tasty - everything you would want on a brunch! They gave him 4 huge pieces of chicken! The mimosas were good too. I would definitely come here again. 4 stars because even though the food was good and the service was great, it's not the best brunch I've ever had. This will definitely become a staple every time I visit Pittsburgh.

I loved this experience at Meat & Potatoes! The only disappointment was I had my mind (and stomach! Lol) set on the lamb burger which is posted on the menu online but it's no longer being served. Huge letdown! But I enjoyed the mushroom flatbread, fried taters w/ truffle mayo...although the fries had way too much salt...and fried pickles. The grilled bread with goat cheese and jam were my favorite part of the meal.

Came here for dinner last December right when they opened at 5pm and had to wait an hour for a table, so definitely make a reservation. Luckily, there's a Starbucks down the street to wait at when it's cold and rainy outside, haha! I got the salmon with black rice and it was delicious. There's a lot of interesting things on the menu and a nice selection of drinks. It is crowded and very loud, but the food is worth it. Can't wait to go back the next time I'm in Pittsburgh!

BEST lunch I've ever had. Seriously. I'm not even talking about dinner!  Thick cut juicy pastrami belly sandwich with truffle fries and perfectly poached eggs on the Irish Benedict. I think my gf was there with me but I'm not sure..I was too focused on the food.  Oh yea, just in case you want to impress your significant other, reserve tickets for the Theater Square right next door! They perform musicals from the Pittsburgh CLO company and it's a perfect place for a dinner/lunch date after you get your Meat and Potatoes on.   Parking is street or in a garage off 7th. On the weekends it's $9 all day.

Comfort food heaven! The restaurant is beautifully decorated with a modern flair. I was there for a client lunch and plenty of comfortable seating for five.   Fried pickles - Delish! And I hate pickles.  Mac n' Cheese - Creamy goodness  Turkey Club - HUGE, opportunity to split with someone  Items are reasonably priced and worth it!
Fantastic food and service!  Great for kids as well.  A different restaurant with creative combinations.  Highly recommended.
Went for brunch. This place is just on another level. It was outstanding. Must do if you are in the city.

The food here is excellent! I have been here a couple times and have not been disappointed. I have never tried bone marrow before and it didn't sound like it would be anything good, but it was. It's a little hard to eat since it is on a bone, other than that very good.
I was here to visit a friend for the day. Couldn't have been happier with the meal. Some of the best food I've had in a restaurant.

Meat and Potatoes (M&P) is the somewhat new gastropub from Nine on Nine Chef/Owner Richard Deshantz.  I have only been there twice but I have a strong feeling that it will be a fixture in the Cultural District for a long time.  It is a prohibition-era themed restaurant that is heavy on marble and velvet.  One fun aspect of M&P is their tableware: it is not uncommon for food to be served on cutting boards, or in mason jars with ceramic lids.    During our first trip over the summer, my girlfriend and I split the ahi tuna appetizer ($13); I got the Ribeye ($42) and she got the softshell crab tacos ($13).  The appetizer was raw chunks of tuna with wasabi infused tobiko on top.  It was served with some sort of rice chips on the side that were there to provide some texture to contrast the tuna.  It is an interesting take on a tuna appetizer and is still one of my favorite dishes.    Our dinner took a while to arrive but that is to be expected when ordering a 26 oz. steak.  My girlfriend enjoyed her softshell crab tacos and at only $13 it was quite a deal for 3 large tacos with an entire crab in each.  The crabs did not look like any softshell crab I have had in spider rolls or on sandwiches.  It was more high quality than what I am used to, but then again it should be considering the restaurant and price.    I was hesitant about the ribeye being $42 but with some goading from our excellent server I could not resist.  It is served on a wooden cutting board with a massive steak knife. It comes with confit steak fries, housemade steak sauce, and bone marrow butter served directly on the bone.  The fries were good and the steak sauce was fantastic.  I normally disagree with ruining the integrity of a steak by dipping it in a sauce, but this wasn't your typical A1.  The sauce, paired with the marrow butter, took an already great steak to another level.  They had four beers on draught during this trip but I enjoyed my dinner with a can of Wittkerke ($5) and a Belhaven Scottish Ale ($7).    On our last trip we went in for dessert and drinks.  We got the chocolate bread pudding and my girlfriend loved it but I wasn't too interested.  I became intrigued by cocktails that require egg whites, or meringue, and my attention could not stray from them.  My first one was the Old Canadian ($8), it consists of Old Grandad Bourbon, meringue, vanilla, maple, bitters, orange, and lemon.  It is served in a small rounded cocktail glass with a dehydrated orange slice that is supported by the thick meringue.  This was my first experience with meringue in a cocktail but it will surely not be my last.  The airiness and sweet texture of the meringue added an entirely new dimension to cocktails.  I normally find cocktails to be one note, either all alcohol and no mixer, or no alcohol and all mixer.  The meringue on top provided a sweetness that mellowed out the strong flavor of bourbon.  I also had the Tequila Fizz and although vastly different in styles of alcohol, it was similar in how effectively the flavors contrasted each other.    It is an expensive place, but it is worth every penny.  Keep M&P in mind for your next birthday or special occasion.  My only qualm is the clientele.  The location and food served doesn't allow for a typical, blue collar Pittsburgher to be comfortable.  I don't believe it is the restaurant's fault, as they are more than accommodating.  The Downtown suits just don't seem to like sitting beside someone wearing a flannel (me).  Ultimately, it is about the food and the food is superb.  That, paired with the service, make this one of my absolute favorite restaurants.     Oh yeah, you can add foie gras to anything...

It was my husband and I first time and the whole experience was awesome. We didn't have a reservation, so we at at the bar! LOVED the POT ROAST and the bring you A- Game if you think you can handle the PORK CHOP!!! Great Food, Great Atmosphere!!!

This place is well deserving of the hype. I had the mushroom flatbread, which was orgasmic. I shared the ribeye for 2 with the creamed spinach and rosemary potatoes. Steak was cooked perfectly and the sides were amazing. The vibe of the room is what you want. Service is great and a fun atmosphere. Need to come back soon . If you are thinking about going DO IT!

In the past month I've had dinner twice there and the food was more impressive each time. The duck breast is amazing. Then I had the pork chop. OMG is was a double bone chop, like having your own personal mini ham. And the sides, Jesus if I lived here I'd be the size of the blimp. O and throw in poutine for an app, the best I've ever had.

The sloppy Joe sandwich was overwhelmingly sauce with little meat flavor. The fish tacos were good. The burger with caramelized onions was cooked perfectly and was excellent. The duck salad was light on the duck and heavy on the salad. The fried pickles were mundane. The chocolate popcorn mousse was light on chocolate was interesting but not to be repeated. Service was good. Prices were high. Atmosphere was fine.

Best pork chop in the city. Cocktails are also top notch but if often takes forever to get you drink. Staff is attentive.  If you want to go on a Friday or Saturday make sure you make reservations 3 weeks in advance.

I finally tried Meat & Potatoes all in all very good food , I had the fried pickles with there spicy ranch ,I found it very interesting .The main course was 34 oz Ribeye for 2 it was a very good choice  with all the sides that come with it .A very nice restaurant but not making a reservation we waited about a hour for a table ,had a few drinks and noticed about 7 tables vacant ? So al in all I enjoyed the meal but I suggest reservations.

We tried this place after being featured in the travel channel as one of the best ribeye steaks in the country. We were not disappointed. Steak was grilled perfectly. Bone marrow was also very good. Alot of interesting things in the menu. Will be back to try them soon...

Loved this place! The waiters were very friendly, the atmosphere is great for a date night and the food was great! We got the steak and potato dinner for two and the fried pickles. The place is in a good location but it is pretty small so be sure to make a reservation before the day of your visit.

I'd give M&P a 3.5 if I could, but I'll round up.  The atmosphere here is great, and we've always had good service. Don't expect to get a table / bar seat most nights (or even a last minute reservation) unless you're lucky, so a visit here can require planning.   From a food perspective, we've had mixed experiences. On a brunch visit with a large group, most were satisfied, but my grandpa's fried chicken was burned (the exterior even looked overly browned) and my huevos rancheros weren't very flavorful. We've been here many times for dinner and have had a large chunk of the menu, and again had some hits and misses: fried pickles, duck pate, short rib flatbread, mac 'n cheese, and all chocolate desserts (that dirt pudding!) were great, while the fried chicken livers (cut way too large and the breading fell off) and duck breast (not very flavorful, overcooked) just didn't do it for us. Beer and cocktail list is just de rigeur.

After visiting Meat and Potatoes 2 times now I can honestly say I'm not impressed and to be honest a little disappointed.  The first time I had reservations and we still were asked to wait 30 minutes for our table to be prepared. When we sat down there were at least 5-6 open tables. The restaurant is pretty small. The meal was good though. I had a Manhattan and the Waygu flat iron steak and my friend had the duck. Both were delicious.  On my second visit we again had to wait for quite some time even with having reservations and the teeny bopper that was our hostess had an attitude. We were seated and waited for an extremely long time. They were out of many things including the fried pickles and so we ordered the Devils on horseback. They were alright. We waited even longer for our food and my flat iron steak fell flat this time. It was cold as was the pasta that our friend ordered. I was extremely disappointed and have to say for the long wait and poor service I would expect decent food. For the price and other reasons combined I don't think Meat and Potatoes will be on my list of places to frequent. There are a lot of better and more reliable options in Pittsburgh

Excellent food and service. Definitely make a reservation and preferably early to avoid dishes being sold out. I was looking forward to the meat and potatoes for 2 but it was sold out by the time we sat down. Still, the pot roast and hanger steak were amazing. Would definitely recommend if you're not on a budget.

Meat & Potatoes is one of the best, most original restaurants in Pittsburgh. I love how they don't shy away from using offal but they elevate it into the sublime.  Was there on a weeknight (shocking that I got reservations the same day) and had the pig's ears salad and some wagyu flank steak. As usual everything was delicious! The only (minor) complaint was the high salt content of the mashed potatoes.  This place embodies the growing "sophisticated" food movement in Pittsburgh, but in an unpretitious manner. Hope that never changes!

I have been here twice now, once with my mother who was visiting and the other was with a group of people. This review is based on the second time we went. My boyfriend and I had both called asking about a reservation for a party of 20 and were told to e-mail someone, we both did and received no e-mail back. We called again numerous times before someone finally got back to us less than a week until the party. She was very nice and explained it would be $250 to rent out the back room (not too bad) and a $500 minimum food and drink order, which between a group wasn't hard to hit. But, I had a couple questions about the menu and checks and was never responded back to. When we arrived they had the back room ready except for the appetizers that we had asked to have out when we arrived. Our waiter was really great and he had extra staff helping him which was nice. The food and drinks were all delicious, I had the steak and it was awesome! One downfall is that the room was in the back behind the kitchen so it's very private so we felt a little left out of the cool atmosphere but it's great if privacy is what you want with a big party.   My only one complaint was they knew it was for my birthday and they didn't mention it or even bring out a small desert which I thought was a little rude since we had paid $250 just for the room and our total bill just between my boyfriend and I was over $500. Also, the manager never came into check on us or see if everything was going well. (I've planned big parties like this before and usually they stop in to make sure you're happy with everything). All things considered we will be back for sure but definitely plan a group event somewhere else with a bit more of a lively area.

When we arrived at the restaurant, the music was booming. We actually went outside; yes, it was that loud. Also, the steak was HUGE and it was undercooked, and then, after we sent it back, it was over cooked. Is Meat and Potatoes just a place for drinks and dessert? Will it soon fall down? Yelp readers, unite!
Went for brunch on a saturday in october.  Great vibe, good music, great mixed drinks, and very filling and clever takes on breakfast/brunch items.  Will be back for sure!

I came here as my going-away dinner in Pgh. I picked the place just becuase of its name (well from a shortlist of restaurants that got picked because of their menu).   Libations:  I had the El Segundo, which is sweet but you can smell the jalapeno floating on the drink with each sip. Truly delicious! I also stole a sip from my friend's Up in Smoke which was equally good, despite having whiskey which I am not a fan of. I decided to be good and stick to just one drink since I had to drive home.   Snacks: We had the ahi tuna, fried chicken livers, devils on horseback and poutine. My fave was the ahi tuna, but I just love raw fish! Everything was truly deletable, the poutine was an experience.   Dinner: I got the braised lamb shank and that night instead of the polenta, they were serving beans and greens with bacon. Mmm, who doesn't like bacon? the lamb shank was oh-so-good! the portion sizes here are huge, I stuffed my face and had enough leftovers to stuff my face again for lunch.  Service/Atmosphere: Service was good, nothing to complain. The place is busy, which I love. Love the energy there!  We couldn't have done dessert even if we wanted to. I almost had to be rolled down the street to home. Happily rolled.

Walked into an empty restaurant on a Sunday at 4 pm and were told they were booked solid. The outdoor seating area with 10 or so tables was completely empty, but without reservations, we'd have to wait at the bar for an hour and a half. I thought that the idea of this place was a gastropub, i.e. a public house. Instead they came across as condescending, pretentious pricks. Way too many other high quality restaurants in Pittsburgh I'll be voting for with my dollars.

I'm not going to rehash what's been stated hear a billion times, this place is solid.  But due try to get a Sunday brunch reservation about a month in advance, the brunch menu is unique and unbelievable.  Skip the bloody mary bar and just get something off of the menu.

Have been many times. Food is always consistantly good. Always busy. However service always seems to be lacking. Hostess cold when you come in. Bartenders always seem to be catering to the regulars. Would come more often if the service was more consistant.
I took my husband here for father's day.  The service was wonderful, food was great. Kinda loud (actually had live music) the music was good just little loud for me.
Food was excellent. Even though they are known for their giant steak to share; the entrees and snacks I had weren't grossly over proportioned. I left 100% satisfied.

Meat and Potatoes is a gastropub that is conveniently located next to the O'Reilly Theater in the Cultural District in Downtown Pittsburgh. There is a lunch and dinner menu during the week and a brunch and dinner menu during the weekends. We attended during Saturday Brunch before a performance at the theater. We made a reservation in which I highly recommend. Those that did not opted to leave due to the wait time and patrons with later reservations did not find luck getting a seat earlier. I didn't have much wait time at all as my table was provided shortly after arrival. The seating is very close and crowded. There is not much privacy or room to move whatsoever. But lets focus on why we go to restaurants, food and service. Our waiter was very patient, pleasant and did a great job refilling our water. The food was plentiful. The servings were much larger than I expected. We ordered the fried tators with truffle mayo and potato gratin as appetizers. The fried tators were seasoned tremendously. May be a bit salty for some, but they were great to us. I elected to get the chicken and cheddar and jalapeno waffle. There were four large pieces of chicken which included a leg, thigh, wing, and breast. I was full the entire day off of this entree. The bourbon bacon syrup offered a tasty contrast to the heat of the waffle. My date had the french toast which was equally large and delicious. If you want to be full, enjoy a flavorful meal, don't mind crowds or tight seating, the brunch at Meat and Potatoes is highly recommended.

I like this place a lot.  I think reservations are a good idea when heading here in the evening, probably mandatory if you're going on a weekend.  Good food, good service, wheelchair accessible including the bathrooms, although the dining room is more than a little tight!  I definitely recommend reservations if you're in a chair like my husband, although we have had good success just showing up, even if it is a little uncomfortable for the people that need to squeeze by his chair.
great food  one of the best in PGH
The drinks here are outstanding and the atmosphere is great.  We tried the duck and the pot roast and both were outstanding.  Definitely a great place for dinner or a drink.

We went here on a whim on Saturday at 10:45, and we were told needed a reservation--that's how busy this place gets!  We decided to sit at the bar so we could eat immediately!  Hubby and I started out with the Bloody Mary Bar, which had every imaginable topping under the sun, you could truly make a meal of that!  I had the dill infused vodka, he had the black pepper garlic--both were awesome!!    Hubby ordered the burger, he said it was delicious, but amazingly messy, with the egg and cheese atop of it, and ended up eating it with a fork and knife!!  Our daughter had the grilled cheese and tomato soup...huge and delish!!  I had the  mushroom bruschetta, humongous portion--I could barely eat one, but it was so yummy I couldn't stop!   Since we were sitting at the bar, we had the opportunity to interact and hear the bartenders talk about the spirits and food.  All three were absolutely professional, knowledgeable, and friendly. Atmosphere is hip and trendy, food and drinks are very reasonably priced-- we will be back for dinner!

Before going to the Benedum, which is literally and conveniently across the street from Meat and Potatoes,  my friend and I decided to have dinner there outdoors.  The service was excellent - in particular the gentleman who cleaned the tables was both pleasant while dutiful.  I had the roast beef which was excellent; my friend ordered the mac and cheese appetizer (too rich and quite unlike mac and cheese in a bad way) and the mushroom risotto (excellent); though we both knew that the restaurant is famous for its "meat and potatoes", we were hoping to have ice cream for dessert - or at least more than a meager choice of 3 options.  I settled on the chocolate mousse which was small, but delicious - nice and rich - I wish there had been more; my friend had a strawberry layered cheesecake dessert which she found delicious as well - just wanted more!... All and all, I recommend M &P - good food; nice quantity (except desserts); great service; great ambiance - would definitely make reservations a few day before hand if you can.
Staff is helpful. Many creative menu items. Love it.

They have gotten their act together a bit better on the timing issue.  Food is coming out faster.  I actually think this is my new favorite place.  I can't even begin to tell you how much I love the fried brussel sprouts.  And the mushroom flatbread....heavenly.  The saffron and beer mussels...wonderful.  My friend had the pork chop....he said it was the best one he's ever had...he cleaned that puppy down to the bone.  The Gin Richard drink....amazing.  Yes....just goes to show, you need to give places a second try before you write it off.  This is now my fav place in the 'Burgh.

On a whim we decide to walk in to this highly recommended restaurant in the theater district of downtown pittsburgh later on a saturday night with no reservations and surprisingly did not wait long to get a table.  It truly lives up to its name because the meat and potatoes were epic.   The hanger steak was perfectly prepared and absolutely divine laid out on top of delicious fingerling potatoes.  However, the soft shell crab tacos fell short for me.  I love soft shell crab and these really missed the mark.  They weren't in any way complimented or highlighted in their presentation.  Our appetizer, the devils on horseback or dates wrapped in bacon with sirhachi, were delicious and the bacon made desire...well, more bacon.  It was so good.    A+ to the staff and the ambiance but not a huge fan of the up close and personal seating arrangements.  I find that most modern and trendy spots seem to want you on top of the couple next to you and everyone walking behind you.  I also was a bit put off by our server bringing a can of beer and a glass to the table and pouring it table side.  Maybe it's just me but I don't want the illusion there's a bunch of igloo camp coolers in the kitchen labeled with beer types they're fishing our libations out of.    All in all, it's not always about the food and with good company any meal can be a positive experience.  I would return again soon as the menu offers a wide array of choices I just couldn't get to that night.  Great place.

Cocktails are amazing, the food was uneven and less inspired than I had hoped for.  If you're going to go here you might as well get the rib eye for the main course, you can't go wrong with rib eye and the rest of the entree menu ended up being pretty lackluster.

Really a strong 4.5. Knocking off .5-1 star for the use of canola oil when they have so much rendered animal fat laying around. Not just healthier, just plain tastes better.   Beyond that - WOW. Just go.   Ordered:  Bone Marrow Mac n Cheese Lamb Burger Duck Breast Korean Rueben Salmon  All amazing. All cooked to the proper and requested level of doneness/temp.   Service was awesome and paced well in terms of how the dishes came out.   Atmosphere - even with a full-house - was relaxing and quiet enough you didn't need to shout in order to have a conversation.   After going to both here and Cure - it's no contest.....M&P HANDS DOWN!   I think I may have found my new favorite. Go and enjoy!
The food was great, but the service was iffy. I ordered the chicken and waffles, and it was delicious, but very filling, as are many of the dishes. The service was very slow, however.

This is one of those places that I can never remember to make a reservation for before a show . If you been following my day at all you will notice I been eating my way through Pittsburgh today . I'm going all in then I'm in serious diet mode. So my city crew decided to dine here for restaurant week 3 courses for 35 bucks. Since I had a late lunch I only ordered drinks and appetizers. To get me in the mood for Puerto Rico I ordered Malibu rum which they didn't have so she made me some pomegranate something or the other... I seen chicken livers on the menu and got excited can't remember the last time I had them. As pictured they came out fried to perfection and so tender yuuummmmers. My next appetizer I chose was the pate which was definitely more on the sweet side for some reason rather than savory. My girlfriends loved there food however I couldn't tell you what it was. Our waitress Jessica was the bomb. I would definitely comeback

Wait, have I never reviewed M&P? Basically my favorite resto in the great city of Pittsburgh?!?!  I LOVE this spot. I always have good experiences and you can't beat the cocktails and Monday night specials!  M&P is wonderful for everything. I love their prohibition-style craft cocktails (especially the blood and sand) and everything on the menu is superb, especially the brunch menu. Faves include the Croque-Madame, chicken and waffles, poutine ...  My favorite time to go though is on Monday nights, for the late-night menu from 10 p.m. to 1 a.m. It's constantly rotating and is a great way to get a good M&P meal on the cheap.

I was again impressed by the service here! I took my family here after my graduation and we were seated in semi private area that had the appearance of a farm kitchen with a modern twist.  The restaurant handled our group of 7 with ease and everyone was extremely satisfied. My foodie brother from Boston was especially impressed. I knew there was a reason I loved this place.
Service is very spotty and the food takes long to come out. However it still tastes delicious and I like their vibe
Delicious food; great atmosphere and excellent (bonus) whiskey selection. Gem in downtown Pitt. Don't miss if traveling.

I had the opportunity to eat at meat & potatoes for the second time last night, and as the story goes, it was the best of times, it was the worst of times.  I must admit it did not live up to its 'reputation'. For our first soirée, there we had brunch, and it turned out GREAT! My wife had the short rib hash (poached egg, horseradish hollandaise) @ around $12-14 it was priced right and tasted good. I had chicken and waffles (not as good as chi-town HOWEVER for PGH it was phabulous) and it was both filling and tasted good. SOO good that I made a mental note and put this place on my must try again list.   I thought this was the type of establishment that a blue collar working man/woman, needed and would be proud to say... 'I've eaten there'. Again on that first night. Meat & Potatoes hit all the right spots. Service food ambience you name it they hit every note. These were the best of times!!!  Now we come to the worst of times. My wife/soul mate is my foodie buddy. If I am belly to the bar 90+% of the time she is with me. Monday night was no exception. We decided to end her birthday week celebration with another run at nirvana. We shot for the moon and ended up in the trees:(.  My wife ordered the $14.00 pub burger extra well done. The waitstaff brought it to the table with panache, and the bar was set high. When she cut the burger it was as far from well done as you could be. The burger was red and spewed blood necessitating its return to the kitchen. Upon its return the meat was still a shade of pink that prompted my wife to throw in the towel and admit defeat. What was suppose to be a beautiful evening with dinner and dancing turned into... Just sparing with an almost live cow. Will I eat there again sure. Will it be soon. I don't think so. I am going to give my wife's wounds some time to heal.
Great line up of bourbons & scotches. Flat bread (i.e. pizza) was fresh and tasty! Mussels were fresh and plentiful and great.
food was good but not enough. Service was aweful. Our waitress was no where to be found. kinda spacy.

I don't know what they could possibly improve. Been there a few times now and find...  - the atmosphere was warm, interesting, stylish (but not too cool for school) - the menu was really interesting (in a great way) - the food was really, really good  - the staff - we sat at the bar - was awesome. They were really nice, attentive without being annoying, and incredibly knowledgeable at what they do - drinks, amazing selection of beer, cocktails, the works.
One of our favorite places in Pittsburgh. Whether it's brunch, lunch or dinner, it never disappoints. Delicious food, great cocktails and a unique atmosphere. Definitely a must try.

Arrived at 5 for a pre- show dinner, we're done and out by 6:30 with plenty of time for the 7 PM show. Dinner was a show unto itself! Our group sampled the Brussels sprouts appetizer- roasted with Parmesan cheese, and the pate, served with toasted bread in a cute little jar..very good with a sweet tang to it. I had the Mussels in a chili broth with sweet potato cubes and roasted chick peas...excellent and plentiful and a nice twist on Moules frites..I had mine with the spectacular Truffle fries with a mayo dip- that alone would suffice for a meal! My husband had the burger with pork belly and an egg...also amazing and huge. The Three little Piggy sandwich that was served could feed a family of four! I would definitely return to sample more of their fare. All was well done and huge portions. Would consider sharing next time.

BRUNCH IS WHERE IT'S AT!  Been there many times and love the brunch.  I only had one bad experience there with a server, but I would never let that discourage me from coming back because the other staff is great!
It's a great experience as far as the food, ambiance and staff. Been here several times and it's definitely worth stopping by whenever I'm in Pittsburgh.

10/10. Would wife. What is there to say, Great cocktails, atmosphere, and food. Brunch is wonderful experience every time. One of those places that feels like you are in a bigger city than pittsburgh.
I love this restaurant!  Great vibe, the food is delicious and the service is top notch!  I return time and time again and am never disappointed.

Visited meat and potatoes after watching Ina Garten speak so I was starving!  Wife and I shared the charcuterie and corn dog for appetizers.  I was surprised by the amount of meat you get in the charcuterie!  Corn dog also tasted pretty good.  For entree we shared the lamb burger which had a really good sauce to it.  Overall the food was good and the environment was hip and fun.  Good for a night of drinks and hanging out.  Reason for not five stars was because although it was good, it didn't completely wow me.

The dining environment was so narrowed and crowded. I could hear every word spoken by the couples next to us.  It's hard to believe this is a highly ranked and recommended restaurant in Pittsburgh since the steak was totally not worth the price (and the 1hr waiting time). There was about 1/3 of the steak was fat. And if you don't order any of the 8-dollar side dishes, all you can get is the beef and the bone marrow. I can't say the steak set was not savory at all but it was just too expensive for that amount of "edible" meat, and the variety of the steak set was the least I have ever had. I should believe some of the negative experiences listed in other reviews before I went and I recommend you should too. Although I don't like the food at all, the service was fine so I rated Meat & Potatoes a 2 star.

Amazing drinks, great service, unbelievable food. The Bloody Mary bar is unparalleled but the French 76 is my favorite . Even though the place was busy and we had no reservations, the hostesses and bartender made me feel welcome. Worth the wait!

I've eaten here a couple of times, the most recent being last week before a Pirates' game.  Superb gastropub food.  I have had the poutine (great), the fried chicken livers (very good), the bone marrow (outrageously good), and the Pappardelle (really excellent).  The bar tenders are great and make some fabulous drinks.  I would, and will, eat here again the next time I am near there. It is a popular place and seating can get difficult, so reservations are recommended.

If you can get in, this is the most consistently delightful dining experience in Pittsburgh. The specialty cocktails at the bar are extremely interesting and varied. If you're into more traditional cocktails, the best old fashioned I've ever had is from here.   Essentially every piece of food I've had from my few trips here has been delightful. The bone marrow is fun and well made, the goat-butter and jam appetizer is a wonderful combination of flavor, the mac-and-cheese is extremely good, and the spicy stuffed dates were so good I've tried replicating them at home. For entrees, I've had/tried burgers, chicken pot pie, mussels, and a few other dishes I'm forgetting. Not a single one has let me down.   Bottom line is: If you want a meal to remember, get a reservation and try as much on their menu as you can. You will not regret it.

My boyfriend and I were in town for a few days and wanted to check out some of the new restaurants in the area. Several people told us to check out this place after I had seen some great reviews online, so we decided to give it a shot. I have to admit I had some pretty high expectations going in due to all the good things I had been hearing and this place hit the nail on the head. I could not have been happier with my meal or with the service. The staff was extremely attentive. The restaurant was crowded when we went (on a Monday night) but I think it added to the excitement and the style. The menu is very different from what you can find anywhere else, they have unique combinations and a very good variety. For example, my boyfriends dish came with Kimchi fried rice and the star of my meal Wagu beef cooked perfectly. I would recommend to anyone and if you're visiting from out of town this is a MUST!!

BRUNCH: This place was fantastic!!!! They take reservations but leave space for walk-ins. We saw them turn a party of 7 away, without advance reservations large-ish parties can't be accommodated {hostess words not mine}. Our food was fantastic and I chose a wild card, fried chicken, cheddar jalapeño waffles with bacon bourbon syrup, love love love!!!!

Bar is 5 stars.  Food rates a 4 star.  Excellent drinks and the bartenders are really creative when you ask them to make something different.  It is also fun to watch them work.  The food is not bad by any means, just pricey for what you get.  I have been there several times and plan to return again.  Will try their Brunch next time,

The place was lively, pretty loud and mostly full as was the bar where I found a seat. Save for the obnoxious shrieking liberal Elvira-mistress-of-the-dark looking woman to my right ("Gio-wadge W. Booshe and da otha Boo-wooshes let the Bin-ladens Family fly right out Texas on 9/11 - Da ownlee plane dat was allowed to full-eye on 9/11 -  that's twoo!! That's verifiable!! Check it out ooh-wan line !!" ) - who was unsuccessfully trying to convince her partner that 9/11 and the Iraq war was an inside job, the crowd was friendly, laughing and a fun atmosphere. Luckily Elvira and friend left (no doubt heading to the Michael Moore film festival) soon after and M&P became a much better place to be.  In town for one night only, I saw the great yelp reviews of M&P and decided to give it a try. In the mood for something light, I decided to sample the wedge salad and, as a recent convert and aspiring bone marrow aficionado decided that to give it a whirl, too.   The recommended Cab was good but not great, the wedge salad was cold, crisp, and just the right amount of blue cheese dressing and fresh blue cheese crumbles. So far , I'm 2 for 2. Over my shoulder I hear "Your bone Marrow, Sir?"  Holy Fred-freaking-Flintstone, I'm served the largest portions and sizes of marrow I've ever seen - gynormous even by (my accustomed) Texas standards. Perfectly broiled with grilled bread, sea salt, pickled onions, chive and -surprise!- capers, it was amazingly good. And amazingly rich. And more than one man should eat, even Fred and Barney in their prime. I was semi-successful doling out samples to those around me  - despite the inner voices in my head from my Mom telling me to clean my plate - I had to quit after two of the three bones. This is absolutely awesome and you must try it - just bring a friend or two when feeling especially carnivorous.  Five stars to you M&P - when back in DT PB I will darken your doorway again on the nearest, convenient, Elvira-less night.
Awesome food, amazing place. We've been there 3 or 4 times and can't wait to go back. Have not been disappointed! The pate will blow your mind! Bone marrow is always a must, also.

This restaurant was ok. The macaroni and cheese wasn't the best I have ever had but the environment was very nice.  I think I may have just ordered the wrong thing. I had the pot roast and while it was tender the flavor was a little off for my taste.  Great location for a fun night out with friends.

Meat and Potatoes brunch holds a special place in my heart! 2011-2013, my friends and I probably had brunch at M&P about once a month. Over years, the prices rose, the quality dipped a bit, and the service tanked. Well... Yesterday I gave it another shot again (a friend had made a brunch reservation). With our reservation we were seated right away (instead of the 45 min wait the previous time). The food was fantastic! Our waiter however, was either stretched too thin with tables or just plan bad! NEVER checked on us. We didn't want to be rude but... Another drink, more water, etc. So this is my update... :)
Fabulous food.  There is a wait for a reservation, but well worth it.

Appealing at first, because of the ambiance and menu, so we made a reservation. We waited 20 minutes before seated for our brunch reservation.
