We then waited another 15 minutes before anyone acknowledged our existence, once seated.  The waiter came over and excused the wait time, because he was new- understandable, I've worked in the service industry before.  Overall, we were not impressed, and will not return. To keep things short, there seemed to be lack of communication between all staff, the tables are too small for the size of the plates brought out, there is not much space for movement around tables (service, excusing yourself to use the restroom, needless to say, privacy), the coffee was cold, and at the end of my meal, a centipede came crawling out of the booth, and scurried towards me. Eeeek. The food may be decent, and the restaurant has a cool concept, but it lacked the seamless service and comfort, which makes an exceptional restaurant experience.

Great experience overall - friendly waitstaff and bartenders - food was delicious. We ordered the smoked wings and the bone marrow as appetizers. It was so much food - which made me very happy - and really delicious. The smoked wings were by far our favorite. For dinner my husband ordered the lamb shank with white beans and kale - very good and incredibly tender lamb shank. I ordered the duck breast - only complaint - the chimichurri sauce seemed misplaced and combated with the delicious flavor of the duck breast - would order again - but request no chimichurri.   Found this restaurant when in Pittsburgh for a weekend - have already recommended to two different friends planning trips within the next six months.   We weren't able to get reservations until 9:45 - but it was worth the wait. Recommend making reservations a few days beforehand to ensure you get a time slot that works for you. The decor is fun - but was very happy to see that the food out-shined the decor - as sometimes it tends to be the more hip the interior - the less quality the food - not at Meat and Potatoes!
I have only been completely satisfied by my experiences here.  Great place.

Was able to get a table outside on a Monday night without a reservation. Very good service and the ribeye special was delicious! Also loved the beer & coozie to take home. So glad we got to enjoy dinner here while in town for a few day.

when the place is 1/3 full on a Monday night, no need for the wait staff to act like they are so busy that they can only talk to you in a mad rush, while literally running. Though the food was good, the wait staff need to learn some professionalism and patience.  They also need to learn that their menu is not very common and not everyone is expected to understand what certain things mean on it.   I think the manager needs to have a talk with the wait staff taking orders, most of whom seemed to exclusively young females (while all the bus people were males).

This place is a must-go! The food and service were fantastic. If you're in the Pittsburgh area and looking for an experience, I highly recommend Meat & Potatoes! They are now open for brunch too...  If you go for brunch, make sure to try the French 76 cocktail. One of the best I've had... Lemongrass infused vodka, champagne, and lemon... Can't go wrong!  Coffee BBQ with eggs and potatoes is a fantastic way to start a lazy weekend!! Will  go back for sure next time I'm in Pittsburgh.

Good for Pittsburgh, but average compared to other cities. Waitress did not inform us of the special dishes for the night. The table next to us had the specials explained to them after we had already ordered. Would have preferred the special, but not a huge deal. Price is reasonable for what you get.

I was in town and craving a steak and this place was highly rated online and by the hotel staff.   I had the hanger steak which was done perfectly.  The only downside, and perhaps it's because I ate at the bar, was the service was lacking.  I never was asked if the steak was done to my satisfaction, if I wanted another glass of wine or dessert, and had to ask twice for my check.  Despite the lack of service, I'd go back for the great meal.

Good eats here.  Hit this place several times before even thinking about Primanti's sandwiches (soggy, bland, etc.)  The sandwich (3 pig) tasted great.  The meat was moist and flavorful.  The egg was also a tasty addition.  I enjoyed the thick cuts of bread, which were grilled.  Probably top five sandwiches I have eaten anywhere.  Thick. tasty. satisfying.    Of course, this place isn't cheap and I certainly wouldn't mind paying less.    But the cost was justified.
Great 'come as you are bar' with barrel aged Manhattans, brilliant food and hip atmosphere. How can you go wrong?  Always good and a new Pgh stable.

Had reservations on a Saturday night and was seated on time in the private room (we were there for a bachelorette party).  The fried pickles were AHmazing!!  Split the steak and it was also delish.  Only drawback was the service......our waitress only came to check on us once.  A party of 6!  I'd definitely go back but hopefully it will be better service.

I went back for more because I like torture .... ok it was a birthday thing.  Decided to order a Caesar salad....another bad choice unless you like soggy pork rinds and ranch dressing in your Caesar salad. I was told that I should have read what was in their Caesar salad. If you are not using Caesar dressing and other traditional ingredients then why call it a Caesar salad. It would be like ordering fish and chips, but substituting the fish for tofu and the chips for fried chickpeas. So the salad, Ranch Pork Rind salad I will call it was about as tasty as that sounds. No more of my money shall be tKen by this establishment!  1 star stands for the first visit and this one. Would rather go to Olive Garden.

The food and drinks were amazing, spectacular really!  The service was Terrible.  The bar area was way under staffed and they were bitter about it.  One bartender asked another to take our order, which he did followed up by "It's going to be a while for your cocktails" in a very rude tone as if we kicked their dog or spit in their face (which we did not).  The bar back was incredibly gracious and very nice, wish we could have ordered from him.  The Pork Chop I would highly recommend, Fred Flinstone would have been envious.  Bone in, huge, cooked perfectly......I actually lucked out ordering.  Couldn't dare ask the server for a recommendation, which I usually prefer since they have insider info. The server came up and smirkily said "what do you want" as if we insulted his family (Again, which we did not).    Service - F Food - A++  It'll be a while if ever before we go back though, poor service creates a poor experience regardless of how good the food is.

If I could give this place 6 stars I would. The cocktails are wonderful. The atmosphere is buzzing and fun, never obnoxious. And the food... The food is amazing! Always love stopping in even if just for a few drinks! The bartenders are fabulous and always make the evening enjoyable!

Are you ready for manly man food served in a manly man setting?  I am!  And thankfully, so was Belle.  I say manly man with my tongue in cheek since M&P owes much to chefs like Gabrielle Hamilton and April Bloomfield, both of whom have been kicking ass in NYC for a few years now.  Bone marrow on toast may be the single most ripped off dish of the last decade or so--this place takes it from Hamilton, who stole it from Fergus Henderson.  Is that a problem?  No!  Bone marrow isn't something you really expect to see on many Pittsburgh menus, so I won't call into question any cook's motives if I end up eating it.  Smack in the middle of the theater district, M&P is a good date spot--the lighting ranges from "romantic" to "theoretical."  Yes, it's convenient, but more importantly it offers you many chances to put your date in situations in which you can evaluate him/her as a prospect.  1. It has a good bar.  If I have to explain to a bartender on Carson St. what goes into a Blood & Sand, I don't want that guy making a Blood & Sand.  Or anything.  But that's not the case here, so you can observe what your date drinks given a wide array of options.  Guys manage to screw this up all the time and yes, girls notice.  Beer (12 oz?  Before dinner?) and lite [sic] beer (ever?) will doom you.  Ordering something like absinthe (available here) is doable, but for God's sake don't go into some overly-long explanation about the green fairy.  Absinthe hasn't been like that for ages.  That's like getting excited about drinking dairy because before refrigeration, it was a risky proposition.  2. Its menu takes a small token of skill to decode.  Every restaurant is required by law (-ish) to have the following items on the menu: random, bland chicken breast dish; chocolate dessert with a lavish description (pick from: forbidden/dream/fantasy/some other erotic term that reinforces the unhealthy cultural relationship between women and food); fish with really boring sides; pasta (usually vegetarian, giving non-carnivores and the thrifty an option).  At a bad restaurant, you stick to these because it's hard to really really screw up pasta, but at a good restaurant, you skip these because the cook just put them on the menu as a nod to less adventurous eaters--certainly not you!  I have never had the salmon at M&P.  I'm sure it's fine.  Salmon is tough to screw up.  I will never have M&P's salmon.  Why would you ever go to a place with pictures of cows and pigs on the wall, a place obviously intended to be a shrine to all things pork and beef and order fish?  It's clearly not the passion of the chef and can be safely skipped.  So if your date orders the salmon, the ravioli, or even the "Plain Jane" burger, be wary.  3. If your dining companion orders any beef dish from a place like this well done, make an excuse and leave.   M&P is not a pretentious place, but it takes its meat seriously.  Don't let someone insult the cooks or the food like that.  When I order something well done (once every 3 years), I'm saying, "I assume the kitchen in this diner is a festering pit of bacteria and this is the only way I can think of to kill it all."  With all these lessons in mind, Belle and I ordered a sea of appetizers (marrow, tartare, and so on) and a lamb entree to split.  Aside from perhaps a little too much binder in the tartare and slightly uninspiring accompaniments with the lamb, everything was excellent.  Nothing life altering, just tasty, solid food that was fun to eat.   This place takes its muscular eating seriously--steaks are served on cutting boards, wine is served in jars, everything has capers.  It's a gastropub, which means no one is going to be blown away by some intricate little molecular trick the kitchen uses.  But if you're in the mood for a plate of bones straight out of the Flintstones to be placed in front of you, this is your place.

Divine, start to finish!  I was in Pittsburgh for the Vet Games. It was Friday night, 11PM, my guy had been playing rugby all day... He needed food and I needed beer. This place was pushing distance from our hotel by the Convention Center, so we decided to check it out.  I called to make sure the kitchen was still open and got Mike at the front desk. He was hilarious on the phone and told us to come over. He was equally amusing when we got there. Bonus point - we hadn't mentioned that we had a wheelchair in our party. It's not usually a big deal, we just move a chair, whatever. We got there and Mike just said he had the best seat in the house for us and would be right back after the 'final preparations.' That was the politest way we've ever heard someone leave to move a chair without making a big deal out of it. A small thing, but it was one of many cute touches throughout our meal and a nice way to start.  Atmosphere is fun, the chalk drawing with the different edible parts of a cow was awesome. There's a fine line between trendy and pretentious and they totally made it.  Food - oh yes. We started with the fries with truffle mayo (string fries, delicious) and the lobster mac 'n cheese (mmm.) I got the mushroom flatbread which was perfect and Jeff got the tomahawk - a huge steak on the bone (shaped like a tomahawk) with chive butter and steak fries. All our food was incredible and we had plenty of leftovers.  The draught selection was on the small side, but they had a super random selection of cans and bottles. It's been a few years since I've lived out east so it was fun to try some new beer. They had an elaborate bar but we weren't able to take advantage of all that.  All in all, great. Host, waitress, food, drinks... I have no idea when I'll be in Pittsburgh again but I would definitely go out of my way if I was in town!

Wings wings wings!!! I love them. Smoked with a house made spicy not too hot with a little sweet. I love the mussel dishes. Usually three preparations to choose from. Order the grilled bread or side of fries as the add on. You will want something to soak up all the broth!! Both Hot chicken and burgers are outstanding! I love the cocktails with the house made bitters and syrups. Great Old Fashions! Good luck finding a seat at the bar!

We made reservations for 7 and were seated very close to that time. However, when we walked in the 2 hostesses at the station were both on the phone and did not acknowledge us until a third hostess came to the station. Once we were seated our waitress came and got us started pretty quickly. My husband got a beer and I just stuck with water (pregnant but the alcohol selection looks awesome!) and I have to say it was poured out of glass bottles but is clearly warm (yes, no ice) tap water. We ordered the special (meat plate) and the devils on horse back and both were fantastic! I do wish the waitress would have explained what each meat was but it didn't matter because they were all delicious! We got the rib eye for two. Best steak I have ever had in my life, loved the house made steak sauce. All in all great night and food. We will definitely be back!

Overall: An excellent lunch and dinner experience. The service accommodating, the drinks well-balanced, and the food savory, if slightly rich. An easy choice for Pittsburgh fine-dining. __________________________________________ Ambiance (4/5): One room and large, so it doesn't get to "chill", but otherwise very relaxed, festive, and modern, if a little chatty from the other guests and expansive from the very-large bar.  one room and a small private table with door, industrial feel with pipes and low-power lights hanging from the high ceilings above. bar of 20. high ceilings, rustic wall mounts of deer heads, greens hang from lights for Christmas, tree lit in corner. Soft ambiance play from above, hum to the place. __________________________________________ Service (4/5): Prompt, if stand-off, arguably "know it all" in delivery, but exceptionally accommodating during lunch and overall very genial and helpful.  Immediate water and refills, long list of suggestions with general portion sizes indicated. Recommendations were as described. Took a bit of time delivering between appetizers though restaurant fairly packed.  I returned for lunch the next day.. 35 minutes after the kitchen had closed! I placed an order at 1:55, they cooked it and put it at the bar. It was still warm, waiting, when I arrived at 2:35. I never felt rushed sitting down this late, and they accommodated me perfectly. __________________________________________ Drinks (5/5): Mixed drinks have a fantastic balance of flavor, alcohol, and texture. Small craft beer selection.  1) sloe gin fizz - awesome lightness with gin and citrus, juniper a bit lost but consistency creamy with egg. Fantastic stuff.  2) Sgt peppers old fashioned - bitters and orange work well together, pull out bourbon oak and heat while tempering. Pepper keeps drink light, very low sugar presence compared to sometimes over sweetened profile. One of the best old fashioneds I've drank. Another winner! __________________________________________ Food (4/5): Aside from a few textural shortcuts and missteps, this is excellent cuisine, both lunch and dinner. Rich and hearty yet balanced and inventive, I look forward to trying another round.  1) tartare - spicy from the chili bowl-glaze and Jalapeno crunch! Soft boiled egg sits atop (done perfectly). Seaweed definitely noticeable. Light onion as well. Quality meat, lighter smoke unnoticeable unless you separate from fixins. Peanut adds a distinguished crunch though the flavor contrasts a bit. Lighter, more conflicted from so many ingredients, not as rustic or simple. I prefer softer texture of bittering agents like arugula, black pepper, and capers to the harsher texture here, and the spice heat slightly hides meat, but very good stuff.  2) Bone marrow - rich, fatty melt in mouth, nice use of salt, white onion, caper to cut richness though still a lot. Bread is hearty, absorbs marrow easily, but could be a bit crisper, though richness may overpower otherwise and sopping marrow out of bone is made easier. The coarse sea-salt is a textural issue against the marrow. It's gritty and cracks as the marrow melts in your mouth while you attempt chewing the bread.  3) Tort sandwich - really crunchy bread. Light! Avocado cuts jalapeno sting, pork fat, radishes maintain levity. Waves of flavor, first light jalapeno and pickled radish, then brash mango aioli and avocado, light pork and smoke following as spice builds, before the toasty crunch finish. Really subtle, in control. Lightly dry without aioli.  4) Mac and cheese - served in mini cast iron! thick! Lightly sweet, little burnt aspect so low textural contrast. Light influence from chorizo, hearty lightly stinging. Really solid and rich, though texturally a bit boring. She agreed.. "thick, rich"..
Do not eat here!! The service was terrible and I got sick from the overly salty steak. There are far better places in downtown Pittsburgh.  Trust me. I eat out for a living.

Definitely one of the *elite* pittsburgh restaurants! Went with the family for my graduation and had an epic meal. We shared two orders of the ribeye steak for two. In addition to being an impressive presentation, the meat was juicy and perfectly cooked. I feel like it used to have a nice rosemary flavor so this time felt a little under seasoned but I know lots of people like a "simpler the better" approach to steaks. The Bramble cocktail satisfied the rosemary urge so I was okay. Have also had great brunch there. Can't really go wrong at m&p!

I've been here thrice. Twice for brunch and once for dinner.   Big fan of the brunch. I've heard oodles and oodles of good things about the Bloody Mary bar, but have yet to try it myself.   I got the Irish Benedict. Fantastic. But very, very filling. I wouldn't have traded it for anyone else's dish, though. Bit bland, but if you like Hollandaise Sauce, M&P has a good one.   I also had the Fried Chicken & Waffles. The maple syrup served with it was great. It made the dish. Not like regular maple syrup, this was a little thinner, with bacon bits in it. The fried chicken was fairly spicy as well, which I liked, gave it a zing.   Dinner was good, but nothing special. They do an excellent job cooking their meat. I had lamb and I got to try some of my friend's mutton, which was very tender, very soft.   I love the restaurant space, with the mirrors around the walls, and the chalkboards. Sometimes I think I come more for the atmosphere, environment, and people-watching more than the food.   But don't get me wrong. The food's good. Like real good. So you should go. But definitely make a reservation. At least one week out because the place fills up fast.

After a great show at the neighboring O'Reilly theater, my friend and I treated ourselves to a great dinner at Meat & Potatoes. Since we did not have a reservation, we ate at the bar, which was comfortable and offered a great ambience. (It was a bonus that some if the cast from the play say there as well.). I'm a pescatarian, so hold the meaty dishes for me; my choices were limited. I had a pasta dish with salmon which was well prepared and not too heavy. Wine list was great; tho I'm not a fan of the stemless glassware. No biggie tho.

Second time we've been here and it doesn't disappoint.  Had a reservation for 6:45, but they were great and seated us early.  Buttermilk chicken livers, Devil's Backbone for appetizers, Sgt. Pepper's Old Fashioned, great entrees and outstanding service from Kate!  Looking forward to next visit!

Good food, especially BRUNCH. The cocktails are unique & I used to have a favorite bartender there (I think their name was Abby) but I haven't seem them in a while! Hope all is well, Abby. Still great service all around. It's expensive but it's Downtown PGH so, kind of expected..

The idea of this restaurant is spot on -- high end cocktails and high end comfort food. The execution, though, is lacking. I ordered two versions of a Manhattan from their cocktail list. Great flavor, but they serve their cocktails in very wide saucer glasses. This just warms up the drinks more quickly than a smaller glass, and a warm cocktail is no one's friend. They pour their wine generously, and the glass selection is great.  I had fries -- fine, but the flavored mayo that came with them lacked flavor. Then I had the harvest salad, which was nice, but strangely cold, like it had just been taken from a fridge. I liked the spare dressing, however. Next came one of the night's specials -- grilled cheese with tomato soup. The soup was great. The sandwich was cold and I only ate one bite of it.  Maybe with more time they'll get their game on. The space is lovely, the servers were friendly, and the central bar is beautiful.

Meat and potatoes is a lively fun place. Food is superb. I had flat iron steak. It was perfectly cooked and full of flavor. My husband had pot roast. Also very good. We shared truffle fries. Excellent. Don't miss lemon angel food cake with raspberry sorbet. A little pricey but worth every penny.

The consistency in the food and drinks are so very appreciated. The service is great and I enjoy my visit each and every time. Had a DJ on a Monday I was there..  Was great music but regardless the playlist was always appropriate. Definitely a place to check out if not for anything but their prohibition drinks

A-OK. Which is unfortunate because we still gave Meat & Potatoes a try after hearing from a Pittsburgh local that has visited multiple times that the atmosphere is a real let-down and the food is good. However, the atmosphere created can ruin a meal, no matter how delicious the food.  Reading other reviews, I see that other people also commented on the incredibly poor customer service of the hostesses. Hosts and hostesses set-up the atmosphere of a restaurant. If the people "welcoming"you to the restaurant show that they are disinterested through their body language of slouching against the counter, not welcoming you first when you enter because they are paying attention to their phones, not asking how they can help you, giving attitude by sighing when you do not have a reservation, and not guiding you to the area where you can wait, it can ruin an entire experience. Which unfortunately because of two young hostesses it did. It was like being greeted by two angsty teenagers.  Our expected wait for the patio was 10 minutes (I am not sure what the wait was for inside because the hostesses did not tell us) e received a text from an automated system to be seated sooner. Coming back there was another hostess, who I talked to later in the evening about our experience with the younger hostesses. This other hostess has worked at Meat & Potatoes longer and was very kind and cheerful and took my comment politely and apologized for our experience. We were seated by the 'less' disinterested or maybe trying a little harder at her job, younger hostess who was at least standing upright when we walked in to the patio.  We were seated outside on the patio, which was lovely even for a hot day and the interior of the restaurant was very dark, loud, and you could smell all the food being served which was not necessarily pleasant. However, every so often smells which included everything from garbage and human smells if you know what I mean, from the alley which the patio was situated in (blocked off by a short fence) was a worse smell. In addition to sitting outside at the patio, there is only a small fence barrier to the alley and street, a group of people passed by and started berating customers that we were eating the 'cockroaches' they saw in the alley.  Our waitress, Crystal, was incredible. Her pleasant nature, positive conversation, knowledge about the menu definitely made the night for us. She came back often to refill our water for us, check in how we were doing, and apologized profusely for forgetting some lemons we asked for the water which was really not necessary, definitely appreciated.  We ordered fried pickles and Poutine from the Snacks menu, the 45oz ribeye and Sgt. Pepper's Old Fashioned to drink. Crystal and the server who brought out our snacks suggested we eat the Poutine quickly while it was hot which would allow the fried pickles to cool down, that information is always appreciated! The ribeye from 'build your own meat & potatoes for two' for $75 is a great deal as it definitely could serve at least four people. It was beautifully displayed on bone with the bone marrow gratin resting across and we ordered it with black truffle butter an extra $4 served in a small glass jar which was filled with black truffle and herbs. The food was excellent. I loved the thin cut fries of the Poutine and the scallion added a acidic contrast to the curds and gravy, but I would have preferred more gravy on them. The fried pickles order was small, but had a perfect breading that did not get soggy. The ribeye was perfectly cooked rare and the bone marrow gratin was oozing with deliciousness.  I would say that all three of us in my party enjoyed the meal, unfortunately the earlier experience of the hostesses actually caused one of my party members to leave before the ribeye, which ruined an otherwise lovely day in Pittsburgh. The food was fairly priced for the quality you are receiving. Our waitress Crystal made the night easy, the horrid detachment of the hostesses, smells and openness public jeering added to cutting our appetite short and our early leave. If we ever come back to Meat & Potatoes, we will not come sit at the restaurant.  I hope they do take-out.

Meat and potatoes simultaneously redefines and honors the historically blue collar experience that is Pittsburgh. This gastropub crafted impressive mixed drinks that satiate a palatte yearning for "something different." The Pimm's Blue Ribbon shows off how versatile and tasty PBR can be when combined with the right liqour. Old Canadian and the Old Thyme Refresher also were both were expertly crafted, showing off the refined techniques of the mixologist behind the bar by utilizing freshly made mixers, simple syrups, and liqueurs rarely found in your common neighborhood bar. This particular night, we were served the bolognese and the salmon. The bolognese contained three types of meats (pork shoulder, short rib and pancetta) in a mind blowing concoction over a melt in your mouth gnocchi. While this is traditionally served over papardelle, the gnocchi was a home run with this sauce. The salmon was served in with a korean style kim chi laden slaw that was not your run of the mill, overwhelming kim chi flavor. Kudos to the chef for balancing this flavor with the delicate texture of the fish. The atmosphere was a bit loud, but not obtrussive (the chairs are super comfortable!!!!!). Service was not astounding but not obnoxious either. This is a must visit for foodies and non-foodies alike. There's something to satisfy everyone at a reasonable price (even the little boy at the next table over with his most excellent hot dog seemed pleased, and we all know that children are the harshest critics!). Support your local establishments and keep this place alive! It could be the next great tradition in a city filled with traditions.
Favorite restaurant in PGH  -- love the brunch.  Absolutely love the housemade granola, ricotta and toast.

Service is inept, food is nothing special and the prices are far too high. This place is all hype and no substance. There are many good dining options in downtown, sadly this place misses the mark. Save your money and go elsewhere.

Everything is amazing here, the food, the cocktails, the decor and the people-watching.  The Bloody Mary bar on Sunday is worth the trip, as are the mac n cheese and the mussels.  Reservations are helpful, but if you can snag a seat at the bar before your show, the service is phenomenal there, too.

Nice atmosphere...requested and received table outside based on reviews seen here. Our server was attentive and food was prepared promptly. We had the fried Brussel sprouts which I liked but my dinner companion felt were way too salty and fried to the point of verging on burnt.  The Pimento Mac N cheese was good but not outstanding.  We also shared an order of mussels cooked in a tomato cream basil sauce.  The order was plentiful and the sauce was very good, but the quality of the mussels was inconsistent...some being quite small.  I really wanted to like this restaurant but I felt like for the quality of the food, the prices weren't justified.

Everything that we ordered was amazing!  I highly recommend eating here any chance you get.  The food is outstanding, the cocktails are amazing, and the staff was fantastic.  One of the best restaurants in the city.

What is better than catching a bite before the show at Heinz Hall? Doing it with a friend at Meat and Potatoes! A few cocktails while catching up... followed by the ever popular mussels, and a special that included steak with red wine risotto and a few chunks of blue cheese. This place is tight, and noisy, but still a crowd pleaser and one of our faves.

Had heard about this restaurant for quite some time, so we tried this during Pittsburgh's winter Restaurant Week. We had three courses, however, our personal favorite was their mac n cheese. If it was socially acceptable, I would have smacked the table after my first bite, it was amazing.   Really nice atmosphere, somewhat difficult to find because you have to walk into the theatre. Definitely more upscale.

Services was slow. Food was just so so. The restaurant itself was quite charming if not a little crammed. If you are going around a show time - you will need to make reservations.   I had the wild mushroom risotto for my appetizer. It was pretty good. I should have had that as my main item and when with another appetizer. I had the sweetbread piccata. It was way too garlicky and it left a bad taste in my mouth. The meat was too 'tender' for me. Apparently it is an acquired taste and lets just say I'm not acquiring it.   I might go back one more time to try something else.

If I could give zero stars I would. Food quantities are absolutely embarrassingly small for the price. Mussels are so tiny you need a microscope to see them. Busboy hit a member of my party in the head with a tray. Just kept walking. Never again.

M&P was awesome.  Went there for my birthday and it was excellent.  We only had drinks and appetizers but both were excellent.  If you're into great cocktails and unique food options, M&P is the choice in the Burgh. CP

The Mac-n Cheese appetizer is delicious, the pasta I had as a main dish was something completely different it's great to taste something out of the basics! Staff and ambient where great as well even on New Year's Eve :)

I was looking forward to try this place when I came on a business trip to Pittsburgh. I had to get a to-go order because of a conference call I had at my hotel.  I ordered a drink while waiting for the order. The drink was really good. I got my food and went to the hotel 4min away from the restaurant. I had ordered bone marrow for an appetizer and hanger steak for a main. The bone marrow app was missing the bread that goes with it! And.. one of the marrows was undercooked :(  The hanger steak was ice cold and chewy. On top of that, they did not provide me with utensils!  I was very disappointed.
Delicious! I really enjoyed all of the dishes. The service wasn't outstanding, hence the subtraction of one star. I'll definitely be back next time I'm in Pittsburgh.

Shared a signature Ribeye along with mashed and mushrooms with a colleague and it was very, very tasty and extremely filling.  You could probably serve three people with that huge steak.  Service was good as well.  My only nit (and hence 4 stars) is that the dinky, dull steak knives they provide are useless.  These are the little wooden handle, $10 for a case type that you got at the Goodwill store in college.  Even though the meat was pretty tender, it was very difficult to cut.  The server said they keep fighting with the manager to buy new, larger knives.  I've eaten at steak joints all over the world and gotta say, this is the only time I've had to complain about cutlery.    So if Mr Meat & Potatoes Manager reads these, don't be a cheapskate, please go buy some real steak knives so I can easily cut that wonderful piece of meat!
good cocktail, good apps, good entrees. solid choice in Pittsburgh.  Being from NYC, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food, presentation and variety.

Excellent brunch. Great bloody mary bar. But they definitely nickel and dime you. I ordered toast that clearly said on the menu jam was included...but they then charged me $1 additional when I asked for it. Make reservations as they are always packed. Will be back again.. but skipping the jam next time ;)
Best Fried Chicken I've had outside of the south. Brunch was fantastic.

This restaurant is simply incredible. I have been going here now for some time and love it every time. We have been for dinner, as well as a couple of times for weekend brunch. I strongly believe that M&P would hold its own in restaurant markets like New York (in fact, I'm always telling my friends n NYC that if this restaurant was in Manhattan you would need to reserve a table a month in advance at least to get in). The menu is full of highlights. Everything is delicious! I am in particular a fan of the brussels sprouts and poutine on the snack menu, the tartare on the appetizer menu, and pretty much all the entrees. The pub burger is a standout--in my mind one of the best burgers in the country, and certainly at the level of the famed Black Label burger at the Minetta Tavern in NYC.

I'll just get the small negative out of the way first.  The host/hostess station is not sunshine and rainbows.  The theme music would probably be The Cure or Dashboard Confessional for the group milling about there.  Not welcoming at all.  That being said, the rest of the experience is amazing!  The brunch was fantastic complete with a $7 bloody Mary bar which, in my opinion, is a steal considering the amount of things to skewer and place in your bloody.  We got the grilled bread, steak omelet (omelet of the day) and the pot roast hash.  The winners of the day were the grilled bread, the cheesy potatoes that came with the omelet, and the pot roast hash.  Our server was awesome as well.  Great place for brunch!

My husband and I went here to celebrate our second wedding anniversary.  We wanted to try something new and asked for some recommendations from friends.  Meat and Potatoes did not disappoint! We made reservations a week or so in advance for a Saturday night.  It was very busy but we did not have to wait for our table.  The wait staff was very knowledgeable and friendly.  They congratulated us on our anniversary.  We asked questions about different dishes on the menu and they provided us with some excellent recommendations. We both one of the specials which was a delicious chicken dish.  We were also surprised by a bottle of wine from a Canadian winery that we love that friends of ours had left at the restaurant.  The fact that they did that for us and served it as a surprise speaks volumes to the kind of people that run the restaurant.  It was a bit crowded in the dining room. You are right next to the tables next to you so you cannot really have private conversations.  (I also feel for the waitstaff who have to make their way around everyone and everything with trays). I only docked points for the crowded feel and the noise. We will be back to try the other amazing dishes on the menu.

The food I had was delicious the service was okay too. It's just way too crowded in there. I understand it's a popular restaurant but it's nearly impossible to walk around to even get to the table. If you don't mind the hustle and bustle I definitely recommend it but for a romantic and personable time I do not. You may as well be sitting at the same table as the people next to you.

Let me start off by saying.... I did NOT eat here.    I called 2 weeks out, in advance for a reservation.  I was told they were booked, that they have a seperate dinning room for walk-ins only.  Today, when I called tonight, to see if we could possibly get in... the lady told me no.  I asked about walk-ins and she said they are completely booked.  I asked about the seperate dinning room for walks ins, thinking we could take our chances....she said that dinning room was booked for a reservation!  WHAT???  I am NOT going to work that hard to spend my $$.  I was calm, cool and collected and told the lady how disappointed I was.  She said, "oh that is just too bad".

Meat & Potatoes get 5 stars for food and 2-3 stars for service.  The food is great, near amazing.  Tasted everything at the table, which ranged from Roasted Branzino, to Risotto to the Pub Burger.  For a Meat & Potato place, they did fish (Branzino) and risotto some of the best I have ever had.  The Pub Burger was nothing short of amazing.  Loved it.  Maybe death row last meal good.  Decent selection of beers, nothing to write home about but a few good small craft choices.  Good bar and good place for drinks and snacks as well as a meal.  The service is a different story.  Our server, Emily, I think we were actually bothering her to be there.  Seemed not to want to work or take care of customers.  Also, we asked her what Devil of Horseback was (a small plate).  She described it wonderfully and the four of us all oohed and aahed.  She neglected to tell us only 3 came on the plate.  She could have told us and offered to add a fourth or tell us to get two.  She seemed experienced just full of attitude.  Based on some other reviews, may be a common theme so be forewarned.  Overall small place but really good food with under attentive staff.

Dinner here was one of the most memorable meals i've had in Pittsburgh.  I LOVE that this restaurant captures the pride & humor of the city.  ie: *Fried pickles served in a paper tray, on a silver platter with spicy ranch dressing. Ha! & Yum! *Mac-n Cheese with chorizo, pulled pork, & "government cheese" Yes, please!  Coat me in this ambrosia & walk away. *Perfectly cooked Pastrami crusted duck served with sauerkraut pierogies & dandelion greens-- BRILLIANT.  The entire menu is peppered with "wink wink, nudge nudge" moments--like puns but with food.  This is exactly what i want from a gastropub--refined & delicious food that isn't stuffy.  These are ingredients you WANT TO EAT paired or prepared in unexpected ways.  The restaurant is a bit loud, but still quite comfortable.  I was ecstatic to see a proper cocktail menu in Pittsburgh & recommend the Up In Smoke--the whiskey balances the salty smorgasbord before you.  Go with a group, order everything & share.  The portions are generous & the plates are lick-the-china delicious.

What a great, cute, romantic little place! Service was great.   The food was awesome!!  We ordered the "Meat and Potatoes for Two: 34 oz. Ribeye" - extremely yummy! Lots of flavor and marbling (my favorite part of a ribeye). Mushroom ragu on top was like icing on a cake. Delicious! The steak fries were about normal when it comes to steak fries, but dipped in the black truffle mayo (worth it for an extra $1 to have it on the side), they were almost up there with being as delicious as the steak (sort of kidding, but really good dipped in the mayo)!!  The bone marrow gratin was a first time try for me! It was actually fairly good, very fatty flavor, and I wouldn't go out of my way to eat it, but I am glad I tried it (plus it came with the entree).  Artisanal cheese board as an appetizer was yummy also. 3 different cheese, and some fruits, and the preserve was lovely!! It comes with some bread too.  I wish we had saved room for dessert - maybe next time.  The tables are a bit tiny.
not as good as it could be. I've been here at least a dozen times, I leave satisfied but never wow that was awesome. brunch is my more favorite time to go

Amazing meal. Happened across them on a walk from my hotel and returned later with friends. The atmosphere is fantastic, and the drink menu would be worth a visit in and of itself. I sampled three flatbreads, all were excellent flavor combinations. We split small plates as well, and I sampled the mac and cheese and the poutine... Both were amazing. My only caveat would be to be cautious when ordering - the dishes are so rich we took half of our food home! If I make it back to Pittsburgh, Meat and Potatoes is on my must-do list.

Several months after M&P had opened, i ate there one night as a walk-in and was seated within minutes on a Friday night around 9:30pm. The food was so delicious, I was truly impressed. So, for some time shortly after, i regularly brought friends and family there to dine. Literally, no matter whether one was seated at the bar or on the floor, the service was excellent, on par with some of the more expensive casual dining establishments in New York City.    Then, due to a change in my regular routine, and because my friend was between shows at CLO, I stopped dining there so regularly, and ended up not returning to the place for several years.  Well, i worked in a research lab at Pitt for many years, and we would often have doctors working with us for a year or two to fulfill a post-doc or fellowship program, many of whom are not from Pittsburgh, or even the U.S.  So i recommended M&P as a "fantastic" place to dine after a new doc asked for a recommendation of somewhere to eat in the Theater District at some point a year or so after I ceased being an M&P "semj-regular." You can imagine how foolish I felt to have her return to me the following Monday only to relay the message that she had a terrible experience.   Then, fast-forward 2 years (now this is about a year and a half ago), and Im at the Christmas market with my "new" boyfriend in Market Square. We had a wonderful afternoon, but suddenly our hunger crept up on us, and we realized we were going to get "hangry" before we could wait out a table at Nola or anything immediately in Market Square, so I think of M&P and feel assured - as it was only about 4:30pm at the time - that we could get a table quickly for a quick bite to eat before their dinner rush came in.  Now, by this time, Meat & Potatoes had apparently become a "popular" place to eat - and the rumor was it was so posh, you had to wait weeks for a reservation; but for a place called Meat & Potatoes, it should be pretty obvious how ridiculous that wait time should seem.  Well, we arrive, and its about 4:45pm - the hostess asks us if we've made a reservation. I say no, and she says with a shitty attitude, "Oh, well, I'm sorry, we're booked for the night, and we strongly recommend you make a reservation with us *weeks* in advance" - she emphasizes "weeks." Thats the end of the conversation as far as this dipshit is concerned.   So, i calmly asked her if there was bar seating available - and then she tells me, yes, in fact, it's first come first serve. Well, how lovely - seeing as how they were closed between 2:30 and 5pm to turn over before their dinner rush, and we happened to be there right as the doors were opening at 5pm. So- because I asked - we were told we could be seated at the bar in about 10 minutes. But here's the thing: I have since never gone back nor recommended the place to anyone bc i will never again risk bringing someone and having a hostess piss them off.    Here's a short list of places I would recommend, instead: Sienna Mercado, Nola, or Sharp Edge if you want comfort food. Tako if you want pretentiousness and ambience for half the same price, wait time, and minus the bitchy hostesses Ten Penny if you want pretentiousness, ambience, and decent food but little to no wait time  And if what you want is fantastic food with no pretentiousness, AND little to no wait time, then skip downtown altogether and go to Lawrenceville.  Umami/Izakaya is fantastic Japanese street food and a unique ambience within Pittsburgh. It sits above Cantina which has decent tacos and good happy hour drink specials. Piccolo Forno nearby offers delicious italian fare for cheap, and is BYOB. But if you like grappa, dont hesitate to have a drink or two at the grapperia behind the restaurant while waiting for your table, or as a night cap. Tender, further toward the 50s on Butler St, is like a 1930s art deco oasis with crafted cocktails anywhere from $9-15 a pop; they're worth it and they're the star of this place. There's BrilloBox on Penn Ave & Main St, which is, in my opinion, hands down one of the best "bar food" experiences you can possibly have in Pittsburgh (there and maybe Yesterday's in Greenfield), and even the vegan food at this joint is so fantastic, even I choose it from the menu from time to time, despite my intense distrust of anything "vegan."   I mean, i can keep going, but the point is, Meat & Potatoes developed hype because its service was once top notch and its food was inventive and a delight to one's senses. But, sadly, it seems to have become rather lackluster in the minds of many, including my own.

This place is so freaking good I can't even get into it. I wish I could get in here more often but I just might go broke. Had some excellent cocktails, I figured hey I don't drink wild drinks that often so I asked the bartender to make me something with bourbon. Whatever he made me was incredible, I think he told me it was called pushing up daisies or something along those lines.   Once we were seated, definitely need reservations here, which we had. We had some risotto as an appetizer. This actually should have been my main course. It was perfectly cooked and so creamy owww! Then next was a steak and rib entree, which I ordered medium-rare, once again on point and so delicious. The special lady ordered the pot pie, And I have to admit it was the best pot pie I have ever had and to top it off it was so large I ended up eating for another 2 days afterwords.   The only thing that was sort of stupid was that I got charged $0.75 for a to go jar for my desert? What gives ?! I just spent over $100 not including tip and your going to pull a  maneuver like that. I mean what's $0.75 on top of my $40 bar tab and $75 dinner bill. It's just the point of it all. I still love this place anyway. The people and service are great and the food kicks butt too!
SPOT ON! Really liked everything about the place, Going back ext time i'm in town for Fried pickles !

Service was pretty good, no complaints. The food, however, is just not that good! I'm not sure how this place compares to other local restaurants, since I no longer live in the area. I would much rather trade their huge portions for better quality food and preparation. I had the brussels which weren't crunchy. My pork was super thick and very difficult to cut. My father had the cassoulet and thought it was too salty.   Bone marrow was good, but they serve it with all types of toppings to conceal the fact that the bone marrow isn't very tasty without them!   Again, I'm not super aware of the options in Pittsburgh, since I no longer live here, but my guess is that you can find better. This place isn't as good as it used to be.
Pork belly tacos and the pappardelle...amazing!
I went for brunch.  It was pretty good, but definitely didnt feel like i was getting a great brunch at this price point.  The potatoes were under-cooked, and the brisket hash was just alright
If you are feeling hungry with a fellow carnivore, I recommend the Meat and Potatoes for two.  A 36oz Ribeye with potato wedges and bone marrow butter for $55.  Yummo!  Burgers are also really great!

One of my favorite dinner spots downtown with dishes that are a bit pricey (for the Pittsburgh market) but well-executed. Never really have been let down with food options here plus they have a reasonable selection of beers. Always busy so make sure to make a reservation beforehand! I haven't had the brunch here so all my comments are for dinner but I will say I've heard good things about the brunch. It's on my to do list...  On a side note, Monday nights after 10 PM they have industry night for the folks who are in the restaurant industry. They offer $8 bites and drink specials- definitely worth checking out if you're out late on a Monday.   Food: I've eaten a number of dishes here and quite frankly have never been disappointed. It is, in true Pittsburgh fashion, rather decadent so don't go if you're on a diet. My favorites: Snacks/Apps- fried taters with black truffle mayo (the mayo really sells it in my opinion), Mac n cheese (a generous serving of mixed in chorizo packs in a nice punch of flavor; eat and expect an impending nap), fried brussels (my favorite but again, not the healthy kind your mom made you eat as a kid) Entrees- lamb burger (just all-in-all well executed burger), pork chop   Also if you're there for industry night on Monday, I believe the menu may rotate each time but if poutines are on the menu (see picture) go for Asian Persuasion and Southern Pride. Three poutine dishes was more than plenty for 4 of us following an appetizer or two.   Drinks: Had a mixed experience with cocktails here. Not all that impressed with them so if you're on the fence about a cocktail or draft beer, I'd steer towards the latter. They seem to always have a few interesting ones on tap. If you're looking for a place for a quick drink with friends downtown and are willing to stand at the bar, it's a worthwhile stop.   Ambience: Matches the food- lots of wood, warm and dimly lit. As I alluded to before, it's a nice way to prep you for the food coma to come. The place seems busy often do not a quiet romantic date spot but certainly trendy and interesting enough for a date or with a few friends. Large groups would probably be difficult to seat here- haven't tried before.   Service: Generally good although can be a bit slower when things are busy. Never had issues so far.

Maybe I am biased because I live in Manhattan but this place is beyond mediocre.  The service, the drinks, and especially the food.  Terrible salmon, over buttered toast for the bone marrow, over spiced kim chi, wilted and overcooked vegetables.  And the service - sub par.

Excellent restaurant!  Reservations are a must, but it is also well worth the wait.  If you do not make reservations, there is a nice area to sit outside of the restaurant.  I've been there for both lunch and dinner (never brunch, but I hear it is awesome). The atmosphere is trendy, yet comfortable.  Food is great, but nothing out of the ordinary - classics with their own twist.  Perfect for a date or dinner with friends.

What a great place. The Decor was great. Our waitress was very nice and really worked to please us. The Kobe beef melted in my mouth and the mashed potatoes were like my mother used to make. You will enjoy eating here.

I was beyond excited to try meat and potatoes for the first time. We had reservations for 7 pm and got seated right away. Shortly after we were seated our waitress came to take our orders. Everything was going perfect.. Until an hour and a half later and we still had not received food. This would be acceptable if the waitress would have came to our table to apologize or to let us know that it would be just a little bit longer, but she did not.   Once the food did arrive, however, it was amazing. I ordered the salmon, which was delicious. Some people in my party had the duck and others had the hanger steak and burgers.   Once it was time for dessert we asked to see a menu and the waitress said that they only did desserts verbally. Then she never said what the desserts were. So we left still hungry with no dessert.  Overall, if you have the time, it's worth the wait for the food. I would rate the food 5/5 and the service a 2/5.

made reservations for dinner for our last nite of our trip in Pittsburgh. Make sure to make a reservation because the place is always busy and packed. Parking is street parking only in the middle of downtown. My bf and I shared the meal for 2 which consists of a 45oz ribeye with bone marrow gratin and side and sauce (these r extra charges). The ribeye was cooked perfectly medium rare. We ordered the brussel sprouts as a side and the house steak sauce. For our appetizer we ordered the buttermilk chicken livers and the chocolate pot de creme for dessert. We will definitely be coming back here when we visit Pittsburgh again=)

Another good Yelp-aided restaurant choice in Pittsburgh.... and another hit!  Thanks Yelp.   It was a nice night in Pittsburgh, so we decided to dine outside on the patio, but the inside looked pretty cool as well.  There looked to be a room off the main area for a group dinner party.  The food was on point.  We started off with fries and an order of "Devils on Horseback".  I can't really give a great explanation of what the latter is, but it involves bacon-wrapped dates, cheese, and I believe olives.  It made me think "high-end stoner food".  I hope that helps.   For entree, my wife got the papparedelle bolognese and I got the special, which was a flank steak with a fried egg, béarnaise sauce and a short rib hash.  My dish was delicious.... a bit on the salty side, but very good.  The pasta was very good as well.  We stuck with wine for our dinner, but the drink menu had a wide variety of cocktails.  If that's your thing, I'm sure you'll find something worth trying.  The service was just okay.  I think our waitress was a bad shift or two away from throwing her apron away.... or maybe she just had a really long night.     Recommend!

It lives up to its reputation of being an amazing brunch spot; spent a cool morning there recently, and loved it! I enjoyed their version of a grilled cheese which included an amazing pickled green tomato not to be out shined by stellar bacon! The Bloody Mary bar was a hit but I chose to enjoy a lavender bubbly drink that was delicate but sweet! The only minor suggestion I may make would be for the front of house staff to not so obviously walk through so frequently to check the status of your meal to determine their wait time, it made us feel rushed or judged. However, the food, drinks and waitstaff was on point and I have no complaints! Can't wait to go back!

Last night, we took my boyfriend's family to Meat and Potatoes.  The food was amazing (which I discuss below), but first I wanted to mention how well we were treated.  We had a reservation for 6 people.  Due to some folks lingering at their table and other issues, we weren't seated until about 30 minutes after the time of our reservation.  Instead of simply leaving us at the bar, the owner came over twice to apologize and comp us a round of drinks and two flatbread appetizers.  That level of attention and care for customers is unique, and our group was still talking this morning about how well we were treated.     Apart from the excellent service, the food was delicious.  We had the bone marrow, tartar and pate appetizers, all of which were great.  The boys had the chicken pot pie, meatloaf and sweetbreads for dinner. These were big hits.  The girls had the steak tacos and the soft shell tacos for dinner, all of which were also very good.  Overall, we had a great experience and will definitely return.

This place was very crowded, they fit me in at the bar and had some good items from the menu.  I did not have it, but the big rib bone of meat that was served to many people looked interesting, I was waiting for Fred Flintstones car to flip on its side it was so big.  Make sure you get a reservation.

Still trying to give Pittsburgh a try but continuously disappointed. Yes, I am from Pgh. We need to send some of these restaurant managers to other 'major' cities to see how it's done. Just got back from southern Cali. Every establishment there is exceptional / they want ur business! and NICE!  Overall, another pig with lipstick. Staff rude Food is ok. Maybe the best u will see here in the burgh!  BAM!
Great food. It's a tight squeeze and I feel like I'm eating with the people next to me, but the food is good enough that I have gone back and will continue to do so.
Loved the food and drinks.  Very unique.  Large portions.  Cook spot before or after a show.

I'm in Pittsburgh working at the PCLO and I've been to Meat & Potatoes, Butcher In The Rye & Pork & Beans. The food is top notch and the service has been excellent. Tonight I had dinner at the bar at Meat & Potatoes and asked for mayo & mustard for my burger. When I got my check I was charged a dollar for truffle mayo. I didn't ask for truffle mayo. When I mentioned it to the server he shrugged his shoulders. It's only a dollar, but I was disappointed with the lack of clarity. If you're going to charge me for mayo. Let me know so I can decide if I really want it. I'm in the industry and still over tipped. But I wanted to stiff him because of his reaction. I thought about talking to the manager, but again... it's only a buck. Still.. it's bad form. Is this your policy?

The best fried chicken I ever had! We've eaten at their sister restaurant, The Butcher and the Rye, several times. We were in Pittsburgh and had the opportunity to have lunch at Meat & Potatoes before a six hour drive. Everything we ordered was delicious. The fried chicken with biscuits was amazing! Crunchy, well seasoned and juicy - the fried chicken was everything that fried chicken should be. We did not try any cocktails because of the drive.
Had the Yukon Potatoes to start, pork belly pastrami had me. Then the porterhouse with bone marrow butter, fantastic.  Had the dessert sampler best of all.

A disappointing recent visit to what has otherwise been a solid restaurant, all due to a poor service experience.   We arrive late on a Thursday, after most shows downtown had started, so the restaurant was not crowded.   We sat at the bar, which is usually a great experience, but today, the 3 bartenders didn't feel like making eye contact or being even nominally friendly much less serving.  No one greeted us when we sat down, and it took forever for someone to take our order.  The drinks were wonderfully prepared, as usual, and the food was solid.  However, they forgot part of our order (seems to be a theme if you look at other reviews), and the staff just seemed to be uninterested in being there or dealing with customers.    Guests near us seemed to be having the same experience -- surly bartenders, distracted staff.  Would have been a 4, but service has got to improve.
The first of many Rick DeShantz restaurants that are consistently the best restaurants in the city.  M&P is on a short list of *must* try restaurants in the city.
Got the croque madam for brunch, which was a 3 star at best. Hostesses were playing Pokemon Go upon our arrival but our waitress was very friendly and the food came out extremely fast.

Outstanding meal with outstanding service.  Exceeded my expectations.  The Bone Marrow was incredible.  Wonderful atmosphere and professional wait staff make this a must when you  are dining out in Pittsburgh.

It wasn't really possible for me to be more excited about M&P when I'd heard about it.  Ambitious menu, attractive space and branding, serious cocktails...you name it, M&P seemed to be doing it right.  The primary problem is I just don't think the food is good enough.    It's not that it flat-out, irredeemably sucks (when you use quality ingredients there are sure to be some good flavors there), it's that 1) foods that are shamelessly unhealthy really have to be off-the-charts tasty or it's not worth it; and 2) it's not cheap for Pittsburgh. Case in point: the fried brussels sprouts somehow lacked any semblance of crispiness.  If I'm looking for soggy and greasy any local dive will do.        Unfortunately the service was also brutal when we went.  We ordered a starter for the table that somehow came after the dinner was entirely over, and the waiter disappeared for long stretches for reasons unknown.  This wasn't during the opening days either.  At this price point I can't imagine winning many diners' loyalty with the level of service.  I'm happy that places are taking on ambitious menu offerings. Perhaps M&P can evolve into a really good place, I hope it does. But until then I'd rather go to Primanti's.

This is a review for brunch. I have never been for dinner or drinks, and probably won't. We took our friend to Meat and Potatoes for a birthday brunch and were less than impressed with the brunch. First, they do not have a milk frother and only offer coffee. That would be ok IF they had black tea (which they do not, or did not, the weekend we went, which is absurd to not have on hand--go to the CVS across the street and get some when you run out). So coffee or bust which seems awfully strange for a "top" brunch place in Pittsburgh. The lack of tea or a latte definitely ruined my brunch. The food was meh. I ordered a regular eggs/bacon/homefries and it came out cold. The others ordered the fried chicken friend pork and it was a "big pile of blah" (direct quote from the eater). The bloody mary bar was like something in a college bar. Not worth it. It was very expensive and very busy, so the service was poor as well. We kept having to flag down a waiter to get service. Should have gone to the neighbourhood greasy spoon.
So good had to go there again!  Any beef eater will be wowed - get the bone marrow, just incredible, brought one home for our Siberian Husky and she was one happy gal!

I've been to Meat and Potatoes three times over the last few months, with the most recent time being about two weeks ago, and the summary message is this: I've been unhappy with my last couple meals.  First time Dinner: Appetizers were great --- unique and tasty. Drinks were great.  My wife and I shared the awesome 34oz Ribeye for two. This ribeye is served with a 1ft bone protruding from the edge of the cutting board style serving platter.  It came with huge steak fries and their bone butter (bone marrow and butter, spices, basically)  We could not have been happier with our meal.  Service was great.  This led to me trying them for lunch.  Lunch: I had the soft-shell-crab sandwich.  While I knew I was being somewhat adventurous ordering this, I was completely turned off by the texture of the crab. I ate less than half of it and threw it away.  Bad experience.  I chalked this one up to bad menu selection.  (I did notice, however, that this item has been removed from the lunch menu.  I wonder why?!)  Second Dinner:  This time, a different couple joined us for dinner before "Holiday Pops" across the street at Heinz Hall.  This time I ordered the Roasted Branzino, which is basically European seabass.  While the presentation was very impressive with basically the whole fish served in a skillet with potatoes, capers, tomatoes, fennel, and artichokes there were problems with the execution.  They remove the bones by slicing the top of the fish and removing what they can through the top.  Long story short -- there were still plenty of bones in my fish.  Next, the fish was relatively small and hardly made a dinner meal for a big guy like myself.  The taste was ok, but playing around with pulling bones out of my mouth (with company) is not an experience I look forward to.  All four of us were underwhelmed with our meals and there are plenty of other alternatives that do a better job.  My overall impression is that service is generally good, and the cocktails served are inventive, fresh, clean, and tasty!  The food, however, seems to be style over substance and I'm just not happy at the end of the day!

Meat and potatoes is a classic Pittsburgh restaurant. The place is full on a Monday night. Great people, friends, friendly staff. The drinks are retro 40ish . The vibe is friendly and the food is rustic and great!

Meat & Potatoes... I can think of few places that I truly, truly want to enjoy more!  It's a cool place, with a great patio, and awesome food.  BUT TERRIBLE SERVICE!! Having gone several times and even having waited over a year to go back, we continue to leave disappointed.  Especially when management doesn't seem to care enough to respond to feedback...  Maybe if I wait another year or try the new place they're opening I'll find what I'm looking for.

Was hyped up after eating at sister place (Butcher in the Rye). Drinks were good, food wasn't bad but was not expecting apps to be served in chachy paper carnival French fry bowls. Ambiance, drinks, food, overall experience better at Butcher

After wanting to try meat and potatoes for a long time my husband and I finally made it!  The restaurant while small is very nicely decorated and while the tables are close together that does not bother me.  We got the wedge salad and split it- it was very large and very tasty!  We also ordered the meat & potatoes for 2.  It was a Tomahawk ribeye.  While it was very tasty it had quite a bit of fat and didn't have as much flavor as I was expecting.  I saw quite a few other dishes going out that looked fantastic so i will be sure to try one of those the next time!

We have been going since 2013 and this was the worst experience I have ever had. I had proof that my reservation was at 7:30 and the hostess argued with me that is was not. Finally they agreed and we were seated. Then it took 20 mins to get our drinks. He did not ever ask if he we wanted another one despite being at our table a few times. I should never have to ask for another drink. The service was terrible. The best thing was the bus boys. Never going again which make me so sad!

After two recent trips to M&P, one for brunch, one for dinner... I finally think they've turned the corner. I haven't always been the biggest advocate as I've had some awful experiences but kudos to you them as of late.  For as nauseating as the whole Edison bulb, overly hip architecture that has sprouted across Pittsburgh, it works well here. They bartenders are skilled, and the best part, they are actually pleasant. Which is more than I can say about a lot of similar establishments. We stuck with beer and some simple Old Fasions, but I was memorized watching them work as we were sitting at the bar.  Frankly, I could come here and just eat from the snacks menu, but we decided on some appetizers with the bone marrow and tartare. Both were exquisite, just the right amount, and made up for any past transgressions from previous visits.  For dinner, I had a plain Jane burger, and it was exactly what I was craving. Cooked medium rare and didn't even need condiments which I rarely find myself saying. Fries, were as expected, very good and presumably cooked in duck fat. Although that's just a guess on my part.  To date the only issue is getting a table or at least, getting reservations. I'm sure it's a stressful job judging by be need of 2-4 hostesses every night but they don't always handle things well. I arrived right around 5PM on a Friday and got two seats at the bar no problem. Amazingly, the place was fairly dead until 6PM.  Confusing as we couldn't get reservations, but we were able to get in so it all worked out.

Good food and cocktails. Their bone marrow was good, but a bit too oily for me. We also ordered the fried chicken liver, which tasted fine,the pig's ears, which I didn't try but my friends like it.  For main, we had steak, salmon and duck. Salmon was really good, tender and fresh. It conbines well with the black rich . However, the sauce and the veggies were a bit salty for me.  The service and the atmosphere was great. A goos 4 star restaurant overall.

Brunch. Meat and Potatoes has officially raised the bar on what a brunch should be. This place FAR exceeded my expectations and then some. From the outside, the place looks a bit gimmicky, but trust me, once they've had their way with you, you will not regret coming.   We sat down in the busy place around 11am on a Saturday and only had to wait 15min for a table for 2. We asked the waitress if they had a bloody mary bar and she said something to the effect of- yeah, I'll bring you the alcohol you choose and then you can garnish your drink at the "bloody mary bar". THIS COULD NOT HAVE BEEN UNDERSOLD ANY MORE! What actually happens is they have 6 or so house made vodka or tequila infusions which are phenomenal! Old Bay vokda? sign me up! Garlic black pepper vodka? you can count me in! You take you glass and fill it to your satisfaction with delicious bloody mary mix, which contains just the right amount of kick, by the way. After this, you are greeted a bountiful assortment of spices, garnishes, vegetables, meats and anything else you can think of putting in your bloody. Everything from smoked weenies, to perfectly cooked shrimp to sinful bacon. Artichoke hearts, several varieties of olives, celery and pickles await as well. They give you the alcohol and bloody mix and the ice, YOU take your destiny from there. Oh, and did I mention you get this entire experience for only 7 dollars?!  We saw after making these heavenly concoctions that we were going to have full bellies so we ordered only one main breakfast dish between the two of us. Chicken and jalapeno cheddar waffles, the menu read. What it actually should say is "Deliciously moist cheddar waffles with satisfying kick of jalapeno with a WHOLE CHICKEN on top served with too-good-to-be-true bourbon bacon maple syrup." I was speechless when the dish arrived as past experiences at other brunching locations served me with a mediocre waffle with two measly strips of chicken on top. This was no ordinary chicken and waffles and I now don't think I can ever order this dish at another restaurant and feel satisfied knowing what's really out here.   Our experience at Meat and Potatoes showed me what brunch can and should be. I salute you, M&P for giving me what I think may actually be the best brunch experience of my life.
Top notch service and food. Atmosphere was great I would definitely recommend meat and potatoes

"So if she's ordering whiskey you can assume she's clearly comfortable with herself, knows what she wants and has no problem making it happen - regardless of what anyone else at the bar might think." - Elite Daily, 10 Reasons Why You Should Always God For The Girl Who Drinks Whiskey   When I moved to a new city and realized that some of my social interests were different than many of my fellow college graduates, I found myself exploring restaurants and bars in downtown, because that's where I wanted to be: in the city. I was first introduced to Meat & Potatoes (M&P) in Pittsburgh's Theatre Square, by a colleague. Several weeks later, I found myself going back, by myself. There is a weird stigma about women going to bars alone but if you know what you like (drink wise and environment wise) then, go for it! I love going out alone to enjoy a drink or meal alone. M&P is the perfect location and environment for such a night. Why? Because it lays somewhere near casual fine dining and brings the working professionals and artsy culture of Pittsburgh together, under one roof. It's a place where I know I will get great service, a stellar Manhattan (I like mine with Blanton's and 2 cherries) and a great seat for people-watching across their large but cozy bar. I've been to M&P so many times now that the bartenders know me by name - whether that is a good thing or not, is up to you. I've enjoyed an hour or more to myself at M&P but, I have also had some fantastic conversations late into the night with those visiting Pittsburgh or locals who also love this spot.  If you are looking for dinner, make a reservation and you will be in store for a whirl! M&P's dinner menu is home to a variety of quality cuts of meat and fish but their mushroom risotto and sprouts are drool-worthy as well. Their weekend brunch and bloody mary bar is one of the best in Pittsburgh but be sure to make a reservation or you won't get a seat!   I went through this phase where I would be craving a great bar environment and I would want to try a new place in town. I am all for trying new spots but, there is a certain time in the night where you simply shouldn't fix what's not broken. Don't walk across the city if what you love is standing in front of you. On a late night's I have gotten into the habit of ordering fernet and coke at the bar, along with their signature espresso panna cotta. Yummy!  Get a group of friends or co-workers together, or venture out alone for a great time and drink at Meat and Potatoes. And, don't forget the whiskey. Pittsburgh is a Meat and Potatoes kind of town, and M&P is where you want to be if you are a downtown dweller or visitor!  - xoxo, A  (A California Girl Living in Pittsburgh on Purpose)

I really wish I could give this restaurant more than 5 stars. My wife and I travel an hour and a half a few times every year just to eat here. It is definitely geared towards food savvy customers. With food coming on half sheet trays, and kitchen towels for napkins it makes restaurant employees from anywhere feel right at home. The servers and bar staff all seem to enjoy their jobs and take pride in everything they bring to the table.      First was the alcohol- They have an excellent list of spirits including many prohibition cocktails, which in my experience have all been delicious. I'm a bourbon drinker, and anytime I find buffalo trace on a menu it's a sign of good things to come. Their barrel aged manhattan was sweet and smooth, and had exactly the right amount of bitters and an imported cherry to boot.      Getting appetizers is far and away my favorite part about coming here. The chicken livers are out of this world, and I always get an order of bone marrow. I've never had anything here that was anything short of fantastic, but if I were to make a recommendation for an entree I would totally suggest getting into what ever offal parts they have on the menu, or any form braised meat ( shank or short rib).     Always remember to save room for dessert. I am not normally a fan of dessert or sweet things in general, but I always save room for that last course here. On our most recent visit I tried tiramisu which was one of the best I've ever had, but the toffee cake was to die for. It was served warm with a side of house-made whipped cream and pomegranate seeds, and I would have ordered a second one had I not been full to the point of bursting. All around great place, with refined drinks, fantastic appetizers, delicious meals, amazing desserts, and the most comfy chairs you could ask for. 10/10 Joe Macklin PS. To all the jag-offs out there who are complaining about things like being told you cant have more people than you made your reservation for, please stop going to restaurants all you do is cause headaches, and no one wants your business. Also to those who hated everything they tried, it is not the fault of the restaurant if you have poor taste.

Had the flat iron steak and it was soooo delicious! The atmosphere was nice but make sure you make a reservation before showing up because they had no seats available. I squeezed myself into the bar. The staff looks like they mix great drinks but I didn't try them.  The food was great, had a potato pancake with pulled pork as well. That was great! I definitely want to go back before I leave Pittsburgh.

Everything here is delicious. Seriously, I mean EVERYTHING! You WILL need a reservation so don't think you will just be able to walk in and get a table. But when a place is this good what do you expect?!? Get the devils on horseback as an appetizer, you will thank me later! Also, if you are a fan of fried pickles they are some of the best in Pittsburgh. I have never had a bad meal at meat and potatoes and have have eaten here way too many times to review all of my meal choices. The specials are always top notch and you cant really go wrong by ordering one. Just go with the fried pickles and devils on horseback as an app then order anything off the menu for a great dining experience! A+ (it's really dark here so bring a flashlight to read the menu)
Their Brunch is banging! and the Bloody Mary Bar is out of this world!
Oh my goodness!  This place was amazing.  Everything we ordered was fantastic!  I highly recommend the Brussel sprouts,  the goat cheese & bread,  as well as the pork sandwich.

I ate here right after attending a play next door at the O'Reilly Theater. After learning that nearby restaurants closed early due to water issues, we quickly noticed that they were still open and decided to partake. We were welcomed and guaranteed a spot without reservation (points added for that)! The waitress was very pleasant and friendly. We ordered our drinks and browsed the extensive menu full of gastropub favorites! I had to order the mac n cheese! So yummy! I also ordered the wings and they were also very tasty!   I can't wait to dine here again and try their brisket. Definitely 5+ stars!!!
Delicious and beautiful and full of mirrors! I love the cocktails. I've never had the food, but it always looks amazing.

Food was excellent! Had a late reservation,  was my fault waited to long to make them and it was for a Friday night, lots of shows in Pittsburgh that night.  I would recommend the bone marrow so worth the price! It was our 33rd anniversary,  enjoyed the food very much. I had the salmon with kimchi and black rice, the salmon was cooked perfect, very moist! The hubby got the pork chop with beans and greens, very flavorful,  and such big portion! Was a younger crowd this night, and only draw back was the tables very close, so heard other conversations. But we did enjoy ourselves!

The restaurant has a very trendy feel to it-even on a Sunday evening the place is buzzing with hip, young foodies, and it has a great atmosphere.   We started with the bone marrow appetizer. It was actually my first time trying bone marrow, and after tasting it, I don't know how I've ever gone without it. It was presented very nicely, and I loved that they had a few different kinds of accompaniments to give it different flavors. I think we had capers, sea salt, pickled red onions, and some sort of gremolata. I loved the sea salt and bone marrow combination.   For our meals, we got the pappardelle pasta and the mushroom flatbread and shared. The pappardelle was good, and had some great chunks of meat in there, but it was served with garlic bread that I honestly felt just detracted from the rest of the dish. The mushroom flatbread was tasty too, although nothing that made it extraordinary.   Overall, the place had a great atmosphere, bone marrow to die for, and some solid entrees. Would be back if I'm ever in the Pittsburgh area!
