In Pittsburgh for one night - this place had some great reviews - had to be done. I'm not familiar with Pittsburgh so didn't know if Parking would be an issue. Happy to discover there is very reasonable parking in the same building as the restaurant.   The inside was pretty full and busy, a little loud but not terrible. Some baffling would probably help a little bit with that.   As a starter I ordered their special Negroni and two small apps. The Negroni - in a word - was excellent. Here's what makes theirs different: Nolets Rose Petal Infused Dry Gin, Campari and Lillet Rouge (Fortified Wine). The fortified wine is a sub for the standard sweet vermouth - and it worked quite well. To accompany that I tried the  Grilled Bread with Goat Butter and Seasonal Jam and the Fried Brussels with Parmesan and Lemon Aeoli. The Brussels were very nice fried but I would have loved them as much if they were simply roasted. The combination of the slight bitterness of the Brussels Sprouts with the savory Parmesan and the ever so slight hint of sweetness in the Lemon Aeoli - was such a nice contrast. And then you switch to the grilled bread - and hit some other regions of the palate - tossing a sip of the Negroni - magic.   I could have stopped there but, as I was leaving the next day, wanted to try at least one of the Mains. So I ordered the Pappardelle - with Bolognese, Short Rib, Pancetta, Pork Shoulder and Garlic Bread on the side.  It was very well prepared and presented. I would have probably enjoyed it more if I hadn't already indulgent the apps. But that's my fault!   I ate at the bar and the servers there worked well as a team - both giving excellent and efficient and friendly service. Very professional. Would definitely come back!!
Rude rude rude. Don't waste your time and money here. The foods not that good and their attitude is even worse!

If you are in Pittsburgh on the weekend and looking for brunch, THIS IS THE PLACE!!! Cool atmosphere with a DJ spinning tunes and a BloodyMary bar.   Fried taters with truffle oil cooked to perfection, and our entrees (Chicken and Waffles and the Hash) were incredible.   Huge portions.    I only wish I could come here every weekend!
Tried this place on the prix fixe menu during restaurant week. Loved every single plate that was put in front of me. Tried it for brunch. Even better. If you haven't gone yet, just do it.

I had one of the best and most interesting meals here. Everything I tried was absolutely delicious. I only say interesting because they have so many delicacies on the menu that you don't find at most restaurants. I had a few firsts here and it was very memorable. With so many reviews on Yelp and their 4 star rating, I could not wait to try it.   Not having a reservation I was expected to be turned away at this popular restaurant but was pleasantly surprised when the hostess was able to get us seated in less than 10 mins in the alternate dining room.   From the moment I was handed the legal sized file folder that contained the two page menu, I was like a kid in a candy store. They had fresh mussels of the day prepared in 3 special ways. I ordered the bone marrow appetizer as it was highly recommended (my first time). It was delicious and very large as a starter.  For my main course I ordered the Steak Diane with the baked potato. The steak was huge and was cooked perfectly with a very delicious savory sauce. I normally do not eat baked potatoes but this one was to die for!   The drink menu was also very nice. Every drink I tried was very delicious. They have my favorite dark rum (Cruzan Black Strap) and it was a perfect compliment in the "dark and stormy". I also tried for my first time absinthe. They had a good selection. I definitely saw the green fairy after that drink!  Overall it was a great experience and I will be back as soon as possible!

We had brunch here on Christmas Eve, and the experience couldn't have been better. Our reservation was for a half hour before they were to close, so we were a little nervous that the service or food may suffer , as it does in so many places that close to closing time. Not the case!   The portions were large and satisfying. I had the Huevos Rancheros, which was the best I've ever had. Coming from someone who lived in Mexico, and has been back to visit many times, this is really saying something. They were even better than I make at home!  I truly respect a restaurant that has so much faith in its food that there isn't a salt shaker to be seen on not one table. One was not needed.  The service was wonderful. The server was always there for our every need, without hovering over our table, and was very knowledgeable about the menu. She steered us all in the right direction with her recommendations, and we all left extremely satisfied and pleasantly plump.   Suffice it to say, this will not be our last trip to Meat stand Potatoes!

All the hype around this place, it's all true. Both the experience and the food are in line with each other and it's all worth the trouble of finding an open table here. Definitely reserve a table in advance. When my husband and I went, we were lucky to find an open table as walk-ins, possibly because it was a weeknight. We ordered the Devils on horseback, Thai curry mussels (with fries) and the pork belly tacos. Omg the flavors here are so incredibly bold, but not overpowering in any way. The reason for my reduction of one star you ask? I got sick afterwards. I can't exactly pinpoint this meal as the culprit, but I'm almost certain the mussels were it. Despite getting a little sick, I would definitely come back to try something different next time. The food here is just that worth it.

The food was brought out HOT, just what you'd expect after almost a half hour waiting to be seated and an additional half hour to get our food,  which we ordered right when we sat down.... and after all that wait,  my food was overcooked (chicken and waffles). If you choose this venue,  definitely make a reservation; however, the water was great and the staff was friendly.

I'm officially updating my review of this place. We stopped by tonight for dinner and it was not good. We ordered the tartare, soft shell crab tacos and the curried moules with frites. The moules were ok. The mussels were like warm, but the sauce was hot. The soft shell crab was not soft. We pulled out bones/shells in every bite. The frites with black truffle mayo were amazing. The tartare was slimy and fishy. We sent it back because it tasted so unseasoned and almost rancid. The manager told us the chef made a new batch. When it came it was just as bad as the first batch. We have been here before several times and have always ordered the tartare. It has always been really good. This one lacked any flavor. You could tell the didn't add an acid or mustard or anything. We sent the second batch back too. yuck. I would not return. In addition, they overcharged our bill by up charging our drinks and other orders. I would not return. There are better places to go... Like Tamari!

I've eaten brunch here twice.  Everytime I say... NEVER AGAIN.  Of course, I somehow get subjected to it again.  I gave it 2 stars because the bloody mary bar is pretty damn sweet, but that's mostly because I can mix a mean bloody mary.  It has VERY little to do with this place. I got to foccacia this last time, it was horrible.  My eggs were FULLY cooked and bland.  The brisket on top was completely leather.  The cheese was scarce and burned.  The potatoes were undercooked and cold.  So... they messed up my MEAT and my POTATOES?  That's just too rich.

From its name I thought this might be a steak house, but in fact there was a variety of menu items, all put together creatively with flavorful, complimentary ingredients.  Good selection of wines and beers too.  We started out with the Devils on Horseback appetizer - OMG, the flavors!  I'm glad the waiter suggested we add a 4th to the order of 3, or my husband and I may have fought over the last one.  I had the lamb shank, which was fall-off-the-bone tender, and my husband had the salmon, which was prepared to the perfect doneness.   I have a gluten allergy, so I was grateful for the GF menu, which has most of the regular menu items but modified to be GF.  We didn't have a reservation on a Saturday night, so we went early (5:15) and had no problem getting a seat for dinner at the bar, which was a fun spot to be.

We were looking for nice dining experience and this restaurant was recommended and did not disappoint. The place is very popular and we had reservations that we made through Yelp and the Table was ready when we arrived. We started off with a couple Old Fashions which were excellent. We ordered the Brussels sprouts and the Chicken livers for appetizers which were so good. For Dinner we had the Brenzino and the Bone in Filet both prepared to perfection. The waitress was very attentive and overall a really great dining experience. We will be back again for sure.
Have been several times for dinner--always excellent--short rib flatbread is magical.  I went to brunch here for first time.  Short rib hash with 2 perfectly luscious poached eggs.  Perfection.

Not at all what I expected. A name like Meat and Potatoes, with an emphasis on pork shoulder and belly, conjures thoughts of sawdust floors and smokehouse. Meat and Potatoes is shooting for the downtown Pittsburgh crowd (i.e.,dressed up rich suburban Pittsburghers between 35 and 60). The meat and cocktails are very good, the service is friendly, and the atmosphere is upscale. Mussels were ok. The Porter House for 2 is truly excellent.   My  burger was ok (for medium rare, it was much more toward the medium side). Definitely try the Sazerac if you're into cocktails. The bread pudding was tasty.  This would be a good place to go on a date, with friends, or a client if everyone is in the mood for a steak dinner. Plan to spend ~$65 and be overly full. Avoid before the theatre rush; it gets crowded.
Meat and potatoes for two is the only thing I'll ever order there simply because my brain and stomach won't let me. Girlfriend agrees, my only complaint is that she puts down as much steak as me! :(

I arrived with a couple friends for a Sunday brunch.  The menu was very intriguing and I ordered the Irish eggs benedict (corned beef) on the basis of a recommendation from the bartender.   A monstrosity appeared as my meal and at first I was quite worried due to the size that it would not be great.  Fortunately, the dish was succulent and despite my better judgement I finished all of the huge platter of 2 poached eggs and corned beef, although I did leave much of the hollandaise sauce as it was too much.  The wait staff were attentive and I was able to try a number of microbrew Stouts with the Irish eggs benedict (these went together quite well) as my glass never was quite finished before they asked if I wanted another.  There is also an incredible scotch cabinet as you walk in the door.  This is one of the best collections of scotch that I have seen outside of NYC.
Very hearty brunch with pretty typical fare done exquisitely.

This is going to be a hard review to write. First of all, I very much love meat & potatoes. The food is amazing and atmosphere is awesome and this is definitely one of the best restaurants in Pittsburgh. But something happened while I was dining there with my husband in the summer that made me really disappointed about the restaurant.  My husband and I went to Meat & Potatoes on a Friday night and we ordered the Meat & Potatoes for Two and with the mushroom as a side (we paid $8 for this side if I remember correctly). It is a big dish so in the end we couldn't finish the steak and we had a large portion of mushroom left. When the waiter came and took our bill, I told him to box the remaining food that we couldn't finish. He came back with our bill and a paper bag. I trusted that he packed everything in so I didn't check the bag to see what was inside. The next day after we got home, I was very excited to eat the leftover but only to find that the waiter did not pack any of our remaining mushroom, which was a large portion left on the plate. I was very disappointed so I called the restaurant right away. Someone picked up the phone and was not very concerned at all and told me the manager would call me back about this issue. However, almost 2 months have passed and I have received no calls from Meat & Potatoes ever since.  I know people might think I'm being cheap here because it's only the mushroom! However, I did pay for that dinner (which was not cheap at all) and was told to be expecting a phone call from the manager. People are not to be fooled like this.  Sorry, I know the food is brilliant but I would not come back again.

Not sure why I didn't try this place earlier. Really nice environment and more casual than I expected.  Our service was very attentive but not pushy.  Definitely the favorite thing we ordered was the flat iron steak.

My advice to the owners of this restaurant.  When someone comes in for lunch, and there are 40 minutes left, don't tell them, "we have to be respectful of our servers than need to leave at 2."  Maybe, I don't know, you as an employee should be more respectful of your owner's business.  And, no, we don't want to eat at the bar on a limited menu.  Company owners try so hard to establish a good business and it only takes one rude, poorly trained employee to ruin the experience and cause a poor review to be written.

My husband and I are huge fans of poutine, so we knew we had to come here after we found out they have it on the menu! Food was great, service was good, and we would definitely come back! Definitely get the mussels -- SO good.

Just a quickie.  One of my favorite Pgh restaurants.  Evening meal is perhaps overrated. But. the Sunday Brunch, is great. Feels like you are in a  "Proper city" nice well done comfort food and the vodka bar, perfect for taking any guest or even yourselves for a special or not so special Sunday.

We stopped by shortly before opening to get a table for brunch, none were available but we were able to snag a seat at the bar. Service was quick & decent. We took advantage of the Bloody Mary bar- I had bacon vodka (the only non-spicy option), while my husband had the honey Sriracha. The bar itself was great! I love mine a little dirty & was disappointed to not find olive juice on the bar. Fun experience & there were plenty of items you could probably make 2-3 skewers if you put everything on! Onto the food. I asked the server if the eggs in purgatory was in a tomato ragu (I saw a mushroom ragu on the menu too) and he said "no, it's mushroom." Based on his response I ordered that. To my surprise, it came out as a tomato sauce. Had I known (why I asked), I would've ordered something else. Very disappointed, and the reason for 3 stars. To have a server not know the ingredients in your regular menu items (it'd be better to say "not sure, let me check") is unacceptable.  The dish was fine, just not what I expected. My husband had the chicken & waffle- huge portion but the bones in chicken always make it tough to eat. He enjoyed the subtle spice from the jalapeños (he says 3.5 stars). I was very excited about this place with the high rating & countless reviews, but am disappointed.

I love the pork chop, steak tartare, bone marrow and of course the tomahawk steak for two. But my very favorite is still the pub burger with fries. Huge steak burger, horseradish cheddar, pork belly pastrami, special sauce, and a gooey fried egg. It's a beautiful Sunday afternoon so I just took a walk with the dog, stopped at M&P, and picked up a burger to go. You just can't beat it!

The ambiance at Meat & Potatoes is 5 stars.  It's unique without taking that so far as to make people uncomfortable. It's warm and bright and dark and cozy all at once with captivating light fixtures, various size tables and tufted chairs.  It's more special and sparkly than a home, but it's not stiff or formal.  The menu isn't overly broad but there's something for everyone.  And the presentation?  Impressive.  The Pork for instance, looked like a polished version of something that would've been served to the Flinstones.  Huge and glossy with homestyle fixins.  It tasted good, but it didn't quite live up to its looks.  The Pork was tasty but slightly (and I mean slightly) chewy and the greens had a vinegar note that didn't quite blend with the rest of the dish and the beans were (nicely) more interesting than one would expect for baked beans, but they were quite firm for beans in a way I'd consider undercooked.  I rarely indulge in french fries, and I'm pleased to say, these ones were well worth the splurge.  Crispy without being burnt, nicely salted, and the large portion is.... well, large.  We ordered another entree, but the presentation of the pork so overshadowed it, I can't even remember what it was!  In the end, the star of the show was the Fried Brussels.  Seemingly a staple at hipster joints nationwide, one could rue the unoriginal dish in place of something more locally inspired, but... Yum.   So crispy and dusted with parmesan and the aioli.  Thank you, Meat & Potatoes, for keeping it simple, simple, simple.  I had a child with me who declared they would eat brussels every meal if I could recreate the dish.    It was an enjoyable meal that didn't blow me away, apart from the brussels (which, I was able to recreate, sans the aioli, at home with a shocking amount of oil.).    The wait staff was pleasant though a little scattered... Rushing away forgetting that we wanted to order dessert (good but nothing to write home about) and in the end, after we asked them to package an entire leftover flatbread that went uneaten, they never brought it out.  We could have asked a third time, but headed home without it.

We were in town for an event last weekend and this place came highly recommended for Sunday brunch and it was a fantastic recommendation!    We had an amazing brunch on Sunday and the bloody mary bar was also top notch.   I got the chicken and waffles and they were delicious! Not to mention the fact that you get, like, a mountain of fried chicken to go along with the cheddar an jalapeno waffle with the bourbon bacon syrup.  It was a ton of food but I couldn't stop eating it.  It was one of the best means I've had in a long time.    My wife had the Brisket & Eggs and it was equally delicious.  I only tried a bite as I had a lot of work to do, but I would have no problem ordering that dish next time we go there.    To go along with the fantastic food was the music!  Vex was playing some very appropriate, nice music that stretches well beyond Top 40 standards.  I was impressed by the stuff he was playing and I think the music was perfect for Sunday brunch.    I will recommend this place to anyone that asks...or doesn't ask.  I can't wait to go back!
Love everything about this place!! Staff Friendly. The wife Loves it . Very filling !! Come Hungry

What a meal! Started with a sampling of the black truffle fries, the 'Devils on Horseback' (best dish of the night, chorizo wrapped in a date wrapped in bacon), and a pile of wings that were spectacular.   I had the Wagyu filet for dinner - very good. My friend had that pork chop that was almost the size of my arm and it was delicious as well.  Ended the night with a creme brulee that was perfectly done (warm center).  The ambiance was great, only complaint would be a lacking wine list.

A friend and I popped in to Meat & Potatoes for brunch on Saturday and ended up having one of the best meals / food experiences of my life!  We didn't have reservations, but they were able to comfortably accommodate us at the bar.  We had some of their specialty cocktails, which were all expertly mixed, aesthetically appealing, and delicious.  For brunch, I had the chicken and waffles and my friend had the flatbread salmon, both from the regular menu.  The chicken was quite possibly the best fried chicken I've ever had, and my friend's flatbread lox was so fresh and delicious.  The atmosphere was interesting and trendy without being uncomfortable, and the service was good as well as friendly.    Additionally, the waitstaff and bartenders all seemed to be enjoying their work, which always speaks volumes to me about they way an eating establishment is run.  I highly recommend Meat & Potatoes to anyone looking for a fun dining experience with original food ideas executed perfectly.

Food was delicious! We ordered the short rib flat bread, Wow! The layers of flavor were so well put together. I ordered the duck. Again delicious. The spaetzel  was a little crunchy, but overall well worth it!

The food is excellent and the ambience is unique.  I particularly liked their martini bar.   The only negative was that we waited along time for a table even though we had reservations and the noise level made it difficult for conversation.    I would definitely recommend

This is a nice restaurant that is within walking distance to many attractions downtown.   Pros: The staff is great.  Multiple times, a server would stop and ask how our meal was and if our drinks were ok.    Our meal was served quickly even though the place was packed.  The drinks were of upscale quality.   Cons: The place was at max capacity and the tables are so close you end up hearing the next tables conversation.  They in turn hear yours and can lead to them chiming in on your conversation.   We ordered the 45oz steak for 2 people.  I do not recommend getting this as it is only a novelty item. The steak was 35% fat and was of poor quality.  We would have been better off ordering individual steaks which would have been much better.

I've been meaning to go to Meat & Potatoes for some time now. We finally got there a few weeks ago. My husband's boss from Sweden was in town and we wanted to take her somewhere nicer in town for dinner. Unfortunately when I called to make reservations no one answered. So we just decided to walk-in. I should have called again about reservations though instead of just winging it, because when we got there, the place was packed and the only availability they had for a half-hour was on the patio. We decided that was okay, ordered drinks at the bar and then were seated outside.  I know this is not the fault of the restaurant at all...but it was about 8:30pm on a weeknight, and as soon as we were seated we were greeted outside by obnoxious jack-hammering across the street. We decided this would be pretty annoying throughout our meal, so we asked the waitress if there was any possible way we could get a table inside. It took about another half-hour, but we were seated at a table in the restaurant.   We order the fried brussel sprouts as an appetizer. Unfortunately I did not think they were very good. I also thought it was weird appetizers are served in cardboard food boats you usually see at concession stands. I guess it was supposed to be ironic. So appetizer in general just wasn't too thrilling.  For my entree I had the duck, which was pretty delicious. My husband and his boss were also happy with their entrees despite the hiccups getting seated and the stinky appetizer.   Like I said, I know the jackhammer wasn't the restaurants fault. It just kind of put a bit of a damper on the rest of the experience. Maybe my expectations were also really high from all the buzz I heard about Meat & Potatoes. For the prices though I just didn't think it was 5 stars this time. I'd like to go back and try their brunch though. Perhaps that will make me add a star or two!
The options I had were limited, disappointed. I have celiac Meat & Potatoes, you would thing they would have more options for gluten fee. The meat did taste good

Enjoyed brunch here in January.  We loved the atmosphere except for the cramped tiny tables.  I don't see how a large person would navigate the seating. I had the chicken and waffles.  The chicken was tasty but the leg was still red near the bone.   My husband had the huevos rancheros and he wasn't a fan.  I'd love to try it again for dinner or happy hour mainly due to the atmosphere, location and interesting food options.
I have only been here once. I had the mussels and a craft beer. The mussels were a little salty and fishy, but overall pretty good. The beer was good too.
Referred by a friend. Really unimpressed with food.  Started with warm water and ended with under seasoned pot roast. The waitress kept saying Awesome.  It wasn't!

Stopped here for dinner at 6:00 pm while in town for work on a Monday night without reservations.  Dining couldn't seat us until 7:30 but was able to grab a seat at bar. Good cocktail and beer list. Ordered the Waygu Sirloin and it was cooked to my medium rare request. It was accompanied by some very yummy potatoes. Good overall service at the bar with some wonderful bearded gentlemen adding to their fun atmosphere. Felt a bit like a place you could find in Portland, OR

It was our first time in Pittsburgh, so my girlfriend and I had no clue where to go. After parking in the Theater Garage and being stuck in a downpour with no umbrella, we stumbled into Meat and Potatoes, and so glad that we did.  At 1030pm, there was still a 20 minute wait so we started with a drink at the bar. The whole establishment feels like a bourbon bar/speakeasy, and is unlike any other place we've ever been. While enjoying a drink at the bar, all three bartenders engaged us in conversation and made us feel right at home. We decided to order just a few small plates and eat at the bar.  We started with a short rib flatbread that was very unique and delicious. Next came the Devils on horseback. Being from Baltimore, we are accustomed to oysters, however these were served with dates. They were a little heavy for our taste, but very flavorful. The standout dish was their fried brussel sprouts. They were so crispy and crunchy, but still had their earthy sort of flavor. I would come back just for an order of those. The bartenders were also making gourmet cocktails with ingredients I had never even heard of. The speed well was right in front of us so we got to smell all of the drinks as they were being made.   Overall, a very unique atmosphere,great food, great drinks, and an amazing staff. They made us feel right at home and I would recommend this place to anyone.

I was visiting my sister from out-of-town and she HAD to bring me to this place for our night out together. Overall, we had a great visit but our service for most of the evening severely lacked which is why I am deducting one star!   Our reservation was at 6:45pm and we arrived a little early at 6:30pm, so while we waited for a table, we sat at the bar to order some drinks. We got delivered a menu and patiently waited for the entire 15 minutes to be acknowledged by someone behind the bar. I tried to understand since they were busy. But, there were 4 bartenders behind the bar and 2 out of 4 of them were hand-washing cups. We felt awkward not being acknowledged by anyone, so this started our evening off a little sour.   We did get our table as promised by 6:45pm and waited around for our server to show up and take our orders. Meanwhile all tables around us are being acknowledged and served. Eventually after a few minutes of sitting, our waiter did come over to our table to take our drink and food orders. We started off with some mussels. These mussels were amazing. The only complaint I had was I wanted MORE!!! They were ridiculously flavorful and just downright amazing (I highly recommend the curry mussels). We ordered some pate too, it was pretty good - but I would recommend mussels for sure!!  Next on to our entrees; my sister ordered the duck and I ordered the steak; extremely flavorful, delicious food. On another level - that is for sure! I absolutely couldn't get over the amount of flavors inside of my dish, it was some of the best I've ever tasted. Again, the food was absolutely tremendous. However, it was extremely frustrating to watch out for our waiter who was serving tables around us, but did not come back to ours. He went back to other tables most of the night to refill beverages but for some reason; he didn't even come over to ours. We had to flag him down to get another alcoholic beverage. Overall, I was extremely disappointed in the service and my sister (who visits this place often) stated that the service has NEVER been that way, and usually most of the servers are very proactive. I was pretty disappointed as it did cause a slight damper, but overall the food was pretty damn amazing. I would definitely return but I would hope to have way better service in the restaurant and at the bar.

Portions are huge so bring your appetite. Bone marrow was good but I think Butcher and the Rye's was better. Food is good but everything is really heavy. Not really recommended for anyone that's trying to diet.

I was only there once and it was great. A menu that has lite bites and real apps. ....awesome Had the pork and it was thick and juicy Dessert was a warm banana bread and it was great. Would love to get back there....if you live in Pittsburgh your blessed !

(11/10/2014)  Heard a lot about Meat and Potatoes, was mentioned in Bon Appetit's article about Pittsburgh being the next big food city.  We arrived close to 10pm on a Monday night, place was bustling, very loud (DJ spinning tunes in the corner, luckily in my age group), full of the pretty people here to see and be seen.  A large bar hogs up most of the main room, a circular dining area rings it.  Place is dimly lit, beautiful dark wood and cast iron, marble and mirrors, like a 19th century parlor.    We were seated towards the end of the bar at an unfortunate turn in the dining room.  Overflow from the bar made passage pretty tight.  Dimwit hostess tried to seat another group between us, either she gave up trying to make me move into oncoming traffic or the incoming guests decided (wisely to ask for another table).  The place pretty much filled to the gills, then I realized, duh, Monday night late menu special "Night Cap" (starts at 10pm).   Cocktails, Prohibition-era, were the best of the night (this was stop #6 on a self-guided restaurant crawl of downtown Pittsburgh).  My friend had the 25th Hour (subbed vodka), I had the Southie; both made great use of herb and spice liqueurs for subtle accents.  Since I knew we were headed this way, saved myself for the Bone Marrow.  An enormous tray arrive with 2 large marrow bones split in half and stacked.  Accoutrements were classic and perfectly matched to cut the unctuousness of the marrow (pickled onion, parsley, sea salt, capers).  We devoured the top two, they were phenomenal.  The bottom two were unfortunately cold (as much of a carnivore as I am, cold marrow is totally gross).  Also had the Devils on Horseback, jumbo Medjool dates stuffed with chorizo, wrapped with bacon and broiled.  Very tasty, touch overwhelming on the dates for me (maybe use a smaller date?).  The menu is not, shall we say, "lite", but hey, you didn't expect that from a place called "Meat and Potatoes" did you.  I can see why the place has turned heads.

Amazing quality food, absolutely delicious. I only wish they changed their menu up more often, I feel like I always end up getting the same thing because nothing new pops out at me. That being said, I can't complain about the steak because it's extraordinary.

Really good atmosphere and lively environment!! Plus the food was also very great and portion size was enough for only one person. Specially the ribs were really good and the sidings with the ribs made it more tasteful! The steak was also good and tasty! Would definitely go here again!

One of my favorites downtown.   The cocktails, in whole, are pretty fantastic. Occasionally, you'll wind up with a slightly inconsistent or unorganized bartender but that certainly doesn't speak to their whole staff. Besides waiting a bit to long for a drink from time to time the service has always been on point.  The food is impeccable with large portions.   Price may detract for some, but it's about where you should expect a gastropub in a Downtown area to be.   If you're a foodie it'll fall into your regular rotation. If you're a casual diner, save it for that special night. The service and atmosphere will help set the mood.
The drinks were great. Tartare and steak were off the chain. Velvet cake was delicious. Definitely want to come back. Pittsburgh you rocked all around
Rich, unique dishes and excellent cocktail selection. The service is outstanding!

This place is AMAZING! Whatever you do, get an item of food with bacon. I got the Pub Burger because I'm a sucker for a fried egg and was more taken with that meaty slab of bacon than the egg!   Meat & Potatoes is quite small, so be prepared to sit next to a stranger while stuffing face with meat, meat, and more meat. This is the only reason it got 4 stars instead of 5.

This is one of my favorite brunch places. You need a reservation and it sometimes takes 2 months to get a table so reserve as soon as possible. The Bloody Mary bar is really cool! You can choose from several flavors of vodka then add a skewer full of meats, cheeses, olives, and other toppings. The chicken and waffles are one of my favorites! Don't be afraid to order something outside of your comfort zone here. They prepare everything very well. The best thing on the whole menu might be the truffle fries though!

I know that I'm late to the party on this one, but I've been trying to be pescatarian for the past half year, so it's been a bit tough to come here. That being said, we break "fast" every now and then, and Meat and Potatoes is a great way to get your meat on. The name is actually quite fitting, because if you want veggies at all, this is not where you're going to find that - I think about 15% of their menu might include vegetables.  The pate is phenomenal, as is the bone marrow appetizer. You'll feel full just from eating that, because it is so rich. But totally worth it. I also had duck here and it was great too. Also - try the red velvet dessert. It comes in a jar, which is really fitting because you won't be able to finish it and then you can just take it home in your purse. So, evidently I have broken "fast" a few times. But, why am I writing only now?  Because I discovered Meat and Potatoes brunch - which is on both Saturday AND Sunday. Hear that Pittsburgh? Saturday AND Sunday. Some of you would do well to note that many of us aren't limited to brunch on Sundays!  Anyway, I've been having a fried chicken craving for the past month or so (if you've been a dedicated meat eater for most of your life, and then go pescatarian, it catches up with you sometimes) and someone told me that Meat and Potatoes does down-to-earth goodness fried chicken and waffles. Let me tell you about the last time I had chicken and waffles. It was at midnight at the Waffle Shop in East Liberty, and the fried chicken was so bad, I left it, and the waffles tasted like cardboard. But that's another story... Needless to say, this fried chicken and waffles was PHENOMENAL. The fried chicken is perfectly breaded and cooked (you can tell them if you just want dark or light meat) and the waffle is made out of this wonderful cheese-jalapeno batter that is only the slightest bit spicy. Which comes with syrup cooked with bacon.   Did you just fall over? That must be my puddle of drool you just slipped on. Sorry.

My boyfriend and I spent our anniversary at Meat & Potatoes last night and we definitely made the right choice! We chose to split the 'Meat & Potatoes for Two,' which is a steak lover's dream! 45oz of perfectly cooked steak, truffle fries--to die for!--on the side, and a side of fried brussel sprouts later, we were both stuffed, happy, and had plenty of leftovers! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone, and will be visiting again!
Love love this place every time I go to Pittsburgh this is a must stop! Their brunch is one of the best! The Bloody Mary bar is the best I've ever had!Chicken and waffles are delicious!

The important stuff: the pimento grilled cheese with pepper bacon is AMAZING.  This was a very interesting place. I had heard a lot about this place, all good. Recommendation was to make reservations for dinner. But, we were going in to brunch on Saturday and decided to take a chance. The whole patio was open, but we were asked to wait 15-20 for a table or be sat at the bar. My friend and I picked the bar, and found maybe a dozen other tables empty - weird. But, I am not an expert on the seating process there so who's to say?  Staff was friendly and the bloody mary bar looked off the chains. Good spot overall.

The brunch lives up to the hype. The Charcuterie board includes multiple meats (duck, rabbit, etc). The chicken and waffles are ample and satisfying. The potatoes are very well seasoned. Make a reservation, it fills up fast. And the ambience / music selection is awesome!

The inside is small but very trendy. The atmosphere is upscale and busy. The service was great. you should definitely get a reservation for this place. The bar is open seating but you could wait for a long time before you get a table. The food is excellent. Be prepared to spend $$$. I will definitely be back.

I really want to give this place 5 stars, but I'm having trouble. I'll try to break down my thoughts about this place, but overall, I loved it! It's a unique place and very few restaurants in the city have a similar vibe or menu.  Atmosphere: Awesome! It's right downtown and in the midst of the cultural district happenings. It's also a little dark inside, but very eclectic, with a trendy, gastropub vibe and drawings of cows (which I enjoy).  Food: Here is where I love and also a little torn. I loved what I had, but I felt like there was a bit of an identity crisis involved. The food was eclectic, but also kind of random. They are called "meat and potatoes" but didn't really have the menu that reflected that name. Maybe that's meant to be the irony, for which case, they did fine. For example, if you wanted just a steak (I'm not a steak person, btw), then you'd have to order the steak offering that is for 2 people. You'd think that a simple option, like steak, is what this place would own. Otherwise, the mussels for an appetizer were great and I also loved my entree (but to be honest, I don't remember what I got now).  Service: Pretty decent, although our server seemed to be in a bad mood and the others around us seemed to have a server that enjoyed what they were doing. This may have improved the experience quite a bit.

This was our first time traveling to Pittsburgh and we decided on this restaurant as our first stop. We had made reservations, so we had no problem getting seated right away. The place has a very cool urban/gastropub vibe with lots of interesting décor. For appetizers, we split the Devils on Horseback  (trust me. Order them.), fried brussel sprouts and the Poutine - they were all excellent. For dinner we had the pot roast, Pappardelle and the Hanger Steak. There was more than enough food to fill you up. They also have a great selection of mixed drinks. The only real complaint was the service. Our waitress was waiting on our table inside, as well as some tables outside, so she was a little elusive. And we asked a busboy at one point to check on our drinks, but he didn't seem too interested.  Other than that, a very good meal.

There is a lot of dimensions to this restaurant.  One being, it attracts a lot of foodies because of the new wave of food options and fanciness.  I have been here several times.  For brunch, for dinner, to sit at the bar.  Let's start with brunch...4.3 stars.  Their brunch menu is excellent if you are a foodie.  They have a lot of tasty and creative items.  Yes, they are a little fancier then my taste but they taste good.  Their dinner menu is just ok.  maybe 3.1 stars.  We went here once after a pirates game and they placed us in what could be compared as a home office.  The room felt so small.  I felt clausterfobic the entire time.   The food was just ok too.  Go somewhere else for dinner!!!

One of my favorite restaurants I've ever been to. I'm from out of town, but come to Pittsburgh every year with my partner just to enjoy a night of wonderful drinks and food from Meat & Potatoes. Their staff are always warm and inviting, and the food is brought promptly. The cozy feel of the area around the bar and the bar itself make for a very personal experience.

Now open for lunch-lunch, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday!  I just had the best sloppy joe (boar meat) I have ever tasted.  No seriously, it was perfectly cooked and seasoned into a consistency that had the expected sloppy Joe sloppiness but still inspired the high end eats of this gastro-pub.  Their fries, as always, are absolute heaven.  And the service (this time we sat at the bar) was friendly, speedy, and knowledgeable.  Without a doubt an excellent experience on the service and actual food end.  Pricing was extremely good for what we ate and their welcoming atmosphere and diverse dishes make it so you want to return and try something different next time around!

Fun atmosphere and a great beer list. There was a wait when we arrived and we sat at the bar and ordered a Bloody Mary and a snack. The food came before the drinks, no big deal. The Bloodies were watered down Tomatoe Juice $9 each = big deal. We were never offered a table even though we put our name in. Disapointing first visit.

You did it again Jason! Just visited my fav spot in Pittsburgh this week...again. Love the handcrafted drinks at this place! Jason made me a Daughter Maitland, an original created by this interesting fella! When you're there ask for him & just try it..you will not be disappointed! Cecil is another mixologist that is super nice & enjoys engaging in interesting conversation! Just a great experience overall! Merry Christmas & I'll see you in Jan.!

Always good food and libations. Was made to wait for 10 minutes on a reservation for 6:30. Wait staff less attentive than I would like. The food and drink bring me back, the seating and service are drawbacks.

I'll start off with the bad. Had to take away 1 star due to the host. She was not friendly. I came in with a friend with no reservation because there were no more available when I tried to make one online. The host took my name down and said she'd call me if there were any cancellations. So basically telling me I wasn't getting a table if no one cancelled. But she quoted another party of two that came in after me 20mins. Unacceptable. Not sure what her deal was. I asked to speak with a manager and told him the situation. He sat us right away. I wish I could remember our servers name because he went above and beyond to take care of us. I had the croque madame. I've had better but it was good. The French toast was to die for. I will fly back just for that French toast and I live in California. Overall I had an amazing experience. Great cocktails great food. I'll be back next time I'm in town.

Spontaneous dinner for a party of 4! Did not make reservations, but were seated in about 10minutes at this small gastro pub which seemed to be pretty lively on a Thursday. Everyone was in a suit and tie, but probably coming after a long day of work. I was dressed very casual.  Our waiter...Alex? He was alright, his bussers were around more than him. My two friends wanted to drink wine, but me and my other friend was fine on just water. He checked both of my friends ID who were drinking than asked to check ours. I told him we wasn't drinking but he insisted he checked out IDs because it's a law blah blah. Yea I get it, but he checked my friends and she was already over the age of 25? He didn't get it until after he checked the water drinkers ID. Anyways on to the food!   Fried Brussel sprouts! Careful when you order, it was overly drenched and seasoned. Ask for another bottle of water, because you'll need it with every cringing bite. If you do order it, maybe ask for less seasoning or salt.  Fried Tots! Pretty much fries with seasoning which were good, but guess what?! It was overly seasoned and salty as well. I ordered these thinking it was tater tots. Don't make the same mistake as me haha  The Artesian cheese board! It was good! I didn't like the blue cheese, but everything else was good. I enjoyed the dates, and strawberry purée jam?   The Caesar salad was different as it had an egg, chicharonnes, and PIG EAR! I had them out the chicha, and pig ear on the side. The Caesar salad was a little bland without it, but the pig ear was different. I think I liked it haha   BONE MARROW!! Oh wow, I was expecting just one piece because in LA, you only get one, but guess what! THREE CAME OUT!! I was so shocked at such a cheap price which I think was $14? It came with capers, salt, onions, and little greens to compliment with the grilled toast. Ugh it was delicious. I couldn't finish it as I was only eating this by myself. They Togod it perfectly with the foil.  The steamed mussels with the tomato base was alright. Barely scratched the surface on that meal. It's still sitting in the fridge as you read this lol.  The Wagyu $31 was great and mouth watering compared to the MEAT FOR TWO deal. The meat for two deal consisted of a 32oz ribeye steak, frites, and a bone marrow for $72. It came out on a beastly cutting board. It looked amazing, but it wasn't. The steak was so freaking fatty. I literally was having surgery and cutting all the fat off. I never worked so hard in my life to eat a steak. There was fat EVERYWHERE! (Refer to pictures) don't get me started on the steak knife... It was comparable to a butter knife. I should of gotten two orders of the WAGYU as it was so much better. I ended up taking 3/4 of the steak home, and finishing the surgery procedure at home.   Overall, meat and potatoes were alright. Would I come back? Just maybe.

Next time I take a trip to Pittsburgh, I'm definitely going to also at that point take a trip to YUMTOWN.  I mean Meat & Potatoes.  I like that an ampersand is in the name of the restaurant.  (I just wanted to use that word.)  Delicious!!!!  Suuuuuuper classy fancy schmancy but dressing up is FUN!  It's in kind of a weird location, I was like, am I going into an office?  But it shares space with another establishment (I want to say...bowling alley?) and they share bathrooms too which are clean, by the by, and probably bigger than they would be if they DIDn't share the bathroom so...that worked out.    Very nice hostess, they checked my coat for me.  Not that that's like something that would separate them from the rest but, just so you know they do that.    LET'S talk about the food!  So yummy!  We were there with lots of people so we shared a bunch of stuff and we had two kinds of mussels--one curry and one regular garlic butter white wine and BOTH were wonderful.  There wasn't a yucky mussel or a gritty one in the bunch, which can totally ruin your minute or more if you aren't laid back.  The curry one was so different but soooo so so good.  Then I had the pork belly tacos and...like, seriously, they have come up in my dreams.  IN MY dreams.  I remember biting into the first one and my pupils probably dilated instantly.  I'm saying that my neurotransmitters immediately fired.  I'm saying they tasted good.  They were served with fresh lime slices and there was a teensy bit too much cilantro draped over it but I picked it off and that was easy to do so...thanks.  You obviously know that people have cilantro things and were thoughtful.    Ned insisted on ordering the meat & potatoes for 2 dish and eating it by himself.  It was...impressive and also frightening.  It was also BEAUtiful!  Huge gigantic dinosaur sized (not really) bone with marrow just glistening there in the candlelight.  I really don't like bone marrow.  Ugh.  The steak was juicy and the potato wedges were huge and the whole thing was slathered with mushrooms and onions and served on a huge cutting board.  It's the kind of steak that makes a man feel like a man.  I think.    Man, now I want those pork belly tacos again.  OK, drinks!  They make a good martini, they have a decent beer list and a good wine list too.    Back to food.  Desserts!  AHHH I'm so glad I had a little room left because jesus CHRIST the desserts were all so good and so rustic looking.  Almost all of them except the tiramisu, I think, were served in mason jars and I LOVE mason jars.  A lot.  I realize that's not necessarily a plus for the masses but they were ALSO fantastically delicious!!!  Ned had the butterscotch....something like pudding or creme brulee with no brulee.  I don't know, all I know is that it was better than mine and I hate when that happens.    Go here!  It's great!  Not too badly priced either.  Definitely going back when I blow through the Pitts.  The burgh.  The Pittsburgh.

ARTSY FOOD, SURROUNDINGS, AND MOOD [Warning: visitor from Florida for short vacation] Its location among all the theaters definitely brings in the goers although the clientele appears to be the under-40yo crowd (fine by me). Sunday around 4pm still resulted in a 30 minute wait.   MODERN RUSTIC VIBE With canning jars at the entrance, the flickering of 'chandeliers', as well as dark furnishings--Meat & Potatoes delivers a poshy yet rustic vibe that still fits well with this area of the 'Burgh. The outside seating is also a great place to people watch yet still tucked under the building's roof.  GET READY FOR SOME FOOD CREATIVITY The appetizers already set the mood for the ride ahead. The Strip Tartare arrived with a smoked Egg--gooey, runny Yolk--the Tartare being soft and well-seasoned against the milder crunchy Bread. Their Brisket Mac & Cheese was an explosion of comfort food but kicked up with hints of Horseradish and Potato Chips. I was also surprised at their Ceasar Salad--loaded with Cheese but enhanced with a sunny Egg on top. And yes... besides combining flavors I often don't see elsewhere (yet make sense) the food tasted great!

Incredibly happening place with a great atmosphere and even better food.  We began our evening at the bar and received incredible service despite how busy it was.  The beer selection was suitable and their take on an Old Fashion with a hint of spice made itself the drink of the night.     We began with a few snacks including the devils on horseback and the wings.  My only qualm was that there were only 3 of the devils on horseback for $7.  Hard to share when you have more than 3 people.  Considering we drank most of our appetizers at the bar, we opted on just ordering entrees at that point.  All were delicious.  My red snapper was outstanding with accoutrements that possibly outshined the fish.  Other entrees such as the Hudson Valley Duck Breast was so reasonable in price considering it was an entire breast with sauerkraut pierogies for only $19.  Our dining partners raved about the hanger steak and the pasta.    The menu is so well versed, there is undoubtedly something for everyone.  The proteins were cooked perfectly but what really impressed me was the originality of the sides that accompanied the proteins.  It's funny, but the name is deceiving...they are by far more than just meat and potatoes.

So good!  I had one of the brunch specials - the omelet.  They were able to leave off the meat (I'm a vegetarian) with no problem.  It was delicious!  Definitely get the grilled bread - it was amazing!  Comes with fresh jam & goat butter.   Perfect post-yoga brunch - only two "problems" : a little pricey (although great for an occasional treat) & we had to make reservations 5 weeks in advance!

I have been here three times for dinner and once for brunch. Every time I have gone has been a beyond awesome meal. I just love this place. I have had something different every time. From the soft shell blue crap sandwich to the smoked pork chop everything has always been amazing. The service has always been spot on. The interior is a modern American with a steak house feel. The drinks are well crafted and never disappointed me or who ever I have fine with. The desserts are always good. Some better then others but always good. Just keep in mind to always call and make a reservation before trying to get a table. It's always booked the day of I find. I learned that the hard way one time. Also the lunch and dinner menu do not have the same items on them so always double check that before picking a time. The only issue I have had with this place was when I walked in and they said they could seat us in an hour. An hour later we come back and that changed to 3 hours. At that point I would rather of been told that they never could of sat us. So I repeat. Always call ahead!

At long last, after years of hearing about this place, I had the chance to eat a meal at Meat & Potatoes. And it didn't disappoint!  The atmosphere in here is really quite interesting - while the place definitely has the look of a modern and comfortable dining area there's lots of little inclusions in decor that make you think about shopping for fresh meat from your local butcher shop. It's kind of hard to describe and has to be seen to be understood, but rest assured, the place looks wonderful and inviting.  But let's be honest, the food is what really matters here! Meat & Potatoes is well-known for serving delicious food. And, well, they do! If you want a great appetizer, go for their grilled bread, which tastes like homemade toasty goodness, especially once you add on the fresh butter and jam that comes with it. As for the main courses, my friend had their special fish tacos (made with tilapia) and I went for a good ol' lamb burger. And yes, both were quite excellent! Something about the ingredients used in them gave what could potentially be considered standard menu fare a unique flavor. My lamb burger for instance had harrisa aioli, arugula and havarti, among other things, rather than the usual onions, American cheese slice, etc. - and the result was delicious perfection. Oh, and the burger? Cooked medium, exactly how I asked! So many places overcook my orders that having a tender, juicy, perfectly cooked burger in front of me was more or less a little piece of Heaven for me.  Not only is the food excellent here, but the service is wonderful! The waiters and waitresses are really attentive here. Have empty plates in front of you? Someone will soon clear them away. Do you have a show to go to that night? They'll make a note of that and get your order out ASAP. I really got the impression that they cared about our dining experience and it elevates Meat & Potatoes in my eyes.  So if you have such wonderful things to say, why only give this place 4 stars, I hear you asking? Well...because this place is LOUD. Like, even on a slow Wednesday night, between the loud music and the people talking here, the noises levels here got quite high. I would NEVER want to be here on a Friday or over the weekend, honestly.  Still, I'd definitely come back - the food and service really are both quite excellent. And given their prices (not super high but not cheap either) I think in my book this is a great location to keep in mind for special nights out with friends or dates. And who knows? Maybe I'll eventually find the energy to brave the noise and crowds and try their brunch - which I hear is also fabulous!

This is a MUST if you are in Pittsburgh! Great ambience for cocktails, excellent choice for dinner. Extensive menu, chose the "meat and potatoes" for two (34 oz steak with crispy black truffle potatoes and shitake mushrooms). Meat was cooked to perfection, waitress gave us excellent recommendations on cocktails and wine list selection. It was like walking into a restaurant in NYC without the crowds.   We went on a week night without reservations, but i would call ahead if going during weekend.

Meat, meat, meat, meat.  Go here if you like meat.  I got the pot roast.  it was super tasty and tender.  I loved the sides that came with it.  My friends got the duck and one of the steaks.  They both raved about them both.  We even tried the bone marrow appetizer.  It was the first time I had ever tried it and I did like it.  It's definitely a little on the pricey side if you go here, but it's worth it to treat yourself to some meat if you hankering for it.

Wow! This place was a real treat! We went for Sunday brunch this past weekend while we were in town, and I was so impressed by this cozy spot!  First, the setting was comfy, cozy, and there was a DJ! Second (and quite possibly most importantly), the Bloody Mary bar. Now this was something unlike anything I've ever seen before. I love how you could choose from any of the infused vodkas, and make it your own! Plus, the bacon was perfection. Third, get the brisket hash. You will not be disappointed! The egg and hollandaise created a delicious sauce, which surrounded the potatoes and brisket in harmony with the spices. I really loved my meal and I wish there was a location in Indianapolis!

Great atmosphere. Hardy menu. Excellent presentation. Delicious food and beverages. I recommend the Devils on Horseback as a starter and the Meat and Potatoes For Two.   Parking was conveniently available only a block away as well.

We got the (I think?) ribeye for two. It's the biggest steak I've ever seen in my entire life. It tasted great. Service was good, atmosphere too. I'd definitely recommend it. Make a reservation unless, like us, you arrive late on a Sunday night.

This restaurant is very cool.  very nice atmosphere and the food was great.  i had short ribs..something i don't eat often and it tasted great!  appetizer...we had wings with sauce on side because the sauce was very hot!  tuna dish for appetizer also very good!!  my boyfriend loved his steak...the flavoring was fantastic!!!  the drinks were made very well..i think a place like this would do well in ny!

This place was in a weird spot. We Ubered over and missed it the first time. But anyways we made a reservation and we're seating a bit after arriving.   It was just two of us and let me tell you if you don't like being in close spaces or you'd prefer to feel like you actually have privacy at you table for two this is not the spot for you. We were packed into these tiny tables with half both seating and half char seating on a curve needless to say I could have grabbed a French friend off my neighboring tables plate without much effort.   But as for the food it was good! We had fried pigs ears which were spicy sweet and tasty. Along with fried pickles which were good but not great. I ordered the salmon. Which I actually loved. It's had a fried egg, black rice, kimchi, and hot sauce. I'd definitely order it again. My fiancé got a pasta dish which he loved. And we finished with the baked French toast which was a bit disappointing but it sounded so good when described to us.   All in all not a bad experience by any means I would have just loved a bit more room and better fried pickles!
Yes! Yes! and Yes!  One of the best steaks I've ever had.  Great selection of drinks and excellent environment.  Loved it!

After hearing and reading raving reviews about Meat & Potatoes, I dined there expecting the best of the best.. of the best in Pittsburgh. Even though it was very tasty, it did not meet the 5-star review that I was expecting. However, I had dinner there for a work function, so I was in the back room with a round table and was away from all of the activity. For me, this took a lot away from my entire experience because I couldn't experience the atmosphere in its entirety.   Let's start with the appetizers. I tried both the fried brussels and Artisinal Cheese Board. The Artisinal Cheese Board was definitely my favorite. The display was so cool, and it was definitely great for sharing. Someone in my party loved the Bone Marrow, which I wasn't feeling brave enough to try (maybe next time?). The Waldorf salad was pretty tasty. A little bit on the bland side, and I was expecting a better presentation, but overall, I would order the salad again.   For the main course, I ordered the Wagyu Flat Iron. I order my meat medium well, and it was a little pinker than I had hoped, but it was still pretty good. And, the serving was huge! I was definitely not expecting as big of a steak...enormous actually.  Dessert...delicious. It seemed like they had seasonal offerings, and I had the gingerbread cake, which was my favorite part of the meal. Again, huge piece of cake.  Oh, and cocktails...my party seemed to enjoy what they had. The bar was hopping.  I've tried to make reservations for this place a few times and it's been booked. Book in advance, and on a Friday or Saturday night, don't expect to walk in and get a table without a reservation, especially because this place is located right in the heart of the Theater District. It's also loud, so don't expect to come here and have a peaceful, quiet dinner...I prefer atmospheres like this one though.  Overall, I would recommend Meat & Potatoes, especially because of its location. It is not your traditional place by any means.  The menu is not ginormous, but it has your fair share of unique offerings. For what they offer, the prices are what you would expect and not outrageous either. For Pittsburgh, it is definitely a place that really stands out and has a more creative, chic take on things.

Started off with a Sazerac at the bar.  When a cocktail is made with passion (and it's good), waiting for a table is not an issue.  Pasta, short ribs and bone marrow to name a few highlights.  I will frequent M&P, often :)

I've eaten here before and enjoyed it, but this week I had the rudest service I have had in a long time. And that was at the front desk!! We arrived early and the hostess said we should come back at the right time. I asked if we could get a table (seeing it was half full) she said she would maybe get us in after 20 minutes. We went to the bar to wait and then magically there was the worst table in the restaurant (right by the door) and it was open just for us... Imagine that.  The attitude was so bad, we left and had a great nice quiet dinner at Ruth's Chris with great service.   So much for meat and potatoes. Never again.
Good cocktails, and good snacks. Not a huge fan of their steak or their mussels.

I came here for one thing, and one thing only. The Bone Marrow Appetizer was what I was after. I've never had it before and I was told that if you're going to try it, make sure you try it at a place that does it good and does it right.  And that place would be right here, at Meat and Potatoes. It was phenomenal. Delicious and cooked to perfection. Yeah, $18 is a lot for this appetizer, but how often would you have this? And, would you want to try and make it a home? No. (what does that saw look like?)  So, I came here for one dish and it was perfect!  I did look around at other meals being served and they all looked good.  The only negative is that it's very noisy. If you are coming here for a nice, quiet dinner for two, forget about it. The tables are very close together and there is no privacy. This is how I met the two ladies sitting next to me while I dined. I could hear everything they said and ended up sharing my Bone Marrow meal with them. Yes, it's dark and noisy, but the food made it all worth while.

Chef/owner Richard DeShantz has received a lot of accolades for this restaurant and his other nearby dining options, Butcher in the Rye, Tako, and Pork and Beans.  His menus are exciting and his food preparation is outstanding.  I can't say enough about their strong service model and romantic/laid back atmosphere.  You want to linger over your craft cocktail or seasonal draft beer just a little longer when you're dining here because it's so relaxing.  The food is exceptional.  I really wanted to try so many of the appetizers but we were running late for a show at the nearby Benedum and didn't want to feel too rushed.  Straight into the entrées then!    I had the Pappardelle pasta dish with Bolognese sauce, pancetta, pork shoulder, and garlic bread.  The noodles were delicate and perfectly cooked to just a smidge past al dente.  The flavor was really spectacular; so good that I overlooked the fact that my dish simply wasn't very warm when it arrived.  The bits of pancetta created a really delicious bite; one that I would go back for again and again.   My partner tried the Wagyu Flat Iron steak for $38 that came with charred fingerling potatoes & onions, corn pudding, avocado, and pickled peppers.  The steak was perfectly cooked and not an overwhelming cut to eat.  The sides were very nice flavor blends to accompany the steak.  The Negroni cocktail we ordered was a little too Campari forward and when we asked our waitress about it, she said that was how it normally looked color-wise so we just added a sidecar of gin to sort that out nicely.  It was such a delicious and enjoyable dinner, we are still talking about it today.  It's such a great little space in the Cultural District.  Definitely make a reservation unless you don't mind parking yourself at their bar.

Overall, this place rocks! This was our first time. We sat outside on the patio on a beautiful night in Pittsburgh. We could here some of the Buccos game while we were there which was awesome! I had the Three Little Pigs and my girlfriend got the Pork Mac N Cheese and the Fried Pickles. Everything was delicious, especially the sandwich with the dippy egg on top!   The only thing I will say is that I wish the hostesses were more accommodating because I originally called to make a reservation and the only time they said they could reserve was 10:15 p.m. So I didn't make it. She did tell me they accept walk ins and I figured we could just go and check it out and when we got there they had a reservation at 8:30 available, so we had to wait an hour to sit down which wasn't bad on a beautiful night. I just wish they would have told us that they offer a full food menu at the bar because it was basically empty when we got there, then we wouldn't have had to wait an hour without a reservation. My advice is call for a reservation and if it's not accommodating to your plans, you can just walk in and make a reservation which seemed to get us in there quicker than calling ahead.   But overall everything was awesome! I definitely want to go back and try some other menu items!
SO DELICIOUS! We had the ribeye for two with the augratin potatoes and mushrooms with the cheese plate everything was amazing I would definitely come back highly recommend!

Ok...3.5 stars, as I liked the tee shirts the staff was wearing, and comparing this place to The Butcher and the Rye (where we are last nite), the relief from all the salty food at the BatR is worth a half star :-)   Skip the Poutine unless you are a fries fan, but personally, In&Outs Animal  Style fries are 10x better.  If you must order their Poutine, ask for ketchup!  Fired Pickles were ok - the dip was especially good.  The fried batter wasn't special, but it wasn't bad.  Devils on Horseback were original and quite good!  Mac and cheese - ehh.  Again, salty, but the hint of spiciness was nice.  Caesar - I liked the ingredients, but the dressing was not subtle, just salty and ok.  It has potential to be a very good Caesar, but the dressing fails it.  At both the BatRye and M&P, throw out the salt shaker in the kitchen!  It is no excuse to flavor food with extra salt.

My boyfriend and I went for dinner last night on New Year's Eve and had less-than-stellar service.  Our appetizer took an hour to be delivered to our table, when the table next to us ordered the same thing and it was delivered in 10 mins.  I was really disappointed in my experience last night and will think twice about coming back.

I love the intimate setting of Meat & Potatoes. It's perfect for a date night. I visited with my husband before a show at the Benedum, which was perfect since it's so close!   LOVE the pig ears. This is the only place I've had decent pig ears above the mason-dixon.   I ended up getting a pasta dish since I was craving some comfort food that night so I can't speak to their specialties. But the papardelle was fantastic and I would order it again if we return.   They had some really intriguing menu items that I look forward to trying next time like buttermilk fried chicken livers and bone marrow. Definitely a menu that appeals to a foodie but can also please anyone since they've got burgers, sandwiches and protein entrees like salmon and chicken.

Just made my second trip to Meat & Potatoes for brunch and they're definitely worth the wait for a good brunch. Their chicken and waffles doesn't sound that different than something you could get almost anywhere, but the chicken is really seasoned well and there is some jalapeño in the waffles. And the French toast is also very good. Love the almond brittle they give with it as it really gives the texture of the French toast a little something different.  The only reason I don't give them a five in this review is because the service was lacking a little.

Came out to Pittsburgh for work and went to Meat and Potatoes.. this was a wonderful dining experience all around. Very cute unique setting, amazing food and great service. We were with a large group of people so tasted at least half of the menu.. for appetizers got their Brussels sprouts, amazing mac and cheese, fried pickles (tastes better than it sounds) and the bacon wrapped dates (must have!) also had a delicious cocktail (forget the name but friends had other ones and all of them were great)..for entrees we got a duck and flat iron steak and shared with a friend. Both entrees were fantastic, the duck was super juicy and tender and served with butternut squash pure.. the flat iron steak was served with mushrooms and potatoes. This is a great place to eat if you are ever in Pittsburgh!

Love this place! Drinks are unique and strong, and the food is amazing. Go with more adventurous eaters so that they are game for the marrow. Don't miss it. My only gripe is that it's a bit dark...like people using their cell phones to read the menu dark but I guess it's a plus if your blind date turns out to be less than thrilling.

I visited Meat & Potatoes while on a day trip through Pittsburgh. Sadly, they were totally booked for brunch, but we made it to an early Sunday dinner.  The food was amazing. I actually preferred the starters over our main (burger). Highlights: Fried Pickles, Gin cocktail (name is escaping me), Poutine  Atmosphere was cozy and cool. The tables are a bit small and cramped, but luckily the restaurant wasn't too crowded. A great spot that I will definitely be back to if I make through Pittsburgh again any time soon!

Came here on two separate occasions - once for dinner and once for drinks and appetizers. This place always seems to be packed no matter what day of the week, so be sure to make a reservation!  I highly recommend the mussels of the day! The mussels were really clean and fresh, and well-prepared; didn't have a bitterness that bad mussels can have, like at the all-you-can-eat chinese buffets (bleh!).  The poutine appetizer was a real disappointment. After having poutine for the first time earlier this year in Toronto, Canada, I was looking forward to see and try Meat & Potatoes' take on the dish. What ended up coming to the table looked more like wanna-be gourmet cheesy fries than actual poutine.   Definitely would come back for the mussels, skipping the appetizers.

Recently had the pleasure of experiencing Meat & Potato. Very unique old style feel and design of the restraunt facility. Although you would think this would make a romantic setting you would be mostly right. The tables are crowded close together (if you like listening into other patrons conversations this is the perfect place for you) and are extremely small. Another problem with this seating configuration (includes a large bar in the center of the restraunt ) is the noise level makes it difficult to hear your dinner companions. We ate on a Saturday night and the place was extremely crowded and noisy. Service was below par-- I suspect due to the fact that our waiter had difficulty accessing our table due to the crowded conditions. We had shared the mussel appetizer and the meat and potato "special" ( 36 oz ribeye with steak fries). The quality of the food could be reasonably characterized as above average but no where near outstanding. Meat & Potato had a wide variety of beer, wine and alcohol selections. We did not patronize the bar but note that it was large and seemed like a fun place to hang out (no need to be concerned with noise at the bar).

Expect slow service as it gets busy during primetime hours. My wife and I tried dining here last year and ended up leaving halfway through. We chalked it up to them being new and tried them once more.   We ordered a selection of appetizers and asked the waitress to course them out. The food was okay but the dining experience was hampered by the slow service. All in all it took almost FOUR HOURS to get all our food. Lest you think we ordered everything on the menu, we ordered the following:  Mussels, Fried pickles, Poutine, Grilled Bread, Devils on Horseback, and the Bone marrow.  The food has definitely improved since our first dining experience. The mussels were very tasty, and I definitely enjoyed the poutine. The grilled bread came with a very good strawberry rubharb jam. A word of warning about the bone marrow, it is well executed but the individual bones have little in each (compared to most places that serve bone marrow).  All in all, a good dining experience if you're looking to spend the evening. If you've got a show to catch you might want to head elsewhere.

First let me begin by saying that this place is not worth the hype.  I came for a holiday dinner with a group of 7. It was evident that the server failed to put my order in as it came out 10 minutes later than everyone else. The noodles in my dish were not fully cooked, and the pasta dish was nothing to even rant about. If the courses are on the more expensive end, I would expect the quality of service and food to match the price tag. Unfortunately, this place does not.  If you are looking for a dinner spot downtown, there are plenty other options with much better food and less expensive.

This is my second stop on my Pittsburg trip. I woke up late for the first time in 2 years and decide to come to market square for lunch... Well it's brunch sink had to confirm. This place is really nice and excellent customer service. Their mimosa and mango Bellini are great. But the stand out hit was their brisket hash, wow it melts in your mouth. I suggest you order some of their toasted bread (not free) to go along. Overall a great place and really good food. So why not 5 stars?...  1. Grilled bread was super burnt on edgeds- attention to detail is important  2. Brisket prices where all fat and no meat which was a disappointment.   Besides this my bartender Will was amazing!

Beautiful room and bar. Food was  just ok (from what I tried).  I shared a few things and nothing really stood out. Great bar experience though. The staff was incredibly kind and we had a lovely evening hanging before a show. I will go back again when in the area, try some other items. Lovely concept though.

Great atmosphere, top notch service and some of the best cocktails I've had in years. Plus the food was incredible. Poutine was my personal favorite of the night, but the duck and pappardelle was phenomenal. Make sure you don't sit in the back room though, it has a very strange cold atmosphere.

Went here for a late dinner, since it was way past the dinner hour, we walked in, waited 1/2 hour for a table. The bone marrow is a must! Pig ear salad had fried pork skin!!! Would have given 5 stars but cannot for 2 reasons, portions are large, tables are not, and I understand the lighting sets the ambiance, but the menu is very hard to read, othe than that, Meat and Potatoes lived up to all it's hype.

Came here for Saturday brunch. BEST chicken and waffles I've had in my life, hands down. Such a huge serving and so tasty. Jalapeño Cheddar waffles were a brilliant use. And the bacon maple syrup? Mmmmm!  Our waitress (I think her name was Sarah) was great and helped put together an order of chicken of waffles even though they were sold out and couldn't provide the usual combo of 2 pieces dark meat and 2 pieces white meat. It's a very generous portion of chicken.  I also LOVED the Bloody Mary bar. It really is a mini buffet. It was my first ever DIY Bloody Mary. I tried the red hot chili pepper infused vodka and added some spices, sauces and pickled things and it was great. I was worried never having had many bloody Mary's in the past would lead me to mix a bad one, but it was delicious!  If I ever make it back to Pittsburgh I'm looking forward to coming back to meat & potatoes and trying the bone marrow appetizer.
What a great place. Amazing food, awesome bartenders. I've been now for dinner too many times to count, and have enjoyed lunches and brunches as well. Have never been disappointed!

I went to Meat & Potatoes with a few friends this evening, just a few days after their opening. Here's what we ate, what we saw, and what I liked and didn't love about it:  The Drinks:  * I had the Dark & Smokey. Obviously, it didn't have quite the same taste as a classic Dark & Stormy, but it was still interesting. I probably wouldn't get it again though. * Someone else had the Old Canadian, and apparently it was amazing. * The only con I had in this category was that we were there and ordered our drinks during what I thought was happy hour (5:45), but when we got our bill, they were full-priced.  The Food:  * Curry Mussels & Frites - great. A bit spicier than those I love over at Point Brugge, but still a nice dish. The frites were good - crispy where they should have been crispy, but I wouldn't really call them frites. They're just good fries. Anyone who knows me knows that my favorite thing to eat in the entire world is fries, so I'm gonna stick to my guns on this one. Verdict: Point Brugge has the best frites in Western PA. Also, why the heck doesn't Park Bruges offer the same EXACT frites as Point Brugge? It was disappointing to come across that a few weeks back. * Poutine - good. I was hoping to learn that the curds were from the local Arsenal Cheese, but I didn't remember to ask.  * Cheese Board - great selections, every one of them. The preserves were tasty too, and the portion size is spot on. * Mac and Cheese - Lobster. Chunks. Creamy. Just right, and maybe my favorite thing we had the whole evening. * The PIG Dip - basically like a french dip, but with pork shoulder. This was my main, and it was outstanding. The bread remained crusty even after a dip or two in the au jus. It came with the frites and a tasty, crisp apple slaw.  The Interior & Branding: I'm a huge fan of pub and brasserie style interiors, so I have to say, I was almost as excited to go here for the decor as I was for the food. The style is somewhat classic and polished, but still cozy.  * Beautiful, well-equipped bar in the center of the restaurant, with a super thick, classic white marble counter and pendant-style bulbs hanging from overhead. * GREAT branding. Nice work on the letterpress, die-cut business cards and the website. FYI - the hours are at the bottom of the About page.
