We arranged reservations almost 2 weeks in advance and when we arrived the waiting area was packed with other reservation holders so reservations are a must.  I did see a table or two that was not occupied during our early dinner but I chuck that up to the hours we were dining, 5pm on a Saturday.  Well it worked out perfect since we were coming from an afternoon show.  I studied the menu for two weeks looking it over and over and wondering what I would order.  I had thought of the fried pickles as these are one of my favorites, or the pork belly taco's because come on pork belly in a taco!  Yum, but no.  My recent love affair with duck had me swooning for it...  I also saw so many wonderful pictures of the bone marrow I had to give that a shot too.  I can say confidently that I picked wisely.  This was one of the best meals I have had in a long time.  As I looked to my H who I convinced to order the Wagyu, I stated, "Welcome to my new favorite restaurant".  He absolutely loved the wagya, he said I wish there was just one more piece of it.  I think he could have had two... Lucky for me my plate filled me and though I could have eaten more I didn't have to, the portion was perfect.  I could've done without the pierogies.   I love pierogies but this one wasn't my thing.  All is fine I gladly gave them to my H to eat and he happily did so.  The atmosphere here seems casual with an upscale feel at the same time and the seats were like sitting on your overstuffed couch.  I melted in.  I will be back M&P you really got all your ducks in a row.
I love the ambience of this restaurant. Great selection of alcohol and great bartenders. Food is excellent, always love going here.
Excellent as always! I took out of town guests here and we ordered the namesake dish, "the meat and potatoes" and we weren't disappointed. The drinks were made well and the service was attentive.

We went here for my fiance's birthday. I called ahead and she asked me if we were there for any special occasion. I told her yes, for a birthday, and asked if they do anything special. The girl on the phone laughed and said no, "you have to pay for dessert". I wasn't looking for free food, but was hoping for a special table, candle, etc. Otherwise, why did she bother to ask?  We got there and the waitress offered me a drink (my fiance was parking the car). She read me the draft beers and offered to come back to take a drink order. We were seated at a small, wobbly table for 2. It was so small, that it couldn't fit our entire order on it, and the waitress told us she had to "map out" how to deliver our food, so that it could all fit on the table.   Once my fiance was seated, we ordered the curry mussels. They were fantastic. I could almost drink the broth alone without the mussels.They were seasoned with red curry, what tasted like cilantro, and had a little bite to the aftertaste. We then ordered fried pickles (amazing breading, not too thick, and didn't fall off), devils on horseback (dates stuffed with sausage wrapped in bacon with a sweet red pepper sauce. Definitely more sweet than we imagined), and poutine (cheese curd was good on them).   My fiance decided on the lamb burger. It was delicious and juicy. It had a good lamb flavor and the bread was fresh and didn't tear. There was some sort of sauce on the burger, which was had good depth of flavor. It came with fries; the fries were fries. Nothing out of this world, but tasty.  I decided on the mushroom risotto. It was perfect. Flavors were delicious and the texture was creamy. It was a small plate and I was full, but not so full that I couldn't move, which usually happens when I eat here. It was a good portion size.  We weren't impressed with the desserts. We were looking for something light, and all they had was chocolate. The "lightest" thing they had, was some type of orange creamcicle dessert, and neither of us are fans. They change the desserts daily, so I was unable to order what I had last time I was there, and loved. To be honest, it was disappointing that we did not have dessert, given that we were there to celebrate a birthday. It would be nice if they had some type of standard dessert to accommodate several different pallets, that way everyone leaves happy.  All in all, it was great food, friendly service, and a good environment. Make sure to call ahead, though. They fill up fast, even during the week.

March 7, 2014. Decided Meat & Potatoes was the place for us to have a birthday celebration dinner. We arrived a tad early for our 7:45 reservation. We were pleasantly surprised when we were seated right away despite the place being packed with theater going crowd. We were only a group of two, lol.   Waiter poured some water right away & took our drink order. Our bottle of wine took some time to arrive. But the place was packed & the staff was constantly moving.   We ordered some fried pickles for fun but I can tell you the menu is packed with an array of appetizers, drinks & mussels of the day! Pickles were delicious & the dipping sauce had a lovely zing to it.   We were seated in the bar area at these tiny two people tables among others coming & going. After an extraordinarily long wait & noticing people coming in after us were getting their meals we were about to ask about our meals when the waiter came to us & told us he took it upon himself to involve his manager & insist on our meals to be made immediately. He apologized. We were fine with that result but if we had theater tickets or other plans we would have been hard press to have stayed & been able to enjoy our meals. I think the wine helped in this situation not to get annoyed.   The best part of the night other then the amazing chocolate dessert & having dinner with my great friend was the lovely friendly couple next to us. The tables are so close together it's impossible not to acknowledge your dinner mates. That made the evening fun & extra special to meet friendly native Pittsburghians!   Note: I enjoyed the game hen with green bean casserole & a scrumptious cranberry stuffing & lovely chicken gravy. The chicken was moist & nicely seasoned. Wish there was a roll or fresh bread to sop up all that gravy!   My friend enjoyed the fish & chips. Lightly battered. Served with fresh greens & smashed peas (my friend absolutely went nuts over the smashed peas & wish she had a small bowl of them) all drizzled with a light malt vinegar. There was a side of their home made tarter sauce.   We shared an amazing chocolate mousse dessert with fresh whipped cream!   All in all we had a nice experience. It was loud & very active. Not a place for a romantic dinner for two but definitely a place to go with friends. If going on theater night allow plenty of time to enjoy your meal or eat at home & enjoy drinks & appetizers or dessert here. Food is delicious & plenty. I didn't pay since it was my birthday but my friend was pleasantly surprised at the bill thinking it would be higher with the quality of food. She would put it at moderately priced to high depending on what you ordered. I would agree with her based on the prices. You can eat well here and spend little or spend a lot.   I say go. Give it a try & decide for yourself!  :-)
PBLT - pastrami belly on a BLT. Even better than it sounds; the arugula complements the fatty meat well. And the bread (thick cut) is excellent.

This was my first taste of Pittsburgh, and I was not disappointed. I had the Pierogi, and it was out of this world. I'd recommend making a reservation in advance, but the host got us in without a wait. I'd chalk that one up to perfect timing.

We made a late night reservation because they are supposed to have the best burger in Pennsylvania. We almost walked out because the service was very slow. Once our waiter remembered us everything was great. The pub burger was excellent, a great poutine as well. Nice wine selection. Our waiter was great, I'm sure he was in the weeds. It was packed, even late at night. Reservations recommended.

I've had a couple co workers tell me this place is great. Man they weren't kidding. I loved everything about it. It was easy to make the reservation (which I highly recommend doing). The staff was so friendly when we arrived. We were seated right away. The atmosphere was definitely something different in a good way. We ordered the fried pickles as a snack while we waited for our main course to come out. We decided on the Meat & Potatoes for two. IT WAS HUGE. The meat was tender and cooked to perfection. We will definitely be returning here!

I truly think Meat & Potatoes is worth the hype. I've never had a bad meal or experience here! It's been around for a while so it might not have the new and exciting vibe as some of the other spots, but there's a reason it gets rave reviews. They do a great job.  I've gone for dinner and lunch (when they were open during lent) and everything has been delicious. My favorite thing to get is mussels, but even just a regular old burger is awesome here. You can go as fancy or casual as you'd like with the menu, and their cocktail list is awesome. Service is always attentive without being overbearing. Even with other new and trendy places popping up around town, I keep coming back here.

My husband and I had an amazing meal at meat and potatoes! The service was fantastic, the food was delicious- we had the pig ears (tasted like bacon), bone marrow appetizer (amazing), the pimento burger and another type of burger, and the oreo brownie! Everything was fantastic! The only con is that the seats are very close together so we didn't have a super private experience. However, i cant wait to go back!

Been itching to try this place out for a long time now but I always have a huge party and waited too late to make the reservation.  This place is small and pretty tight but since we had a larger party, we got a private room! It's dimly lit and very hipster.  We got fries and wings as appetizers and they were both amazing. Wings weren't too hot and I've never had better fries in my life! I personally got the three little piggy sandwich and it was the best out of everyone else's meal. It's more like a yummy breakfast sandwich with s runny egg, thick cut bacon, and ham. It also came with fries. I loved it! The others at my table got a variety of different items. Two people got the shortbreads and two others got sandwiches. Everything looked amazing. If I were in the mood for this type of food, I would go back!

Meat & Potatoes is always somewhere I feel like I need to go because of the hype surrounding it, but I never really have a strong urge to be here based on a non-noteworthy experience I had a few years ago.  In any event, I wanted to wrap up my birthday weekend with brunch at M&P because I hadn't been here yet for that and I've been told they have the best bloody mary in Pittsburgh.  Our food was great. Our bloody mary's were just...alright.  Our service was...meh.  I love the atmosphere of Meat and Potatoes. It is not a huge space but they do utilize it well and make the most out of it with the seating. I definitely recommend a reservation no matter what you're coming here for, otherwise there will be a wait.  It is bright and they had a DJ spinning real vinyls which was cool. It was very relaxed and vibe-y and their menu, though limited to brunch, is extensive in the sense that you can order breakfast or more lunch-type of items.  We started with the truffle fries and bloody marys. I got the bacon infused vodka for mine and my date had the horseradish vodka.  We braved the crowd to go to the bar to do the add-ins.  Mine was okay - not the best and not the worst.  The truffle fries were to die for.  I ordered the huevos rancheros for my meal and my date had the brisket hash.  The food came out piping hot and the flavor was really good.  The huevos rancheros were insanely spicy. Too intense for me almost.   Our waiter was not really  engaging us at all. He showed up when he had to, took our orders and brought out the food. It wasn't bad service, but it wasn't that good either. Which is disappointing, because M&P is a really nice place and the end bill reflects the atmosphere and the quality of food, so I wish the overall service/experience matched.  Regardless, I'd come here again because their menu is interesting and you know you're going to eat a satisfying meal.

This was my second visit to Meat & Potatoes, this time for Sunday Brunch.  This visit didn't disappoint.  My husband and I spent the weekend in Pittsburgh for Valentine's Day.  I made a reservation through Yelp, which was helpful, because the restaurant was fairly busy.  Seating is always a bit tight and awkward, but that's ok.  We were seated and ordered coffee, which was fresh, hot and satisfying.  I ordered the special lemon ricotta pancakes and peppered bacon.  My husband ordered the traditional breakfast, housemade sausage, eggs, potatoes and toast.  The pancakes were DIVINE, topped with the most delicious lemon curd.  The peppered bacon was tasty too.  My husband enjoyed his breakfast as well, but wished that he had ordered the signature chicken and waffles, once he saw the surrounding table's orders arrive.  Also the Bloody Mary bar was pretty popular.  All-in-all, this was a great choice and we would absolutely return.
We loved it. The charcuterie board very good. The 34oz ribeye with fries  and bone marrow fabulous! Can't  wait to go back!
Fun, lively atmosphere! Amazing cocktails, meatloaf and burgers. Best meal while in Pittsburgh and I had some good meals!!

Best restaurant experience in Pittsburgh! Food is delightful, and not too expensive either. The bone marrow and the duck liver pate are delicious. My wife had the wild mushroom risotto and was in heaven.   Extra points for a super friendly staff, and the manager of the restaurant comp-ing us 2 free desserts just because we complimented him on the food.   Everything was amazing!

First time to Meat and Potatoes restaurant and we will go back. My husband and I had the fried pickles, the salmon, and the pork and blue cheese flatbread. I am not a fan of fried pickles but said I would try one-I ended up having more. Our server asked if we were attending a show that evening and we were. Our meal was served in a timely manner.

This is a great spot for drinks. The service is awesome, but their food is hit or miss. We ordered the chicken liver, beef tartare, risotto and meatloaf, which is on their special of the day menu.  The risotto and the chicken liver were good. The rest are horrible because they came out extremely salty.

Only negative thing I can say is that I hate the name.  The old Amy wouldn't even go to the bar because of the name, but I'm glad that I'm always evolving.  Really awesome cocktails, and you can tell that they don't skimp on ingredients or presentation.    Have been here twice for cocktails, and last night we added food.  Unfortunately the Manhattans made me lose my ability to recall what we ate at the bar.  Cute and friendly bartenders!  Highly recommend for night out on the town in Pittsburgh!

Rather excellent place. Came in 30 minutes prior to our reservation and sat at the bar. Cocktails were very good. Were seated later at our table in the main area, which is very lively and stylish, very well suited for a relaxed conversation. Great atmosphere!   The food was VERY good. The meat was prepared really well. I had pork belly tacos and hubby had bone-in filet, both cooked to perfection, followed by dessert served in a glass jar. Servers were polite and attentive.   The only downside was that the filet (that was on special and was not listed in the menu) turned out to cost almost twice as much as the most expensive item on the regular menu, a small thing that our server "forgot" to mention. Even though my husband thoroughly enjoyed it and would have ordered it anyway, it would have been nice to mention it in advance, as you don't generally expect a price of $56/entree in a place that has $20-25/entrees in their menu. Hence minus one star.   Otherwise it was a wonderful evening and we will come back. But please, do mention the price next time!

BRUNCH REVIEW  Pros: Great food Reasonable prices Great service  Bloody Mary bar  Mehs: Parking costs (up to $8) Reservations need to be made more than a week in advance   Cons: I spent some time thinking about some cons, but there really aren't any. This is an excellent choice for brunch!  We've gone here for brunch a few times, and have always had a mouth-watering meal with great service. For the delectable food you get, the price is outstanding, and you will quickly get hooked on the experience. A meal for two, including coffee and Bloody Marys, comes to slightly under $50.

This is a fun place in a great location in the Cultural District.  The food is very good, and the decor is charming.  The service is fairly quick, and the wait staff is very polite and helpful.  I was surprised at the devils on horseback, which turned out to be a very delicious appetizer...and something I was not expecting at a place called "Meat and Potatoes."  I have heard people rave about the good food here, and it turns out to be very good and there are some fun choices, however it's certainly not the best Pittsburgh has to offer.

Holy cow (or pig?)! This place is amazing! The atmosphere is quite hip, the food is astounding, the music selection is perfect, and the seating is probably the most comfortable restaurant seating I have ever experienced. I ordered the wagyu steak as my entree and our starters were the fried pickles, fried taters, and cheese board. It was legitimately all amazing. There are several parking garages nearby, so parking is a breeze. I will be back! This has definitely become a staple of my trips back to Pittsburgh.

It is a very quaint atmosphere. It's very nice for the bar and the service was excellent. We had the mack and cheese appetizer which was delicious and we also had the fried pickles which were also very good.  I had the pot roast and was delicious and fell apart with A fork.  I suggest you call ahead for reservations because getting a table will be very tight during dinner hours. I still have to say I think it's one of the better or best restaurants in the downtown area
Food and service was excellent.  Just very close seating arrangements.  We might as well have been sitting with the people beside us.  But otherwise, very good.
great food (recommend the Pappardelle) and cocktails (order a Suburban) and reasonably priced (less than $20 / plate typically)

I would love to recommend this restaurant, but I cannot.  Let's start on a positive note - the atmosphere is nice.  They did a nice job decorating.  The tables are a bit close, but they didn't have much space to work with...nice job.  The wine was just fine too.  The food, on the other hand, was not good at all.  First, the menu is extremely limited.  Second, we ordered the gnocci and the pork.  The gnocci was mushy and soggy.  It was not very flavorful.  The best part of the pasta dish was the garlic toast.  We also ordered the pork.  It was fatty and tough.  It is served with an apple slaw that has a strange mixture of flavors - not very good.  The menu indicates that the meal comes with baked beans.  In reality, it is just a spoonful of beans on top of the pork.  The beans were the best part of the meal, so it was disappointing that there wasn't really even one serving on the plate.  We will not be back.

It's a splurge and you certainly are going to need a reservation (we booked right here on Yelp and it worked perfectly!), but the portions are huge and the food is perfectly seasoned! Boyfriend noticed there was no salt and pepper on the table, but when the food came (quickly!) we suddenly understood why! I had the pork - a HUGE portion! - and boyfriend had a smaller portioned chicken entree. (I forgot to take a pic until I was already done eating as much as I could of my pork!) The buffalo Mac and cheese was spicy - boyfriend enjoyed it more than me because I'm a spice wimp - but I can understand why people like it so much! It was the perfect date Night spot - even if a little pricey, still delicious and worth a little more coin!

I had the Pork. The chop was the best that I ever had. It was perfectly cooked. I ordered it medium well. The knife, however was dull. They need to update their cutlery. The collard greens were indeed sweet. My drink was the Diablo. It is now my favorite next to the Moscow Mule.

Probably a 4.5, only because I wasnt thrilled with my Old Fashioned and I thought the menu was a tad minimal...would have liked have seen 2-3 more entrees (I am not a hanger steak or flat iron guy...give me traditional cuts. I also saw short ribs on other items, would have liked to see a short rib entree)...I am having a hard time deciding on 4 or 5 stars....I think it is really close to 5, but a couple small things, like the drink, the pastrami (see below) and a friend saying the steak was a ittle tough are making me  go 4 instead of 5. But honestly, this was probably the best sit down meal I had all week in this town and wouldnt hesitate to suggest you try it.   We had a group of 8, so we started with a bunch of the small plates, or whatever they call them. The Fried Pickles...oh my....I am not a huge fried pickle person, but if everywhere that has them made them like this, I would be. Best. Fried. Pickles. Ever! The Poutine...being from the west coast, I had no idea what this was. But I am now a fan. Very tasty. The grilled bread...meh...it was fine, but not exciting to me, but a buddy with me said it was his favorite.  The Brussel were also very tasty. Im not usually a Brussel guy, but it was outstanding. I wanted to love the corn dog....it was good, dont get me wrong, but it just wasnt as exciting as I was hoping for. It was solid though.  The bone marrow....wow...what can I say? It was extravagant, decadent, rich, buttery goodness. And my buddy that lives in town said his dog loved the bones...  Soooo...I had the pork chop....holy crap was that thing huge! It was very moist and tender with a nice smoky flavor. The apple salw had a nice little kick to it, and the cool spicy crunch of the slaw with the tender smokey-ness of the pork and the sweetness of the beans was a great combo. The only thing I felt that came up short was the pastrami. It was just this really fatty piece of limp meat that didnt have much contributing in the flavor dept and wasnt the best texture, to me. Overall, the dish was a big win though.   I really enjoyed this place and would like to give it a 4.5....if you are looking at yelp trying to decide where to go in Pittsburgh, this is the place...I just wished I had more time there to try more of their menu (like lunch...the sandwiches and burgers sounded great). I think it is really close to 5 stars, it was just a couple really small things that cant let me do it (btw- I hate when people give good reviews, but not 5 stars and dont explain why)

I can't review the food here but am disappointed in the service I received because I made reservations for 7 people a week in advance for a Thursday night dinner. We showed up to the restaurant with 1 more person and they told us they couldn't accommodate our party until at least 1030 when it was only 730. We told them we would squeeze the other person in and didn't mind if it was tight but they told us no and to try Six Penn down the street. Not very good customer service in my opinion, so 2 stars.

This was my second experience here and for the second time I was not too crazy about the food. However both times that I went it was later in the evening (2 hours before closing) so I don't know if that had something to do with it. On a brighter note I will say that the atmosphere was cool and my drinks were well made and flavorful. Outside of stopping by to grab a few drinks...I probably wouldn't eat here again.

We went on Saturday June 7 at 11 am.  We asked to sit outside.  The hostess said it would be a 30 minute wait.  We then asked about a seat at the bar.  They said sure.  The bar was empty since they just opened.  We waited ten minutes. We asked about the empty bar seats and they said it would be thirty minutes!  Why didn't they tell us at the beginning?  The 3 hostesses were disorganized and not friendly at all.  We left,  unhappy with the hostess staff.  They do not represent the restauant well at all.

Very disappointed! This is definitely one of the hottest restaurant in town. Every time we try to make an reservation, it was either fully booked, or no table available until 10pm! This place has been getting great reviews, which it made us even more curious to try it out and also raised our expectation. Last week, we made reservation a week before and got in at 5. The decoration was nice but different than I imagined. The stuff were friendly and nice.   Now the meals, Of course we have to order bone marrows. It is one of the reason we want to come, they serve something that others don't have. However! It was just like eating fat, on a toast. Hard no for this. Pig ears, deep fried, the sauce was very sour. Pickle was Good  tho. No to the pig ears. Pork chops- urgh.. no, stoped after two bites, I've had better. Salad-again, some thing you can do much better at home by yourself Burgh was good  Over all, everything was good but the food. I don't know why people loves this place so much, but it is not for me. I might give it another try if it is not so hard to get in. Since I have to book it a week ahead, i Would rather go somewhere I really like and enjoy. We almost had our rehearsal dinner here, but they don't have a room big enough can host the party. Now I'm glad we landed some where else.

Fantastic joint located in the Cultural District of Pittsburgh's Downtown area. I admit, I'm surprised that I put off coming to this place for so long. My friend and I ended up splitting a Meat & Potatoes for Two ($69), which included a 34 oz. ribeye steak meat cooked medium rare, confit steak fries, mushroom ragu, homemade steak sauce, and bone marrow gratin. I also ended up getting a devils on horseback as a small plate. Let's start with the main entree ... the steak meat for the ribeye was dope. Not only very tender, but also very flavorful especially with the homemade steak sauce, which gave the meat a more tangy flavor. Quantity of meat was abundant and even for two, it took my friend and I the entire meal to eat all that meat up. The confit steak fries were also not your average steak fries ... not soggy, but very crisp and tasty with seasoning (much appreciated). The bone marrow tasted like fat ... not sure if this is how it should taste (as this is the first time I've ever had anything like it), but it was very interesting indeed and I used it to coat a few of the steak fries that I ate. The mushroom ragu was great. Fresh, firm, and flavorful. The devils on horseback was tasty ... came in a small tray and I only got three. Not sure if the price on it was justified, but the taste was good. In general, a great place to go. Just go hungry and ready to eat meat!

Great ambiance but the tables seemed small and crowded once we got our entrees. The mussels of the day were delicious! The poutine, however, felt like it was... missing something? It tasted great, don't get me wrong, but the ratio of gravy/cheese curds/fries seemed off. I still enjoyed it though. The salty pig flatbread was very good as well. Our waiter mistakenly gave me cold coffee after our meal but noticed the error before giving it to me and replaced it immediately. All of the food here is hearty and there is so much of it you'll probably end up boxing your leftovers to bring home.

Cool restaurant. Came for brunch while on a short trip to Pittsburgh. My BF loved their create your own Bloody Mary Bar. I ordered the chicken and waffles which was a huge plate of chicken, enough for feed at least 2 people. BF ordered the bibimbop which was a disappointment, he should have known not to order a Korean dish at a non-Korean resto! Recommend sticking to the more traditional menu items.
I know you can't go wrong with fried chicken but this chicken was different. Absolutely amazing.  My husband had the chicken paillard and it was amazing too!

This brunch Bloody Mary bar is to die for. Just a note, get there earlier if you want the entire experience because they do run out of toppings as the brunch goes on. The French toast is mind blowing, as was the pancake of the day. The more savory dishes were good but not amazing, which is why I'm taking off a star.
This place was amazing for brunch!! The drinks were awesome, the food was delicious and the music was on point. I highly recommend for brunch.
Loved this place.  The environment was so fun and the staff was great! We had the 45 oz ribeye and it was so delicious! I would definitely go back.

Excellent excellent excellent. Went for the brunch and ordered the chicken and waffles. One of the best breakfasts I have ever had, hands down. The amount of food for the price is stellar. Massive cheddar jalapeño pepper waffle with four huge pieces of chicken and bacon maple syrup. Start with truffle potatoes!!! MAKE A RESERVATION AND GET OVER HERE TO EAT NOW.

My wife and I had the build your own MEAT & Potatoes for Two 45oz. RIBEYE for $75. We had see in on a Travel network show and it looked so good. How disappointing! The tasted of the steak was not bad but about 1/3 was fat. For $75 a better cut of meat should be served. The bone marrow was not all that special and that was what the Travel channel made a big deal of. Save your money and pass on Meat and Potatoes.

The bar is a fantastic place to hang. The bartenders are the best in the 'Burgh! Mai, Greta, Blake, Jason are all fantastic. The drinks are delicious and the food is out if this world. Truly all-around fantastic place. Love it here!! I recommend the Devils on Horseback, mussels, short ribs, chicken livers, and the burger. All are awesome choices.

Had dinner here this past Saturday night.  Was wowed from start to finish, was greeted right away and sat for our 8:00PM Reservation.  Had an extremely knowledgeable waitress named Rachel that made fantastic recommendations based on the true preparation of the dishes.  There was too much that we wanted to try on their far from ordinary menu, full of interesting dishes.  We went with the Beef tartar appetizer which was so fantastic, smooth, flavorful and the delicious egg topped it off perfectly.  We also tried the tuna taquitas which were great as well.  The Fried Pickles are a must have, the breading is incredible but they are huge.  For entrees we enjoyed the Moules Frites with White Wine Garlic Broth, which the girlfriend said where some of the best she ever had.  I enjoyed their signature duck dish, this was such fresh meat but what really made it for me was the pastrami edging.  The sauerkraut pierogoies were a nice side of the dish aswell.  Dont miss out on their drinks, this was the best Manhattan cocktail ive ever had!  Also enjoyed a drink called the Perfect Sour, that was a great addition similar to a Pisco Sour.  Will be returning soon with plenty of options to try !

Delicious lunch-time fare was the consensus of the group, and with large portions, almost everyone in my party of 6 (was was excellently cared for by staff) took home leftovers to look forward to. My turkey melt was the best I'd ever had, the bloody marys were generous and enjoyed by everyone at the table (Even Scottie who claims to not like them!). ** Reservations recommended, ESPECIALLY FOR PARTIES OVER 5, AND WELL IN ADVANCE! It's not a huge place, and after dining there with family, I can see how it would be hard to merge any open tables to fit more than that at a time with smaller reservations also waiting  But, if you're a smaller party, even if you have to wait, the food, drink and service will be well worth it.**

This is my absolute favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh.  The best Moscow Mule I've had in Pittsburgh,  My girlfriend and I got Meat and Potatoes for two, and we were so sad that we couldn't quite finish it because it was so good.  Must haves: Bone Marrow (ask for extra bread) Moscow Mule Cheese Board Mussels And if you're lucky enough to be there on a day when they have it : Softshell crab sandwich.  I think the only thing I've ever had here that I thought was lacking was a charcuterie, it was expensive, and just plain lacking in substance.  But one experience like that is not nearly enough to knock off even half a star for me when it comes to Meat & Potatoes.

Being from the South, I had to try the fried pickles! They were different than I was used to and my colleague had never tried them. They were not the thin sliced pickle chips, but rather like mini fried green tomatoes! They were fresh and tasty. The wait staff was very responsive and answered all of our questions. We didn't recognize all of the items that went with everything. The portions are huge, so come hungry! I ordered the pork chop and it was enough to feed 2 people. My colleague ordered the half BBQ chicken and it fed 3 people! Everything was fresh and the patio was nice!

This place is amazing. Great service, wonderful food, delicious drinks. Make sure to get a reservation way in advance because they are usually booked solid!   I had the pork chops, and it is enough for 3 meals! The collard greens that came with it are amazing (I'm currently trying to figure out the recipe!). I highly recommend this restaurant, and cannot wait to go back! If I can ever get a reservation....

See my review for Tako.  Again, this crew does three things right each time: Ambience (their best feature, and to be honest much needed in this beautiful city), bold flavors (hence this review), and a good blend of inherent Pittsburgh with outside flavors. Oh and a fourth: Some of the best drinks I have had, PERIOD.  Now, hailing from NYC and being a child of the world, I think my palette has evolved to the point where gut feelings mean more than just Borbyrigmi (that's what Google is here for people)...but now food gives me that instant gratification and "light bulb."  Before I proceed, I will say this. They have the best burger I have had in Pittsburgh, period (yes, it even beat you Tessaro's). More on that later.  Now, none of the above makes me any more special than the next person to judge food, but I think my take is authentic. With Tako, they did it well. With Butcher, they did well for what it is supposed to be.  I wish I could say the same for M&P. Why the 3 stars? Consistency man, consistency. My first experience was fantastic. Meat and Potatoes for two and good lord I wanted another round but I couldn't keep dessert waiting. My second time there, the meat was slightly dry, less juicy, and the potatoes weren't well seasoned and I just couldn't stand it. The Brussels were delicious, the tots were seasoned well, but good god that meat and potatoes the second time around really irked me.  So visit three was brunch and I have to say it does live up to the hype. The brunch was muito bom as they say in Portuguese, I had the Pub Burger and I have to say this is one of the best burgers I have had in my entire life as well as in Pittsburgh. The pastrami belly was just cooked to perfection and seasoned just right. The bun was perfect and the horseradish cheddar complimented the entire burger perfectly. The fried egg was perfect and thank you chef for keeping that yolk runny like my nose as I write this - unrelenting (gross, I know).  I tried my friends' Grilled Cheese and it was delicious and next time I will be trying the Brisket Hash because it was just delightful.   The bloody mary bar was as good as any other bloody mary bar you can find around town. I specifically ordered the Quarterdeck and it was very good. The folks that own these establishments really make excellent drinks.  Finally, I went back again for dinner and Ordered the Wagyu flatiron and...not bad. Not fantastic, but with such a fine cut of meat I expected more. Just a bit dry for my taste. My sister's pappardelle however, was perfect and that pork shoulder fell apart in my mouth and I wish I had ordered that. Though simple, they really toasted that garlic bread really well and I don't know what it was but there was a slight non-garlicy zing to the bread or maybe just herbal butter or something..but it was great!  As you can see the waves of consistency truly have a great impact on this review and hence the 3 stars.   Overall, beautiful atmosphere, perfect for dates and gatherings, good for what it is (gastropub with old world style décor), fantastic drinks, but food needs more consistency and can be hit or miss. Service is great!

This place is literally my favorite place to eat in pittsburgh. My boyfriend and I stumbled across it when at the three rivers art festival last year and decided to give it a shot... So glad we did.   Every time we come here, we start off with some appetizers. Their fried taters are small. Cut French fries that come with their house made aioli- which is incredible. Their fried pickles are literally the best in all of the burgh- they come with spicy ranch dressing, again, housemade, and are to die for. I switch up the entrees each time I go- they have different specials each week. Their Waldorf salad is delicious. I've had the three little pigs sandwich which is incredibly large and worth the money.  The drinks are amazing. They have tons of unique beers on tap and last time I went I asked the bar tender for a fruity drink- he made me a drink with an egg white in it! Sounds odd but it was awesome.. Where else can you get that? Their deserts are incredible- they have a desert chef who makes the deserts as fresh as they come. Their chocolate mouse is incredible.  Meat and potatoes is a must. It's my favorite restaurant and they do everything perfect. Brunch, lunch and dinner- each menu is amazing. I'm obsessed.

Hands down one of the best brunch spots in the city!  Not only is the food great, they also have a bloody Mary bar on Sundays.  My husband jokes that he could make a meal out of the options on the bloody Mary bar.

Ordered the 45oz bone in tomahawk ribeye--medium with confit potatoes and buffalo Mac n cheese. Very disappointed with the result--steak was significantly undercooked and under-flavored. The portion size is excellent but the cut of meat is not the highest grade. The steak truly needs a sauce (their house steak sauce was very good), but any steak enthusiast will tell you that a great steak should never be tarnished with even a great sauce. The confit potatoes and buffalo Mac were very average. Service and atmosphere were great. Strictly based on the taste and quality of food and factoring in cost, I would not come here for the food. Very good for a pub steak but well below average for a steakhouse steak. Likely will not return.
Always come to this place when I visit Pittsburgh. Whatever you get is going to be absolutely delish. My favorite: huevos rancheros. You can't miss their mimosas either!!

The food and atmosphere of Meat and Potatoes was awesome! I had the Plain Jane Burger, and my boyfriend had the Brisket Sandwich. Both were delicious and cooked to perfection. I highly recommend this restaurant if you're in Pittsburgh!
Original and great food. Top notch service. Beautiful atmosphere. My favorite in Pittsburgh.

Was in town passing through and this was the first restaurant to come up with 4 starts. Well deserved!! Didn't have a reservation but got a seat at the bar. Just had beer so I can't comment on the drinks. Had the fried chicken livers for a snack. Delicious if you don't mind liver texture. Had the pork belly sliders and some of my buddy's curry muscles for dinner. Both were delicious. Huge portions and great taste. Guy next to us had the pork chop. It was about the size of a brick! Like I said huge portions. Next time I'll go with a fellow carnivore and get the 34oz steak.

Quite possibly the best meal I have had in my 38 years on this earth. Food and service were excellent. Great coctails to pair with the meals as well. Emily B was our server and she was very knowledgeable of their menu.

The food's ok, the ambiance is better.  The fried brussel sprouts were lemony, too salty, and had too much parmesan cheese, the ranch dressing on the side was unnecessary.  The Kobe Corndog was pretty good on the inside, with a very pinkish hotdog meat. The outer breading was rather dry and too thick. On top was sprinkled a few leaves of cilantro, very thin radish slices, and a light wasabi-based sauce - these additions didn't really add to the corndog. The ketchup on the side was unnecessary.  The wagyu iron flat, the beef was a good texture, easy to chew and eat. It was a nice pink color in the center and browned on the outside. It was also too salty. I liked the sweet and slight tartness of the picked red onions. The yucca fries were rather dehydrated but ok. The plantain chips were too hard and dry.  Lively gastropub, there is a large square bar area in the center of the room, wood tables and comfy plush chairs around the room's peripheral, . Dim lighting with filament light bulbs, upbeat music playing overhead, and plenty of chatter. Seems hip and happening.  The service was good, the waitress was attentive and considerate.

How has this place been open for two years and I haven't been there yet!    There was honestly not one bad thing about this visit.  From the amazingly interesting and tasty drinks to the perfectly plated duck, I really need to go back - now.  Our trip there was my birthday lunch and since I was not going back to work, bring on the drinks.  I started with the glenshaw sour and was a bit disturbed by the egg whites that it contained, but all of my fears were alleviated with that first frothy lemony sip.  I followed that up with a brandy buck - how many birthday lunches does a person get?  Applejack brandy and pungent ginger were a perfect combination.  M had the thai steak salad that was piled high with thin strips of skirt steak.  It looked amazing.  J had the mussels.  It might have been the biggest pile of mussels I have ever seen - and we eat a lot of mussels.  The pancetta in the sauce definitely differentiated these mussels from others around town.  I had the duck.  Perfectly medium rare duck slices over spaetzle with massive saurkraut pierogies.  I was in heaven.  We finished it off with some of the creamist creme brulee I have ever had.   Awesome birthday lunch.  Can't wait to go back for brunch, dinner, more lunch, drinks....

Amazing meal, a bit cramped but ended up making friends with the table next to us. Will be back to try more offerings from the menu. The servers were very attentive and provided good menu suggestions. Our appetizers were so tasty waiting for our meal was a pleasure.

I came here for my birthday dinner a while back and I was so satisfied with the meal! First the environment and decor is between rustic and modern and it almost felt like it was between divey and trendy/nice without it feeling disgusting. I think the reason why it felt divey was because of the half oval bar in the middle of the restaurant, where it seemed very "college-y" with people hanging around or draping themselves all over it.  They have an insanely extensive whiskey menu, which basically won me over at that point! My table shared an order of the fried pickles as an appetizer, and I got the Red Snapper. It's a bit on the lighter side, which is what I wanted, with a lot of veggies, and the fish was cooked so well. Next time, I want to try the Pork Chop. The table next to mine had a few people that ordered it and it was huge... huge. It looked really good.  Their seasonal menu also sounded really good and I'm sure it was! We also got 2 desserts, which I believe were also on rotation. One was a pb oreo dirt pot, and the other was a malted chocolate pot de creme... and the pot de creme was to die for. It is definitely one of the best restaurant desserts I've ever had!

I've been here three times now and thought it was time I did some raving! The first two times I came in groups for formal-ish dinners with work. Both times phenomenal service and incredible food. They have a back room that's quieter that you can reserve (or rent out? I'm not sure - someone else was paying). The third time I came with my parents for my medical school graduation a few weeks ago. My parents are notoriously impossible to please when it comes to restaurants. I've never seen them get beyond a "I guess this place is ok" sentiment. But Meat & Potatoes seriously won them over. My dad was in love with the beer menu ("tins" only), my sister was in love with the historic cocktails, even my mother was thrilled by her food (never happens).  The vibe is cool, the menu is incredible, the quality is great, and the prices are totally reasonable for what you're getting. I wish I could afford to eat here every day.  The devils on horseback - laced with crack, I swear. And I thought I hated dates.  The cocktails - I've tried half the menu by now, all amazing.   My one teensy tiny bit of constructive criticism, just for the sake of not glowing too much - make sure you don't get a table immediately next to the bar if possible. They're placed pretty close and if the bar gets crowded (it's right in the middle of the dining room), sometimes other patrons will invade your space. We actually asked them not so seat us at a table that was already invaded. They obliged, and then we watched 3 other families also refuse the table. I did feel a little sorry for the poor souls who eventually ended up at it. But not that sorry, because the food and the drink and the awesomeness would have made it worth a little discomfort anyway.

Dishes were too upscale for my boyfriend and I. We were unfamiliar with most of the words and foods. We tried the bone marrow appetizer and meat & potatoes for the main course. The bone marrow was new to us, and it was very bland in taste and slimy in texture due to the high fat content. The steak was pretty good but not phenomenal. None of the food was worth the (high) price.

Every time a special event crops up, the answer to the question "where should we go to celebrate?" is always Meat and Potatoes.   Sometimes I'll try to mitigate the compulsion to eat here and try somewhere new, but more often than not we'll end up tucked away in an intimate table at our old standby.   Everything about Meat and Potatoes, from the obsessive attention to detail where cooking to order is concerned to the fantastic presentation of the food helps it maintain it's place on the top of our list.   The decor - a smallish place with intimate tables organized around a beautiful central bar in a very pre -prohibition era look - is reflected in their libations selections. And these bar tenders can actually mix drinks! Amazing!    The only possible downside is that, due to the open floor plan and the positioning of the bar, the place can seem a bit crowded and boisterous. If this does not jive with your idea of romance, choose a non-romantic reason to come.   There are only two "bad" seats in the house. A two top directly to the right of the entrance and a table along the curve of the wall that's really hard to get in and out of.   What really, really makes this place for me is the service. The wait staff is always subtly there but not in your face. They're knowledgeable without being snotty and very attentive.   The menu features a range of delicious options and preparations like the sweatbread tacos make some more intimidating choices accessible to those who might not otherwise try them.    All things aside, the absolute best thing about this place is that I have never been dissatisfied with either food or experience. In all the years that they've been open, there has not been one time where I thought the quality was slipping and that is really something else.   Hope this was helpful!!!

One of the best restaurants in the burgh! I've been to Meat & Potatoes close to 10 times and I have always had amazing food.  The menu always changes, but my last visit led me to the best burger of my life, partly due to the fois gras and black truffle.  The truffle aioli served with the fries is so great that you will want to eat only that, every night of the week.  Brunch on weekends is amazing as well, and there is a build your own bloody mary bar.  They have mixologists on staff and the cocktails might be the best in town.   The bar staff is great but the table service can be a little slow at times.    I will be back.  Many times!

Brunch here was a real treat! 5 friends and I decided to treat ourselves as late semester pick me up and it couldn't have been much better.  We had a reservation (highly recommended, as the space is small and popular) and were seated relatively quickly. We each ordered something different and passed plates:  -Brisket and Eggs: Delicious, the meat was a little tough, but the kimchi made up for it.  -Irish Benedict: Hearty but a bit bland. It also was really heavy. Definitely the least favorite.  -Short Rib Hash: Pretty good, is a somewhat small portion but apparently was filling  -French Toast: Absolute perfection. It was a bit sweet but all of the flavors worked well together.  -Omelet Special (Sundried Tomato, Cheese Curds, Roast Beef)-Pretty good, but the real star was the potato gratin that came on the side. That was divine.   We also decided to share 3 desserts. They were small so it worked out:  -Black Bottom Chocolate Pecan: The presentation was awesome-it came in a jar with whipped cream on top! It was really warm and rich. Definitely delicious, but probably couldn't have eaten one by myself.  -Pumpkin Tarte with Cranberry Sauce-Yum! Very festive and not too heavy. It was also less sweet which was pretty good considering the other 2 desserts.  -Mudslide Tiramisu: Light, flavorful and just great. This was probably the table's favorite. I would definitely order this again, no matter the time of the year.   All in all, Meat and Potatoes was a delicious treat, and  I hope to go back soon!

My advice for you.....make a rsvp. Otherwise, the waiting line will be hours and hours. But it is so worth it.   The food is great. The ambience is perfect and classy. The staff is welcoming and knowledgeable.   Their brunch food is what they are well known for (in my opinion) but you really can't go wrong with either meal. The bloody Mary is quite the gem as well.

We have been trying to get reservations for months at this restaurant and finally made it there last night. I have to share I have no idea what the hype is for this restaurant. The menu was anything but meat and potatoes. My friend ordered the special braised pork Pierogies and they were not edible. She said that there was a strange smell to them. Another friend ordered a burger and said it was fine but no different than other burgers. Another friend ordered the burger that came with pork. The pork was s big piece of fat that she had to remove. I ordered the catfish tacos which was really the only thing on the menu that interested me. They were good but really, I was at a restaurant named Meat and Potatoes. Silly me, I thought I would be ordering a nice seared rare filet with some fingerling potatoes made special by the chef. I was very disappointed and won't be returning. I just can't figure out why they are doing so well with all of the truly fabulous restaurants in Pittsburgh.

During my first real visit to Pittsburgh I had the joy of sitting down to a meal at Meat & Potatoes- being from Philadelphia people have a lot of bad things to say about Pittsburgh (not sure why, probably because we're just mean), but the meal I had here did many things to break down these rumors and start me toward thinking that Pittsburgh could be an awesome place.   The waitress we had was super attentive and friendly and any place that serves things in jars basically has me hooked from the onset. As for the food, I tried the tacos and mac n cheese simply because I was having serious trouble deciding and just randomly picked, and I was not disappointed with my choice. The mixture of meat/bbq sauce/apple slaw creates quite the mouth-gasm upon eating. and the mac N cheese was so rich I had to take half of it home- it was simply too great. I suppose my only complaint might be that the neighboring table (and perhaps my dinner companion) might have heard my moderately audible moans. whoops. so impolite. but moving on...  Being that I've only been here once I can't quite give them a 5 star rating only because I think I'd need to eat another meal here, but from what I've tried I can certainly say they've got my attention, and I would certainly repeat my visit to try all the other delights they have to offer.

a delicious late night steak tartare.  what else to say?  darkly lit, strong bar atmosphere.  in a good way.  if you think you can hang, go check it out.  can be intimidating.  in a good way.  worth a trip down to the cultural district just because.

Amazing brunch in downtown Pittsburgh.  So much to choose from!!!!  We had the special egg's benedict with smoked turkey, huevos rancheros and fries with truffle mayo.  Great drinks, ambience, service, and huge portions.  This place will want to make you live in Pittsburgh.  Definitely make a reservation.  We had a 11 AM table, and by the time it was 11:30 it was jammed packed.
Love it here! I dream of their cheese plate!!! The wagyu and brussels sprouts are to-die as well.

I really enjoyed their Sunday brunch here. I ordered the meat sampler, which was entirely too much for this girl to eat herself. The server, who was excellent, did warn me beforehand. I will say that Sundays are overwhelmingly busy and the place is pretty small. So, if you don't mind a crowd, it's a fine place for brunch. I went again recently on a weeknight. Although the food was good, there was nothing original or impressive about it. I'm an avid home cook, so I recognize a lot of dishes "borrowed" from more established chefs out there. Still, it was tasty and I think that this restaurant is a good addition to the downtown restaurant scene. Definitely worth a try.

So I should start out by saying when I eat an expensive restaurant, my expectations are pretty high.  The food was fine but we were disappointed with the service.  After we sat down it probably took about 20 minutes for someone to even come and take our drink order.  Unfortunately this trend continued throughout the dinner with the server never being around when we needed her.  We ended up ordering 1 less drink than usual because of the slow service.

Reservations for two Saturday night 4/9/16. All around great experience. The waitress was friendly and attentive. We choose the smokey wings as our appetizer and the steak and frites for our entrees. The wings were flavorful and the steak cut like butter. We couldn't ask for anything more at Meat & Potatoes! We came for meat and we ate meat!
Great atmosphere, great service, great drinks, went there on New Years but make sure there are no bills to be paid. "Can't put a price on a good time !

Went here for Easter dinner and it was just amazing. It is elegant and very normally priced, and the food is just unreal. I definitely will return again soon! Also, reservations are necessary. Don't try to go on a Friday or Saturday (or any night really) without a reservation, because chances are they are completely booked!

There aren't enough stars or superlatives in the world to adequately rate this place! Incredible! Phenomenal! Excellent!   The drinks are top notch. The bartenders are beyond just bartenders, they are truly mixologists who take pride in their work. Each craft cocktail was carefully balanced and simply delicious!    The food coming out of the kitchen all looked and smelled insanely good! We started with fried Brussels and devils on horseback. Both were outstanding!! Next we checked out the mussels of the day and selected a Thai inspired coconut curried broth with mussels and bread for soaking up that awesome sauce. When I tell you they were THE BEST mussels I've EVER HAD, I mean it! So many places have underseasoned broths resulting in flavorless mussels. Not here! It was to die for!   We weren't able to continue on to entrees as we were delightful stuffed after our three starters and cocktails. But the couple next to us ordered the 75 oz ribeye for two and graciously allowed us to try the steak and bone marrow gratin. Melt in your mouth deliciousness!!   You can't go wrong at Meat and Potatoes!! Almost too good to be true!

I've had 2 great experiences here. Pricy, totally worth it :) great portion sizes! Their potatoes are absolutely delicious. I don't have much more to add that hasn't already been said haha. Check it out!
Drinks are wonderful....but the food is uneven. When it is good, it is very good...when it isn't....it isn't bad, it just lacks impact.

I've heard rave reviews of the brunch here so decided to try it out. It did not disappoint! I got the Pub Burger and WOW... so delicious. The service was great as well. Our server wasn't constantly checking in, but seemed to notice when we needed more water, drinks, etc.   There was a huge mix of people there also; young couples, elderly folks, families, and the like. Also, there was a DJ which I thought was odd at first. Until I heard the mix of music. It was fantastic!  I'll definitely go again. The Bloody Mary bar is to die for.

The food was amazing! Big portions and full of flavor. I'm so happy my Uber driver suggested this place and I was able to convince my group to travel away from campus to try and validate the yumminess.  Now for the bad the hostess/host stand and seating process is a joke. We came on a Wednesday right before noon and visually saw empty tables but we had to wait in line to tell the hostess we would like a table for two ppl. Either the gal at the stand wasn't familiar with the system or she is forced (let's hope forced) to fill-in fields (she asked for our name and phone #) and she actually had to print out a small ticket to give to the guy that took us to our table. WTF!?!?!? It took a while and again, we could see the empty tables.  We finally were seated at a tiny table inside. We had luggage so this was not ideal. The waiter was prompt but asked us for our beverage order yet we had no drink menus to select from (small mistake and very forgivable).   I would definitely come back when I visit Pittsburgh again however perhaps I'll make a reservation, naaaahh, I don't think that will help that seating process.

It was virtually impossible for us to get a reservation for two while in town for Labor Day but the stars somehow aligned and we got in. And it was delicious.  We started with drinks from the bar, then kept ordering food. The tuna taquitos for him to start and the moules of the day for me. The ahi was delicious and a creamy spread of fresh avocado inside the crunchy shell made for a nice handheld appetizer. My mussels were packed with flavor and unique. We also had an order of the chorizo mac 'n cheese, which we both managed to eat quickly.   Atmosphere is fabulous. What a cool spot. Our server was okay - he wasn't overly helpful when I asked about a few of the specialty cocktails nor did I feel he was good at recommending items. Oh well. We still had a great night at M&P. My man ordered the burger (medium rare) and fries and loved it. Full from the mussels I ordered the devils on horseback appetizer which were the most perfect trio of stuffed dates wrapped in a slightly salty bacon. For dessert we shared the dirt pudding, reminiscent of our childhood years with layers of chocolately rich pudding and crushed oreos. The adult version was so good.   One of our favorite dining experiences while in Pittsburgh. Kudos, Meat and Potatoes!

Pittsburgh, as a tourist here for the first time, my hat's off to you!  Meat & Potatoes lives up to its name, and the food here was exactly what we needed on a rainy and cold night!  The pot roast was unbelievable, and their gnocchi special was the s***!

We stopped in last night.  I couldn't get reservations when I called earlier in the week, but we were going to Heinz Hall right across the street so we figured we might be able to get a seat at the bar.  Luckily we did.  It was packed and now we know why.  Good drinks, fantastic food.  We had the Brussel sprouts, Tartare, and the Mushroom flatbread.  All delicious.  Can't wait to go back.  Service was smooth and Chef DeShantz is a genius.

I went here on a date last night and, as much as I loved my company, I may have considered leaving him for whoever prepared the duck. Delicious. Not too game-y but just enough. Perfect at medium-rare and teamed up wonderfully with the accompanying pierogies, etc. The only thing I wasn't terribly keen on was the dressing for the greens. The flavor was a tad overpowering/bitter. And I tend to like bitter. My date and I also split the prosciutto mac n cheese and the fried pickles before the meal. Both perfection, although in retrospect we ordered waaaay too much food for just the two of us. This is also a really nice date spot - great ambiance - as a lot of previous reviewers have mentioned.

My fiancé and I had a great meal here! We were seated right away and the food was delicious!!! I got the hot chicken and he had the buffalo wings. I highly recommend these choices. Such a great atmosphere too!! Can't wait to go again

This place was very delicious. The presentation was amazing, you always taste your food first with smell and sight  We had the oysters, poutine and Brussels sprouts for apps I would recommend all!!! We then had the flat iron steak, lamb, salmon and Hamburger they were all amazing!!! The adult beverages  the one with tequila a honey bee something mmmm YESSS please!  If your in the area go!!!  We didn't sit in main dining we had to sit in back for walk ins and would do it again, plus the staff was so happy and helpful so knowledgeable!!!

Soo good!!! Love the Bone marrow, yummmmm. Deff should try if in Pittsburgh. Can be a bit expensive but hay, you get what you pay for. I recommend making a reservation because it is a very popular place. I typically just sit at the bar but even that can get crowded.

Fabulous food. Started with the chicken wings- probably the best we've ever eaten. The Caesar salad was over the top as well, topped with pork rinds that we're as light as a feather and delicious. The hanger steak entree was perfect. Our only complaint was slow service but otherwise very very good.
Very interesting menu. I had the bone marrow on bread, it was GOOD! Very nice modern atmosphere. Hot young professionals like to hang out here.

Guys, I finally made it to M&P!!  After a couple false starts, I finally got my act together, made a reservation well in advance, and brought a fellow aspiring foodie friend who was visiting town.  We split the bone marrow appetizer, which is three huge femurs and an assortment of toppings, served with toasted bread.  Fantastic.  I chose the special salad, which consisted of roasted Brussels sprouts with candied walnuts and a brisket vinaigrette dressing, and then talked myself out of the Wagyu flatiron (next visit) and into the pappardelle pasta dish that comes in a ragu sauce that was made by angels.  I opted not to get a cocktail and paired it all with a nice dry cider instead.  My friend got the pastrami crusted duck, and she delighted in it.  We both took ours home for a second meal.  We were well pleased.  Service was excellent, and the atmosphere is very much in keeping with the design aesthetic of this restaurant group--a bit eclectic, rustic, and modern hipster.  Well worth the visit, and I look forward to a return.

I came here in March one Sun. morning, after hearing the hype about the brunch.  While I'm always curious to try much-hyped restaurants, I'm always a bit skeptical--I guess this comes from being afraid that I'll be disappointed.  My dining companion, who'd been here several times with other people, had been wanting to come with me, but I was never able to get a reservation (I've heard you have to reserve weeks ahead, which is testament to just how popular brunch is here).  However, he informed me that he'd always sat at the bar, which doesn't require a reservation, so we decided to try for that.  We arrived at about 11am, and, after about a half hour wait, we were seated.  I was torn over whether to try the bloody Mary bar, which many other reviewers recommended, or a brunchtail, recommended by my dining companion.  Between wanting to save room for food and the cocktail of the day (I forget exactly what it was, but it had rhubarb, which I love), I opted for the hair of the dog, which turned out to be an excellent choice--indeed, so excellent that when the bartender asked if I wanted another, I assented enthusiastically, which I never do, since I try to be conscious of my alcohol intake.  For my entree, I ordered the chicken and waffles, per reviewer recommendations, even though I was a bit skeptical since I don't really care for jalapeno.  I had never tried this dish before, but I've had it since (in Atlanta, no less), so I have a standard for comparison.  While I always hesitate to use this much-cliched word, it was--epic!  The bourbon maple syrup was sweet, but not overly so, and it complemented the savoriness of the waffle (in which I couldn't taste any jalapeno at all) perfectly.  I took the chicken off of the waffle and poured the syrup directly on it in order to ensure that as much of it covered the waffle as possible, and then replaced the chicken.  The chicken was delightfully crispy on the outside and tender and juicy inside--some of the best fried chicken I've had in PGH.  Since I couldn't hope to eat the whole thing in one sitting (it's huge!), I ate the waffle and half the chicken, and took half the chicken home (it was still great the next day!).   After eating the waffle, I felt so full, there was no need for another meal until 5pm.  The atmosphere is great--very trendy and bright, and there's a DJ spinning tunes on Sun. mornings.  The bartenders, who served us, were attentive and helpful.  While I initially doubted I'd come out saying this, I can confidently say that M&P brunch is worth the hype.  Try it--you won't be disappointed!

We chose this venue for the last night of our Pittsburgh mini-vacation.  I began with the house's barrel aged Manhattan cocktail. Smooth, and not too sweet. My partner had her usual Riesling.  We shared the marrow bones, which at $18 are priced and portioned for two. This may have been the single best presentation of this dish I have encountered - and I've been eating them since I had them at St. John in London back in 2002 when this was a new idea. Three large bones, packed with marrow. Condiments were gros sel, pickled onion, capers, and a gremolata. I tried all four condiments - the salt worked best. The charred toasts were also excellent and moist with oil. We demanded more toasts to process the luscious masses of marrow.  For a main course I selected the lamb cassoulet. If I remember the menu correctly, this comprised lamb neck (Jamison farm?), lamb sausage and a sort of "streusel" of lamb bacon. The dish arrived as a sort of timbale of meat atop a ragout of beans, topped with pea greens. It was attractive if not the typical presentation. No confit, no duck or goose. The lamb was tender, the cut more like half of a  braised lamb shank than the usual slice of neck. The beans had the proper texture. The sausage sort of broke down. Overall I enjoyed the dish, but descriptions fail me  it's sort of a cross between a braised lamb shank and a cassoulet.   I washed it down with Terrazas Cabernet from Argentina, a great buy.  My partner plumped for the roasted Pennsylvania chicken which was firing on all cylinders. Despite it being tender young chicken there was a deep flavor, nice round dumplings, bacon fat. The sauerkraut and Brussels sprouts sort of disappeared into the juices.  Collard greens, a side order were light, spicy and sweet - not the usual taste of turkey neck or pork bones.  No room for dessert after the marrow and meats.  Good service and good value.

I find places to eat sometimes by purely seeing which few spots are the "most reviewed " in an area. This was #1 in Pittsburgh, so I went!  Appearance: I drove RIGHT by this place once because I couldn't see the signs in the windows for it. Lol. It's a surprisingly small, quaint, cozy gastropub tucked into the first floor of which looks to be an office building that you have to walk through a lobby to get to. The big windows at the back of the restaurant unfortunately face the side of another building, but the 2 giant ones at the front give you a decent view of the street. It's all street parking, so good luck with that.  Atmosphere: I LOVED it here! OMG! The giant, high ceilings, the interesting light fixtures, the staff uniforms and the freaking mirrors that curved with the walls were awesome. It was hype in there! Loud, but a good loud, like people were having fun loud, but you could still talk to the person next to you or more importantly, the bartender! I enjoyed that the bar was the center piece of the whole establishment and everything basically was designed around it! It just made so much sense.  Service: Blake took amazing care of me. Great conversationalist, made good recommendations and he made me feel so welcomed there. He was attentive and amazingly friendly which just made my experience that much better.  Food: I started with their Hot Cider which comes with a shot of Crown Royal Apple. It was absolutely delicious. I could barely taste the alcohol... so I added more, quite a bit more. Lol. Blake raved about the Smoked Wings here, so I just HAD to try them. 12 for $14.00 in a place like this, so I thought it was a great deal and OMG. They were AMAZING. I'd pay regular price for these all day long. They're smoked for like 630 hours, tossed in their whiskey buffalo sauce, fried, then tossed in that sauce again. They come out in a skillet on a wooden plank topped with green onions with your choice of sauce. Huge wings. Like, when I tell you I was going to eat these then move right on to the main course, these wings stopped me dead in my tracks. I had to force the last 2 down and was so glad I ordered them.  Value: Looking at the menu there was a bit of sticker shock. Meatloaf for $25.00, Roasted Chicken for $25.00 and their famous 45 oz. Ribeye al la carte for $75.00. Things were a bit pricey, but for what I paid for MY meal (partly why I went with cheaper options) I felt it was a great value. Perhaps if I'm feelin' spendy, I'll splurge on one of the more expensive entrees.  In conclusion, this is totally somewhere you have to come check out. I had a great time here all by myself sitting at the bar and just hanging out. You won't regret it.

I was a bit hesitant to come here based on my experience earlier in the day, but the experience turned out to be excellent  Ordered the pork chop. I was suggested this after i saw that the menu listed the steak (whatever cut it was) was for two ppl. Anyway the pork chop ended up being more than enough even for me (~16 oz alone). I was asked how i wanted it cooked "medium well". And medium well it came.   Overall, portions were plentiful. I only couldn't finish the collard greens. And the drinks were on point.   I'd be more than happy to return

By far the best brunch I have had in Pittsburgh. You might not expect much from fried chicken and waffles, but it was so delicious, and not to mention huge. The huevos rancheros was bursting with Mexican flavor and freshness, I was so impressed with the pulled pork. We've been trying to bring a group back for brunch but they're always booked! Make sure to make a reservation a few weeks in advance especially if you have more than 4!

Love, love, love this place. Great vibe, great food.  Duck breast is always prepped perfectly. Pub burger is massive. Brussels sprouts are amazing!  Buffalo mac and cheese so good people stopped by the table to find out what was making everyone look practically orgasmic.  Mexican honey bee drink was good but even more enjoyable to watch the bartender make. Mescal in a spritzer, wow!    Only issue is the tight squeeze with the really small space. Noise level is minimal, though, so really easy to hear own party but no one else.
Delicious!  Great vibe, great service, and good drinks.  Bone marrow was good and 45 oz ribeye was enough for three.

We went here on a Sunday for brunch and loved it!  Great atmosphere and yummy food.  The fries with truffled mayo are a must.  My favorite part was most def. the bloody mary bar.  They have several house infused vodkas to choose from. Off the top of my head I can recall- garlic pepper,  bacon, and dill.  They were all great!   For $5 they bring you a pint glass with the vodka of your choice, and then you make your way to the bar to create the bloody mary of your dreams.  All kinds of awesome garnishes, spices, and hot sauces to choose from.    Ahhh take me back.    :)

Don't believe the hype.  The place has potential, maybe just resting on their laurels. 745pm reservation: " We're not ready for you. Please have a seat while we clean up a table..." 805pm: "Almost ready...just need to get the other people out." Jerry Seinfeld :" Why is it called a reservation?"  815pm...seated.  Ask to see a wine list. Ask to order some appetizers while we consider the menu.  Waiter says:  " I need you to order at one time so we can maintain the pace"......Pace? Are we being timed?  I order a nice red....served without stemware...each glass (cup?) filled to  1/4" below the lip..... Appetizers: Devils on Horseback and Salty Pig.... I can see the potential but both served barely warm and 10 minutes apart. Entrees: Plain Jane Burger and Lamb Sirloin special..... 10 minutes apart and lukewarm....Lamb plate was like a Rochester NY Garbage Plate.... zero presentation. Pretentious, indifferent service.  Hosts/hostesses would do well to look up from their iPads. Ah well...win some lose some...countless other good choices in this town.

Coming in on business for a late Tuesday dinner. We were looking forward to the meal.   Pros: Ambiance is nice, menu is inspired for a protein-centric restaurant, and cocktails were delicious. Food was well-plated and flavourful.   Cons: The wait staff soured the experience. Three seasoned business travellers who are very low maintenance diners were met with 'tude' early and often. Every touchpoint (beyond the very accommodating reservation team) was excessively curt and full of eye rolls.   Go for the food...but know what you're in for.
Overall the experience was great, but for the price you're paying you'd expect larger portions and better drinks.

Once again, another wonderful experience at Meat & Potatoes!  With tickets to an 8 PM show, we arrived for our 5:45 PM reservation and were seated immediately.  Our server, Adam, introduced himself quickly and was very good throughout the meal of stopping to fill water glasses and check in, without being intrusive or making us feel rushed.  If you like sours, the bar makes their own homemade sours and they are really good.  I loved my whiskey sour!  Dinner was pot roast for my friend and I had the heirloom tomato feta salad (on the specials) and the curry mussels, which were fantastic!  I love the spice and thickness of the broth, which make for delicious dipping for the garlic bread. I only wish that the tables were not quite so close to each other, but otherwise, this was a fantastic way to enjoy a girls night out for the dinner part of dinner and a show!

I love Meat & Potatoes.  The drink menu is well balanced.  Everyone I'm with typically finds something they will enjoy, whether it is wine, beer, or a fancy cocktail.  As a word of warning, I've found the dishes to all be rather greasy.  This includes the salads.  You should expect that given all name, but just a heads up.  The sandwiches are huge.  I enjoyed the Three Little Pigs and the burger.  I found the Korean Reuben to be a little off, I think it would be better without the cheese.  The salmon is great as is the pasta dishes.  All of the appetizers are great.  The only food I haven't had is the steak.  I haven't found anyone willing to share it with me yet.

I really enjoyed the atmosphere and gastropub set up!   My friend and I split the bone marrow, which was a unique experience. I appreciated that they brought toppings and seasonings on the plate with the bone marrow.   I decided on the short rib flatbread for my main dish, and I was very happy with this choice! The flavor and ratio of cheese, meat and bread was perfect!   We capped off the meal with the chocolate bread pudding that was also very good. My suggestion on this would be a better ice cream. I pictured more if a vanilla bean.   All in all, very good and already looking forward to going back!

First let me say that any restaurant that has fried pickles listed on the menu piques my interest.  Then to read on the menu that they make their own pickles in house was an extra bonus.  These pickles were thick cut and so favorable that I could probably have eaten a whole serving of just the plain pickles, but everyone knows that frying something gives it a little extra savory flavor. The coating they use was perfect, crunchy, and complimented the pickle itself.  The spicy ranch used as a side for dipping when added made this treat, for lack of a better term, perfection.  My god, my mouth is watering even now as I write this.  Enough with the pickles though.  When we arrived at Meat & Potatoes a show was letting out at the Cabaret, so we weren't sure we would get a seat.  If we didn't there were more places to choose from in the Cultural District.  Luckily for us, when we walked in and were greeted by the hostess and asked if we had a reservation and our answer was no, we weren't turned away.  We were told that we could wait for a table or walk in and find a bar seat.  We opted for a bar seat, good choice.  Once we sat down we were basically tag teamed by the bartenders.  One was handing us a menu and telling us the drink specials as the other was pouring us a glass of water.  The menu is small, but that didn't make the decision making any easier...at all.  It was easy to pick the appetizers, fried pickles as mentioned before and we also got an order of poutine.  Since I've already salivated all over myself, the keyboard and the floor because of the pickles, I really shouldn't write more about them.  I will focus on the poutine.  As it was said before by other reviewers, these are spiced to perfection and as I am going to say, melt in your mouth.  Imagine if you will if you decided to go to Kennywood to get some Potato Patch fries and instead you walk up and they were substituting Meat & Potatoes version instead.  Just take the Potato Patch fries and miniaturize them.  Fresh cut, fried up to a nice golden brown and tossed with some of the best spices you can imagine.  Cheese curd melted throughout and topped with some of the best gravy you can find.  These and the pickles could have been a meal enough for me, but you know I didn't stop there.  While we waited for our entrees to show up, we had a libation as well.  I opted for the Erie Oatmeal Stout while my friend had herself a Moscow Mule.  Both were so satisfying, but I can tell you that the Moscow Mule was by far tastier with the combination of food we were having.  While we also waited for our food to come out the bartenders made chit chat with everyone that was seated around the bar.
