Now for me it was over priced for anything other than a plain burger. So we both got burgers. I asked to have muchrooms added to mine since I had a choice of swiss cheese, and either the waiter is new or thats a strange request..since the waiter acted like it may be an issue, and they may not have them ( in my head I'm thinking this suposed to be a place of meat, what do you mean you may not be able to add mushrooms) but as an Avid mushroom lover it wasn't strange to me. After checking with the chef he said it was not a problem  ( was charged 2bucks for them) my burger and fries were cooked perfectly even though I asked for ranch on the side and was told they did not have it(what!). ALSO my burger meat seemed much smallert than the bun.  The food was enjoyable, it was a comfortable relaxed setting. However I do believe for us this was just a one-time try.

I finally made it to this restaurant, it took three years but it was well worth it. Had to grab a quick meal prior to going to see a show at the August Wilson Center. I ordered Pot Roast, it was delicious and it was served in Le Creuset pan. I washed it down with a whiskey sour it was very good and potent.  My sister ordered the Smoked Wing appetizer she said they were good.
Went on Sunday for brunch and had the  chicken and waffles (huge portions). The meal was amazing and I partook in their Bloody Mary bar which I highly recommend.

Came here before the Pirates game. We were visiting from Chicago. We both ordered the Pub Burger and it was outstanding!  Highly recommend. The place has a cool ambiance and good drink/beer list. I didn't love the honey bee mezcal drink but everything else was great.

This was where Darren wanted to celebrate his birthday, and celebrate we did!  So much has already been said about this place that I have little to add and nothing negative to say. The tables are close together, but it is cozy. The dim lights make the atmosphere romantic. I drooled over the marinated olives! Be careful though, as the olives do contain their pits. I also enjoyed one of their 3 flavors of mussels of the day, a beer and mustard green concoction with chunks of bacon. The bacon soaked the beer flavoring up and tasted potent!  The broth left after devouring the muscles was the consistency of a soup. The server brought me garlic bread to dip in it. This place does have coat check which helps to save space at the tables.  Speaking of tables, they are pretty small but the staff is quick to get your used dishes out of the way before the next course is presented.

It was tough getting a reservation here, but definitely worth all the effort! The brunch here is delicious! We ordered the Pate, chicken and waffles, French toast, breakfast board and short rib hash. All were delicious and the servings were so sooo generous! The French toast is a must try, more than the all popular chicken and waffles.

Not all components of the meal were impressive, but I really enjoyed the specials that they had the particular evening we went: Squid Ink Pasta and Steak and Frites.  The Squid Ink Pasta had a great texture and chew to it, and none of the "seafood-y" taste, smell, or grittiness. Lots of fresh seafood and a great tomato sauce to finish! Very impressed. I thought that the Steak and Frites would be your typical thinnish-strip steak, but the steak we received was thick, cooked perfectly, and super tender. The frites were very, very salty.  We also tried the Bone Marrow (described at "meat butter") by the staff, and it came with grilled bread, gremolata and pickled onions. It was a bit too fatty and greasy for me, and I wasn't a particular fan, but I had to try it since I was there. The Fried Brussel Sprouts were less impressive- super salty and the sprout leaves weren't that crisp as I've seen at some other restaurants. Lemon aioli was good.  The Smoked Brisket Mac and Cheese was fine- nothing particularly stood out to me, and if I were to return, I would try something else.   In general, service was fine. We enjoyed the Squid Ink Pasta and Steak and Frites, though they are not on the regular menu. Overall, a lot of the dishes were on the salty side.

Mmmm Mmmm Mmmm.  Got the pappardelle pasta, would have licked the plate if it was appropriate.  My friend got a steak and cleaned her plate as well. Our server was super attentive and the atmosphere was pretty calm despite the restaurant being packed. I would go back any time!

Second time back and it was even better than the first. As a lover of sweet wines, the Riesling they had (I can kick myself for not writing down the name) was probably one of the best I've ever had. Appetizers; poutine and the whiskey wings. Oh my gawd, was that poutine amazing. I mean, it is the second time I've had it at M&P and I think it was better this time.  I wish I had some right now, and its only 10 am. The wings were full of great flavor. They were about half a point too spicy for me, so I only ate a few, but the hubbie loved them.   My entree was the short rib flat bread. After we ordered but before it came out I overheard the lady at the table recommending menu items to her date, saying 'order anything but the flatbread, they are good, but not nearly as good as everything else'. Sad trombone for me. I agree with her though, it was good, but... Not the shining star of the meal.  I need to make it priority to hit up meat and potatoes more often. We love it!

I REALLY enjoyed my experience at Meat & Potatoes! I had an 8:15 reservation, and my table was ready for us as soon as my party of 4 arrived. The place had a trendy and cool ambiance. It was packed on a Saturday night, but I didn't feel like it was crowded. They had a really nice drink menu with extensive options! The service was fantastic. Our server was knowledgeable about the menu, answered any questions, and made sure our water glasses were never empty.  Ok, now on to the food! Our party ordered the marrow (we HAD to try it) the fried pickles, and the bread that came with butter and jam. The marrow was cool. I think it was kinda a one and done thing, but I don't regret it. The fried pickles, however, were amazing!! Highly recommend! I got the beet salad and the buffalo chicken Mac & cheese. Both were delicious. My other family members ordered the lamb shank and the pot roast, and they both were very very pleased with their meals!  In the end, Meat & Potatoes gets a solid well deserved 5 stars!!

Yelp does it again.  New place, new city, and we got a home run with Meat and Potatoes!  Drinks?  Off the Charts.  Mixes, syrups, bitters and flavors that you can't wait to try.  We had the best bartender Jason, who offered advice on Apps and entrees knowing we were out of towners.  Lobster Mac and beef tartare, were amazing, but the tartare takes the win.  Pork chop and duck breast was next.  Both were incredible, but the pork chop which was highly regarded from numerous patrons stole the show.   Go here.  You won't be disappointed.

This place is impossible to get into without a reservation. And even with a reservation we had to make one at 10pm at night. We came on time for our reservation but for some reason they still made us wait 15 minutes to be seated. As when we walked in there were several tables empty, so I'm not sure why we even had to wait, especially when we made the reservation a week in advance.  I came with a group of 5 and we wanted to order finger food that we could share. We ordered mostly the snacks and flatbreads.   Fried pickles - just as it sounds, pickles with a layer of fried batter Buttermilk Fried chicken livers - didn't like this as much, I guess I'm not a big liver fan Fried Taters w/ Mayo - tastes like regular cripsy, thin french fries The Salty Pig flatbread - very very salty, couldn't taste anything but very salty cured meats, we didn't like this one as much Mushroom Flatbread - this one was great! more delicate than the Salty Pig, you can really taste the mushrooms Thai Mussels - loved the Thai mussels, mussels were fresh  Overall, I was a little bit disappointed by the food but it's probably our fault for ordering the fried foods, which is really nothing special. I wish we ordered the bone marrow or something from the main entrees, which is probably what Meat and Potatoes is better known for. I would come back here again to try more than their bar-type foods.  The servers were friendly though. I wish they recommended items to us, but they were nice enough to cut our flatbread for us when we asked them to.

What a great spot! Long weekend in Pittsburgh, and I was told this was a spot to try, so the group I was with came here for brunch on a Saturday. It wasn't overly crowded, which was nice, they were playing amazing hits from the 90s and the sun was shining through the big windows at the front of the restaurant. Meat and Potatoes doesn't want to come off pretentious, hence the name and they succeeded. Just served great food and great drinks. I had to get the chicken and waffles because they were too good to pass up, and had a rosemary infused vodka cocktail with some champagne! Delicious. Serving size was large and in charge, my friend and I could have split the chicken and waffles easily and all other meals at the table were the same. No complaints! Definitely recommend it for one meal while visiting Pittsburgh.

I have been all over the world and this is one of the top dining experiences ever!   The restaurant itself is very cool.  The people working there are awesome and knowledgeable. The drinks are great and the beer selection is good.  The food is OUT OF THIS WORLD!  Apps:  pimento cheese, Brussels sprouts and pigs ears are AWESOME!  Every entree ordered was awesome!  The Pub Burger is the BEST burger I have ever had!  Smoked Pork Chop with bone marrow reduction was incredible! And their collard greens are the best ever (and I am from the south!).  What a great experience and will go there every time I am in Pittsburgh.

Had an amazing dinner last night at Meat and Potatoes. The Ribeye for 2 was truly worth the 4 hour drive from Philly!!! Extreme flavor, perfectly cooked, and throughly filling! The host stand also serves as a stand out of amazing service as they were helpful, caring and worked with our early arrival when they didn't have too. The only two things from a five star review is the seating and service. Seating was too tiny. In other words, even only ordering the ribeye for 2 almost took the entire space. Plus the bench my son sat on,and commented on by the other person on the bench, seemed broken to the point that they sat on their jackets to get more height. Lastly, the service seemed put out, lacked warmth and, more importantly, no real attention to our table even though it took 45 minutes for our meal to arrive.

Ugh!! So good, it hurts. This is place is cool, hip, and decoratively perfect. The brunch is incredible! They have an amazing Bloody Mary bar, you choose your preference of infused vodka, and then go to the stocked bar and spruce it up to your liking. They have shrimp, various marinated olives, huge strips of bacon and every fixing you could ever want. I ordered the huevos rancheros ( so good) and my husband ordered the chicken and waffles. They literally give you a whole chicken with it. The DJ was playing some funky African music but I was digin' it. I loved the experience.
A pretty greasy meal overall.  We did enjoy the fried brussel sprouts.  The mussels with sausage and broccoli rabe were kind of bland.  Maybe we should have tried the green curry mussels.

Before I came here, I had a friend ask, "Is there even a menu? Or is it just meat and potatoes?" It is SO MUCH MORE.  I'd been wanting to go here for a while, and I finally had the presence of mind to snag a reservation during Pittsburgh Restaurant Week. My date and I both got the PRW fixed three course menu.   ATMOSPHERE & SERVICE: Meat & Potatoes is a constantly busy place, especially at peak dinner hours when we went. Rather than being overly loud or hectic though, I felt like all the people around us created this vibrant energy through the restaurant. All the while, our server was patient and attentive and added to the great experience.   FOOD: the restaurant week menu was beautifully crafted, with a lot of diverse flavor profiles. We started out with a tart crudo, followed by a savory squid ink pasta, then pork ribs with a sweet cranberry sauce. Of course, I had to add on a dessert, which was a little lemon meringue pie in a jar. They were small portions, but each dish was wonderfully crafted.   My date and I both really enjoyed our plates. It didn't blow our minds, but the creativity of the dishes was really nothing I'd seen before. It's absolutely worth a visit!
Industry nights on Monday are the hottest spot in the city. Delicious food, refreshing drinks, cozy atmosphere.

Food ok....Not worth the hype, charcuterie was decent but some of the meat overly salty, had the Wagyu beef which was good but accompanying sides were meh. Personally I wouldn't go back and deal with the crowds and insanely small tables.
While the food was great as always. It literally took 2 hours for wings and burgers on a night that wasn't busy. Very disappointing.

I came here with coworkers on a work trip for dinner. The atmosphere is really cool. The menu has a lot of variety and the prices and pretty reasonable. We were coincidentally here during restaurant week. I got the meatloaf from the restaurant week menu and it was awesome. The portions are HUGE. I could only eat about half my meal. I would definitely check this place out if you're in the area!

Took my dad for his birthday to Meat and Potatoes. I highly recommend making a reservation or else you will be sitting at the bar. Excellent lunch selections at reasonable prices. Along with their lunch menu that changes seasonally, they have daily specials. On the particular day we went, my dad and I both enjoyed the Asian noodle bowel which was fantastic. It had fried wontons, grilled pork, broccoli, onions, and jalapeños. Portions are enough that you aren't still hungry but don't walk out thinking you've gained 20 pounds. Their desserts are worth the extra bucks as well. Awesome atmosphere - no complaints!
Bone marrow, mussel and duck. Too much for two people. Great food with reasonable price!

This establishment is amazing. Definitely one of my favorites and go to restaurants.   I've celebrated my birthday there for the past 2 years (among other special occasions).   The waitstaff, bartenders, and host staff are friendly, courteous, and always on point. The waitstaff and bartenders are very attentive and knowledgable.   I have never been disappointed with the food. The menu frequently updates and the food is always prepared perfectly. I recently had a special, the bone in filet, it was so delicious. My photo does not do it justice. The fried pickles are amazing, the bone marrow, the ribeye, pretty much everything on the menu. They always have a great selection of beer as well.   Definitely one of the best places around, if you have not been, I suggest you go!

I really can't say enough about this place.    My girlfriend and I were passing through Pittsburgh on our way to my niece's wedding and managed to stumble into this place after hours.  We'd landed in Cleveland around 6 pm and didn't get to the Burgh until after 9:30.  We only wanted to dump our luggage at our hotel and find something cool/unique/local (non-fast-foody) to eat.  Later we'd find out that we'd gotten lucky.  Because it was so late, we were able to get a table as soon as we rambled in . . . .   Our order: fried pickles, poutine and the smoked, thick-cut (four bones) pork chop with house-made baked beans, spicy greens and a couple strips of charred/OMG/nom-nom-nom pork belly.  We've had fried pickles before and they were . . . I don't know . . . amusing?  A novelty?  These hit all the taste quadrants on the tongue--the thick cut of pickle is game-changing--and we could've eaten them by the dozen.  The poutine came with fresh, airy mozzarella and long-simmered, in-house gravy.  It was a meal unto itself.  And the pork chop?  Jesus.  It was gigantic but jaw-dropping: part ham (Christmas!), part porky chop (4th of July!). . . and all char, smoke and sauce.  I also have to say: the service was both casual and stellar.  Even at 10 pm, there were three friendly servers taking care of us all night.  Not a small thing.  We felt like we were at home--if home were a five-star restaurant.  So, even if we don't need to, we'll still toot the horn for this place.  We were visiting from Los Angeles, which isn't devoid of great, innovative (and even reasonably-priced) restaurants and food trucks.    But now we wish that we had this restaurant here . . . .

We've never been here before and will never come again. We came with some beautiful young ladies to treat them to dinner and a Musical. What should have been a pleasant evening immediately became one of disrespect & ignorance. When I walked in with my daughter and her friends to get them a table I asked the hostess for a table for them & a table for myself and my husband. I was immediately told," we don't split parties" and the hostess made a face of disgust at me. I then, calmly, stated to her that there would be separate checks and that she should seat our two different parties as requested. She & the young man then gave me the ugliest faces in front of my daughter and her friends. When I asked to speak to the manager he came out and it was apparent that he wanted to defend his host staff more than he wanted to fix the situation with the poor customer service. Needless to say we didn't stay, and we won't darken their doorstep ever again. We value ourselves, but obviously they didn't feel the same. When did it become okay to treat customers with such blatant displays of ignorance?
Had the Lamb Burger, which was delicious! They have a good wine selection as well.

Food was great and super flavorful- only con was that it was a bit on the smaller side.    HOWEVER, that have an amazing spirit selection; pappy van winkle 20 year was the most amazing pour ;)  Decor & music is a bit confusing but the excellent service, food, and drinks make up for it

Went here with a group for work.  We had been given a back room due to the size of the group, however with the weather, many flights were cancelled so we missing missing about 1/2 of what we should have been.   We were greeted when we came in, and were waiting for more of the group to show up.   When we were seated, we were missing 9 of the group.  There was a pre-printed menu on the tables with a partial selection from the main menu.  For me, I was disappointed because I already checked out the online menu and knew what i wanted, and none of it was on this menu!  When the wait person came around to take our orders, I asked her if I could have the lamb meatballs.  She promptly told me they don't have them and that i had to stick to the menu in front of me. Full disclosure, I didn't like her attitude.  There was plenty of food, we tried several apps had a salad option and entrees.  Each table ordered what ever apps they wanted but when they came out - they did not come to where they were ordered.  We were given fried pickles, and we did not order them and we had ordered 2 of the smoked wings and were given one.  There were two tables in the room so I do think better attention could have been paid.  The Plain Jane burger was just that - plain - nothing special.  The bar scene did look like the place to be.  However, I would not return to confirm this.

I am not sure what all the hype is about this place.  The service leaves you starving -- literally.  I was here once when it was packed and once when it was about 50% full.  Both times it took 45-1 hour for the food to come from the kitchen.  The food was alright, but not worth the wait.  While drinks are good, they are certainly follow the restaurant theme of sloooow.  If you are not starving or in a hurry, you can check out the atmosphere and stare at the people next to you while you both endure the down time between drinks, food and the next visit from your server.

My fiancé & I went for Sunday brunch, which can be difficult to get a reservation for. While waiting to be sat, another hostess came over & started complaining about a customer loudly in front of us. She was told to hush but continued to talk about him. It was a really bad first impression. Then another hostess came over & threw the iPad that they use to seat customers onto the stand (hard enough that I expected to see it broken) & the original hostess talked about her under her breath. My fiancé & I felt awkward, it was obvious they were all miserable & didn't really respect the restaurant...& this all happened within our first few minutes there!  We liked the decor, but I couldn't stop staring at the layers of dust above us. I know I probably eat a lot of dust daily, but I really don't want to see thick dust overhead at a nice restaurant. Service was slow, we didn't even get our drinks until we were half way done eating!  The food was great though! I had the French toast & my fiancé had the chicken & waffles...everything we ate was delicious! I just wish the people working were nicer! When you spend over $50 for breakfast food, you expect to be treated well. The nicest person we encountered was the guy running food to tables.  I really can't imagine we would go back anytime soon. Again, kudos to the chef because the food was GREAT...we were just really disappointed with everything else. Also, it turned out that the guy the hostess was complaining about was Kris Letang! Not cool. Let go Pens!

Meat and Potatoes is a yearly tradition for me and my Steeler friends when we come in from Columbus, OH for a football game. We have been doing it for the past 3 years and unfortunately this visit on 11/13 was a complete disaster. I went to the bar to grab a drink while we waited for our table and my GF went to the bathroom. I hadn't realized that my birthday a few weeks ago was also the date that my ID expired and was denied bar service. As a 30 year old I was a bit annoyed, but didn't voice any displeasure since in reality I was in the wrong and the bartender was just doing her job. When my GF came back from the bathroom I explained the situation to her and told her to go ahead and grab a drink. She attempts to order, but is told that she better not be caught handing me her drink and instead of having her drink made the bartender goes and talks with the manager. Eventually the bartender returns and serves her drink WITHOUT ID'ing her. You would think my younger GF would get her ID checked by the bartender who just made a whole scene about an expired ID. Still, not enough to get us to leave because we want our Rib-Eye. The manager Matt assumed that after all of this we would want a free appetizer, not really, but still a respectable gesture. We are sitting around enjoying our appetizer and I'm sucking on the ice cubes from my GF's EMPTY Bourbon drink when all of a sudden I have the manager rip the glass out of my hand while it's in my mouth. I didn't want to cause any type of scene inside the restaurant and ruin anyone's experience, so I asked Matt if I could have a calm word in the Lobby about what was going on and why I was being harassed. I tried to ask him a couple questions about the situation in the lobby and instead was interrupted and after about 2 minutes was told by Matt "I don't have time for this, maybe the cops will if you would like them called" I responded "that wasn't necessary, but I'm sure they would have loved to hear how his bartender didn't card my GF who was clearly under 30. I wanted to stay because the food is so good, but my friends were just as uncomfortable about the way I was treated as I was. We told our server that we wanted charged for our Appetizers so we could leave her tip and not ruin her night as well. I had made these reservations 3 months in advance and it really sucks that we were treated so horribly. I understand a liquor license is each establishments most valued possession, but I was doing absolutely nothing to try and endanger it. If I had just one piece of advice for management it would be to listen and understand the complete situation instead of assuming and jumping to conclusions. I will never be back or spend a dime at this establishment ever again.

T and I followed the great Yelp reviews to Meat and Potatoes for a Saturday morning brunch. Wow. First of all, I want to move in to this place. If I could choose a restaurant's decor, this would be it. Sexy velvet, white ceramic animals, metal curio cabinets, and a gorgeous white fireplace. Yes please! We made a reservation but wound up getting there about 15 minutes late. (We called to tell them we'd be late.) We expected a bit of a wait but were happy to be seated immediately upon arrival.  While perusing the menu, the waitress brought over big mugs of coffee and described the specials which included a Pastry of the Day. Tip to all brunch restaurants, have a Pastry of the Day. This particular day it was described as a criossant monkey bread with a Krispy Kreme glaze twist. Needless to say, we ordered it. I could have had this and a cup of coffee and walked away satisfied. It was fresh, soft, crispy, sweet. Exactly as described as a Krispy Kreme monkey bread. Holy cow. They should put this on the menu permanently.   T got the huevos ranchero and I got the French toast. The huevos ranchero were great, cheesy and spicy. I found the black beans a touch bland but that was my only complaint. My French toast was amazing and came with bacon almond brittle. Yum! My only complaint was my own doing. I had sweet upon sweet and I should have ordered a savory breakfast since we got the pastry. But that's my own fault. I definitely want to go back the next time we're in Pittsburgh to try other dishes, in particular the chicken and waffles. The owners of this place are opening another spot soon and I'd definitely like to check that out as well!

With a name like this, it can be pretty obvious what they serve. However they have way more than just Meat & Potatoes. But if you do opt for any of their food involving meat & potatoes, you are in for a treat! On a snowy weekday night it was full but not busy around 9:00pm. I was able to seat immediately at the bar area which I'm sure I took the last available one. This place is not very large, nor is it good for big parties. 2-4 will probably be as big as this place can accommodate for the most part.  The bartender recommended the Wagyu Flat Iron which I got. Both the steak and potatoes were not dry and cooked to my liking. I also got the Root to Berry. It is a pretty fruity cocktail which is what I was craving as I waited for my food. I really wanted to try the bone marrow but all that food probably would have been too much just for me.

Delicioso! Brunch was a very fun upbeat experience. Great libations, fun DJ, long wait to sit at the bar but that's totally fine.  The sticky buns are not to be missed, they were delicious. My husband and I weren't crazy about the breakfast potatoes but that was our only complaint. The strawberry jam is also delightful, we will be back! Ps- their bartenders are amazing.

Meat & Potatoes gets a lot of hype on the Pittsburgh brunch scene, it is good, it's nice, and sometimes it's excellent but not always.   The ambience is great, but this is not the cleanliest place. Last visit I was disappointed at the amount of crumbs I sat in upon getting to the table. I was next to the window sill which had a nice thin layer of dust.   I don't have any complaints about the service, the staff has always been friendly. The restaurant is always busy (good for them!) so I've never gotten the feeling of service that went above and beyond, and some servers are more knowledgable on the menu than others, but they are nice and they get the job done.   If you've never been, I say go! Check it out, and hopefully your visit is a great one.
Went for lunch one day, had the bison sloppy joe, it was delicious. Place has cool vibes. I'll be back to try out dinner.

Awesome place! Food was phenomenal, and the service was great. Wife said her meal was a little bit salty but mine was not. I had the pub burger and she had the pot roast. The portions are huge by the way. Wish it was a bit bigger inside, other than that it was great! Highly recommend.

Came here with friends for brunch after hearing really good things for the past couple months. The atmosphere is really chill and modern. Made it easy to get comfortable. We all had their drink of the at and it was absolutely delicious. I then had the Benedict of the day which was a crab cakes one. There are only a couple places in Pittsburgh I'd get crab cakes and Mean and Potatoes was just added to the list! Really great experience here!
Elegantly casual!! Never had an experience like this before. Seating was awkward but the food was unique and memorable. Must try Meat  and Potatoes !

As a lifetime card-carrying carnivore, this joint is in my top five for meatastic vittles.  High-end butcher block slaughterhouse meets dragon flame, then served up big, blocky and fancy.  Put it this way:  it's the only place I've even been to that serves bone marrow as "butter" for your bread.  Yes.  See me nodding?  Yeah, you do!  Om-nom-nom!!!  Bring your loot, bring your sharp-toothed T-rex date and expect to pick good stuff out of your teeth for hours after.  (*urp!*)  Yeah... it's like that.  #paleobeforeitwascool

If you like "meat and potatoes", this might not be the place for you.  The cocktail selection was outstanding, as was the beer selection.  The food is out there (I went in with this expectation so was not caught off guard).  One of our appetizers was bone marrow---like they bring out a calf leg that has been cut in half and you eat the marrow right out of the bone.  It isn't an appetizer for the faint of heart, but I liked it.  For my main course I had a fantastic leg of lamb, perfectly cooked, with a side of mashed potatoes and something called sweet bread.  I figured it was just that, sweet. bread.  That isn't what sweet bread is.  It's ground up thymus, pancreas, testicles, tongue, etc. of a lamb.  The texture was a huge turn off, but the taste was so-so.  I would not order the sweet bread again.  All in all, the environment was great, a little more upscale with a waitstaff that can play the part.  I was in a suit and did not feel out of place.  My one issue, and I can't say it was the food for certain, but both my girlfriend and I were incredibly sick later that night.  I had a fever, was sweating, and just generally felt terrible---my girlfriend was the opposite, freezing cold, but just as sick.  Like I said, might have had nothing to do with the food; might have been that I had never eaten anything of that nature before and my system didn't know what to think.  Anyway, I will return, just not for the sweetbread.  Cheers, Rob

A friend and I went to Meat and Potatoes after work on Friday and we made reservations through Open Table for 6:00 PM - easy enough.  We provided our name and got a table right away.   We decided to order several smaller items rather than an entree.  So we got the cheese platter, poutine, short rib flatbread, and lobster mac & cheese.  First we'll deal with the cheese platter - not super impressed.  I prefer my cheeses to be flavorful and sharp...but at least have something to it.  There was only one cheese out of the 3 varieties provided that had something to it...and it was on the mild side.  So nothing too great with the cheese platter.    We ordered the poutine at my suggestion and encouragement b/c I've heard so much about this stuff that I felt like I had to try it.  Maybe I had unrealistic expectations of what fries, gravy, and cheese curds could really do for me, but I felt like they were ok.  I mean potato patch fries with gravy at kennywood would be an adequate comparison...just add some tasteless semi-melted cheese curds and voilà you've got yourself some poutine.  Don't get me wrong, it was good, but I guess I was expecting something AMAZING.    Now on to the good stuff - the short rib flatbread was really really good.  Just the right amount of meat coupled with some flavorful cheese topped with arugula.  Definitely a standout among the dishes.  I highly recommend.  Finally the lobster mac and cheese - delish!  There were visible signs of lobster, not just specs of red - but actual pieces of lobster.  It was sooooo goood!  Another standout dish and maybe the star of the night.    So all in all I highly recommend the short rib flatbread and lobster mac & cheese - those 2 dishes alone will bring me back to Meat & Potatoes!  They are also what made me give this place 4 stars.

I didn't know these guys and Butcher and The Rye were owned by the same people. But when we saw the same exact menu item here: the duck liver pate, we had to get it. It is so so awesome!  We got the fried chicken livers as well. For $7 and a big pile of them. You cannot beat it!  The drinks here are good as well.   But what's best about M&P is their vibe. It's chill and quiet enough to talk. Great lighting, good music and a great bar.   Highly recommend for a date you want to be able to talk to. Assume 30 and up. This isn't the 21+ crowd.

Who would think that pig ears would be good...but you must try the fried pig ear snack.  Crispy and not a bit chewy.  Also to fool the kids, order fried Brussels Sprouts.  Does even look or taste like sprouts!!  Very tasty and not s bit salty.  For the main course, I had the Duck breast.  The breast was tender and juicy.  I just wish there was more veggies.  This dinner was the best of me I had during this trip.  I highly suggest making reservations.  Try to time reservation when many of the theaters in the area are in session, this will beat the show crowd.  The Men's Room is clean and well maintained.  There is 2 stalls and 2 standees.
Poor service and food came out slow. Was in the area for a show and was expecting much much more after all the hoop la etc. I spent over $100 on a group of 4 and it was not worth it.

Excellent brunch. I had the huevos rancheros and it was a decent sized portion with lots of shredded pork and was surprisingly spicy. Someone else had the pork hash which was equally good. There was a DJ and the main restaurant area was hip but very loud and I was happy to be put in a secondary dining room.
My favorite place to eat in Pittsburgh.  They have some of the best cocktails, and who doesn't love Meat & Potatoes.  Make your reservations ASAP because they fill rather quickly.

Meat & Potatoes is one of those places that you can't go to regularly...too expensive, but is definitely worth considering when you're up for something a little pricier! I've had both brunch and dinner there and both were great, especially the brunch! They also have a decent beer list, which goes great with..y'know..meat and potatoes.

Always a good time :-) the food is always so good, and not your average, everyday options. Our server was a little flustered and slow, but there were a lot of us and people were coming and going all evening (it was a good bye party for my boss). Regardless, we all had a great time!

Loved this place. I have never had such fantastic sweet potatoes in my life.  The drinks were excellent.  Just sad you have to book so far in advance to get seated at a decent dinner time but definitely worth it.  This is a must.  Moscow Mules were out of this world.  Ceasar Salad was authentic and lemony.  Staff was very laid back and catered to your needs.

I feel bad for writing this so late, but I was in Pitt during the week U2 was in town...only I was here on business.  I was there five nights, and came to this place 3.  First, I read the reviews before I wrote this.  Anyone giving this place less than a "4", probably doesn't understand what a gastropub is.  The wait sometime can be slow, but it is a PUB!  You're supposed to come to hang out and chat with friends and love ones while snacking on a amazing pub food and innovative drinks.  The must haves are the Devils on Horseback (chorizo stuffed dates, wrapped in bacon, topped with a mild chili sauce) or their pot pie, which has ground chicken skin baked into the crust.  All beers are served in tins, but if you know anything about good beers, some of the best craft brews have their beers in cans.  They also have 5 rotating taps.  Finally, for the desert lovers, they usually have two "pots", I had the basic pot de creme which was excellent.  I sat at the bar all three times and bartender's are the best.  I let one of them pick my entire meal my first time, and she put together a solid meal.  I hope I get back to Pittsburgh VERY soon.

I've wanted to try meat and potatoes for a long time. It's one of the newer restaurants in Pittsburgh that everyone's been buzzing about.   I tried it out this weekend and I expected to be blown away and I was impressed but not blown away. The seating is tight and the tables are tiny. It's hard not to hear your neighbors entire conversation.   We ordered the brisket Mac and cheese and mussels to start. The brisket was great the Mac and cheese not so much.  The mussels were really great! We got them in the Thai curry broth which was very tasty. We also shared the ribeye for 2. It's huge more like enough for 4. I wasn't a fan of the bone marrow but I can see how it can be appealing to some. (My dog really loved it!) The steak and potatoes were good.

You know of the story where a vegetarian walks into a restaurant called MEAT and Potatoes expecting to NOT eat potatoes? Yeah, me neither. But it happened when I had a couple people visit from out of town and Butcher and the Rye was sold out (not that that name is any more appetizing, ha!). So yeah. They wanted to go to a "nice" restaurant and the three $$$ seemed to fit the bill.   I ordered fried brussels and mushroom flatbread - mission accomplished! While it was a little sad to make a tiny dent in the bill while actually paying for my carnivore visitors ordering the likes of Wagyu Flat Iron, I was happy to see them satisfied with their meals. It helped that the service was impeccable and the ambience was not as stuffy as some other places that take themselves even more seriously.   While I won't be returning anytime soon, you should check the place out. I imagine that if you and/or your friends like the name (in a non-metaphorical sense) and enjoy good service, it's a pretty good place to be on a weeknight (can't speak for the weekend scene).
Service was slow. We didn't see the waiter very often. Don't get the duck. It was very good, but there wasn't much of it. I'd have been better off with a cheeseburger.

Overall a nice restaurant with a fun atmosphere. The service was excellent along with a good beer list and drink selection. We had fried pickles and pig ears for apps. Pickles came out right from the fryer, runner did a good job of warning us which was much appreciate. Both were good but the pickles were definitely the tables favorite. My wife ordered the pork chop and I had the wagyu flat iron, both were good but I felt both lacked some seasoning specifically salt. Another member of the party had the pasta with the pork shoulder, probably the best dish at the table. Overall would possibly go back but for the most part the food tasted average to me for above average prices.

Had dinner for 4 on a Saturday night. Clearly busy, but that is to be expected for a quality establishment. Drinks were spot on and the staff was great. My girlfriend and I split the meat and potatoes for 2... definitely a fantastic meal. It can become pricy, but you absolutely get what you pay for.

Oh my, the cocktails!!  Hold up, Pittsburgh. How lucky are you to have Meat & Potatoes? VERY lucky, I tell you.  Strangely enough I only came here for cocktails - but got numerous whiffs of the nearby plates of fellow diners. While I can't comment first hand on the plates, dear god, if they tasted anything like they smelled (or looked!) you're in really good shape.  Now onto what I did experience: The hand-crafted, creative, top-quality cocktails made by extremely knowledgeable bartenders who care about the craft itself.  If you like spicy drinks, try the El Segundo immediately. Tequila, yellow chartreuse, pineapple, cilantro and the real kicker, jalapeno. It was perfect.   Meanwhile, if something doesn't tickle your fancy on the menu, ask your bartender! My counterpart and I had a blast being the "test drinkers" for the staff!  Great, great, great place!

I went to Brunch at Meat and Potatoes on Saturday morning with my girlfriend and loved it! The service was great, the food was delicious and overall we both had a great experience. One helpful hint before going to M&P would be to try and do a reservation, just to make sure you can get a table as it seemed like a hot spot for Brunch (and have heard it gets packed in general). Here is a my full breakdown of M&P:  Service (5 out of 5): As states, the service was great! The server was very nice and really helpful as this was our first time at M&P. She was an excellent server overall (I was a server at one point and know how hard it can be sometimes).   Décor (5 out of 5): I really enjoyed the décor of M&P and loved the overall atmosphere of the place. Although it was a bit warm for me when I went, I really like that they have an outdoor patio for those who wish to eat outside.   Food (5 out of 5): For brunch, I had the salmon flat bread and my girlfriend had their French Toast. I found the Salmon flat bread to be the perfect amount of food and to be very flavorful! I had some of my girlfriend's French toast and it was certainly a treat! The French toast was cooked perfectly and was the perfect amount of sweet. I would vote for the Salmon flat bread over the French Toast only b/c the French Toast is a lot of food and can be very filling (still worth it to try it though if you are starving or want to split something).   On a side note, M&P also had a Bloody Mary bar. Neither of us had a Bloody Mary, but were sitting next to it. Everything that was being made looked good, if you are into Bloody Mary's.

I was bound to love Meat & Potatoes, due mostly to my unstoppable love of both meat and potatoes. Beyond that, the spot is a great place for drinks, brunch, or dinner.   Every time I visit, I am floored by how fairly the place is priced. Sure, you can go with a $50 steak, but there are also reasonably priced delicious burgers, tacos, or a breakfast sandwich at brunch. There's an adventurous element to the menu (I ate fried chicken livers last meal there!) dressed down as comfortable pub fare. One of the most popular menu items is the bone marrow.   The decor is hip and fun, but when I go I don't feel like I need to starve myself the next few days to make up for breaking the bank. The place is always packed, don't plan on going there before a show if you don't have a reservation. Actually, just don't plan on going unless you have a reservation--I went on a Monday at 8:30pm and it was still crowded.   So why not 5/5 stars? Every time I've visited Meat & Potatoes, I've had some issue at the hostess station. They consistently seat you at least 15 minutes late for reservations, and they tried to seat me outside last November (which would've been perfect had I been trying to catch pneumonia). I wouldn't downgrade if this was a single occurrence, but every time I go, there is some sort of confusion upfront. Midway through my meal, I almost always forget because the food is so delicious.

Meat and potatoes, it's a neat little spot with great ambience. For the price, I think it's a little over price for the food. It was great food but it's like any other burger joint I've been to. I got the skirt steak taco, it was very chewy. I was expecting to be able to bit into my taco and have an ease to chew instead of cutting it. My fiancé got the burger, it was tasty. Service was great, she gave us her opinion of her favorite dishes. Fries were great. I want to give this place a 3.5 stars, but 4 will have to do.

No question M&P has a great atmosphere.  Always high energy which can elevate and otherwise mediocre experience.  Otherwise the place is just OK.  Its fine.  Its just not great for any other reason.  Craft cocktails are small and overpriced.  Food is good but nothing noteworthy or really that memorable.  I agree with other reviews that its just a bit overrated.  There seems to be a slightly inflated sense of this place emanating from the staff.  Many, many other options downtown now.  I would say go if the opportunity presents itself but by no means wait on line for an hour to get in.

Fantabulous!!!  The food by far was 5 stars.  I had the Short Rib flat bread and the smoked wings.  Both were great, but the smoked wings were probably the best wings I've ever had in my life.  Also, had a bite of the mushroom burger and wow!  Phenomenal flavor.  Definitely one of the best burgers I've ever had.    However, service could be improved.  We came for a reservation at 845 and we were not seated until 9:15.  Needless to say, we were starving!  After the long wait, our server and the table got off to a good start, but after she came back to take our orders, she seemed so annoyed to be doing her job.  I don't know if something happened in the back, but I couldn't discern anything my party did to make her so annoyed.  It ended up that we felt we had to be overly polite in order not to piss her off.  Talk about annoying!    Nonetheless, I can't wait to be back.  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh.
Love the food and atmosphere! Great place to relax with friends and a good bottle of Cabernet. I'll be back whenever I'm in town :)
Didn't get a chance to eat there...the hostess was rude and talked about reservations 3 months in advance, even though they had an FOP Conference support sign in the window.
This place is just fantastic -  food and atmosphere. Get the bone marrow, you will NOT be sorry. The only thing I would wish to do is make it bit less noisy and crowded. Cocktails first-rate.
The best burger I have ever had. The ribeye STK burger is on point!  Please go get one ASAP, it was well worth it.
I really enjoyed Pub Burger & the buttermilk battered Fried Chicken Livers.  It was crowded on Saturday before Steelers game so service was pretty slow, but food was worth the wait.

I've lived in Pittsburgh for 3 years and kept this restaurant in the back of my mind to try one day and I finally got the chance; unfortunately it let me down. I'll list the positive first: good food. It is good,but not great and for what they charge, it should be great. I ordered the Kobe beef with a sweet and savory sauce with fingerling potatoes. The sauce needed to be mixed together and that was not explained in the menu or from the waitress (more in that in a bit) so my first couple bites were actually disappointing. My wife tried a salad, which was good but not memorable. I was also disappointed with the lackluster beer list and the decor. It's designed to look old but with the Christmas pine cones, it looked 'dirty old' and was not appetizing. Also, seating was uncomfortably tight. I sat too close to people on either side with wait staff bumping our table while standing too close to take orders. Lastly, on the decor, they don't have their own bathrooms! You need to use the theater. I was recently in a restaurant in Dallas that was awarded one of the top 5 bathrooms in Dallas. I didn't know there was someone keeping a list but if they went here, they would be very disappointed. Finally I wasn't impressed by the staff. The people greeting didn't seem happy to be there and our waitress didn't explain anything on the menu and seemed not to know about it. When my wife asked about the speciality salad, she shrugged and said"I don't know; I don't like warm salads." When I asked for a recommendation, she merely told me the top 4 entry items were most popular. I feel the only reason this restaurant is popular is: A: it's near the theater and B: Pittsburgh doesn't have too many places to compete for fine dining... yet.

Two of my friends told me to go here while I am in Pittsburgh so I knew I had to stop by.  I was there for a work trip so I just snagged a seat at the bar.   I was told I had to get the brussel sprouts and after seeing they were fried with Parmesan cheese I knew I had to get it.  I was deciding between the fried chicken liver and fried pig ears, I asked the bartender and he said oo yeah tough choice but I would go with the pig ears so I ordered that.  Yes the brussel sprouts were so good and it is a pretty big portion.  If you don't like brussel sprouts, this will change your mind.  I know the sound of fried pig ears sounds weird but it is just meat and just chewy and oh my was this good!  It had a sweet chili sauce with it and pickled vegetables inside.  I was so happy I ordered that and it was so different.  I would definitely recommend that dish.   Looking at everyone's dishes around me everything looked so good and the bartenders were very attentive and super nice.  I would recommend this place to anyone visiting Pittsburgh!

Very good food, excellent drinks (pricey but worth every penny), and casual classy ambience. Beautifully appointed all around.  Overall a very positive experience.  Only downside was that it's very cramped in the seating area - if you have loud, nosey, or annoying neighbors, you are in for a bad experience.  Fortunately, we had none of those - in fact, our neighbors were very friendly & pleasant to chat with - so we had a great time.  It's a bit of a gamble, though.
Amazing Food.  I am a big fan of this place.  They also have awesome beer glasses.  I recommend buying one!

I ordered fried pickles as an appetizer and Pub Burger as the main dish and both were delicious. Pub Burger was $14 dollars but well worth it. The burger was large, well seasoned, juicy (not soggy), and flavorful. Came with a side of fries which were crispy with just the right amount of salt. The wait for the food wasn't bad considering how many people were at the restaurant. It took maybe around 20 min from the time we ordered our food to the time we received it. We were also served appetizers in that time frame which made the wait more bearable.

Rather than partaking in the giant place of dinosaur meat that is the "Meat & Potatoes for Two" - their signature dish - (seriously, though, it was a terrifying-looking impressive plate of meat), we chose the small-plates route through Meat & Potatoes.   The cocktail and wine list got us started off right, and we were just barely able to squeeze down the following: Fried pickles - clearly, if you know me, I will never NOT get the fried pickles Fried brussels sprouts - again, never say no. They maybe had a little bit too much cheese, but the lemon aioli was on point Fried chicken livers - we kinda overdid it on the fried snacks, but it was such a rare treat Bone marrow - just had to try this, and the portion of 3 large bones did not disappoint Wild mushroom risotto - was maybe a little heavy on the truffle, but the mushrooms were super tasty Special Bahn Mi tacos - some beautiful cuts of meat in a tasty sauce with fresh veggies on a pretty big taco  We arrived around 7, and by the time we left, the place was really filling up, which made the dance club soundtrack finally make sense. Our server kept the drinks coming and the courses flowing.

Brunch is a solid 5, dinner is a 4, so average 4.5 and a traditional 'round down' on yelp to a 4.  Dinner can be on the saltier side. Breakfast has so many unique and delicious options, I haven't made my way though all of them but everything I've had has been delicious.

While I was in town, I wanted see what all the hype was about - and it definitely was worth it!  Meat & Potatoes is a must on your list for any night out.   I headed out with a few of my gal pals, and we had so much fun. The food was amazing, the drinks were fantastic. I'm always a little weary about drinking beer out of a can, but it was okay with the atmosphere.  The Fried Pickles were spectacular as was the Kobe Corn Dog - it just sounds intriguing, right?  The Mac 'n Cheese was excellent too - hello, chorizo!  My only complaint was that we had reservations, and we had to wait for another 30 minutes and there were open tables. Not sure what was going on...but worth the wait.   Overall, awesome evening in my book.
By far the best restaurants in the 'burgh! You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, and the drinks are awesome. Try the bloody mary bar at brunch!

We had a great dinner and food lives up to the local hype.  Menu is varied and unique.  Only down side is that my Martini was sub par and no Grey Goose behind the bar.    I'll go back...simply drink beer the next visit.

One of Richard DeShantz's places, so you know the food is probably going to be good.  They also do very good cocktails   my favorite Meat and Potatoes memory was sitting outside during the Furry Convention and watching folks in full fur suits walk up and down the street.  Highly recommended

I think this restaurant is over hyped. They aren't as good as they think they are (meaning an attitude adjustment by their staff may also be in order). Our group had a variety of foods including the chicken and waffles, the burger, the Mac and cheese (no flavor), Brussels sprouts (meh), and the fried chicken sandwich. Nothing was a stand out. It's not on my list for a return visit.

Perfect atmosphere....probably because there aren't TVs....which can be good or bad (on Steeler Sunday).  Amazing bar, creative cocktails, over the top Bloody Marys/Bloody Mary bar on the weekends. Very trendy, interesting menu choices. I tend to have a difficult time choosing something that sounds absolutely delicious, but did enjoy the sunday brunch and burger. A little pricey but very upscale, first class, quality ingredients..which is very evident.

Great hole-in-the-wall pub in downtown Pittsburgh's theater or "entertainment" district. We ordered only off the appetizers menu and both were absolutely astonishingly good the onion rings and brussels sprouts. Based on how far on opposite ends of the health spectrum these were I can tell Meat & Potatoes puts plenty of effort into their food.  They do have a full bar, as they should, with friendly bar tending service that I haven't seen that often around the Steel City. These people know their craft and love doing it.  Next time I'm in Pitt I will definitely swing by here again!

The husband and I went to meat & potatoes before seeing Puscifer downtown.  We had a great time!  5 stars for awesome food AND service.  We made a reservation, and when you do that, they ask if you're going to an event and what time it starts--so they can have you out on time.  We started off with two cocktails (I got an Old Canadian and he got a black pepper manhattan.)  I was looking around at the online menu before we left for dinner, and much to my disappointment the Old Canadian was no longer on the menu at the restaurant.  However, the waitress checked and had the bartender make one for me anyway! Woohoo! It was delicious maple-y whiskey goodness. :)  We also shared poutine (hey, I'm an Old Canadian, remember??) and i was great.  Not at ALL like the fast food nacho cheese fries I remember having in Quebec as a little kid...but in a good way.  Nice, crispy fries with mushroomy gravy and real cheese.  Bonus!  Husband got a burger (more mushrooms) and I got fish tacos, which were spicy, cilantro-y, and amazing.  Even though he is a total carnivore, he said he'd order them next time.  We loved the hip, dark atmosphere--it honestly reminded us a little of home (Omaha).  We will definitely walk down here after dinner in the summer a few times just to get a drink at the bar, and it will probably become a regular date night spot for us as well.  I don't know why we waited so long to try it!!

I dined here this past weekend as part of a birthday celebration.  Upon entering the restaurant we were led through the main portion and into a backroom.  While the backroom was nice for talking to all members of the party, the decor was extremely plain and did not match the rest of the restaurant.  For dinner I started out by ordering the poutine as an appetizer.  This was the first time that I had ever had poutine in Pittsburgh and it was a good resemblance to the popular Canadian dish.  I was also lucky enough to taste some of the tartar which came on top of bone marrow.  Both of the appetizers that I had were very good and I was happy to have ordered them.  My entree was the duck breast which came on top of mashed sweet potatoes and red cabbage which was topped with a nice sauce and brussels sprouts with bacon.  The duck was cooked perfectly and I even enjoyed the potatoes which was odd since I am not normally a sweet potato fan.  I also had the pleasure of trying both the bass/papperdelle dish and the three pigs.  Each was excellent!  The bottom line for me is that my dinner here was the best dinner that I have had in a long time.  With that being said I am really looking forward to coming back and hope that it is in the near future!

Went here for my anniversary. The atmosphere wasn't exactly ideal for me. I felt that it was far too crowded and they didn't have an adequate amount of staff to take care of the amount of people in the place. However, the food was delicious and making a reservation was easy and we didn't have to wait long for our table to be ready.

Extremely well prepared and delicious. Starting with the bone marrow was absolutely devine. It is not the traditional marrow. They service it right out of the bone with various toppings to boot. The marrow tastes like putting a meat flavored butter on an already buttered toast. It almost tastes like pork belly but this one just melts on the bread. Next I moved to the wagu flat iron. The only reason for the 4 and not the 5 is the timing. I was not quite done enjoining the marrow and the meat was getting cold. Apart from that the steak was very tender and delicious. Warning that the carrot salad that comes with the steak is really tasty but spicy so be cautious. I would say it is on the medium side of spiciness but unexpected.

I was hoping for something better after reading all of the great reviews. I think that maybe I just didn't like the place, but I could see that many would. You are basically sitting next to another couple (some people don't mind this). The decor is cool though, modern take on Victorian era/whiskey bar...nice outdoor seating area..With a name like Meat and Potatoes I was expecting simple dishes done well comprised of...Meat and Potatoes! I ordered the chicken and Yukon gold potatoes..very one note taste, even though the chicken came with olives, potatoes, onions, fennel...all the extras didn't help dish. BF had the pot roast, which wasn't that good..again, very one note taste and bottled gravy taste. Mashed potatoes were just eh, ok at best.........the lobster mac and cheese, AGAIN one note taste, just a heavy cheese sauce (Velveeta like), way too much sauce to noodle ratio...wasn't bad, but not what I would hope for from this place. Even my cocktail tasted like it was made from a mix.. I ordered the peanut butter/banana cake...but it was just stale cake crumbles in a mason jar with peanut butter and cool whip-like substance on it...not that good. I dunno, maybe I'd give it another go.....Not horrible, but not that great either.
Wow what a piece of meat and great meal . Delicious!! Worth it  for any occasion. Be sure to make a reservation.

Jason is a fabulous waiter!  Without him it would have been 2 stars.  Walked in, as a tourist, "What can I help you with?"  Not a particularily friendly greeting at the door. I walked into a restaurant, let's see....eating maybe? Food nice.  Cobb Salad was delicious, styled up, smallish portion.  Nice atmosphere.  Overall worth a try.

Always great.  Was surprised that they ran out of the big steak on a Sunday night.   Service is always great and the bone marrow is off the charts.  Chicken livers are also a favorite.   I did notice that they have now made the steak more ala carte, not that you needed the potatoes but the sauce was nice.  My kids love it and it's always on our list when we visit.
Meat AND potatoes!!! Omg, so good! I love this place. You really won't be disappointed and it's worth the wait.

I made my reservation for Meat and Potatoes a couple months in advance and they were more than accommodating when I had called two additional times to make it larger. So, I was really happy with their customer service from the get go.   We arrived 15 minutes before our 10:30 pm reservation and were seated exactly on time. I was hoping that since was later in the evening that we'd get seated earlier, but the place was actually still very packed.   The hostess seated us at a table with very plush, tufted dining chairs and a beautiful wood table. (I immediately had dining room envy.) The menu gave you choices, but it wasn't overwhelming. However, there were so many different things that we wanted to try for starters, but we settled on the Mac and Cheese, Fried Taters, and the Smoked Buffalo Wings. My plan was to focus on the Smoked Buffalo wings and the fries, due to the breakup that my digestion system had with lactose a few years ago. For my main dish, I ordered the Waygu Flatiron Steak because, I mean, this place was probably named "Meat and Potatoes" for a reason.   And, I soon discovered what that reason was....   ::Cue Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 21 in C Major::   A culinary masterpiece sans fanfare and haute cuisine presentation descended upon us. The appetizers arrived in beautiful, steaming piles on cast iron dishes. Even though I was hungry,  I couldn't help but wonder how we'd even finish half of it.  That worry was quickly erased. I began shoveling french fries into my mouth. And, after I saw my sister break the crust on the steaming pile of corkscrew noodles drenched in creamy cheesiness, the plans to forgo the Mac and Cheese were quickly forgotten.   Everything was OUT OF CONTROL good. The wings were an amazing ratio of saucy to crispy. And, there was a perfect smokiness to the wing sauce. I would venture to say that they were the best that I have ever had. The mac and cheese was uniquely divine and set a new standard for the cheese pasta dish. The fries were perfect crisp and seasoned.  Potatoes were never done better justice.   When the waiters came back for our plates, there were only bones and emptiness left in this post apocalyptic foodie wasteland. We, the Annihilators, were full, happy, and ready to tackle the next course.   The Waygu Flatiron was perfectly marbled and seasoned, served with heirloom tomatoes, pickled jimaca, and wasabi mashed potatoes. The steak has become what I would want for my last meal on Earth. The mashed potatoes weren't my favorite. The consistency was a bit stiff and the wasabi was off putting when contrasted with the other flavors in the dish.   We were too gorged to even consider dessert, but we did get the pumpkin cheesecake to go. It is served a cute little mason jar with a few raspberries on top. (I hate raspberries, but we'll forgive them this one offense.) This dessert was light and delicious. And, should probably be incorporated into my Thanksgiving menu. I'm just sayin'.  Richard DeShantz, you make gourmand dreams come true.
Honestly...really tasty, definitely a place you must check out once, but not a place that can be your regular jazz. Portions are humongous!

We had visited another restaurant owned by the same group previously, and loved it, so we had high hopes for this place to. Most of the food was pretty tasty and service was attentive. We started with cocktails and crispy pork ears served with quick pickles. The ears were nice and crunchy - more like crispy bacon than some other places I've tried them. We also had the poutine which much like American poutine in general does hold up to its Canadian counterpart. But if you haven't had it in Canada, this one was okay. My one compliant is the cheese curds - there isn't enough and their consistency is such that they don't really melt. I had the buffalo two ways - buffalo steak served with buffalo sweet breads. The steak was yummy and fairly light. I usually like sweet breads, but these were maybe too big because they seemed a little too glandular for me to stomach. Plus I wasn't a fan of the buffalo sauce. If you like buffalo wings, you might enjoy this spin. We also had the bone in steak served with twice baked potatoes. It was a nice steak and a good representation for a restaurant of the same name.

After three years of making reservations, and canceling (sorry) at the last minute, I FINALLY MADE IT TO MEAT AND POTATOES. finally.   And I must say, it's kinda worth the wait. The seats are so comfy, the table is roomy, and the beer is cold. And, the food is amazing.   Came in for an early reservation, at 5:30. Was sat immediately, in the well decorated dining room. Ordered a Victory "Summer Love", due to Nicki's (our AWESOME server) suggestion. Before i had half of my beer gone, my order of Bone Marrow was steaming on my table. This. Stuff. Is. Amazing. The kid that brought my food told me how the breakdown went, as I was popping my marrow cherry. He described the marrow at "meat butter". There are no better words. Bread, sea salt, herbs, capers and pickled onions accompany the marrow, but you don't even really need them! Still, amazing with.   My entree came next, the Duck. I originally was super excited about the duck, but my first bite of pickled cauliflower turned me off. I chugged a little more of my beer, and went to work on the duck. It was perfection. They can keep the pickled cauliflower next time.    Dessert was a red velvet gob cookie, I love red velvet, but this was a little weird and hard to eat. But hey, everything else was amazing, so I'm not gonna complain!!  Happy Eating!

I ordered the collard greens as an ap. They were the best I have ever had. I had the pot roast as mc. I could not stop ooohing and ahhhing, literally. The gravy was so savory, the mashed so awesome with it, the vegies so perfect, I could not finish all the chuck, which was tender and tasty. Sever was very competent, nice ambiance.
Went here for dinner and really enjoyed it.

I had brunch here today and really enjoyed it. The menu is large and the food was delicious. I tried the brisket hash which had perfectly cooked poached eggs and tender and fatty (but not too fatty) brisket. I also opted for the Bloody Mary bar which was a nice set up for you to craft anything you wanted including lots of cured meat toppers. Someone at our table got the chicken and waffles and it literally had almost a whole chicken on top - way too much food and really unnecessary although e said the flavor was good. I did think that the menu items were all very heavy so are a splurge - there was not a vegetable to be found on the menu. I also felt the chairs were too low for the table. But overall a solid dining option in downtown Pittsburgh.

Came here for an early dinner. Happy hr. drinks wete delicious. I had the smoked meatloaf. Deeeeelicious! It was huge! I'll definitely come back. Service at the bar is exceptional! All the dishes that I saw coming out looked very appetizing.

I used the Yelp "seat me" function to make a reservation and was very pleased with the entire process. My mom and I came here on a Monday night before a show and truly enjoyed our experience at Meat and Potatoes.  This was my first time here for dinner (I've had brunch here twice) and I was excited for the opportunity since it is so busy here and you need reservations typically to get a table. We started off with drinks and I enjoyed a Duke of Earl, which is an Earl grey infused tanqueray.  I am not much of a cocktail person but I enjoyed it, not too sweet nor too bitter.  We shared an appetizer of Devils on Horseback, which is a delicious fig stuffed with cheese and wrapped in bacon.  There were three, so we each had one and half and likely would have eaten more. We decided to share our entrees and ordered the scallops and a flatbread with pulled pork.  The scallops were cooked perfectly and served with quinua.  Loved it.  The flatbread was just 'meh'. Nothing exciting there. We enjoyed our visit to Meat and Potatoes and thought the staff were all friendly and attentive.  Our server, Crystal, was friendly and very informative.  She knew we were going to a show and made sure our dinners were timed perfectly.   I thought the price was reasonable for the level of service and quality of food.

Wow. One of the best steaks ever. A 34 oz bone-in Ribeye. A steak of all steaks. Tender. Perfectly cooked medium rare. And it came with delicious mushrooms, bone marrow and crispy steak fries. Everything was well-seasoned. A meal fit for a king.

We came to Pittsburgh from Cleveland for our one year wedding anniversary and our first stop was Meat and Potatoes for brunch. Read good reviews and had high hopes and they did not disappoint. Literally some of the best brunch food my husband and I have had and we're big brunch fans. The most impressive part was the perfectly poached egg on my hash, which is really hard to find. Our server was lovely, the Bloody Mary bar well stocked and we could not have been more satisfied. This is officially our Pittsburgh brunch spot.

I'm in town for a Siim conference and was looking for a place for dinner. I read the reviews on yelp and thought I have to try this place. Thank you Yelpers this place has delicious food and drinks. If your in town you must try this place.

My husband and I were very behind in trying Meat and Potatoes (so behind actually that we tried its newer sister restaurant Butcher and the Rye first), and we finally checked it out tonight before our Alton Brown Live show at the Benedum.  I had heard over and over again, particularly when Meat and Potatoes first opened, that the staff was underwhelming. Though they exceeded my extremely low expectations, I must admit that this restaurant receives 4 stars (and not 5) from me because of the staff that I encountered. The best analogy for me is to think of the sales associates (or should I say models) at Abercrombie. They will ring up your purchase, but they will not do it with a smile or go the extra mile. However, when I'm paying nearly $100 for a meal for two (drinks, appetizer, entrees, dessert, and tip), I expect my waiter to have a better personality than an A&F employee.  The second, but more minor, reason for my 4 star review is the seating. Though the restaurant is beautiful aesthetically, the made-for-2-people bench seat with accompanying miniature round table and chair is very teeny. This compact seating reminds me of restaurants in New York City and is not something that I want to experience in Pittsburgh. Plus, we were sitting a bit too close to a drunk woman ranting loudly to the strangers sitting immediately next to her about her ex-husband and his numerous infidelities and addiction issues.  However, despite these few flaws, I had a great dinner. We started with the Wild Mushroom Risotto appetizer. It was warm and rich and full of flavor. I would definitely order this dish again, though I do believe that it had a tad too much salt. For our main course, my husband ordered the Pot Roast, while I went with the Hudson Valley Duck Breast. The two bites of Pot Roast that I tried were very pleasing. The dish was homey and flavorful and appeared to be a great portion size. Overall, I enjoyed the Hudson Valley Duck Breast but did think that it had some opportunities for improvement. The little dandelion green salad on the plate seemed a bit unnecessary. However, it was descent tasting, particularly the pickled onions on top.  The sauerkraut pierogies on the dish were a major disappointment to me. They tasted pretty one-note and could have used some sort of sour cream sauce on top to improve the flavor. However, the star of the dish - the pastrami crusted duck - was perfection! The duck was cooked rare/medium rare (just the way that I like it) and perfectly seasoned. By the end of the meal, I was too full to finish and felt absolutely devastated to leave two slices of duck sitting on my plate.  We had allowed two hours for dinner before our show, so since we were finished in only 45 minutes, we decided to order a dessert. Though I'm sure the desserts change frequently, I do wish that the restaurant would print a small menu with the options. I had a tough time remembering all the options when the waiter listed them for me and also couldn't see the distant dessert sign on the wall. We selected the Baked Chocolate Mousse that was out-of-this-world delicious. I have to say that it was my favorite item of the evening, with the duck in a very close second.  Though I may have sounded critical throughout this review, especially since having the meal-of-my-life at Butcher and the Rye just a couple weeks ago, I do have to say that I enjoyed my first Meat and Potatoes experience, and it definitely won't be my last.

Awesome!  This place has really cool cocktails made by really great bartenders.  The staff is friendly and engaging.  We had the smoked wings which were great!  We also had the pub burger and the hot chicken sandwich and they were both great!  It's a really great place to go to when you are in Pittsburgh and/or going to a show nearby.  I need to come back to try more.
Amazing food. Good service. Fun drinks. Great atmosphere! Our steak for two was impressive, but a lot of the meat was fatty to the point it wasn't edible, but great to take home to the dog!

I went with my boyfriend and another couple for brunch recently. Bloody mary bar was awesome (there were so many options for toppings), you are able to pick your liquor and then go to the bar and add whatever you would like which makes it fun. The food was great and our table had a great view and was spacious. The server seemed to be either hungover or that he did not want to be there. Other than the service, everything was amazing and we will be back!

My fiancé and I decided to try the highly talked about brunch and Bloody Mary bar this morning for my birthday. We had made a reservation, so we were seated immediately. I ordered a Bloody Mary and the Benedict of the day, my fiancé ordered a Bloody Mary and the huevos rancheros. About 10 minutes later we saw our food come out, but they tried to give it to another table. 5 minutes later, they finally brought it to us. We had yet to receive our glasses to take to the Bloody Mary bar, so we had to ask again (we were seated by the bar and could see our glasses full of vodka and ice just sitting there melting). I tried my food before heading to the bar and it was ice cold. I hate complaining, but it was inedible. They took it back and continued to apologize profusely. Once I got my food back, my fiancé was finished with his (I told him to keep eating so his wouldn't get cold). It would have been nice to have been able to eat together. They didn't even take anything off of the bill.   It is upsetting because we were looking forward to coming here and even saved it for a special occasion, but the service wasn't great and my food was cold and they didn't do anything about it but apologize.   It is an expensive place to not have a perfect experience. Because of that I don't know if we will ever be back.

A favorable vegetarian review of Meat and Potatoes? They must be doing something right!  We had reservations for 16 for dinner before the symphony.  We were split up into 2 tables which was fine.  There was a private room by the kitchen for bigger parties.  The place was packed at 6PM on a Saturday night.  We ordered drinks-I had the Ronaldo, which featured house made raspberry vodka. It was as sweet and delicious as I thought it would be.    As for the menu, there are quite a few vegetarian sides and appetizers, so we got the mushroom flatbread which was amazing.  Fresh argula and shaved parmesan really completed the dish.  For dinner, we ordered the only vegetarian entree, which was the pumpkin ravioli.  For me, I don't mind having few choices when I go out to eat-I usually find the smaller the menu the better the dishes are.  I wasn't disappointed with this dish.  The raviolis were stuffed with pumpkin in a creamy sauce that was light and flavorful.  I only wish there were more-it was that good!  I'm not a huge dessert eater so we didn't even look at the menu.  I took one star off for the service.  When our flatbread came out we weren't given plates and couldn't flag our waiter down for them.  He also never checked to see if we wanted to order another round of drinks-another waiter came by and helped us instead.  Other than that, it was a great meal.

more like 3.5.  We had brunch on Saturday. Reservations for 10:30am, when they open, and highly recommended. There was already a line in the lobby, even on a cold Saturday morning.  Pleasantly surprised by the their ability to change the offerings. We had two vegetarians in the group (at Meat and Potatoes? I know..), but it was no issue. They did the huevos rancheros sans the pork and it was really good. Also had the banana waffles which disappeared quickly. Very solid drip coffee, and a wild Bloody Mary bar. Music was bit loud for a Saturday morning. Very solid offering.

Has it really been almost 3 years since my first review of Meat & Potatoes? Well, I think it's about time I author a new review, especially since I've been there a number of times since. Most recently, I had the opportunity to have dinner with several other Yelpers. What I've always loved about this restaurant is its proximity to so many fun and interesting things in downtown Pittsburgh, especially the theater district. In addition, the interior decor and ambiance resonates with the types of restaurants I enjoy going out to for dinner. It's cozy, relaxing, and sexy. Prior to my most recent dinner adventure at MP, I last dined here in December 2014 for my birthday, and before that sometime during the summer of 2014. To be quite frank, I immediately noticed that the menu hasn't really changed much over the last 6-8 months (give or take). I mean, don't get me wrong, the salmon and hangar steak are delish (really, really delish), but I've become bored looking at them on the menu. Give us something new and exciting, MP! Even some of the drinks have been on the menu for a lengthy period of time. We all know your bartenders are extremely creative, so let's see some new items hit the menu. OK, I'll step off my stool now. On the bright side, the food and service were really great. The five of us shared their bone marrow appetizer and a cheese plate. For a drink, I chose their old fashioned cocktail. Having recently stopped into The Commoner and ordering their old fashioned, I much prefer the MP version. For my entree, I ordered the hangar steak. I know, I know. I just complained that the hangar steak has been on the menu for ummm ever, but it is really good and was cooked to a perfect medium rare. I enjoyed my meal, I loved every moment of it and really wanted to savor some dessert, but just didn't have the room. Of course I'll keep dining at MP, but would love (really love) to sit down, open a menu and see some newer items listed.

I've eaten ant Meat and Potatoes before but it was before I really started writing reviews consistently. I stopped in the other night with a coworker and had some appetizers at the bar.
