I loved the cushy chairs and could easily have stayed for hours.  Miriam and I split some dishes and each ordered a Caesar salad.  This was a Caesar unlike I have ever experienced and was the best one I have ever had.  From the menu: romaine/ kale / house dressing / crispy pig ears / chicharrones / fried egg / pickled green tomatoes $10.  Oh my gosh.  It was rich and flavorful, the mix of textures was terrific.  The green tomatoes and tangy dressing giving relief to the richness of the chicharrones, pig ears and egg.  I am craving one right now.  We split the buttermilk fried chicken livers with what I believe was a mustard based dipping sauce.  Perfectly battered, fried, the livers were cooked medium.  These were as good as the reviews state and I wouldn't hesitate to order this again and again.  I think there were 8 so I would definitely split them unless your going to make a meal of them at the bar with a drink.  That may just be an idea!    We also split the Ahi Taquitos $14 with ponzu / avocado / jalapenos / ahi amarillo.  Crispy and absolutely wonderful.  I wish they were a little bigger because they were gone in too few bites.  These are very dainty but have huge flavor and a great balance of ingredients.  They're a little on the spicy side but not so much as to be overboard.    Lastly we split the special for the evening.   Braised pork belly with mole, corn on the cob, pickled cabbage, jalapeños and radish.  I loved this.  Loved it!  This should definitely stay on the menu.  The pork was cooked perfectly, it was tender, unctuous fatty dream.  The mole was terrific and I really enjoyed the 4 inch corn on the cobs.  I can't pinpoint the seasoning but I wanted more.    Our 5 dishes were $60 with tax and I really didn't mind a bit.  The quality and brilliance of the food was well worth it and I am excited to give a 5 star review to a Pittsburgh restaurant.  Keep up the good work!  I will be back to try more of this brilliant and interesting menu.

I made a reservation for Meat & Poatoes before a Friday evening show in the cultural district. The instant we arrived, we were sat, which started the meal off right.   We started with the bone marrow; I ordered the mushroom flatbread and my boyfriend ordered the porkchop. The bone marrow was devine. Paired with the crostini, red onions, and capers, it created the perfect bite. My flatbread was very good, though had a bit too much truffle oil. The porkchop was incredibly moist--probably the best porkchop I've ever had.

The BEST brunch in the 'Burgh, hands down!  For starters, FINALLY a Pittsburgh establishment has an honest to God Bloody Mary bar!  And, if you sit at the bar during Saturday or Sunday brunch, Bloody Mary's are all you can drink for $15.  That, my friend, is a deal.  Now on to the food.  Wow.  Here I go with superlatives again, but the shortrib hash with poached eggs drizzled with horseradish hollandaise was, without a doubt, absolutely stellar!  Rich, melt-in-your-mouth, succulent shredded shortribs melded together with creamy potato cubes.  Perched atop were two perfectly poached eggs whose yolks, when pierced by a fork, enveloped the hash in creaminess only surpassed by the final crowning glory of a zippy housemade horseradish hollandise.  Superb....I've been fantasizing about them ever since.    The hubby enjoyed a plate of chicken and waffles.  You may recall he ordered the same thing at Alchemy & Ale recently...Meat & Potatoes makes chicken and waffles the way they SHOULD be made!  Crisp, crunchy, JUICY, ON THE BONE chicken pieces piled atop a crunchy on the outside, tender on the inside cheddar jalapeno waffle kissed with bacon bourbon maple syrup.  Ooooooo....maple. Bacon. Bourbon.    We each had a specialty drink - me the Bacon & Egg - a blend of bacon vodka, orange juice, sugar and egg white.  The bacon vodka was a house infusion that packed more bacon punch than the Bakon brand I have in my bar.  I am going to try my own bacon infusion again!  The drink was interesting, but next time I want all that bacon-y goodness in a Bloody Mary!    Fond memories of San Remo and Monte Carlo meals always ending with Fernet Branca enticed the hubster to order a Kingston which included Drambuie and Fernet Branca along with pineapple juice.  He enjoyed it, but enjoyed his Shock Top Pumpkin Wheat Ale even more!  He IS a pumkin ale fan.  The brunch prices here are amazingly reasonable!  The staff is friendly, knowledgeable, professional and efficient.  The kitchen is top notch!  Meat & Potatoes is a PERFECT way to start a weekend morning!
This place was in my top 10 of the year.  Food, atmosphere, service all on point.  The Pork Chop was outstanding!  I'd suggest you get good friends or a loved one and make an evening out of it.

Went here for brunch and while the food was absolutely fantastic, the service was pretty poor. After waiting to be seated (which was expected), we waited a good 15 minutes for anyone to come over and acknowledge us. Our drink orders didn't come until our appetizers did, and the server did not seem to know what was in most of the drinks. It also took her another 15 minutes to bring the check over after we requested it. While it wasn't the worst service I've experienced, it certainly didn't match up to the quality of the food or the prices of the restaurant. We'll probably return for the food, but won't be bringing guests here!

I LOVED Meat & Potatoes so much I went for dinner on Friday evening and back for brunch on Sunday morning.  I made both reservations about a month in advance of my trip, and the pickings were already a bit slim in terms of the times available. Strongly recommend a reservation, as the place was crowded both times, even at opening on Sunday morning on a snowy day. The front of the house seems a bit disorganized, so after waiting for almost 10 minutes and the confusion of who would seat us, we opted not to check our coats.  The dining room is not super large, and is dominated by a huge bar. It was hopping at 8:00 on a Friday night. We sat at a two top- a tiny, round marble table on the front side of the room. There are about 10 of these in very close proximity to one another. While cute, they're a bit too small to accommodate the admittedly large amount of food we wanted to order. I found it a bit awkward to be so close to my neighbors (why not just have a communal table?) This is not significant enough to prevent me from returning, and I actually prefer more tables + less wait to fewer tables.   The beer list was extensive and well-priced, with options from $3-$8. We started with fried brussels sprouts, which were a bit lemony and covered in parmesan cheese. These were AMAZING. Even if you don't like brussels sprouts, try these! I ordered the lamb burger and my fiance had the fish and chips. Be aware that the fish and chips have such a fancy presentation that they don't look like traditional fish and chips, and my midwestern fiance was not thrilled. They're stacked individually, and the tartar sauce and cold greens top them, which created serious temperature issues. We wouldn't order these again. The lamb burger was delicious- cooked perfectly well, the house-made bun was pillowy soft, and it was very well-seasoned and flavorful. The fries were among the best I've ever had- even my normally fry-hating fiancee was fighting for these. For dessert, we got a cooked chocolate mousse that was delicious.  We returned for brunch on Sunday morning at 10:30, right when they open. We had to drive back to Chicago that day, and it was snowing. The place was totally full by about 10:50. Service was impeccable, and we liked the brunch even more than the delicious dinner. I had the chicken and waffles, which were extremely well executed. The chicken was so flavorful and moist, and the cornbread jalapeno waffle was the perfect vessel to eat the chicken. There were also four enormous pieces of chicken! It came with delicious bourbon maple syrup with chunks of pepper bacon. The perfect sweet and savory meal!  My fiance ordered the kimchee brisket with eggs, and he loved it. He ate every last bite, and hasn't stopped talking about for the last week.  In summary: go here, order everything, leave satisfied. You will not regret it. We are plotting to go back to Pittsburgh solely to go to this restaurant!

We have been waiting to get a reservation here for a long time and dinner was phenomenal! I definitely splurged on the night but I have no regrets. I got a Caesar salad without the pork because the pig ears threw me off. But then I decided to get the flat iron steak and it was cooked to perfection just like cutting into butter. Lastly I got the Mexican honeybee drink to go with the lemon angel food cake for desert best choice I have ever made in my life. It is a pricey place but I will forever be going there for dinner with friends and family. It is definitely worth the wait!!

I had my first experience at meat and potatoes last night. Service was slow, very limited menu with nothing outstanding to choose from. The pappardelle dish was good. Appetizers were not good, except the poutine, which was ok I've had way better. Very disappointed, and I'll ever go back.

This place does it right! The steak for 2 meal was incredible. Great ribeye, cooked perfectly, along with the best confit fries and creamed spinach I've ever had. My friends all said the burgers and collard greens were top notch too.
Fantastic restaurant. One of the best in Pittsburgh. Go lunch time before the crowd and the lunch menu is reasonable.

I've been to Meat and Potatoes several times now and and both occasions the food has been very good. Last night I went for a late night bite and some dessert. Given the late hour we were able to walk in and get seating, though this is certainly not the norm. Usually I have been given a rather long wait time if I just try and walk up. Reservations are definitely recommended. Last night was certainly a pleasant surprise and they hostess was friendly and happy to seat us right away.  On this occasion I got the charcuterie which came with several smoked meats, olives and pickled vegetables. The cauliflower was exceptionally good and I enjoyed all the meat. My only gripe (and this is nitpicking) was that the bread was large pieces of toasted bread. I tend to like  more pieces or toast points, but again, I'm just being persnickety. Yes, i did just use that word, I;m so pretentious sometimes.   The dessert was fantastic. We shared two desserts, a white chocolate panna cotta with blackberries and a rich chocolate mousse like dessert. Both were absolutely phenomenal. I really enjoy places that make their own desserts.   On a previous visit I had the Meat and Potatoes for two, which is a perfectly seasoned 34 oz Ribeye, Confit Steak Fries (which are perfectly seasoned potato wedges really) and the most interesting part, a Bone Marrow Gratin. It was my first time trying bone marrow, which I thought was good and matched well with the steak. My date did not care for it much (in all fairness she didn't care for me much either so I wouldn't put much stock in her tastes :) ).  Overall, the food here is very good, and I've never been disappointed. The only thing I really don't love is the seating. I always feel like I am crowded by the tables next to me. I have ample room to move and I don't bump elbows or anything like that, but the tables are just close enough to take away the intimacy of the small 2 seater tables. It's not a deal breaker, but the only real negative I can say about the plate.

The salmon was tasty, but the fried brussels were too salty.  I liked the spicy sauce on the fish. The marrow bones were not filled with marrow.  It was scant portioning, and I've made better at home. Atmosphere is louder than most.  Seating, fairly crowded. Bloody mary was just ok. Wait staff, fine.

Simply put, we were underwhelmed. Let's go in order. The beer list is pretty good. It took about 15 minutes for our group of 10 to get drinks.  The menu is decent, but surprisingly lacks a variety of meat choices for dinners. Appetizers were above average. The fried pickles were nothing special. The short rib flat bread was great. The tater tots are fries, which is just dumb.  No bread is given prior to the meal, which is disappointing.  I had the pork chop. It's gigantic. It was cooked perfectly but did lack seasoning. I had a side of mashed, and they were just ok. Overall, it was alright.  My wife had the red fish. She didn't like it, and afterwards said she should've never ordered fish at a place called "Meat & Potatoes". I tried hers and it was indeed bland....kind of like our dining experience.  This will likely be the most boring review we write. Sorry about that.

This place gets a 5 solely for atmosphere, cocktails and menu. Although what I ordered did not impress, I really enjoyed the whole experience.  Flank steak was cold, supposed to be? Sauce overpowered the steak. Would definitely get it on the side.   Salty pig was kind of a let down.   Atmosphere is 5/5

Pros:  Very Good food.  Nice atmosphere.  Good menu.  I like the infused vodkas-the old bay was really good.  Cons:  Decent service.  Bloody Mary's were just ok  Reservations highly recommended.  At 11:15 on a Sunday we had to wait I've an hour for a table.

The brunch was as good as it gets! It was spectacular! I can't wait to go back! I had the french toast and it was excellent!!!!!!! My husband had steak and eggs and he was VERY happy! We'll be back very soon!

Went there before the stadium series hockey game so area was packed with visitors. It required reservation to get a table on this Saturday afternoon keep that in mind if visiting on a high tourism time. On Saturday they were serving a brunch and not their menu you see on line. I was disappointed since I saw items on menu I wanted to try but was. It able to. My wife had the shrimp and grits said it was best she had ever has. I had pub burger with pastrami pork belly. Burger was good maybe too much not the kind of burger you pick up and eat a little messy but still very good. We shared and cheesecake apple crunch, not exactly what it real name. It was also very good. We would definitely come back.

I had never tried bone marrow before, and I was intrigued. When the waiter came over, I asked if bone marrow is something I could have on its own as a meal. He advised I order another dish, especially since this would be new for me. I went with the bone marrow and Caesar salad, which consisted of romaine, pickled green tomatoes, crispy pig ears, chicharrones, fried egg, and parmesan. Most of the ingredients in the Caesar were also unfamiliar to me.  My meal was excellent. Read more about my experience: http://www.ginapacelli.com/2015/09/14/pittsburgh-meat-potatoes/

I have to update this review. Even though I can't give it more than 5 stars, I just have to. I love this place that. much.  I have to call out two of my favorite bartenders ever (of any place I've lived!), Blake and Mikey. The amount of awesome that they are is hard to describe. So I shan't. Just make sure you visit M&P some time on a weekday as they generally don't work weekends anymore and request a cocktail like the tequila old fashioned or the Honey Boo Boo.  Also, the kobe beef corn dog. Omg, that corn dog. Best. Corn dog. Ever.   The only reason I would consider not moving out of Pittsburgh (besides my boyfriend, of course ... ) is Meat & Potatoes. Now I'm sounding like the obsessive girlfriend, but damn y'all, the food is bombtastic.

I took a group here and we all were very satisfied with our food. My wife had the chicken and said it was exceptional. My daughter had the porch chop and it was HUGE and she loved it. Her boyfriend had the duck and he also loved it. Oh...and we had an order of mac and cheese which may have been some of the best mac and cheese that I have ever had. I usually don't like it when they doctor up mac and cheese with fancy stuff....but this time it worked. Why 4 instead of 5 stars? I had the pot roast and while it was good, it was tough. Good flavor but a few places it was too tough to eat. But, I would go back and just not order the pot roast.

I came here for dinner with some friends recently. An appetizer was accidentally delivered to our table without explanation. We figured that we would eat it and they would add it to the bill at the end. The waitress came and took it away rudely. When we communicated that everything was okay and we were going to finish it and planned to pay for it, she took it away anyway while mumbling under her breath. We continued on with our night, paid the tab and went home. The next morning, my husband noticed that someone had added an extra $20 tip to the tip that we left on our bill. I will not be returning because I am disgusted at how dishonest and rude that our waitress was.

4 years and 700 reviews later..  This place is still awesome.  This is coming from the picky, non-beef/pork eater who can find a few items to love--think grilled cheese with chicken skin cracklin and truffle, whaaa!  The place itself is really open with a massive bar smack dab in the middle.  It's done in a more airy, classic style, especially compared to its train wreck Butcher sister. It's also exactly what you expect, topped with Edison bulbs, large, plush chairs, and the clean-lined bar top.  Not nearly as stuffy as it definitely could have been.  The most recent adventure to Meat and Potatoes was for brunch.  +1 called for reservations (make reservations, really), showed up, and we were immediately seated in the crawl space for parties of two along the wall.  I clearly first got my seasonal bellini on, which at the time was some type of pineapple. Ooooh, damn. There's also the bloody mary bar which everyone raves about; if my nebbing skills are anything, it did look a bit extensive and cool.  I, of course, ordered the french toast. Sugar bread and booze! It's brunch! But this french toast was different.  Sourdough but tender, served in a huge bowl, topped with almond brittle. It was almost caramelized and incredible.  Enough to almost make me forget the starter of granola and fruit.  The pile of goodness was topped with honey and a sweet ricotta I still can't get over.  The guy inhaled his huevos ranchero, but allowed me to carefully remove a pile of egg, salsa, and black bean that was just spicy enough for all the flavor it gave. Pair that with the roasted pork it was served with, and +1 actually cleared his plate.  Okay, so maybe I didn't have meat nor potatoes, but it shows how anyone can get into the newer wave of frou frou downtown dining with the original.  It's the only logical place to start (with a bellini or two).

Sunday brunch was amazing. My fiance had the French toast which was spot on perfectly balanced, and I had the chicken and waffles. First off there's enough chicken to feed a small family, and it's made ridiculously difficult to put down with the application of the bacon glaze syrup.   My only complaint was there was more bacon than syrup, and after being charged  $1 for butter I wasn't too keen to be charged for syrup as well. The chicken was perfect, the waffle above average. The jalapeño waffle was good, but a bit undercooked and dry. Again, I could've asked for more syrup but out of principle resistance to being charged extra for a condiment I didn't request any.
Gastro Pub at its best!!  Great food, friendly staff and amazing cocktails.  Before a show, after a show, or really any time is the right time for Meat & Potatoes.

PLAN AHEAD AND MAKE A RESERVATION. I was visiting Pittsburgh for a few days and I knew I wanted to eat here, but I didn't think of making a reservation ahead of time. Don't be like me. Make a reservation before you get there. You don't want to waste your time waiting for a table, hoping there is a no show. Luckily, I called again another day and they were able to seat us in the "back room" within 20 minutes on a Saturday evening! The back room is separate from the main dining area so you miss out on the amazing ambiance, but you still get to order from the same menu.   We had a group of 4 and decided to order a bunch of dishes and share so we could try a little bit of everything. We ordered: --Meat and Potatoes: 34 oz ribeye with sautéed mushrooms, bone marrow, and (mutant) potato wedges. Highly recommend sharing this with more than 2 people so you don't waste any food. The ribeye was meaty, cooked just right at medium rare, flavorful, succulent and fatty. Cut a piece of ribeye and top it off with bone marrow for extra flavor and extra fat. :) --Caesar Salad: This salad comes with fried pork ears. It's delicious! Love the home made Caesar dressing too.  --Mussels of the day with garlic bread: Get it! There were 3 different flavors to choose from. They give you a ton of mussels!  --Lobster Mac: It was good but I wouldn't order it again. They give you large chucks of lobster.  --Pork Belly Tacos: delicious!!! The tortilla is so yummy and you can feel the pork crunch and melt in your mouth.   I love the ambiance of this place. It's a great place for a date night. Order a few drinks and some plates to share for a great night. I love the romantic vibe this places gives off. Round marble tables with candlelight centerpiece gives off an intimate vibe for a nice sit down dinner.

Just walked in the door.  It is 4:45 pm.  We have reservations for 5.  As we walked in, this young hostess asks us if she can help us.  I state that we have a reservation for 5.  She snaps at us that they don't open for 15 minutes.  Very rude.  Hope the other staff is a little nicer.  Stay tuned.  Ok, it seems like I can't write another review so I am going to edit this one.  The server , Aaron, was professional.  The food was excellent.  I had the pork chop and my wife had pot roast.  I never order pork but glad I did.  The pot roast was also superb.   Wine was good.  Will come back to this place.

It was about 8 pm on a Sunday night. We just got off the Duquesne Incline and found street parking after we drove across the river to downtown. We originally planned to see the Rubber Duck installation after dark before grabbing dinner. Thanks to a quick last-minute change of mind, we called Meat and Potatoes and were lucky enough to score an 8:45 pm reservation.   It certainly took a lot of luck to get this table. Once inside, we saw that both the bar and the dining tables were fully-occupied. The lively patrons and the dark and sleek interiors reminded me of a recent dining experience at The Girl and the Goat in Chicago, where I had my best dining experience in 2012.   To my pleasant surprise, the quality of the food here was comparable to that from TGTG. The bread with goat milk butter and jam was so addictive that I couldn't put down my butter knife. The seared duck breast we had was just as good as any I had in Manhattan, only at a fraction of the price tag at $19. The pierogi with the duck dish was good but seemed out of place. I guess it was a way to keep the meat and potatoes theme. The only disappointment was the blue cheese flatbread, where despite its inventive combination of flavors, didn't impress either of us.   For a restaurant this good, we were surprised to hear the dessert selection was rather average. We were so lukewarm about the choices that we decided to skip them all together.   The modern interiors and nicely-prepared dishes were more than enough to give this place a 3-star rating. When our bill came out to be around $50 for the two of us, the fourth star is much deserved.

Gastropubs are an up and coming experience for the diner and drinker :) but the concept of meat and potatoes in the burgh has identity, individuality and unique appeal. This place resonates with you well after you leave in positive vibes!   The decor is welcoming and warm with a successful blend of early 20th century artifacts and hip contemporary design and color. The menu is intense and truly a carb fiesta! Beers in the house are plentiful in selection and the service was outstanding. The server knows the brews, recommends wonderful ales that accompany whatever choice from the menu . This is now a staple for me on each visit to the steel city. Try it, you will not be disappointed! Excellent experience and meal.

My boyfriend took me here for my birthday-last Tuesday. He made a reservation, told them it was my birthday and asked if they did anything special for birthday, the gentleman said 'yes of course we do'. Got there ten minutes early, the hostess did not even mention anything about it being my birthday, and sat us immediately (into a sardine can). The people on each side were about two feet from us.    Food: We got a 'snack' - the toast with goat butter and jam- very tasty and reasonable priced. Then we ordered the "meat and potatoes for two". The steak fries, bone marrow, and mushrooms were really good, but the steak was 70% fat, it was $50 for the steak. For $50 it should have been a lean cut of meat. We cut close 50% of it off because of all the fat. *All of the food took a while to come out but that is to be expected when you are paying a lot for a meal.  We asked for a box and the check and our waitress came back with a box, then she final recognized that it was my birthday by saying 'oh you aren't interested in a birthday dessert?' We declined. She did not even wish me a happy birthday or even wish me a wonderful night, just okay I'll get your check.   They have a lot of interesting foods on the menu so I might go back again. But I would never go back if celebrating a special event. Terrible ambiance, too noisy, it's not romantic, did nothing to make me feel 'special' on my birthday. (I'd recommend Morton's on Liberty for that).

Arrived 5pm Friday.  Sat at the bar for 15 minutes then we were seated.  FYI the bar menu is the same as the restaurant menu.   Order the Tartare appetizer !!  If you are curious, order the Tartare, If you thought you would never eat raw meat, order the Tartare, If you think eating raw meat is weird, order the Tartare, If you want to experience something completely delicious and unexpected order the Tartare !!!  Did I say order the Tartare ??  You will not be disappointed, I can promise you that.   I went with three friends before a Play and they did ask us if we were going to a show and the time to make sure that we were not late.  Also if you have leftovers, and you probably will, they will hold them for you so you can pick them up after your show. The place was immaculate, the staff was super friendly and the food was everything I expected it to be.  We had the fried brussel sprouts they were cheesy and tasty and the mussels of the day.  The mussels were plentiful (enough for 2 people)and comes with garlic bread.  My friend ordered the pork chop which was huge; it took up the whole plate.  It was a triple chop and cooked absolutely perfectly. I ordered the Three little Pigs.  Panchetta, pork fillet, ham, swiss and an unGodly perfect egg atop.  You will be incredibly full and satisfied when you leave this place.   The drinks at the bar are reasonable for the Burgh and very, very good and the Bartenders are attentive. This place is a MUST if you are in the Burgh and like Meat,  and by the way Order the Tartare !!
Always love the food here. Difficult to get in unless you're happy sitting at the bar. But the food is great!

We stopped here after the Pirates game.  Around 9:30 we tried to make an online reservation but none were available.  Took the chance and showed up and to our delight they had plenty of availability.  We enjoyed Bone Marrow, Pigs Ears (very yummy) Salmon with black Rice and Pork Pappardelle.  All the food was delicious.  The menu is so interesting. I would take off 1/2 a star for the slowness of the service.  We sat for awhile before we ever met our server or received our drinks.  Never received a refill on water. Our server, who was very nice, had a very large party in a private room and I think it was difficult for her to handle it all.  The other thing I would share is that it is very dark.  Good for setting a mood - not so good for reading the menu.

So we had been planing a visit to Meat & Potatoes for a few weeks now but after reading most of the BAD service reviews on here I was worried! We walk in abut 15 min before our reservation time and was greeted by a young girl who asked us our name and directed us to wait at the bar. We order a few drinks off the menu, they were good....  So we were shown to our table and my fingers were crossed that our server would be amazing!  We looked over our brunch menu noticed that it was a little different the the one we saw online, but ok.  K.C came over to our table and BAM we were off and running! She is truly an amazing server... Told us all about the specials and took our drink order, great personality and very tentative to our needs! She made great suggestions for food ideas and we ordered....  Food was fantastic and all 6 of us were very happy... I had the short rib hash and It was so yummy.... So I give them 5 stars and will be back to see K.C please ask for her when you make the reservation, you won't be disappointed !

Always a good place if you're looking to grab a nice dinner with a small group or even a night out with your significant other. Have tried both lunch and dinner here and both did not disappoint. Personally like the porkchop or you can't go wrong with a steak  option for dinner. I also ordered the side of Mac n cheese at lunch and it was easily one of the best I've had.

Having been to Meat & Potatoes countless times, I recently revisited for the first time in over a year and was delighted to see that it hasn't missed a beat, despite the fact that the ownership has continued to add more hip restaurants/bars to its repertoire. The cocktails are still awesome. There's still an interesting beer list, a few of which are draft, but most of which is entirely in cans. The menu continues to change every so often and offer some great items including the mussels, which seem to have become a mainstay there, a mushroom risotto (awesome though a bit heavy on the parsley) and a pickled chicken sandwich with bread + butter pickles, garlic mayo and iceberg lettuce, which was just freakin' delicious! On an earlier occasion a while back, I had a beef sandwich that was a daily special and was about the best beef sandwich that I've ever had! While I find the atmosphere to be too modern and contrived to be called a gastropub as they call themselves, it's fun and lively. It has a speakeasy feel to it, though it's very open and visible, so it's more like a speakeasy that came out of the closet. The service was decent. Bonus points for the kitchen being open until midnight on Fridays and Saturdays.

Meet and Potatoes is a nice place in a great location with very tasty food. No wonder they are almost always really busy which may make it hard to get a table or quick serivce. However the food is always worth the wait.
Rude staff...cant even sit at bar with out being told  where to sit..OVER RATED. .BLOODY MARY BAR SUCKED..who wants capers to get stuck in the straw?

Finally tried Meat & Potatoes, not sure why it took me so long! I gave it 4 stars because of the service. It was mediocre, nothing special. We sat down at 7:30 and had our meals by 7:42. I couldn't believe it was so fast. I must say the bartender was awesome...a true mixologist! Bar service was better than what we had at the table. We had the fried Brussels for an appetizer. They were delicious and the perfect size. I got the pappardelle pasta with bolognese sauce which I enjoyed. The pork was amazing and very tender. A huge portion too for $18, you can't beat that. My boyfriend had the flat iron. He loved it! It came with a potato pancake and sweet potato purée that was absolutely delicious. All in all we had a good experience and I'm excited to go back and try something else.

This was my first restaurant visit of the New Year 2016! And if this is any indication of what is to follow I'm in for a treat!   Meat & Potatoes.....ahh what a refreshing place!   First, I was quickly seated on a Friday! That's amazing in and of itself. The atmosphere is pleasant and since I was seated in a relatively private section of the restaurant it was perfect.....  The food not only looks amazing it tastes that way too... But I decided to indulge in the "Dub" burger and fries... And I had the "Grilled" bread with jam and goat butter for an appetizer. And as a beverage I tremendously enjoyed the "Nino" cocktail.   This is far from my last visit....I highly recommend eating here before a show, a date night, or just a night on the town!

Now that you have to book a spot at M&P brunch three weeks in advance, the anticipation of the visit feels like half the fun. The meal itself isn't bad, either. ;)  The Bloody Mary bar is the highlight of the trip, every time, all the time. Grape leaves, sun-dried tomatoes, whole roasted garlic, sweet peppers, and every hot sauce on earth are just some of the accouterments to choose from when you take the plunge of building your own brunch time beverage experience. Don't be if it takes you six or seven minutes to craft your savory beverage/breakfast snack cup.  Now armed with two cups of booze and snacks, we return to our inappropriately small, round table to receive our meals from a despondent server. A great attitude is always appreciated, especially at brunch, in order to enhance the dining experience. A bad attitude is simply a missed opportunity. Admittedly we did chuckle after the server took a surprisingly condescending/undercover policeman tone after I ordered tequila for the bloody bar: "IDs first, then we'll talk flavors." Aye aye, captain.  My dining companion made the superb decision to order the Bi Bim Bap. Its Korean spicy funkiness made for an incredible flavor profile. Perfectly cooked black rice, crisp cucumbers, and a sunny side up egg solidified the dish as a slice of heaven. During the ordering process I panicked and ordered a breakfast charcuterie tray. The small selection of meats, though attractively served on a butcher block, was salty even for cured flesh. The two deviled eggs were tasty, but not impressive. I noticed that this meal has since been removed from the menu. Good choice.  With a Bloody bar that's on fleek, and meals that consistently remind you why you're an omnivore, M&P is worth the wait.

This is a review ONLY for the burger.  That's because I love burgers. I seek out good burgers. In fact, the other day I was told a good chef in Memphis (whose restaurants is allegedly not doing well) commented he would *never* put a burger on his menu. That's a really silly idea. There are people like me who travel for work and check yelp for a great local burger. People like me read reviews of good burgers and then travel specifically to the restaurant for the burger. Which of course adds to revenues and grows business.  Meat & Potatoes is trying very hard to be a trendy gastropub in downtown Pittsburgh. Located in a "new" building the restaurant was created to feel like it's been here for years. They focus like any gastropub on good food and good alcohol, using every part of the animal they can. I visited for lunch, not dinner, but the burger was of course on the menu.  This was a very good burger. Topped with caramelized onions, havarti cheese, tomato jam and arugula, the well-proportioned meat sat squarely between a freshly baked bun. The bun was out of this world. A bite was an explosion of flavors. I would absolutely come here again for the burger.  The fries were fine. Freshly cut, lots of salt, and served with a small serving of ketchup.   Four stars for a really good burger.

Got the meat and potatoes for two which almost didn't fit on the table! The ribey was cooked perfectly the potatoes melted in your mouth as did the bone marrow.  The house made steak sauce was prefect for the meat and the mushrooms it was a bit tangy with good spice. Just a few things to take note of the dish takes 45 minutes to cook so don't come prepared to order and eat in 5 minutes but trust me it's well worth the wait.

We dined at Meat & Potatoes for Saturday brunch. I was eager to try their heralded ribeye and bone marrow but was unable to accommodate it in my scheduled.  We shared the Bruschetta and the short rib hash. Both were unique takes on two homey dishes. The bruschetta was quite unorthodox in that there was no raw tomato salad. It featured crostini topped with mushrooms, eggs, chimichurri, and goat cheese. It was very savory. It had a great spectrum of textures including crispy, soft, and creamy.  The short run hash was essentially short rib and soft cooked potatoes under an egg with horseradish hollandaise. I felt this dish was quite savory too, yet it had a more complex layering of flavors.   During Saturday brunch, they offer a build your own Bloody Mary at the bar. The service was exceptional and the atmosphere was just as good.

I've had the pleasure of dining at Meat & Potatoes for many different circumstances--I've enjoyed drinks and small bites at the bar, I've used their side-room for a large-party Friday lunch during Lent (sweet life, a fish sandwich menu), and I've had every type of ambience, from a bustling and packed house and a table of five to a slow and early night with a table of two.  I love meat and potatoes. My concern with Meat & Potatoes (see what I did there?) is that your night is entirely dependent upon your server; and, unfortunately, of the many times I've been there, I've almost come to expect poor and sloppy service. Is it really that hard to be a good server at a classy restaurant? My experience in the food industry is minimal (I waited tables at a sushi joint for about a year in high school), but I seemed to think it took more effort to be a bad server than a mediocre server...so why am I constantly plagued with bad service at this place?  Cue rant? My first time was at the bar, and the bartenders were more than friendly--one of them actually recognized me from his time at Embury ("The guy who likes bourbon, yeah?!")! They'll make any drink you want, and they'll recommend drinks that you didn't know you wanted. My second time was at a table, and the service was awful--sure, it was a busy night, but ten minutes to get water, followed by a half-hearted "you ready yet?" didn't really excite me into a good meal. Further visits are plagued with memories of a server that kept attempting to up-sell ("Would you like garlic bread for the table?", or "How about  refill on your fries?", which I guess could be understandable--but then, after asking if I wanted a drink on the rocks, and then charging for ice on the check? What? Does this parenthetical even make sense?) When asking about a cut of meat, or even something as simple as a good beer, I've been told, "I don't know, its meat," or, "Yeah, I don't know, it's all beer." I don't want you to think I'm complaining unnecessarily, or that I'm being petty with my critiques, I just expect a server that pretends to care about you or enjoys the job that he/she has.  In short, the food here is delicious. They make a burger with an egg on it (the name escapes me) which may be my favorite burger in Pennsylvania. The bone marrow is rich and buttery. The cocktails are delicious and the bartenders are excellent (a lot of them came from Embury and the Firehouse Lounge). The devils on horseback are perfect. The muscles are well worth the price. The meat cuts rarely disappoint. When I attended for lunch, the simple twist on the fish sandwich was excellent (that potato salad made me drool).  I just can't stand that consistently awful goddamn service.  I'll keep coming back, and I'll probably keep giving 20%, but at least I can bitch about it on the Internet.

Fantastic food, staff, and atmosphere, but definitely not for vegetarians or super pro-animal rights people! I recommend to any meat-eaters, and particularly those people who enjoy rabbit, duck, and lamb. I, myself, don't like those dishes, so I ordered the scallops and they were phenomenal. The cocktails list was super creative and had plenty of new drinks I've never seen before. One downside was the amount of space given per table. I wouldn't recommend to people who enjoy lots of space.
The lunch service was deplorable.  The food was just average trying to be interesting.  Maybe dinner is better?

Well, as suggested I made reservations. However, to get a reservation at a 5:30 I had to make it 4 weeks out. We were about 20 minutes early so we checked in and told the hostess that we were going to be at the bar to get a drink, until our table was ready. My wife was exited to check out the Bloody Mary Bar for $5.00, that we've heard so much about. The bar tender proceeded to tell us that the bloody Mary bar is only for lunch, but he could make her one. So a Bloody Mary and a Jack and Coke came to $22.00 plus tip. Ouch! That was a bit more than we were expecting but we were out on the town and just wanted to have a good time and enjoy ourselves. So 5:30 came and went and we still didn't get a table. So about 5:45 I went back out to the hostess stand and asked about our 5:30 reservation. They told me it would be another few minutes. So we finally get a seat right next to the corner of the bar. The problem is that it was so narrow between the bar and my chair every time somebody went by they would bump into my chair or me. So I asked out waiter if we could move over one table. He did allow us, so that was good. So my wife is sitting against the wall on like a big long velour couch and I was sitting in a velour chair across from her. She was complaining how uncomfortable she was, and so was I at this point. Both of our seats felt like the springs were blown out and we were sitting in a hole. The velour upholstery was all stained up and looked filthy. The mirrors on the wall looked filthy at first, but then I realized they were just old pitted. With all of the high ratings, despite the tiny tables, I was expecting better. So as an appetizer we ordered the bone marrow and mushroom risotto. Both were very good I must say. For our main course I ordered the Hudson Valley Duck Breast and my wife ordered the Wagyu Flat Iron. We both ordered them medium rare as recommended by our waiter. My Duck breast was very chewy and gristly, even after I trimmed off what looked fat and gristle. I couldn't even find a piece that I didn't have to spit out after a few minutes of chewing. My wife gave me some of her Wagyu Flat Iron to eat instead. It wasn't bad but defiantly didn't seem like Wagyu beef. I didn't complain though, I just wanted to get out of the uncomfortable chair I was sitting in and go home. Our waiter asked what was wrong with my dinner because I obviously didn't eat it. So I told him it was very chewy and gristly. He said that was one their signature dishes and after talking to his manager, he took my dinner off of our check. The service from our waiter was good so he got a nice tip, but as for the restaurant, we were very disappointed.

I absolutely love coming to Meat and Potatoes, especially before a show. We've been here several times and always enjoy delicious cocktails and appetizers. The entrees are good but don't always wow me. I miss the duck preparation they used to have but still enjoy their mussels and chicken. Brunch here is hands down fantastic!! Definitely worth a visit when you're in the cultural district.

If you like meat, this is the place to go.....Very good dining experiences, especially when entertaining out of town guests when you have no Idea of their preferences.  You can find a wonderful dinner regardless of your preference.  They are very capable serving vegan to marrow.
Bad service, gross food, bad drinks, VERY $$$. Typical for Pittsburgh. Will never go back.

Great food. Okaish service (particularly the hosts at the entrance). Tables are too small and close to each other for a restaurant of this price--it is hard to squeeze in to get to the bench without dropping anything from the neighbors' table. But food really compensates for it

Great atmosphere, typically very busy on the weekends so call a day ahead for reservations. For a cheaper meal the three pigs is good. The curry mussels are delicious as well. The $75 ribeye for two is my favorite on their menu.

Trendy and expensive... but I knew that coming in. Made a reservation and walked in for dinner and saw a few tables open. It wasn't busy on a weekday.   Sadly, the bloody mary I had been craving was disappointing for dinner. You have to come during brunch to customize it.

This place was super dope. My boyfriend and I went on a Monday night after reading about it in the Zagat guide. It was one of the unique experiences ever. The fried chicken livers, duck paté, and kimchee salmon we all awesome. The bar was also crowded on a Monday night- great atmosphere.

Come hungry! When I travel I always to eat and a new place. Not somewhere I can go to at home. The name drew to this place. I was shocked that a place named "Meat and Potatoes" didn't have meatloaf, but I suffered thru that with an outstanding Pot Roast. I saw the Rib-Eye for two. Well I can't say here what I said there, but it was HUGE. This place is well worth the visit. Try the Kentucky barrel bourbon ale beer, it is out of this world

I came here with my husband for early dinner at 5. We didn't have reservation but the placed was packed, fortunately a nice person gave us her table to sit at the bar. The ambiance is nice and upscale. They had the comfiest chairs to sit at the table! The service was pretty good even when it was super busy. I found the food good but not amazing. They also have big food portion size which I am not a big fan of. Overall it was a nice experience but not exceptional.
The Moscow mule that I had was subpar. Service here was slow and i didn't feel like I was welcomed at all. Being a 4/5 star restaurant, I didn't feel like the staff was attentive or nice enough.

This place is a great addition to the Pittsburgh restaurant scene.  It's been on my list for quite awhile and I finally got there on my recent visit to the burgh.  A friend and I risked it without reservations and met at 6, we were lucky and easily snagged 2 seats at the bar.  This place is small - it took me awhile to realize that the mirrors on the walls around the place were just that - mirrors and that the place wasn't huge.  I started with the Old Fashion and she went with the Brandy Buck.  Both drinks were delicious.  We both had a hard time trying to decide what to order because everything sounded great.  Finally, I was sucked in by the brussel sprout kim chi on the Koren Ruben - and boy, I'm glad I was.  This was hands down one of the best sandwiches I've ever eaten.  First of all, it was gigantic - I swear the sandwich weighed about 3 pounds.  Thick pieces of some sort of bread - it was hard to tell with all the goodness sandwiched between the bread.  A big pile of delicious corned beef, swiss cheese and then that brussel sprout kim chi.  I think I could eat that stuff by the bowl.  Not only was the sandwich massive, but it was accompanied by a huge bowl of pretty good fries.  And it also had some sort of delicious sauce on the side - I think it was supposed to be thousand island, but it tasted suspiciously like the sriracha tzatziki that came with one of the daily specials.  I didn't really care, it too was awesome.  My friend opted for dessert while I went for another drink.  Her lemon passionfruit cheesecake was amazing.  My wine was pretty good too.  The service was great and the food was amazing.  This place has earned itself a stop on my regular rotation.  Yum!

After finding out we were heading to Pittsburgh, I couldn't help but be excited about coming to Meat & Potatoes. I have seen Meat & Potatoes on the Travel Channel and never thought I would ever have a chance to try this place.   This restaurant is decorated so nice! I love the feel and the atmosphere of the place. The restaurant is not big but they did amazing with what they have. In the center of the restaurant is a really cool bar area. It is definitely a hip place for dinner.  We started off with the devils on horseback which are dates wrapped in bacon. They were highly recommended on Yelp and by our waitress so we had to try them. Boy were they delicious. It came in an order of 3 and that was gone within 5 seconds. For our main course we shared the Meat & Potatoes for Two which comes with a 34 oz ribeye with confit steak fries, house made steak sauce and bone marrow gratin. This was so amazing. It is a lot of food for two people but we enjoyed every bite of it. I hope to visit Pittsburgh again so I can try more things on the menu!
We did not have reservations, but were seated promptly on a Saturday night around 6pm. The atmosphere was alright.. food was delicious. Both my husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our meals.

If you're looking for quality crafted cocktails, bloody mary bar for brunch, delicious chicken and waffles, or an excellent dinner - this place has all of the above. I recommend a date night at this location if you have yet to try and I also recommend the brunch. It is on point.

Came here for my 9th anniversary and it wasn't bad. Tried the bone marrow and it was OK. Not the best I've had. The steak was perfect and the ambiance was nice. The tables were a bit small but overall a nice place to eat.

I'm going to need to get back to Meat & Potatoes for another bone marrow treatment soon!!  That dish is barbarically delicious.  The menu is somewhat limited, and it took forever to get our food, but all told, a nice evening.  Wasabi mashed potatoes are very good.

Went here for my bday dinner. It was so fantastic!! We got the pate which is so amazing. Creamy and has the best flavor. Also the Mac and cheese is sooooo good. Creamy and crunchy and has pieces of duck fat. Incredible. I got the duck and it was so good. I lived these crunchy sand the sides it came with. My friend got the pot roast and thought it was very good but mine was better. :) defiantly don't miss this spot!

Went here for a date night. I love craft cocktails and this place answers that call. Amazing drinks with a talented bartender. The food is not bad at all. Think fancy comfort food, hence the name. While creative, I did happen to think the food was a bit bland for my taste. This is  the reason for the three star rating, because at the prices they charge for both cocktails and food, you expect top end. I will be going back again though, if not for anything else besides drinks.

Sorry guys - I have to remove 1 star because of the lunch menu.  Compared to dinner and brunch it falls way short.  Also, this was one of my first food experiences in Pittsburgh that wowed me.  Since then, I've had the opportunity to dine in a variety of awesome places.  Therefore, I had to re-evaluate my 5 star reviews.  Don't get me wrong, I'm still a fan and will still frequent the restaurant!

Belated review! Birthday dinner for 9 in their private room. We had everything (including a monster hangover the next day). Cocktails are pricy!!! Bring your carsh & your credit card. Mussels bone marrow devils on horseback - oh my! Mussels were huge hit. Pickles were a good choice too. Flat iron voted awesome. Pork chop ordered by hockey-playing bro-in-law was giant & envied. Burgers were all around tasty. I blew it & ordered the brisket samitch which was soggy. Shoulda had the Wagyu. Stupid stupid stupid!! The Langer had the duck & said it was delicious. The bill was enormous & worth it.

M & P was FANTASTIC. I had been waiting for so long to visit this place and finally made my way up to Pittsburgh. Staff was friendly and service was timely. The food was amazing. I specifically came for the bone marrow and it did not disappoint! The fried pig ears and the duck also gets a 10/10 from me. We also had a few cocktails, I had the dark and stormy, it was well made and delicious. If you saw M&P on food network and you want to visit it is well worth it!
Always make this a stop! Great late night eats!

I had a great time here. If you are eating alone, sit at the bar. I was totally entertained by watching Blake craft fine cocktails while I ate. The fried pickles are some of the best I have had throughout the south. They make the pickles in house and it totally makes a difference! I had a Sgt. Peppers old fashion, you have to try it, best ever! The aroma and smooth flavor where all the ingredients just Work together to give you that flavor that you savor long after the last sip was to die for. This is a bucket list drink if you like bourbon.

Wow.  Am I review 500 for M&P?!  Here goes:  Saturday night, the place was packed.  We started with drinks and here's what I know:  The Glenshaw was really tasty, but kind of had a hint of Fall with the allspice swirled into the frothy egg white.  Next up:  The Bramble: gin + blackberry + lemon = summer solstice, for sure.  Perfect.  The Steak Tartar was amazing.  Large portion highly spiced and a little sweet, topped with a smoked soft boiled egg.  The egg was not for me but the others said YAY!  The Mac and Cheese was ridiculously sinful.  Star of the appetizers was without doubt the Devils on Horseback.  Dates wrapped in bacon with manchego cheese and a nicely seasoned red pepper sauce.  There were four of us and our dinners came from all corners of the menu:  Duck for me - generously served and well complemented with a couple of sauerkraut pierogies.  Others had the pot roast, roast pork and pasta - everyone was so very happy.  Loved. The. Duck.  We positively waddled out of there quacking about our next visit.  Better get the reservation made and soon!

I am very saddened to have to give this place a poor review. Mostly because of the wait and the food it just wasn't what I was expecting from a restaurant that has 4 positive star reviews. I was really looking forward to bringing my hubby to a great steak place for his birthday but I was just not happy with the meal.   When we first arrived our reservation had been for 8 o'clock but i asked to move it to 830 so that we can sit at a bigger table as opposed to one of the small roundtables. The hostess on the phone told me that that would be no problem in that 830 they would have a rectangular table ready for us to sit at and dine.   We arrived early and sat at the bar waiting for our table to be available I looked around and seen at least three or four Open tables at the time but I assumed maybe they had already been reserved for other couples. As we waited we both ordered an appetizer of mac & cheese and fried chicken liver.  It took about 15 minutes for appetizers to come out and by the time they did our table was ready. We grabbed our drinks and the woman guided us to a small roundtable I looked at her and said well we requested a square table and that's why we waited until 830 as opposed to 8 o'clock.  She stared at us as if she had no idea what we were talking about she said okay well just give me a minute. She came back two minutes later and decided to sit us at one of their 4 Seater square metal tables as opposed to the two-seater woodblock table. I didn't mind sitting there but when we sat down there was an awfully weird smell almost like mildew and the seats that we say in still had crumbs in it from the guest that were sitting there before us.   I wipe down my seat and didn't bother to complain. The waitress gave us menus and asked us if we wouldn't know what we wanted to order. of course after having waited for 30 minutes we already knew. We decided to get that 34 ounce ribeye meal for two. I was very excited about ordering the ribeye especially after seeing all the beautiful pictures on yelp about how tender and juicy was. But to my surprise when it finally came to the table and I tried to cut into it it wasn't as tender as I had first assumed. We ordered the steak medium and it was very pink on the inside so I knew they didn't mess up the cooking process. Once I had tasted it it lacked flavor tremendously as if they had just brought the steak from the store, cooked it up and threw it on our plates. I assume the steak in itself would be full of flavor and bursting with with with taste but it just wasn't it was flavorless and bland and the only thing that made me eat it was a steak sauce that accompanied it.  The mac & cheese wasn't too good either it lacked that very delicious cheesy taste that you get from most creamy mac & cheese dishes. I did however enjoy the chicken livers they were very soft and not too hard to chew but the breading kept falling off of each piece that I picked up which only defeated the purpose of it being fried in the first place.   A few slices through the steak I was so disappointed that I just decided to stop eating and just stuck to the potato wedges and mushrooms that came with the dish.  It was a Monday night when we went so they had a guest DJs come in and also a group of people advertising Pimm's gin liquor. There is another issue I had with this restaurant. The music should go according to the Environment. The DJ that they had hired to play music was playing it way too loud I almost felt like I was in a club even though I looked around and saw people casually dining. It didn't make sense to me at all. the free samples of gin may have been the only upside to that evening. I had informed them over the phone that it was my hubby's birthday soon but before we received the check we never even heard a mention about it.  Once I brought it up to the waitress she asked if we had any desserts in mind. I wasn't too excited about the regular food so dessert wasn't really an option for me. My hubby on the other hand really enjoyed the steak so he decided to get a dessert to maybe save the evening for me. the vanilla dessert was very delicious. i scraped the inside of the glass container just to savor  each bite.  By the end of the night after a few beers a cocktail in all the food we had ordered my bill was about $140 including the tip. I was very disappointed that I had spent so much money and was so dissatisfied I should've just stuck with my regional got it went to capital Grille where I have never been disappointed. Maybe this place has better options for lunch or brunch or maybe I should just order something else but either way I probably won't be returning to meat and potatoes anytime soon.

Must try this restaurant if you're in the area. The food tastes amazing, the service is great, and the ambience is perfect for a date night.   We ordered the wagyu flat iron steak, which also comes with potatoes and guac. Their sauce is very unique and everything just pairs so well with each other. We also got the mussels, which I highly recommend. Their house special that day was the curry lemongrass. The mussels were cooked perfectly and the sauce was so good. You should order the mussels with bread (extra $1) to dip it in the sauce since there is a lot left over. Their mashed potatoes was also good, paired well with the steak.   The only thing that could have been better is if they brought out the mashed potatoes with the steak together. I think they forgot about it and brought it towards the end (when we were already half way done with the steak). However, the service was great and they apologized for the wait. Overall, my bf and I had an amazing experience here and would definitely come back if we visit Pittsburgh again!

Another awesome meal - the aged Manhattans were great, decided to give the wings a try, they were great.  Slightly smokey and the sauce was not very spicy - a bit on the sweet side with a hint of Bourbon.  Great service and lots of fun watching the bartenders work.

I think this place takes itself overly serious...when your restroom is in the hallway of a neighboring theater it's time to take yourself a little less serious and deal with what you are.   As a appetizer we had the Kobe Corn Dog (which was very mediocre {didn't have the proper crisp, flavor was off}) and the Poutine (gravy was good wish there was more cheese curd).  I was going to order the Bone Marrow but the couple next to us said "you have to try the Mac-N-Cheese it's amazing" so we did....it was really good. There is Chorizo and Pulled Pork in it so it is very hardy....(we were both going to order entrees but after this we shared one).  We finished with the Hudson Valley Duck Breast. The pastrami duck was cooked a medium rear and was delicious with the chimichurri.  The pierogies it came with were good but nothing special.  Our server was fine....with us! He was seemingly short with the couple next to us who (the female was a vegetarian) seemingly asked questions about every dish. You got the vibe that maybe he's been spoken to about this by his managers....i.e. quipping back.  Highlight of the night might have been the two Spanish guys (in "wife-beaters") who sat themselves at a table to "just get some drinks." After two Corona's they left but clearly the restaurant did not have the proper procedures in place to deal with this....  (It shows I have 4 check in's here.....I've only been here once. Verizon network was having issues that night into the morning.)

Read the recent reviews! If you do, you'll see that the overlying theme of many of the reviews is their poor service. This is also the reason why I'm giving them two stars. Service is just not good. For real.   This used to be my absolute favorite restaurant here in Pittsburgh. The atmosphere was great, the food was on par, and drinks were amazing. Over time though, their service has gone downhill so much, that I really don't have any desire to come back. I've actually left feeling embarrassed for taking out of town guests here, it's been so bad. Before I go on about service though, I want to say that their food has also changed over the years, and it's just, well........it's just not as good anymore. Gah, I hate saying that out loud. I really do. I want to like it still. But I've given Meat and Potatoes too many chances over the past year, and each time I've left sorely disappointed.   The real reason I'm writing this review is to share my frustrations with their lack of service. From the hostesses to the waiters, they are just not good. Sometimes they are not friendly, sometimes they're downright snooty and condescending, or heck, sometimes we don't get service at all and have to wait there for obscene amounts of time before someone actually comes by our table. Now you may wonder why I just don't speak up and say something, but I'm not a confrontational type of person. I'd rather just hurry up and get the heck out of there. Unfortunately, I always have this moment between visits where I think on the good old days when things were great there and decide to give them another chance. But, I guess the joke is on me. No more.   Whew, glad I got that off my chest. And clearly, I'm not the only one bothered by their lack of service. I guess you could take your chances and maybe get a diamond in the rough as your waiter, or you could spare yourself the likely possibility of getting a dud and go somewhere else. Either way, you've been warned.

I went here for dinner recently and loved it.  I had the Brussel Sprouts, Bone Marrow app and the Wyagu Flatiron Steak.  All of them were delicious and the Bone Marrow app was large enough to be a meal by itself.  Great ambiance and a great date spot.  Loving that places like this are popping up in Pittsburgh.

This was one of my favorite restaurants back when I lived in Pittsburgh.  A lot of people went there for the trendy and lively atmosphere, but I always went there for the food.  I've tried almost all of the food on their menu and have never been disappointed by any of them.  My favorite was the duck liver pate.  AMAZING!!!  The wine list was pretty impressive as well.

This was an amazing experience !!  Daughter and son in law treated us for a lovely birthday dinner. Started with drinks an apps. Brussels sprouts, chicken livers, marrow bones and a fabulous tomato salad. Everything was great. Super duper server. She was on top of every single thing. With great humor. I had a delicious ravioli with lamb ragu. Oh my gosh was it delish!!  Each dish was super. Pork chop was huge. Godzilla sized. Duck breast and mussels yummy. And then a lovely surprise birthday dessert. Altogether a wonderful time. Will go back soon!

I went there for my birthday with a couple of friends. I was very impressed with the decor of the restaurant and liked the ambiance of it. I especially enjoyed the chairs which were so comfortable to sit in. I shared the bone marrow appetizer with my friends and loved the contrast of the bone marrow with the accompanying seasonings. The main entree I ordered was the wagyu steak and it was cooked perfectly. I would give this place a 5/5 if it was not for the extremely late reservations that they offered me. Other than that, I would recommend this to anyone!

Is there an option to give the drinks, dessert, and snacks a 5, and everything else a 3? If your primary goal is to grab a few drinks and small bites before/after a show then this is probably your place. The drinks were unique and delicious definitely worth stopping in for, but the main entrees were less than stellar.  A nice, fancy meal it was not.   I really wanted to like this place a lot more than I actually did. Is this place more hype than substance? I'm left wishing we had gone to Butcher and the Rye instead. We made reservations a few months ago via Yelp and had really high hopes! The sitting areas were super tight, and the plush high back chairs were difficult to move and get in and out of. We did appreciate how well the staff worked together to clear tables, and how the servers checked with patrons to see if they had a timeline to work around (trying to make it to a show etc.)  I went with the Roast Chicken (chicken, garlic sausage, marble potatoes, heirloom squash and broccoli rabe) and my husband went with the highly reviewed pot roast. For the chicken, there was a mix of flavors that did not taste pleasing. I kept eating, and mixing thinking it's probably meant to all be eaten together rather than one or two items separately. I was getting a flavor profile similar to sauerbrauten (german potroast). I will say, the heirloom squash in this dish was the singular bright spot. How it was dressed or seasoned (apple cider maybe?) oh so, good. I'd eat a plate of just that - five stars right there!  The pot roast was alright as well. We both commented the entree needed more pepper. No salt and pepper shakers available at the tables though. Some gristle was lurking in between the bits of meat, so you never knew what you were going to get. Was it outstanding, no, was it good - a solid good in my opinion.   Okay so dessert milk chocolate pot de creme (other options were a cheesecake dish, and berry lemon cake/sorbet combo.) This pot de creme was oh so good, with the perfect amount of chocolate with a luscious texture. It's so hard to get desserts right, but thankfully this one was done right.  Finally, we both went home with leftovers from our entrees. Usually leftovers taste the same or better the next day. This was not the case, sigh. The pot roast was again alright, but the gristle that was hiding among the untouched mashed potatoes was not appetizing. I gave the chicken another shot, and while the chicken just by itself tasted better I realized the offending flavor in the dish was the sausage. I can't quite pin what was unappetizing about the sausage, but it did not go well with the vinegaryness of the rest of the dish. I love sausage, but this did not play well with others.  We had a hard time believing this restaurant is under the same umbrella as BATR. If we had gone to this establishment first, I think it would be a hard sell to try others in the brand.  Last tip, parking. There's a few garages nearby that seem reasonable during non-events, but we happened to have dined when The Price is Right was filming in town, so.....that was $15 for parking. We've parked downtown before on a Saturday night and it was a few bucks, so this was a bit of a shock.

The food is fantastic! We got the Ribeye for two and it was perfectly cooked. We were initially told it would take 55 minutes to cook, but it came out in about 25. The au gratin potatoes have got to be the best I've ever had. They were creamy, cheesy, and perfectly cooked. Highly recommend this as a side.

I've really tried to like this place as it seems that everyone thinks that it's amazing, but I've been consistently disappointed. The food is okay, but often too rich in a kind of cheap mayonnaise kind of way. The seating was really cramped -- I guess they're trying to alleviate how difficult it is to get a reservation, but I haven't seen 2-person tables packed that tightly outside of Valentine's Day. We were basically sitting right next to the couples on either side of us. The cocktails are their redeeming grace, but increasingly there are a lot of places in the 'burgh for great cocktails. So, not a bad, but a solid 3 stars.

I went to Meat and Potatoes for a friends birthday dinner. We made reservations far in advance, so that was not an issue. However, it is connected to one of the theaters so it is frequently packed with the show crowd.   The ambience of the restauarant is really nice, it is a bit dark and small inside but is very cozy. I thought it would be a really good date place. It also has outside seating, but it was cold when we went so we did not have a chance to check that out.   As my drink, I got the bourbon smash which has bourbon crushed with mint leaves and berries and oh my god is it delicious. I have tried numerous times to create it myself at home with some bulleit bourbon, mint, berries and simple syrup but I have never been able to recreate it perfectly.   We got the bone marrow as an appetizer. I thought the presentation was really nice, the bone itself came out and had small dishes with sea salt, capers, and some other type of spice. It was presented with delicious toasty bread. While I was not a huge fan of the bone marrow itself, it went on the bread like butter and what really made it stand out was the garnishes to put on it.  For my entree I got the duck. It was presented in slices, and almost looked like steak. I ordered it medium rare and it was really delicious. My friend had the turducken special, and while I could not stop giggling at the concept/name, it was a really good special too.

We were very excited to try this restaurant and went there on Saturday night for my husband's birthday. After reading a lot of the Yelp reviews, I was looking forward to the food and was concerned about the poor service many before us reviewed.  Well as you may guess by the rating, neither the food or the service was up to par. In my opinion, one of the very best things a restaurant can do to ensure its success is to make sure their servers are knowledgeable, gracious, super efficient & personable. If I'd had that, I'd probably give the food another chance.   The most glaring failure during order taking was asking if we wanted bread or frites with our mussels and failing to mention when my husband said frites that he would again be served French fries with his brisket sandwich. Who seriously needs 2 orders of fries during 1 service? Our first beers we ordered off the bar menu were served in cans - that's an inexcusable restaurant decision that I wish they had made more obvious on that bar menu. Seriously, it's a gastropub not a tailgate!  Draft beers were not mentioned by our server and had we not read the board on the other side of the bar and done an online search for the beer's description, we wouldn't have known they existed or what they were. She had no idea about any of the drafts when we asked.  So many things on the menu were appealing we decided to order 4 items. We started with the smoked wings (recommended highly by other Yelpers) and the curry mussels. I got the feeling if we hadn't specified to our server that we considered the final 2 items to be our entrees, that all 4 items would have shown up at our ridiculously tiny table for 2 at once. When the 2 appetizers arrived at once we had to pile everything on top of each other because the table didn't have room for 2 appetizers plus 2 small appetizer plates. The wings were actually really delicious with a nice smokey flavor and turned out to be  the highlight of the meal. The mussels were nicely sized and plentiful but the curry sauce was sorely lacking in flavor.   Then our server disappeared for 20 minutes, stopped by to tell us she was sorry about our wait but our food would be up in 1 minute, then disappeared for 25 additional minutes. My husband found her scurrying by long enough to tell her to please cancel the rest of our food if it wasn't already sitting in the back. She disappeared for another 5 minutes and appeared with only my husband's brisket sandwich which came with more frites. She squeezed into the tiny space between us & the next table and informed me that my short rib flatbread had hit the floor as she was racing it to our table but that they had started another one and it would be done in 7 minutes. Not sure why the first one couldn't come out in 45 if it only took 7 to cook.   Neither the brisket nor the flatbread were very good and unfortunately our attitudes toward Meat & Potatoes weren't either by the end of the evening.
I love the decor of this place. Inspired me to put a chalk wall in my own house ! I've only had appetizers and drinks but can't wait to come back for dinner !
The prices are a little high, but you get what you pay for. I was very pleased with the attentive staff, and the tasteful food! Also a very convienient location to shows downtown.

Best steakhouse in town. Hands down. I used to work there so I know how much care, creativity, and passion they have for their food. Oh how I miss eating steak tartare all night long in the back kitchen when the chef wasn't looking. Short rib flatbread is amazing appetizer as well. But if it's your first time, go with the meat and potatoes for two. I included two pictures of the steak tartare and the watermelon civiche straight from the back of the kitchen from when I worked there.

Awesome food. We were here late and they cut our server so the service was kind of a mess. Try to make a reservation a couple days in advance at a normal dinner time and I bet you won't have any issues.

Found this little hot spot a few weeks go through Yelp, and have been back twice since.  Unique Gastropub with welcoming, relaxing, and era representative decor.  The staff here is very friendly and helpful.  Indoor and outdoor dining, with great music playing appropriately in the background.  All of this is great, but secondary to the food, which is simply incredible.  Unique snack and starters including great fried pickles Mac n cheese, fried brusselsprouts.  Salads are amazing including one I had last night which was a mixed light greens, watermelon, jalapeño peppers, radish and a light citrus dressing.  Burgers are awesome, had a special pulled pork taco with slaw, pickled cucumbers and cilantro.  Amazing!  The fish entrees are great, and they have a bone in ribeye for two along with potato wedges that are a work of art.  I haven't had that yet, but have seen it served many times.  People seem very pleased.  This is will be a go to spot for me every time I am visiting Pitt..  One of the more hip & trendy places I have been to...  Highly recommended...  Reservations recommended.

Yes, this was our first visit to Pittsburgh, we loved the food, but wish we could of booked an earlier time. We ate at 11:30 overall the food was good nothing bad about it. Here is the link  & video to my blog to read my full review as I can't post any video's here on yelp lol   http://cierrasplayground.com/?p=1004

Meat and potatoes delivered neither of the aforementioned, although there were plenty cockroaches and a rat to serenade us on our night out in the Burgh. To avoid ruining the hip vibe inside we were placed outside (we have a 2 year old and she's so. not. hip) where we waited and waited and waited some more for appetizers, some flatbread, and a ricotta that never saw the light of day. Clearly we ordered the most time-intensive meals on the menu. Although beverages came out as expected, we were quickly forgotten outside and left waiting until I made my way to the front desk and asked for a check. The server came out and actually asked if we were still enjoying our beverages after being told by the front desk we were upset (and beverages being beyond empty). Interesting. I asked for the manager and she comped the drinks and was quite pleasant considering the situation, but there's something about making my child wait for food that infuriates me. There is nowhere else in this city where I've experienced such lackluster service and poor ambience (when building a restaurant avoid placing your patio along the alley filled with garbage disposal units). Many thanks to our hotel staff for having Microwave Mac n cheese on hand to feed my daughter at 10:00 at night. We won't be back come hell or high water.

I went on a Saturday for brunch. I asked my waitress what the best things on the menu were and she was extremely informative and helpful. I finally decided on the brisket hash and it was actually one of the best things I have ever eaten. The truffle flavor was amazing and went so well with the melt-in-your-mouth brisket. I am so sad I am only visiting the area and cannot come back to this restaurant to try everything else on the menu.   The stuffed french toast looked amazing and wish I had two stomachs so I could have gotten it too. I know that they infuse their own vodkas and have a Bloody Mary bar which is really cool.  Love love love this place and highly recommend!!

Cramped.  Food was OK.  Service was great.  Good Bloody Mary bar, just difficult to get to and from due to the cramped nature of the place.  We were there for brunch, but we will definitely be back to see if we have a different experience for dinner.
My second time here and it was amazing as usual.  I highly recommend the mussels and the pot roast.  Also, get a reservation or your wait time will be lengthy.

This is just a super solid gastropub style restaurant. It's the first restaurant by the owner of Butcher and the Rye and tako, and I still think that, out of the three restaurants, the food is most consistently the best.  I have been here numerous times for dinner and for brunch, and the food is always decent and sometimes excellent.  I recommend the burgers, which are decently priced and done very well here.  Their tacos seem to rotate, but I had some delicious pork belly ones here awhile back.  I don't often order the main courses for dinner, so I can't really speak to the quality of those.  I like coming here for brunch even better than for dinner.  The main reason for this is their EPIC bloody mary bar.  When you order a bloody mary (which was at an *amazing* price of $5 the last time I was here ... I hope it hasn't increased since then) you can choose the spirit (vodka, tequila, sometimes flavored spirits, i.e. jalapeno or horseradish).  Then they just bring you the spirit and you go to the bloody mary bar to complete your drink.  Their baseline tomato juice mix is already very tasty, and then there are an assortment of hot sauces and spices that you can add to taste. Finally, there are SO MANY SNACKS you can add to your bloody mary, from the usual pickles and cornichons to cheese cubes, salami, bacon, and even grape leaves!
