Since there is often a decent wait for brunch if you didn't make an advance reservation, my favorite thing to do is drink bloody marys during the wait.  Just don't fill up too much on the BM toppings, because you'll want room for the delicious brunch food.

Been there twice while visiting the city. Both times were magnificent! First, the space is very fancy urban farm to table atmosphere with many interesting concoctions to drink as well as a great beer list. Devils on horseback- delicious, sweet and savory bites of heaven...bone marrow-I think about this plate and my mouth waters! With the perfect little complementing additions to enhance the rich fatty beef flavor, it is like there isn't enough. I swear this would be my choice of a "last meal". Steak for two is what we ate both times because it was so impressive from other yelp reviews as well as in person the first round...you can't go wrong! A great date spot and atmosphere to get a little fancy but- warning that you sit VERY close to other people so not an intimate atmosphere but a great pregame place to get a full belly and do a little downtown exploring.

Well worth the price! Had the meatloaf, and it was amazing. The decor in here is really great, and the wait staff is ver attentive. We had a smattering if appetizers and liked them all. Huge portions as well!

Went with my husband for his birthday lunch only to find out that after we paid $11 to park there that they substituted their advertised lunch menu with a lenten menu. The menu had one burger and about 6 fish sandwiches...which the hostess neglected to inform me of when we placed the reservation. As we are not catholic and had chosen this restaurant for their beef menu options we just ended up leaving. Since we literally only made the trip to pittsburgh for this restaurant we are now out the waste of time and money.

I visited Meat and Potatoes for a brunch following an evening of bachelorette party fun. The decor was very rustic farmhouse chic and cool. The Bloody Mary bar was everything a self-proclaimed Bloody Mary aficionado could have ever dreamed of; house infused vodkas, homemade smooth tomato juice, 20 hot sauces, meats, cheeses, shrimp, bacon, olives, pickles, horseradish. It was incredible. The whimsical menu had some wonderful options. I wanted to try one of everything. I had chicken and waffles which was pretty amazing. Others had pancakes and stuffed French toast which were big hits. We had an excellent time as fabulous food at Meat and Potatoes.
In PGH... 1. The best brunch  2. The best friend chicken 3. The best Bloody Mary bar 4. Nuff said

I swung down here with a friend for a quick snack, etc.  We sat at the bar.  The food was good, but the service left much to be desired. Very slow, and my friend couldn't even get a basic cocktail recommendation.  In fairness, I think the staff were overwhelmed, as the walls were nearly bulging given how crowded it was.  Nice place, probably better at the tables than the bar, but not somewhere I'm rushing to get back to.
Two Martinis, Waldorf salad (bacon / walnuts / apples / grapes / celery / green goddess dressing / aged cheddar) and Mac & Cheese (chorizo / pulled pork / government cheese).  At the bar.  Perfect.

Ambiance: Relaxed, casual, a bar scene but perfect for foodie families. Snacks and appetizers are great! Warm and cozy atmosphere.   Service: Our waitress was excellent! I got the pub burger and she gave me an extra napkin without me even asking. Super considerate and great service.  Fried Brussels: DELICIOUS, smoky, balanced,  cheesy, clean and sharp. Best Brussels I have ever had. Fried golden brown and covered in Parmesan, perfectly cooked and not mushy.   Poutine: Not anything out of this world but tasted good. Compared to the Brussels the poutine is mediocre but who can turn down fries, gravy and cheese curds? Fries vaguely remind me of five guys which is a plus because five guys makes pretty damn good fries.   Pub Burger: Incredible and suuuuper good, it's a burger with melt in your mouth pastrami pork belly, an egg and sauce. Really really good and absolutely huge, this is the best burger I have had in awhile  Wagu Flat Iron: Melt in your mouth, like a fillet mignon but with really great flavor. Cooked perfectly  Steak for Two: Huuuuuuuge. Really good too! If you like steak ribeye and are feeling hungry grab a buddy and get this. It comes out on this huge wooden cutting board with all of your sauces and sides. Sauces and sides are extra but you will definitely have leftovers, we had our steak with confit potatoes and roasted cauliflower and it was fantastic.   Overall: This restaurant is great!!! I would definitely go back the next time I'm in Pittsburgh. It's casual atmosphere has 80's music in the background and is very inviting. Our plates were so huge we didn't even get to dessert! Moderate price points and an excellent meal for all to be had.

The hubs and I were in Pittsburgh for a few days. We came here after a letdown of a German dinner (my choosing). I should have listened to my husband and came here for dinner. We only had drinks and dessert, so I can't comment on the entirety of the menu.  The drink selection was good and the bartenders were very knowledgable. I don't know if it's a new trend, but I noticed that several restaurants in Pittsburgh have Absinthe on the menu. I had the US Absinthe and it definitely had earthy tones, just as described by the bartender.  The atmosphere was great and it made me want to stay and drink yummy cocktails all night. We probably would have if we didn't have a 6:00 AM flight the next morning. The food selection on the menu look great and the dishes around us at the bar looked delish. If we ever go back to Pittsburgh we'll definitely be eating a full meal here.

Amazing brunch. The bloody mary bar is like a five course appetizer bar. If you like meat, the cuts here are fantastic and cooked to perfection. The only downside is that the place takes reservations and if you come without one, you will have to sit at the bar (if you are lucky) all the while watching as tables around you are mysteriously empty. It's also a tiny bit too expensive, making it a special occasion place, not an everyday affair. For those of you worried that this place isn't good for vegetarians, they usually have something on the menu to satisfy those who find meat unappetizing. If you ask for them to make a dish (such as the huevos rancheros) without meat, they will oblige. While they do love meat, last time we went in, our server also reminded us that "potatoes is also part of our name."

Such a cute place! They even have their own in house DJ! My friends and I couldnt decide what to order for brunch since everything sounded so good. I ended up getting the Smoked Kielbasa Sandwich and Im so glad I did! The Kielbasa sausage was very hefty and flavorful. We got the Pancakes of the day to share. That day it was pancakes with pear compote, mascarpone cream, and candied hazelnuts. There were four pancakes stacked on top of each other, and each was very fluffy and thick. They served the pancakes with butter and syrup, but my friends and I didnt use any of it because the pancakes were already delicious without them. I was just in Pittsburgh for the weekend and definitely regret not trying their dinner menu..

I've been here three times now and I am not sure what the hype is all about. It was pretty mediocre all the way around. The ribeye for two was the biggest disappointment of my life. No joke. After waiting almost an hour and half for it to come out, It was 90% gristle and fat. Yes I know Ribeyes are more fatty. Ribeyes are my preferred cut of meat. This was not up to snuff. Everything was very gimmicky and trendy just to be trendy. This restaurant is constantly hyped up by everything I read online and by everyone, but after this third visit I just cannot see the appeal.

I recently met several co-workers for lunch and the food was fantastic! One co-worker had the cold fried chicken sandwich and the other co-worker had the burger. Both co-workers raved about their meals. My only complaint was that the food that I received (Beef Short Ribs and Grits) was served somewhat lukewarm. The flavor was great and would rate 5 stars if the food would have been warmer. I would have asked that my food be re-heated, but I was starving and didn't want to wait. Other than that, everything was wonderful!  The short ribs were like butter!

This saddens me as I really loved this place, every time I come in town I come here. We came and was one of the worst experiences to the point I may not return. First, they gave me a hard time about a reservation of 8 because it was Friday... The place was not busy at all. Our waiter was horrible, literally never came back and he would get a drink for one end of the table and not come check on the other. When we got food he never once came to check on us. It took initially 30 mins to get him to take our order. So with one couple ordering the steak for two... We were told it would take 45-50mins... It took over an hr and half! Again it wasn't busy. First, they should tell you about that when you sit down. One girls hamburger get was over cooked and gave her a hard time when she asked to add bacon to it, my pot roast was overlooked and the gravy tasted funny, the devil on horseback was served cold and the waygu was dripping with butter or oil... Was horrible. For the cost it was horrible overall. To have a reservation at 7:30 not get your food till after 9 is an issue. Super disappointed because it's usually so good.

First: Make a reservation. Seats are hard to come by if you don't rsvp in advance.   Second: No kids menu, however, they offer flat bread cheese pizza, burgers, plain chicken wings, and pasta.   Third: If you love meat, well this is just the place for you! I ordered the pork meal...it was huge! Everything was perfect, from the side greens (full of flavor) to the hunk of meat itself.

Absolutely dynamite.  The bone marrow is a must.  Fried pickles and pig ears were spot on.  Fried chicken and spicy grits were very authentic. If you have to make a hard choice, get the smoked pork chop. Smoked to perfection.  Great place.  Congrats to all the partners for a super A+ establishment.

In summer 2014, our interns got into the practice of scouting out restaurants, then recommending good ones to the whole crew. Meat & Potatoes was one of the places they discovered. Excellent menu selection & service. Can't comment on the bar since it was lunch at a corporation that frowns on such behavior. Maybe after work some time.

I have been to Meat and Potatoes several times but had not been there for about a year. I am sad to say that I think this place has "jumped the shark". Same menu from two years back generally and the place now just seems a bit tired. All of those cutting edge dishes are now just me-too's. Nothing special. Service was lackadaisical. No need to rush back here.

We have eaten here 7 or 8 times since they opened and every time we are so pleased with it. We lucked out last night (4th of July, pre-fireworks, post-Pirate game) and snagged 2 seats at the bar - I'm so glad we stopped! We hadn't eaten at M&P in a few months and some of the menu had changed. I had a fantastic drink called Pimm's Blue Ribbon - I'm going to try to mimic it at home..it was so refreshing!  We ordered the fried pickles to start - they were delicious. Think slices and the breading was fantastic - I'm not even convinced they were fried b/c they were not at all greasy or soggy - yum!  We each ordered 2 specials - the Kobe Beef Hot Dog came topped with chili and mac-n-cheese with a side of fries. I had the Pulled Pork BBQ special - topped with pickled cabbage and a delicious potato salad on the side.  Overall - another fantastic meal at M&P.  It never disappoints!

Meat and potatoes are as ubiquitous as mac and cheese. I think it's safe to say that this is the new "trendy" place in town. There was no wait, as I made a last-minute reservation for right when they opened.   The interior threw me off a bit - it's very plush, to say the least. I wasn't expecting it, especially since they share bathrooms with the theater, and they're more, um, pedestrian.   Cocktails were good. I had the Cane and Able (10 cane rum, Ardbeg 10 yr, lemon, vanilla, jalapeno, angostura). I was afraid it would be too busy, but it was pretty well-balanced. The soft vanilla and smoke from the Scotch really rounded off the peppery edges.   As for food, it was mostly good. The fried pickles and poutine were solid. I had the pot roast, which was very tender and flavorful, and went well with the whipped potatoes and veggies. My friend got their take on the Fish and Chips (country fried skate with yukon gold chips, malt vinegar aioli, mushy peas and pickled green tomatoes). It was an overwhelming mess. All the components were done really well, but the flavor combinations seemed very disjoined and overworked. Just too much.   We opted for dessert elsewhere, so I can't comment on that.   Overall, a good experience.
Great environment and service. Beer selection was below average, but the rest of the drinks were on point! Bar seating is perfect if you eat alone as I did.  I don't think you could order wrong here.

Previously I found the intake staff to be lacking a bit.  But this last time all was fine.  We had to reconfirm (my issue) for the reservations, and arrived at 5:45 and awaited our friends who came in at 6:15 due to traffic.    The intake was flawless; the waitress, new to us, was the perfect representative of this trendy place in the cultural district.  We had to wait 25 minutes for others to show up but the wait staff came around ever 3 minutes to check...   Orders done quickly; and the kicker was the question about the time of the show we were going to... so .. the checks came out just in the proper time to hightail it over to the Byrham for Sister Act.   Food was all excellent.  So, I've modified my previous comments based on this last encounter.  We are going to establish this place at the "go to" when in this section of the cultural district.  While I am sure other places are great, why not just enjoy the ambience of a proven venue!     Remember the Cabaret is only a few yards away inside and the provides even more even possibilities.  Noone ever comments on this but... the restroom was perfect, coat racks located just outside the restaurant, and literature for the cultural district easily available.  So -- go, enjoy, tip generously.  Roy

I recently visited Meat & Potatoes for the first time and I absolutely loved it.  My girlfriend and I had a 5:30 reservation on a Friday night. As soon as we walked in the front door I could tell that it was going to be a great dining experience. The minute you walk in you're greeted by a friendly group of hostesses, and the friendly service doesn't end there.   Our waiter, Brent was wonderfully attentive, friendly and constantly checking up on us. My girlfriend and I shared the Macaroni and also the Fried Pickles, both were delicious. For our entrees I had the Duck Breast and she had the Pappardelle, even though neither one of us cleared our plates we were still beyond happy with our meals.   Meat & Potatoes is one of those places that you can't say anything bad about, at least I can't. The staff, the food, the atmosphere A+! I can't wait to go back.
Very good food. The venue is quite small so you will need to make a reservation or get lucky at the bar.

Meat & Potatoes is a trendy eatery located in the Cultural District and right in the center of Theatre Square. Parking here is extremely easy, especially if you go into the parking lot located on 7th Street (I think it's called Theatre Square Parking Lot?) The restaurant itself its bustling, especially on Friday and Saturday nights, so make sure you call in advance or use Open Table to make a reservation. I came here last night for the second time to celebrate my boyfriend and I's anniversary. We had a reservation at 10 pm, since we were at Benedum Center for an opera. Upon arrival, we were seated within 5 minutes. The ambience is lively, classy, and has a wonderfully energetic aura about it. Our server immediately came over and brought water. Since my boyfriend and I were extremely hungry, we ordered as soon as she came over. We shared the bone marrow, which was a decadent appetizer served with grilled toast, parsley and pine nuts, sea salt, capers, and pickled onions. It was delicious! The only con may be that it's quite a heavy starter, especially considering all the prime choices of protein you can order. For dinner, my boyfriend had the leg of lamb steak, and I had the adobo pork shank. My boyfriend loved his meal (he's a sucker for lamb) and it was a perfectly sized portion that allowed you to get full but not full enough for dessert. The pork shank was amazing. As soon as I tried to cut off a piece, the entire shank just fell apart. The meat was tender, a little bitter, and had some underlying spice. All in all, a great dinner. We ended up ordering the pot de creme for dessert and it was one of the best ends to a dinner I could ever imagine. The chocolate was silky and just melted in your mouth. The freshly whipped creme and crumbles added light and crunchy textures that perfectly complemented the chocolate. After a few bites, it can get a little too sweet, but the dessert, itself, never gets heavy. Service here was the right balance of hands off and attentive. Our server checked in a couple times to make sure everything was tasting right and brought us water right as our water levels were diminishing. However, my boyfriend and I were never interrupted when we talked and had the chance to just enjoy each other's company. Overall, I'd say Meat & Potatoes is a winner. It's hard for me to pick one con about this place. As long as you make sure you have a reservation, you're golden.

SO utterly pleased with my experience at M&P. We reserved with OpenTable through Yelp for an 8:15pm seating on a Thursday, so although we arrived about 30 mins early, we were seated within 15 minutes. i would recommend doing the same, as the other yelpers seem to have long waits otherwise...  Drinks--creative and delicious (my choice: Moscow Mule in its own self-titled copper mug)  Food--also inspired. i loved the devils on horseback and could've eaten another two orders on my own. Mussles tasted fresh and well-seasoned. the pasta i ordered was a bit undercooked, but the 3-meat sauce it came in more than made up for that shortcoming. charcuterie board was delish and enough to satisfy, but not fill 2 people up before their meal.  Service--attentive but busy  Vibe--industrial, cool, funky; great for an intimate group of friends or a date.  Can't wait to come back to Pittsburgh one day and return...  Walk to nearby Andy's at the Fairmont hotel for a nightcap, and enjoy the fab jazz trio and sophisticated atmosphere :)

You won't find another place in Pittsburgh like this one! It is by far my favorite in the city. The drinks and the food are amazing as well as the atmosphere.    I typically get the devils on horseback to start which are dates stuffed with chorizo and wrapped in bacon and then topped with some sort of incredible sauce! After that I get the saffron curry mussels. Which are to die for. I've tried many other things and loved them all as well. But when you love something why question it?  Ps the prosciutto crusted duck is also amazing!

We were visiting Pittsburgh and when we walked into the restaurant me and my friends were the only non-white people there. The hostess instead of speaking to us, even after we said we were next in line, turned to the white family behind us and asked if they had a reservation and tried to seat them, completely ignoring us. We found this behavior very racist and we were treated very badly, they were very unpleasant and did not help us at all.

I was part of a party of six that came here for brunch on a Sunday. Our reservation was honored and being that we were a little early, we headed to the bar for a cocktail. The bartender blended us fantastic concoctions from their menu.  I've seen reviews for the poor service at this establishment and I believe that the time it takes to make these cocktails is part of that problem. Many of these drinks are rather lengthy in execution and if there is a restaurant full of patrons and only two bartenders, drink delivery could be an issue.  We were sat and our server, KC, came by and immediately got our attention. She was attentive and personable and spot on.  My main course consisted of the Fried Chicken and Jalapeno Waffle. The chicken was passable but the waffle was incredible. Everyone at the table was pleased with their meal and we promised a return visit in the not-too-distant future.  Good job, Meat & Potatoes in downtown Pittsburgh. Well done!

We showed an hour early for our reservation and most fortunately, due to the Pirates game cancelation, we were graciously accomodated- not always easy with a baby carseat! Our server started a little slow but gave excellent recommendations. Each menu selection was perfect, including two of the beverages we enjoyed- Goose Island 321, and a featured Watemelon Draft I forgot the brand.. The truffle risotto appetizer for $14 was my entree- I do not have a large appetite but it was more than enough for me and to share. Perfectly prepared-to die for! I would recommend it as a side to share for normal diners! It was beautiful visually, the aroma, the taste, and texture...perfection! The Wagu steak $31, served with sauteed mushrooms was one of the other entrees I tasted and was also great! The steak was beautifully tender and cooked to perfection. The third entree was also a winner- the paperdelle with short rib and Bolognese sauce. It was light and the noodles handcut, there were generous meat chunks  that were fork-tender. The atmosphere is uncluttered,  hip, urban- upscale, but the prices don't break the bank. I think this is one our best treats of the city in the cultural disrict.

I have been wanting to go to Meat & Potatoes for a long time. I have heard such good things so this was a place I really needed to go to. Lo and behold I was asked to a late night birthday celebration! It was held on Monday after 10.   We were presented with two menus. A late night menu and the regular menu.  I was torn. The late night menu was $5!!! And the menu looked amazing, mussels, oyster, patty melt, shake and bake chicken, and an assortment of flat breads! Wow, what a great menu and a great deal.  But would the portions be enough? Or was this a sampling menu.   I was hungry. I didn't want this $5 menu to turn out to be some sliders and a chicken leg. So I asked the waitress about the portion size. She said that they were small, but still good and made a shape with her hands that looked like a slider sized bun.  OK, I thought to myself, better go with the big girl menu.  I ordered the Kimchi Ruben from the regular menu. The rest of the party went with the late night menu, and ordered two of each of the $5 plates.   My food came first, and it was delicious. The bread was thick and crusty, and did not get soggy even the next day. The corned beef was cut to perfection and the kimchi (brussels sprouts) was spot on. Just enough spice and heat to make me want to try it again.   But, then the rest of the food came out. And let me tell you, that  $5 menu was no joke. The flat breads were so good. I got to try the greens and chilies flatbread. OH MY. The greens were cooked to sweet perfection and when you took a bite it was heaven, with that kick of chilies mixed in. Just enough to make you go, "WOW" but not overwhelming. The Patty Melt was amazing. Juicy, cheesy, and the bread was thick and toasted just right. The mussels were marinating in this amazing buttery garlic sauce that made you dip your crusts of bread in it, just to get another bite. So good.  (Can you tell we shared plates?)  My only complaint is that if the waitress wouldn't have told me that the sizes were small I would have saved some money and just ordered off the late night menu. But I was not disappointed with my order or all of the other dishes I tried at all. And it makes me want to go back soon. This time, I will focus on the late night menu!!
This restaurant is well suited for dating and the food here is good. The bartender was very friendly when I and my girlfriend visited. We ordered duck breast and it was well cooked.

Being as this was Meat & Potatoes I did not expect many options that were more on the vegetable eaters side. There were very very few options for someone who doesn't eat a lot of meat. But the meal I decided on was really delicious, a pasta meal. The atmosphere was OK, I was in a low table near the bar and next to the Whiskey Cabinet. The manager even asked us to hold a bottle of whiskey while he unlocked and re-locked the cabinet. The bar was filled with rude business men cat calling the waitress. Not very classy for the cost. I wouldn't go back by choice.

Rachel C and I feasted like champion eaters at Meat & Potatoes. We started with the mussels, which were a very generous portion. They were served in a peppery curry sauce and we received some bread for dipping. Then the kitchen sent out some fried pickles and brussels on the house - both were great!   Next up was the mac and cheese with chorizo and pulled pork (!!!). The cheese was definitely very Velveeta-esque (pretty sure it was Velveeta). Delish. I was so stuffed at this point that I really couldn't eat much of my main course. A shame because it was also awesome. Hanger steak with all kinds of veggies and potatoes.   Our server was great and very knowledgeable about the menu. When she brought over my slightly-dirty martini, she immediately asked me to let her know if it was too dirty. It was, and I appreciated that she recognized that right away. My replacement martini was just right.   Next time I find myself in Pittsburgh, Meat and Potatoes is definitely on the agenda!

Note: By ALL means, make a reservation. A few months ago, we were turned away because we didn't have one.    It was a harrowing journey from Kay's Beaver Falls lovenest to Downtown Pittsburgh for my belated birthday date with culinary destiny: Meat & Potatoes. A fender bender on Route 60 did not deter us nor did the frigid temperatures. I was meant to come here, yesterday, not moons before, and we made it just in time. A phone call Kay made en route to M&P explaining that we might be late was unnecessary even though they promised to hold our table for another 30 minutes. They also knew we were meant to dine here.  Emily, our ornately tattooed server who went up, away, and beyond her call of duty to make this a gastronomic night of nights, knew we were meant to come here against all adversity. The glitter in her bespectacled eyes and her pixieish demeanor were simultaneously homey, reassuring ('don't worry, ya made it! i promise it'll rule!'), and magically stirring, as if she was a riot grrl/food fairy/carnival barker leading us onto a rollercoaster of protein, starch, and housemade opulence. The restaurant was dark like a theater, a theater of madness, wonder...  I believe, she wanted to test us, test...me. She saw me coming, months ago, I swear...in a crystal ball...  A ternion of Devils On Horseback charged towards us with flag-like skewers jutting from their armadillo backs. Honeyed, bacon-wrapped, armored like hellborne beetles, full of chorizo sausage, manchego cheese, and topped with peppers, onions, and a red sauce reminiscent of ketchup that I cannot recall the name of, I finished off two, Kay dispatched one.  After quickly shellacking our first appetizer, I inspected my surroundings. Dish rags were napkins. Mason jars held food, candles. Water was poured from glass milk bottles. A large bar in the center of the room came off as a carousel for cackling, well-to-do adults who wanted very much to be seen. In what was a demonic, Dickensian Coney Island for carnivores and time-travelers, Kay and I just tried to survive in it.  The second appetizer came in the form of Pate, as M&P calls it. A duck liver mucilage is topped off with a sauternes jam in a sealed jar and served with toasted, grainy bread and a spreading knife. A rare treat, we rationed it, swaying with each gloriously silken, subtly sweet, crunchy bite.   Knowing that they must grind their own beef, I was compelled to try the Pub Burger, or was it compelled to try...me? The imperious fried egg was the first thing I saw followed by the flaky, buttery bun and the horseradish cheddar flap. The trembling, fat pastrami pork belly slab became noticeable only after the initial chomp. A "special sauce" lurked...somewhere within. Magnificently frizzled and exotically seasoned "fried taters" sat off to the side in a steaming heap. These are also offered as a "snack" with truffle mayonnaise, but when I asked to have the truffle mayonnaise, Emily gladly obliged for an upcharge. The beef, egg, cheese, and pastrami all colluded to create a creamy-meets-meaty alchemy for my mouth, and I savored it in lieu of attacking it. This was more than a burger; this was a game of chess, the crowning french fries and the exquisite truffle mayo acting as a respite between moves unti...checkmate!   Kay had a pot full of mussels that were likely the greatest and freshest of all the mussels ever noshed on. Arriving at an ideal consistency between gummy, gamey, and tender, the mussels soaked in a intoxicatingly beery brine that begged to be absorbed by our bread and were chaperoned by plump cubes of a bacon packed with flavors that were at once earthy and unearthly. Clearly, this was not bacon from a supermarket cooler.   We almost ordered dessert. That was until Kay said with a playful look in her eye, "You know you want that marrow. Order it. It's your night." Emily approved, laughing as she headed back to the kitchen as if aloft on butterfly wings, likely saying in her head, "Man, these groovy folks GET it!"   Out came three bones colossal enough to have come from wyverns along with cups of gremolata, pearl onions, capers, sea salt, and more bread. With this dish, we danced on the edge of de trop, the filthy rich jellied lard nearly overwhelming us. It has been called "God's Butter." After last night, I shall call it "Satan's Tallow."   Lastly, dessert arrived in a dyad of mason jars. One was Red Velvet Cake, complete with a lone candle to commemorate my birthday. The other was a chocolate mousse so iniquitous, so profoundly profane in its sugariness, I coveted it, longing to snatch it from Kay's hands. Not even a cap of whipped cream was enough to cut its carnal cocoa essence. The Red Velvet held its own, however, its batter bright red and moist, its cream cheese icing adding angelic vim in an attempt to offer salvation from tawny, aerated damnation. Thus ended our ride and trial. It did not kill us. We are now stronger.

I wish this place opened earlier during my time in Pittsburgh. Gastropubs should be the new thing, and it definitely is mine.   My friends and I (party of 4) went for a really late dinner Wednesday night. I made a reservation for 10pm, and we were seated at a well-located table with super comfortable chairs. The server was very personable and attentive throughout the entire meal, and eager to make suggestions.  We started with drinks, my friend and I ordered cocktails (Blood & Sand/Thompson Daiquiri), and my boyfriend ordered a draft that was served in a cute little mason jar. The cocktails were delicious and well-crafted, but very strong and tiny, not to mention a bit pricey. (although reasonable for restaurants like this)  Between the four of us, we ordered the Charcuterie (3.5/5), fried taters w/ truffle mayo (5/5), fried pickles (4/5), Arancini (5/5), Mac-n-Cheese (4/5), Pate (5/5), The Salty Pig flatbread (didn't try), Bolognese Gnocci (5/5), Pub Burger (4/5), and Tartare (4/5).   I would recommend getting the Pate, fried taters w/ truffle mayo, and the Bolognese Gnocci.   I am definitely going back to try some of their steaks and their brunch menu as well!

I always inquire how my Manhattan is made. Up with rye is not just the way I like, it's the way it should be. After Mike came to me on the rocks I should have seen it as the first sign something was up.   I came here on Friday for lunch and was a bit disappointed. I heard such great things, but unfortunately there were several issues. The Manhattan isn't a big deal but the wait time for our beers was a joke. It wasn't packed. The bartender wasn't busy. It was slow service. I was waiting forever.   So the drink was a little bit of a drag, the service wasn't the best, at least the food was going to be amazing right? Ehhh. My salmon bibimbap was excellent. I can't front there. The chicken sandwich though was underwhelming. The Mac and cheese was alright. And the fried pickles were below average.   I came here thinking this would be the one meal we got in Pittsburgh that cost a little more than anything else. It's a fairly inexpensive city compared to New York. Wish we spent our money elsewhere.
I love meat and potatoes. It's one of those places you want to show everyone. There's always something new to try! I highly recommend the three little pigs sandwich or Hudson valley duck

A great spot in downtown Pittsburgh! My boyfriend and I had both been wanting to try Meat & Potatoes out for a long time and it definitely lived up to the hype. I ordered the duck breast which was AMAZING and he ordered the steak special. I am not a huge steak person myself but I tried some of his and it was the most tender, melt-in-your-mouth steak I have ever had. Such a game changer that I will definitely order it the next time we visit. Prices are higher but you very much get what you pay for.   This was the best date night we've had in a long time, with good food, great wine, and great music playing as well!! Our waiter was also fantastic and knowledgeable about the menu and explained all the desserts to us one by one. The staff were all friendly and seemed to enjoy working there, making for an upscale venue with a very relaxed, not-too-serious vibe.

Hmmmmm..... I wonder what they serve here?  Oh yeah it's right in the name but that's not all.  I love this place, great vibe, cool people watching and a very diverse clientele. You have your city dwellers, your city workers, your hipsters with their fedoras as well as trendsetters with their cool glasses. Oh and a lot of pretty ladies! Just Sayin'.   The menu is more than just your grandmothers idea of meat and potatoes. Take time to explore it, there are some magnificent choices on this menu. As far as the beer menu, diverse and good and the bar is exceptional. Waitstaff, bartenders are all friendly. I have never had a bad experience at this place.  In fact probably going back tonight.

Went at 8pm this past Thursday night with my husband and Meat and Potatoes was still full out busy. We got seated right away and I started off with a signature drink called Blood and Sand... which was pretty good (anything with Dewars is pretty good).   We got the cheese board for an appetizer which was excellent with sugared walnuts, pecans, dates and homemade peach jam. It was so good I thought my husband was going to get another board so he could eat that as his meal.   For dinner I had the salmon with black rice and my husband had the duck. Both were really good and for dessert we had their custard which was extremely rich... so you could only eat a little but...very worth it.   Our server was also helpful giving us details on the food and recommended a great white wine to pair with my salmon. The wine was light and spicy, and ended up enhancing the spices and flavor of my meal.   Over all, we had a great experience at Meat and Potatoes and we cannot wait to go back.

This place is awesome: terrific food and great service. We had the bone marrow, hanger steak, salad, mussels with smoked salmon and the vegetarian pasta. All of it was fabulous, even the vegetarian ravioli, stuffed with fresh peas. It was really refreshing to see what is essentially a steak place offer really thoughtful and tasty light and vegetarian fare.   I would have given them 5 stars except for the fact that they have outdoor seating and kept leaving the door open to the outdoor area and flies came into the restaurant and became a bit of a problem. Put up a curtain screen or something if the doors are to be left open.

Only been here for Brunch and I am sold! I will be back. We had the Irish Benedict and the Brisket & Kimchi. My boyfriend and I shared. We literally could not decide which one was better. Service was great, always attentive and never pushy. We started with the Bloody Mary bar. It was very interesting but I don't think I know how to make a Bloody Mary as a good as a bar tender. But a great idea in theory. Also, they are only $5, can't beat that. As for the other libations, spectacular! Especially the Irish breakfast! I'm already planning my next visit!

Now if you want a gastropub that has high end food and libations, M&P is the place.  Nice decor with nice high back seats and a large bar in the middle of the room. The bar was full and so was the restaurant on a Sunday night before the Pirate Dodger game, with many in team colors for both teams.  Some nice up beat music playing.   Service was on point.  We shared the Cobb salad that had bacon lardons, tomatoes, egg, scallions, some great blue cheese and a avocado ranch dressing.  A great start to our dinner.  For a appetizer we ordered the Lobster Mac that has some black truffle.  The mac was good, especially when you had a chunk of the lobster or truffle. Two people in our group split the Meat & Potatoes for Two (34 oz. ribeye, confit stay fries, mushroom argue and bone marrow gratin.  The meat was cooked perfectly.  The bone marrow was perfect sweet combination.  The confit potatoes were very good with a nice crunch and flavor.  The Pork Chop, ordered by someone at our table, looked great and was told it was top notch.

Having a rough day so far in PIT, but came here expecting to be amazed and wowed. Bummer. Wine was mediocre by the glass. Fried Brussels were fried into oblivion. Duck was very salty and flavorless. Now waiting on the roast chicken and hoping for the best! Won't rush to come back after some tasty meals I've had around the corner. Too much steakhouse, not enough modern vibe here.  Just sent back the roast chicken too. I'm not a bone marrow fan but that clearly seems to be the thing to come for. If you're not not eating red meat, don't bother.

If there was one place I wanted to try in Pittsburgh, it was Meat & Potatoes. As Pittsburgh's first gastropub, Chef Richard DeShantz knocked it out of the park by featuring a veritable montage of some of my favorite foods. And since the 2011 opening of Meat & Potatoes, he's taken over the Downtown Pittsburgh scene by opening up Butcher & the Rye and Tako, in addition to his bistro, Nine on Nine.  Meat & Potatoes features a bustling, yet cozy space with a central bar as the focal point. The GF and I met up with some friends and grabbed a drink at the bar while we waited for our reservation. After waiting an extra 10 or 15 minutes past our time, we were graciously offered a private dining room. But as we were about to head to our table, a perfect table for 4 by the corner opened up so we could enjoy the animated atmosphere.  Cameron's Kick [$10] Chivas Regal 12 year scotch, Irishman whiskey, orgeat, lemon, nutmeg  I started off the night with the Cameron's Kick, which featured smooth Chivas Regal and the kick of Irishman whiskey. The orgeat syrup imparted nice undertones to complement the scotch and in combination with the lemon and nutmeg, this was a surprisingly light and subtly sweet tipple.  Fried Pickles [$5] Spicy ranch  For our meal proper, we began with the fried pickles, which were spot on. A pet peeve of mine is when fried pickles come in spear form. Clearly, they're meant to be in chip form. These had a great crunch and a nice brininess that was accented by the spicy ranch.  Kobe Corn Dog [$7] Wasabi aioli, spicy ketchup, radish, sesame seeds  The kobe corn dog had a nice cornmeal crust that had a sweetness that was balanced by the richness of the beef dog. The light crunch of radish added some levity, with the wasabi aioli providing some spice. The ketchup had just the right amount of kick to provide some brightness to each bite as well.  Braised Pork Belly [$18] Carrots, English peas, pork jus, baby turnips, pea tendrils  On special for the day was the braised pork belly. So obviously, this was a must order and I'm so glad I did. The pork was unctuous, well-braised, and had a nice final crisp to provide some texture. Three huge hunks provided triple the pleasure. But not to be outdone, the English peas and gorgeous carrots had a wonderful sweetness that provided that countervailing element to balance out the heft of the pork belly. The baby turnips provided some starch and additional texture, with the pea tendrils adding an herbaceous element to each bite. This isn't just meat and potatoes people. Pittsburgh can cook!  Meat & Potatoes for Two [$59] 34 oz ribeye, confit steak fries, mushroom ragu, housemade steak sauce, bone marrow gratin   But the main reason I was here? Behold the hallmark dish - meat and potatoes for two. A huge 34 ounce long-bone ribeye is featured, though I'm fairly certain there was more than 34 ounces of beef on this particular night. Though I could have used a bit more of a salt-seasoned crust, it was cooked perfectly medium-rare. And more importantly, the beef cut and ate like filet. In fact, I don't remember the last time I had ribeye so tender. This was all topped by a mushroom ragu that provided earthy heft to each bite. The gratin provided wonderful texture to the fatty bits of marrow - easily a cup's worth of God's butter. The confit potatoes were perfect - a light crunch on the outside with creamy tenderness within. Perfect to dip with either the spicy ketchup or the housemade steak sauce. This dish can easily be shared by 4. Safe to say, there were leftovers, even for me.  Lobster Mac n Cheese [$16]  Taleggio, white cheddar, Doritos, truffle  You don't think I stopped there did you? I had to get the lobster mac, which featured the delicious combo of taleggio, white cheddar, black truffles, and yes, Doritos. The cavatappi was al dente and had great bite. The cheese sauce was a bit soupier than I typically like, but the earthiness of the truffle and the salty of the Doritos definitely came through.  Lemon Berry Pie [$7]  And since we were celebrating the GF's birthday weekend, we had to end with some dessert. The lemon berry pie was layered in a mason jar. Light, sweet, tart, and tangy, it was the perfect palate cleaner.  It's safe to say that Meat & Potatoes is a must if you're visiting Pittsburgh. Service was helpful and on top of things, despite it being a busy night as well. Not only are the dishes well-executed and delicious, I also couldn't believe the price point of the meal. It's not to say the meal was cheap and I'm sure there's the element of cost of living when compared to Philly or NYC, but I would have gladly paid more. The next time I'm in town, I know I'll need to check out Butcher & the Rye and Tako. But I know a part of me that will feel the urge to simply return to Meat & Potatoes.
The food was spectacular! The service was great! I couldn't think of a better place to dine!

If you're fortunate enough  to not be seated in the cramped 2 top steerage class, and to have a server that cares enough to tell you about the 'specials board', then it's great. Off-times are best if one wants to indulge in the brunch bloody bar.

I'm so thrilled to have such a charming true gastropub in the city, particularly in downtown where new restaurants seems to pop up then die out quickly.   I had great expectations when first walking in - the ambiance had an upscale comfortable and quaint feel that made one fill right at home. The menu, which was an brown folder with age sheets of paper, had just the right amount of selections as to not overwhelm the guest with too many choices. I absolutely adored the cocktail list, and after 2 trips I have tried the Aviation (a twist on the "traditional" version which I believe does not call for grapefruit juice), the Sazerac, and the Old Canadian. The Old Canadian proved to be my favorite, meringue in a cocktail is simply one of the greatest ideas a cocktailian has ever had...go early 1900's.   I'm fairly certain that ever dish was concocted by the devil, everything was perfect! The mussels were fresh, plump, and they didn't have the fishy taste that is all too common in restaurants, and yes, believe it or not mussels really shouldn't taste like that. Next came the duck liver pate, served in a small clasped, jar with a couple slices of toasty, buttery baguette. Unfortunately not enough bread for the large amount of pate. Either way, the smooth, savory taste of duck pate on crunch bread is one I'll never forget. The pork belly potato skins were probably one of the best things I've ever had, though I can't it was particularly good for my health. You have to splurge some times? Snail and blue cheese risotto had great potential, though it was not as creamy as a risotto should be - it was a little on the watery side. I had no idea apple played a role in the dish, quite a minor role to say the least.  Overall, this is the type of place you want to spend some time in, which is exactly what I'm looking for in a restaurant. I could sit in the dangerously comfortable chairs, or the well designed, open bar for hours drinking prohibition cocktails and munching on the small bites. Seriously, you need to go.
Stopped in for a drink after a Pirates game! Drinks were delicious, service was adequate and our snacks were tasty! I loved the grilled bread and fried green tomatoes!
Nice place with ambience. There is salsa dancing in the back area on Fridays and lessons are given early on.  Warm atmosphere and friendly ppl. Fast Service.

I've gone to Meat & Potatoes twice and ordered the bone marrow appetizer ($18) both times. It is definitely an experience I believe everyone should try. At first, it is really hard to wrap your head around the concept, but once you do it, you realize the buttery steak taste is something you can get no where else. By the second time you order this appetizer, you are desensitized to the idea of eating marrow and it is not as big of a shocker. The menu options range from appetizers, salads, flat breads, burgers, sandwiches, pasta and main courses. I ordered the waldorf salad and it was wonderful! It tasted like a fresh picked mixtures of lettuce, fruit and "green goddess dressing." I also ordered the "Meat & Potatoes for Two" (34 oz ribeye), which I wasn't too impressed with for $59. I would get it again for the experience though, seeing as how it's a 34 oz ribeye to share and isn't too common of a experience at other restaurants I've been to. Although exotic, their drinks are not very tasty. I ordered the "25th hour" drink ($9) which had lavender agave in it, but I didnt taste much lavender. It was a dry tasting, bitter drink. I would be open to trying more drinks though. As far as going for dinner, the place gets cramped (tables/seats are pretty close together) and there are an overwhelming amount of people at the bar. Getting to the bathroom is a challenge when the people at the bar won't move aside for you, which can be irritating, but this would not keep me from going at dinner time! I do recommend this place to someone who is willing to try a fancier, exotic restaurant with a great price for the quality, but if it is a first time, I would recommend lunch time to genuinely experience the food and a calmer environment.

Over all a great experience. Food was very tasty and served in a timely manner even though the place was packed. Menu is the most unique I have ever seen. Very interesting spin put on some timeless classics.   Only negatives for me were the place is tiny !! Get a reservation unless you are okay with eating at the bar. Also not really my scene. Bartenders and everyone else in there looked like overly trendy hipsters.

Had a lovely dinner while in pittsburgh house hunting. Brussels sprouts app was delish with ample Parmesan cheese to add even more flavor. Smoked beets were good.. truffle fries were outstanding.. chicken sandwich was ok a little on the spicy side and fried. People next to us had what looked to be amazing pot roast!!! Plan to come again.

Hello Meat and Potatoes Restaurant, Can you please add seasoning to your dishes? Thank you.  (Note I went here in April 2013 so they could have turned over a new flour de sel flake and season the meat and potatoes but I don't think I'd take that bet.)

3.5 Stars -- Best part of meal was the appetizer special with pickled wax beans and olives/tomatoes/fresh ricotta with grilled toast.  Very disappointing was that they brought entree about 2 minutes after appetizer platter showed up.  That's why did't get a 4-star rating.  Service should be on par!  The fresh pappardelle Bolognese was decent, not stellar, the pot roast was sublime.  The timing of the entree was the largest problem.  Though they were apologetic, no attempt was made to comp anything or make it right.

My wife and I visited last night after see Garth Brooks at Consol Energy Center. Garth was great.   As far as Meat and Potatoes, I will give the food it's due. Steak for two was great. We tried the Bone Marrow, and have to say it's not going to be on my bucket list. Restaurant did nothing wrong to it, just the texture and appearance doesn't appeal to me. Steak was cooked perfectly and the potatoes and mushrooms on point.  Now for why we won't return. The tables are not large enough to hold two waters and two drinks, much less the food that was served. We were seated by the front door and once food was served, the crowd wouldn't leave us alone to eat as they felt compelled to be 'funny' and heard. Additionally the atmosphere and vibe is more bar than restaurant. It is too noisy, and too crowded.  Good food gets the 3 Star, the atmosphere scores a big zero for me. Too much competition out there to put up with this place.

We came here per an out of towners rec cross referenced with yelp. From the start it was a bad experience. We put our name and number down for our 40 minute wait. We asked if it was okay to walk down the block to check out the bridges. We get a call 10 minutes after we left telling us that it's going to be an additional 30 minutes as our table was just "given away." We were literally down the street so we walked back to ask what the deal was, something about her forgetting to put us on the list (yet we were there when she did Plus it was right next to the phone number they called us on...) The three ladies up front suggest we might have better luck at another spot down the street. But we were determined to eat here. So we stand around. 10 minutes later we're seated. The hostess really needs to learn some time estimating skills.  The meals: the French toast was good, not amazing. The candied bacon was a nice touch. The rancheros were nothing to write home about, pretty boring and not a lot of flavor. The chicken and waffles were about the same, there wasn't a whole lot of meat on the chicken so it was basically fried skin and waffles. I didn't try the pub burger as I'm not a red meat eater (I'm new to the meat eating game.) we ordered some bread to start as we were all pretty hungover from the wedding the night before, it took forever to come out.  The Bellini was decent, apparently the Bloody Mary bar is "amazing" so if you're into a boozy brunch bar, there's that. The staff were pretty lax, had to ask a few times for coffee and water refills. The space it self is huge, but there was a live musician which cramped it up slightly. That being said, it was rather loud, we couldn't really hear the folks at our table chatting. The bathrooms are not even inside the space itself, but outside to the back in the lobby. Overall, I'd slip it, but I think I just have higher expectations from places with 4 stars

Meat & Potatoes was an obvious choice on the 'Pittsburgh to visit' list as all of the Yelp reviews rave about it. We got there at about 5:30 PM not realizing really how small this place is. Spoiler alert: this place is fricking tiny. Don't let the mirrors fool you into thinking there's a back dining area. It's just a reflection.  They couldn't accommodate us at a table, so we headed to the bar. The bar was packed, but I was able to snag one seat next to some guys in suits. Come to find out, the older dude was a complete ass and I overheard him saying some really mean things to the busboy (he was however nice to the female bartender....) If you're out there and reading this, I have 0 respect for people like you. Learn some common courtesy. Okay, moving on..  I ordered the drink special which was some kind of pear concoction. It had a bunch of different herbs and spices that made it sound bizarre, but it tasted phenomenal. We also went for the fried pickles. They were really good but extremely hot. I had to cut them up in little pieces just to be able to release the steam.  The service was great and what you would expect at a restaurant of this caliber. There was a female and male bartender and they were both on point with making sure everyone had a drink or food.  We had originally planned on eating dinner here but decided since we only had 2 days in 'Burgh that we were ready to try another place on our list, so we headed out after a couple of drinks and appetizer. If I came here for dinner and ate a full meal, I would probably give 5 stars too. Their menu looked divine and I hope to make it back soon to give it a real go.
I enjoyed the three pigs sandwich and pimento Mac and cheese more than some people were enjoying their dates.

Stopped in here after a strong recommendation from someone during my trip to Pittsburgh. Based on the name, it didn't sound like the kind of place I could show up in a suit, but I wasn't about to go to the hotel and change clothes. To my surprise, this place was as trendy and chic as could be, and full of after work professionals.  I sat at the bar and started with an order of wings. Turned out to be best wings I've had in quite a while. I then ordered the pork chop which comes with apple cole slaw, pastrami and baked beans. The pork chop is huge! But the meal is delicious. Everything was awesome and the only reason i didn't finish the pork chop was because it was so big.    The rum selection at this place was also awesome, which in my eyes completed what was an excellent experience. Highly recommended!
Outstanding Gastropub in the burgh... Mussels are outstanding and if they have the curry lemongrass ones get em and a bunch if bread.  You don't want it to go to waste.... Unless it's your waist

Handsome bartenders!  Indulgent bone marrow that was fatty, salty, herby goodness.  Sweetbread tacos and brisket sandwiches were ok but I won't have them again.  If I go back I will be getting a real meal.  It was super crowded on Thursday evening.  I don't like my coat hanging in the entrance area.

Terrific evening at Meat & Potatoes. We decided that the appetizers were more exciting than the main courses, so my wife and I put together a meal of the artisan cheese plate, mussels plus garlic bread and fries, and brisket mac and cheese. All terrific. The large bowl of mussels could certainly be a meal for one, and was a lot for two. The Diamondback cocktail was outstanding, with the yellow chartreuse and apple brandy adding nuances while letting the Bulleit rye shine. I'll be ordering these in the future. My one demerit, and the reason my review is not 5 stars: The tables for two are just too small. I admit, by having multiple appetizers, we required more than the usual amount of space, but the tiny round tables really don't work. Also, the bench seat along the wall is low and uncomfortable (I felt like I was sitting on a hump and worried that a spring might pop through), and I heard others complain about the cushioned chairs as well. Everything looks great -- but this is a case of form not following function. M&P needs to rethink this aspect of its design.

It had been awhile since my last visit to M&P, mostly because scoring a brunch reservation is about as easy as getting a hole-in-one.  But with a little planning we did it, and were really looking forward to the brunch.  I had the short rib hash, and my friends had the granola and berries and the huevos ranchero.  We had the sticky bun as an appetizer.  In order of greatness:  huevos ranchero was spicy and excellent.  The short rib hash and the granola were both good, but not great.  My hash was underwelming, the short rib meat was tender and delicious but there were only a few bites, mostly potatoes in my skillet.  The poached eggs  and horseradish sauce were the best part, and I just wanted more meat!  The presentation of the yogurt and granola was unique, and the combination of fresh berries and dried fruit made for a great texture/flavor combination, but atop two slices of raisin walnut bread it was just well...odd.  The bread was dense, so it wasn't soggy, but there was just something bland about it.  I would have loved more of the ricotta and the granola sans bread!  Last on our favorites list was the sticky bun, which was on the specials list.  First, know that the appetizer is a single sticky bun, do not be mislead by the plural form listed on the menu.  It was on the dry side, and we all just wanted to dunk it straight into our coffee. We all commented that a sticky bun is supposed to be sticky...this was more of a cinnamon roll...without icing.   Overall, it's still a great atmosphere, the DJ was a great bonus on Sunday morning before a Pirates game, cocktails looked spectacular as always.  Definitely get the heuvos ranchero, and from the looks of the table next to us...get the chicken and waffles...and share it...because it looked AMAZING!

I will make this as helpful as possible for a review of a mostly boozed dinner.  I was in Pittsburgh for work and came here based on Yelp. I sat at the bar so I could work on my tablet like an antisocial monster. I had the Aged Manhattan which was AMAZING at $12. Then the Sgt Pepper's Old Fashion, $10. The bartender & bar back were so nice and attentive, also chatty and cute (not relevant, just saying). The decor, glassware and room vibe were all great. I needed food after those great whiskey options & was pretty upset there was only one steak entree option at a place called Meat and Potatoes... I ordered fried pickles which were delicious & complained to the staff. Apparently they almost always have a steak feature in addition to the one entree & the 45 oz ribeye for two, just not during my visit.  Go here, hopefully you can get tipsy & eat steak.

The decor here is fun, but the seating leaves a lot to be desired.  I don't know who came up with the idea to seat couples that don't know each other right next to each other, but that is the biggest draw back of this place for me.  I have been to a lot of the steak houses in the Burgh (Ruth Chris, Morton's, Capital Grille, Hyde Park) and Meat and Potatoes is my favorite.  I have never had a better aged rib eye, macaroni and cheese, and mashed potatoes.

It's been 3 years since my last review and after last nights experience, I had to update it.  I made reservations for 6p as soon as I could - January I believe - for 4/19 as I got my nephew the b-day gift of tickets to a show at 8p and he wanted to try bone marrow.  So what aunt doesn't try to fulfill that wish!?  (different nephew than previous review).    Traffic was horrendous yesterday evening and I even gave us 45 minutes to get to the reservations when it typically takes 15 minutes.  Knowing that i was going to be - at most 10 minutes late.  I gave Meat & Potatoes the courtesy of letting them know I was going to be a few minutes late.  Come to find out when I get to the restaurant at 6:03 (THREE MINUTES LATE) - they moved our reservation to 6:30.  First - who does that without telling you?!  I said i would be at most 10 minutes late - I said while on the phone I didn't expect more than 5 minutes.  I had made our reservations at 6p so that he could get and enjoy his food and we could get to the show with plenty of time- he's 13 from out of town - he wanted to experience something new!  Second - they tell me - we have you checked in and will seat you in the next 5 minutes.   We didn't get seated till 6:45 - 45 minutes after we arrived.  45 minutes after our reservations that I had confirmed via text message (their alert and Yelps alert!) that I had reservations at 6p.  I finally said something to the hostess at 6:45 as they had seated WALK INS before us.  That's when the steam started coming out of my ears.    While we were waiting - a group of 4 came in - and were seated within 10 minutes of arriving.  They had reservations for Thursday night - NOT tuesday - however the hostess was able to seat them.  Low and behold - when we finally got seated - they were seated beside us - at 2 - 2 tops put together.   I had a waitress that rolled her eyes at me when I told her we had a show to get to at 8p - and that it took forever to seat us.  My nephew didn't get the experience i had intended (as I had made reservations with 2 hours leeway!!!) I don't blame myself for that.  I blame meat and potatoes.  We didn't get our food till 7:25 - how are we supposed to enjoy anything?  We had to immediately ask for our check.  Oh - and we only ordered appetizers as there wasn't time for anything else - so you lost money as well.    Meat & Potatoes has likely lost my business by this.  The hostesses were rude and incompetent.  The waitress was rude.  I eat out often.  I am a "foodie" - I love trying the new places and eating at favorites.  But not at Meat & Potatoes.  The whole situation could have been avoided if I hadn't been a courteous customer and not called.  Lesson learned.  No reason to be a courteous patron to Meat and Potatoes folks!  Just show up as a walk in - you'll get seated faster than you would with a CONFIRMED reservation.

The food is excellent.  It is consistently well prepared amd the menu offers a wide variety.  The Bloody Mary bar is the best I have experienced in the area. It is filling - there are so many items to add to the bev.   However, I've had brunch twice here and both times I was sharply and frequently reminded that the kitchen was closing soon after our reservation time.

Excellent food and amazing staff. I really like the vibe here as well. The crowd varies from yuppie to urban. The drinks are incredibly elaborate and the food is extraordinary. I have never had a bad time at the joint. Although, it may be challenging to get seated or attention from the bartenders on a weekend night.

One of the best new restaurants in the Burgh! Went here for brunch and absolutely loved it.  The build your own Bloody Mary bar is incredible - the flavored vodka infusions, selection of "fixings" and most of all the price - only $5 each!!    Food was incredible too - had the brisket and eggs which was perfectly seasoned and delicious.  Sampled some of the chicken and waffles - the chicken was the best fried chicken I've ever had.   Can't wait for a repeat visit!

What a bust. No notice they switched out their menu for a fried fish sandwich only lent menu.   Decided to go to Burgatory instead.  Meat and Potatos was slow. Burgatory was packed. Who made the better menu selection.

Everything here when I went for my anniversary was great. Drinks were very well made and the food was delicious. Only negatives were the closeness of the tables and the slightly condescending attitude of our waiter when we asked questions about the ingredients. Will definitely return.
Love this place. Been several times. Great spirits selection. Awesome food. Chill atmosphere. Prompt and attentive service:)

I have eaten at Meat & Potatoes for both Brunch & Dinner. The restaurant serves delicious meals, great drinks and a friendly wait staff.   The restaurant can get extremely busy, especially before a show in one of the nearby theaters. I would definitely recommend booking a reservation in advance, as you will not get seated without one during busy hours.   The restaurant has a dark atmosphere and a few of the tables are very close together, making it difficult to hold a conversation with all of the noise. I have found that it is better to eat at Meat & Potatoes will a group of friends or family, as you will get seated on the side of the restaurant that is less crowded.   Further, the restaurant has a private party room that can accommodate a large group of people for any event.   Overall, I would recommend Meat & Potatoes to anyone! It is a great place for a post-work drink, a pre-show dinner or a Sunday morning brunch.

Absolutely amazing food. Started with the short rib Mac and cheese for me and bone marrow for my husband. Both were fantastic but the bone marrow was the star. For entrees my husband had the lamb cassoulet and would not stop raving about it. I had the pappardelle and it was the best thing I've ever eaten, ever. I would have licked my plate clean if I could. We skipped dessert since nothing was standing out. Service was so/ so but the food made up for it

Wow. The food here is some of the best we've had. Stared with the smoked wings which were fantastic, fried Brussels sprouts, and the house bread. All delicious. For main course we had the waygu steak and the double bones pork chop. The pork chop was huge!!! Once again delicious. Great service as well. Our waitress was new but full of great recommendations and super friendly!!

Great GastroPub   Bone Marrow is off the charts good.   Dishes are creative and unique.   Duck with Grits was very good.  Only recommendation is that they need to improve the wines they offer - I had a taste of three different wines and they were just lower quality.

I recommend this place a lot. The atmosphere and decor is great from the moment you even walk into the lobby. The menu can suit anyone as they have burgers to bone marrow. The port de creme dessert is my weakness in life. Any flavor, I love them all. Oh and you can get one to go in a cute mason jar for an extra few bucks (danger).  They do "night caps" throughout the year on Mondays after 10pm that are super budget friendly and fun so follow them on Instagram to stay up on that. Or don't if you hate constant temptation.
Our favorite for brunch in Pittsburgh.  Great menu and even better Bloody Mary bar.  Never disappointed.

Best.Brunch.Ever!  We went this past Sunday.  We had a reservation, which turned out to be a very good idea, because they were packed and had a few walk in's waiting for their turn for a table.  We got Brent again for our server.  BJ got a Snapper Head Butternuts and I got an Aloe Vera Lemonade which I thought was a perfect drink.  We started with an order of grilled bread with goat butter and rhubarb jam which I thought was perfect!  BJ got the short rib hash with poached egg and  horseradish hollandaise.  He thought the flavor was excellent!!  I got one of the specials which was chorizo quesadilla served with potatoes au gratin and pickled veggies and avocado cream.  So, so yummy.  The portion sizes were adequate, leaving you satisfied but not over stuffed.  We also decided to have a red velvet cake and shared a Irish Breakfast coffee.  The coffee was served in a brandy glass with Jameson, bacon whipped cream and zest of orange.  Perfect ending to a fantastic brunch!

I must admit that I went into this with 'pretentious bistroid' as my mindset, but going to the theater next door, thought I'd give it a try since it was closest.  Upon entering, the visual I took in was pretty much 'pretentious bistroid'.  Another Pittsburgh joint trying to be all NY or LA in a city that will never BE NY or LA.  I'd eaten there once before when it was Cafe Zao, and the atmosphere wasn't quite as pretentious, but the prices were truly outrageous, which was kind of what I was expecting this time around.  I went for brunch, and I was pleasantly surprised to find that not to be so.  I found a few things on the menu that looked intriguing for brunch, and the waiter, an older gentleman, was actually very kind and helpful, more so than the pretty little youth prancing around, noses in air, as if their mere presence was a gift to the diners.  I was flipping between three choices, and the waiter helped me decide on the Corned Beef Benedict.  We split an order of the pate, and each got coffee.    First came the water, in kitschy bottles, poured by the waiter and left on the table. It's kind of a lame attempt at 'theming' but theming only works if you go all the way with it.  But when in Pittsburgh is anything ever taken to the enth degree, when 'meh' is viewed as fabulosity?  Next arrived the pate in an adorable little mini-mason jar, complete with the dual snap lids. Again, really?  Cute, but highly unnecessary.  It was accompanied by two pieces of toast, cut in four, and the pate actually needed another slice of bread to match portioning.  However, the flavor and texture were very good.  A decent little appetizer.    The coffee test passed. I never soil coffee with cream and sugar, even if it's REALLY bad. My friend however will use cream and sugar if it is weak.  She didn't have to.  The coffee was decent for a cup of Pittsburgh American Joe.  Brunch arrived.  My friend had the short rib hash, and I had the Benedict.  The lunch dishes didn't match the attempted 'theming' (nor does the decor), and my friend (who is blind) took one bite from her little trendy dish and the food slipped over onto the table.  Again the waiter was extremely kind and helpful and brought her a real plate so she could eat without doing much damage.    The food...bottom line...was very good.  Flavorful, not toy food (but not quite a Pittsburgh shovel full), filling, and done well.    The server was not totally aloof (not chatty), but he was helpful and efficient without throwing an attitude.  My friend expressed an interest in dessert, and tried the chocolate mousse, which I did take a bite of, and it was really delicious.  The check came to around $48...not bad for an appetizer, two coffees, two entrees and a dessert in what is a somewhat 'upscale' type place.    I can't complain about the food or the price for lunch.  They surprised me very nicely.  My biggest complaint comes from the general atmosphere.  The seating is a long upholstered bench along the wall, with TINY marble tables, and an armless armchair on the outside of the table. Had the place been crowded we would have been sitting WITH the people at the next table.  Even with an empty table between us, we had to listen to the pretentious blurting of some food writer who was gushing all over the chef pretending that Pittsburgh was going to be the next gastronomical tourist destination...hate to break your heart sweetie, but Pittsburgh ain't going to be the next big tourist destination for ANYTHING until corruption money is funneled back into education, and yinzers stop partying like it's 1979.  I didn't quite know what to do with my feet as they either were resting on the cast iron legs of the tiny table, or had to be spread wide apart to hit the floor.  One, the tables are too small and round for two for brunch, with water, drinks, a water bottle, sugar, creamer, flatware, side dishes...oh wait...it's ok...I have a lap. Two, I can't imagine this being more comfortable or accommodating for a larger dinner setting.  The attempt at 'theming' either needs to be polished to completion, or abandoned, because what they do have just looks silly in a highly over-designed architectural space. You want to go 'speakeasy', then do some research and go all the way. Otherwise, skip the kitsch and focus on what you clearly are doing pretty well...make good food at a fairly reasonable price.  I can't say this would be a comfortable regular haunt, but I would go back for a somewhat special occasion.  Question is...do you want regulars, or special occasions in a VERY small market?

I'm not really sure what all the hype is about here I went for brunch and got a bloody Mary for five dollars which is a great deal but I couldn't understand what any of the mixers were at the bar because none of them were labeled. I also had a grilled cheese sandwich with a tomato celery soup the cheese was really hard as if it had been sitting for a little while and the soup was very interesting my fault for not asking more detail about the soup. I just think that it shouldn't be hard to make a really good grilled cheese. I've heard good things about the bone marrow appetizer so I would definitely go back and give that a try.

love love loved this place! i'd heard about it before but never had the time to wait. yes, if your'e going on a whim be prepared to either scope out a seat at the bar or wait roughly 3 hours for a table. but it's worth it. my date and i stood at the bar and had drinks while we waited for a seat to open up. we didn't even quite finish our drinks before we were able to sit. and the bartender was super helpful with helping us scope out seats. both bartenders were very nice, personable, helpful, and friendly. i was pretty impressed. once we sat, we ordered food as well. i had the cheese board and split the pate with my date and he had the corndog. everything was super tasty and i'm eager to try more. i tried 2 different drinks. the first word (or last word? i don't remember, but it was a gin based drink) and the glenshaw sour. both were super tasty-- a twist on the gin and tonic and an old fashioned vodka sour. trust me, the drinks and food are both worth the wait if you have the time. and the prices really aren't too bad. sure, it's pricey, but i expected that. it's not overpriced, i wasn't upset about it, and everyone needs to check this place out.
Great service, pot roast was incredible,  pork belly tacos were great, and the appetizers were great (namely the fried pickles and Brussels sprouts). Wonderful! Will recommend to friends!
Skip Mortons. Come here. It's seriously a wonderful dining experience. Spectacular food.

Went to a Steeler game over the weekend and was looking for a place to find the best sandwich in Pittsburgh PA! But oh my lord did I find the best sandwich I'll ever have in my life..The Three Little Pigs sandwich is the thickest, juiciest, and most tasty sandwich you'll ever take a bite out of. After devouring this beast, I was huffing and puffing all the way to a bed and went into the best food coma of my life. Service was tremendous and staff was very friendly. I might come back to Pittsburgh for this place and the sandwich, and maybe a steeler game :P TRY IT OUT

I got the wagyu steak, and it was excellent! The penicillin cocktail was also very good, but light on the alcohol. Overall, I would recommend. The only downside in my opinion is that it is very pricey for the ambiance. It feels more like a speakeasy/bar than a fancy restaurant. Yet, we still spent about $130 for dinner and 2 drink/person for 2 people. At that price, I expect a fancier atmosphere.

Amazing gastropub in downtown Pittsburgh.  We've been here for after-dinner drinks and snacks, but most recently had the opportunity to check out their brunch, which they have on Saturdays and Sundays.  On a recent Sunday we tried to call ahead for reservations but were informed that they were completely booked.  However, we discovered that if you don't mind sitting at the bar, you can show up for brunch and walk right in.  We got there right at 10:30 and we had no problems.    Great atmosphere: exposed brick with a marble-top bar and old-school fixtures and weird antler-type chandeliers and things hanging on the walls, and a lot of mirrors and chalkboards where specials are written on the wall.   They had many brunch specials, but we went with the Irish Benedict and the Huevos Ranchero.  The Irish Benedict had an amazing hollandaise sauce over poached eggs, corned beef, cheese and some yummy thick toast.  The Huevos Ranchero were also amazing, with a delicious tomato-chili sauce, picked onions, and black beans.    Both meals were so large that we couldn't finish them.  I also ordered the potato gratin on the side, but it was sort of meh in comparison to everything else.    And the brunch cocktails were delicious: the papaya bellini was great, but the French 76 was amazing.   They have an extensive bloody mary bar which we didn't get, but it looked really fun, with all these self-serve fixins like tons of different types of olives, asparagus, artichoke, etc. etc.  Overall, great service, great atmosphere, fantastic food.  We'll be back for more Meat & Potatoes!

I took my boyfriend here for his 30th birthday. Even though we've been to Meat & Potatoes before this was our favorite experience. Waitress was amazing, hanger steak was prepared perfectly, and they surprised us with complimentary champagne and desert for his birthday. All around a great place to celebrate a special occasion or brunch which we love!

Great brunch! We heard a lot of great things about this place from locals, so we had to try when we got to town. Even at 1pm it was still packed, but we got a table quickly. The food was totally stellar and we got to take advantage of the bloody Mary bar. The atmosphere was cozy though small, but who cares what the place is like when you can get the best chicken and waffles in town?!

Wonderful Dinner and Great Service!! Four of us arrived for our reservation and we were immediately seated. We did shared seven dishes and two desserts. Everything was great. Mussels and Frites, Pork Belly Tacos, were just two entrees we thoroughly enjoyed. Both Desserts, the Panna Cota and the Pot of Chocolate were excellent. They have a Great selection of Micro Brew's on Draft, as well as a nice list of Wines by the glass.  We really enjoyed the evening and highly recommend Meat and Potatoes to All. Enjoy!!

This is by far my favorite place to eat in Pittsburgh. I have gone more times than I can remember. Every single time I go, I try something different and I have never been disappointed. The brunch on Sunday with the Bloody Mary Bar is ridiculously fun, awesome and delicious. I had fried chicken with jalepeno waffles the last time I went and they were the best! Drinks are always different, interesting and amazing and I love the beer selection as well. They have wonderful specials on the menu board. The atmosphere is beautiful and relaxing. LOVE this place. Cannot speak highly enough about it.

Great experience the server was very helpful and knowledgeable about the menu and food options. There are so many good items to choose from that I found it hard to decide. In the end I picked the wagyu flat Iron steak. It didn't disappoint. It was very tender and savory, and the portion size was sufficient enough to please my appetite but still leave me room for dessert. My wife had the smores and I had the chocolate pot de creme. Both very tasty.  As for drinks, I wish I could recall the name of the cocktail I got. It was tequila based and I would definitely order it again(if I every remember the name). Lastly the only thing you have to okay with is how close your table is to your neighbor's. Very tight squeeze. But, that's really the only con to the place.
